column2: Answer

column1: @Xulfiqar Sir i want to know what precautions should we take when we overhaul a 2.5 kva generator? I have to replace to block as it has been cracked... and also the connecting rod is broken, now i want to overhaul then engine, the mechanic said that he will install new block and he will also bore it... Now i want to know how to make sure that rings seat properly, as i have read your post regarding break in period of car that we should not hold on one rpm and also not idle for break in period... So how can we manage that on generator? And also tell me other things like should i run it without load initially and also tell me can i do the break in period on gas or not? and plz also point other points of precautions... @Hassan1991 @brownrose78 @capsat @ etc **Yes i do have copied the title
column2: To ensure a successful overhaul of your 2.5 kVA generator engine, it's crucial to follow the service manual diligently. The rebuild process should mirror that of a standard engine, with particular attention to setting gaps correctly to eliminate the need for a break-in period. Additionally, understanding the generator's specific RPM range, governed by controllers, is essential. While removing these controllers may allow RPM control akin to an engine, adherence to the manual's instructions renders this unnecessary. Marking components during disassembly facilitates straightforward reinstallation. Regarding fuel, a preference for petrol over CNG is recommended, given CNG's propensity for running hotter and drier. Regular oil changes, slightly before scheduled intervals, aid in draining any metal dust accumulation, with periodic switches between CNG and petrol advised to mitigate adverse effects on valves and valve seats. Lastly, consider adjusting tappets during the second oil change, typically occurring between 80-90 hours of operation.

column1: First time building my audio system for a 2009 Corolla, needed component recommendations as I was interested in genuine stuff only. I was looking for an SQ build and I'm from Karachi. You could also share the legitimate seller's information too who deal in original products only! Your suggestions will be appreciated.
column2: If you're looking to set up an audio system, here are some recommendations: Start with the basics, including a 4-channel 1000W amplifier (preferably Pioneer or Sony), a sealed box subwoofer (10" JBL or Champion series Pioneer recommended), and quality components with crossovers and mods (preferably Pioneer). For those interested, a complete audio system setup is available for sale, including high-quality components such as Cadence Q65K components, Sony XM-N1004 amplifier, Pioneer 311D4 subwoofer, and branded wiring. All components are in excellent working condition, rated 9 out of 10, with a good cosmetic appearance. The asking price for the entire setup is 25,000 rupees.

column1: Hi, my car doesn’t have a thermostat valve and do i need to get a thermostat installed in my 2c engine i have bought car like this My car is 1982 corolla with 2c engine(front fan) and does this fan works with accelerator or this is a jugaar on my car as i give accelerator fan starts to spin fast and continous flow of water in radiator and i want to flush my radiator with coolant any recommendation which is low price. Another question 2c engine required oil and what about lifter that pumps fuel mechanic told me to replace that my car starts good without any issue and good race acceleration , and recommended oil for 5 speed manual transmission and diff oil which one should i get do mention quantity of oil too
column2: Flush your cooling system with Citric acid, change all ribber pipes and hoses and drive on water for a couple of days. If everything remains ok, drain and fill with coolant. The stock 4K engine in 1982 Corolla comes with a belt driven fan. Use Shell HX7 or HX5 for the engine. If the fuel pump is ok, leave it as it is. For manual transmission, check which gearbox is installed and then Google the recommended grade.

column1: Salam, The car in question is 7th gen civic.The upper rubber trim of windshield has become brittle and is cracking. There is also a small rust spec along the upper channel. Need to know if its possible to remove and replace this trim without removing the windshield. The manual does not state the rubber trim replacement as a process, rather only as part of windshield replacement where it is applied on the glass first.
column2: Glass installation typically requires the expertise of professional installers who can perform a glass-out job. Quality installers, often found through reputable shops, offer primer and use specialized tools like piano wire to cut glass urethane, ensuring precision and minimizing the risk of water leakage. Moldings are removable and usually the first step in windshield removal. While damage to moldings can complicate the process, it's essential to remove the screen for proper repair. Additionally, having Sika polyurethane on hand is recommended for potential removal needs. Dealerships and established shops often have contacts for skilled installers, ensuring reliable and high-quality workmanship.

column1: helo guys , this is my second thread on PW before this i rebuilt cultus and i hope many of you guys have seen that thread , so here i am overhauling my 2500 Watt chinese honda clone generator which is serving in my home for last more than 3 years , it run all his life on natural gas and with ATS , means it kicks in even when we dont need it especially at night and thats the reason why it has such a high reading on its hour meter ,,,,,,,,more than 2500 hours , and now there is nothing left in it , as you know summer is approaching and so does the heavy load shading which some time goes to 10 hours a day in rwp , so its time to rebuilt it other wise it will creat lot of trouble in peak summer/load shading season , also try to show you how to instal a natural gas kit after certain modication in gas kit so that it the engine always starts on half crank on natural/sui gas ,,,,,,,,,,and if posible also try my best to share the ATS circuit , i made that on my own but honestelly speaking i hardelly remember any thing as its almost 3 year old , will try to copy that , that ATS is installed on generator in parts , so i plan to remove all the components and put them in one box of stabilizer so that it looks good and also it will be easy to shift that ATS on some other generator , as i have a plan to buy a bigger generator and shift that ATS on it , right now its hard to remove that ATS as it is splitted in 4 parts , any how will share that later , any suggestion/comments are most welcome , thanks

column1: I have a Nissan Sunny 1998 model with a diesel engine that has been modified with a GA15DE engine. I am experiencing issues when driving in traffic jam areas, particularly when I am in first or second gear. The car starts to hesitate and eventually stalls. After a short while, I can start it again by using the self-start button. This issue occurs regardless of whether I am using CNG or petrol as fuel. However, on the highway, the car runs smoothly. Occasionally, it may hesitate in the third gear but does not stall.
column2: it is purely an electrical issue. The engine ecu is it correctly wired up? ignition timing is out of specs / or the igniter in distributor is leaky short circuit is more strong at idle. causing engine to die

column1: I have a Nissan Sunny 1998 model with a diesel engine that has been modified with a GA15DE engine. I am experiencing issues when driving in traffic jam areas, particularly when I am in first or second gear. The car starts to hesitate and eventually stalls. After a short while, I can start it again by using the self-start button. This issue occurs regardless of whether I am using CNG or petrol as fuel. However, on the highway, the car runs smoothly. Occasionally, it may hesitate in the third gear but does not stall.
column2: Check its wiring because 90% people don’t wire efi engines properly. Also check its ignition timing should be 8-10 degree. Also check spark plug wires if they are leaking or spark plug seals are leaking and leaving oil residue on spark plug wire tips.

column1: This thread is dedicated for discussion on Civic 2010 Navigation Panel only. I just want to post few ideas and want to know if that can be done. There is option of TV in navigation panel so is there any option on backside of the panel to attach antenna with it and will channels like PTV and STN work with it then. Or is there any other way I connect TV to that navigation panel. Secondly, how do we use REAR Camera while not in reverse gear. There is a option of rear in Meny but when I click on it it displays black screen. There is arrow on the top right when I press it and enters code 0000 it accepts and give me option to confirm but when i press it nothing happens. (0000 is accepted while any other code it gives error) Thirdly, my memory card SD is on FAT32 file system with 5 folders and 10 songs in each folder but the system does not play it. Does anybody know why and how can I use it? Fourth, How can I update my maps and stuff because i think its outdated. I have a trick to change the picture that you see when you switch off your navigation mode. Open the memory card in your computer and you will see that ROAD picture. Open the picture in Paint Brush and edit as you want. You can paste your picture or add text to existing picture. customization looks good. I have done that and it works. (To avoid problems first copy your memory card as it is to your computer as a back up)
column2: In the context of vehicle technology, a discussion on Civic 2010 Navigation Panel unfolded with queries and insights. Users explored the feasibility of connecting a TV to the navigation panel through antennae, addressing issues with reception and camera power. There was a dialogue on the dual-wire setup of rear-view cameras for both reverse gear and normal driving, with varying opinions on the necessity of using them while driving. Troubleshooting included resolving problems with FAT32-formatted SD cards, and a suggestion was made to update navigation maps using new image files. Additionally, a creative tip for customizing the startup picture on the navigation mode was shared. The discussion shed light on challenges and solutions related to vehicle entertainment systems and technology.

column1: My car's tire measurements are 185/65. Recently one of the back tire got into an accident and got burst. Thankfully I had a tire which was of 185/60 that I got installed. Is that a issue that the back tires of my car have 2 different tire profiles (one is 185/65 and another is 185/60)?
column2: Quite a big issue, among many things that will be affected will be Handling, Stability, Tire wear (damage risk), Suspension wear, Economy, Comfort, etc. The difference may seem small but the diameter difference cannot be kept like this. Best would be to go for the same sized tire on the affected side, so all are of the same profile.

column1: I have a Civic 99 Automatic. The Issue I am facing for the last few weeks is when it is moving above 100, and I push the pedal, and it reaches around 120, suddenly the speed drops as if the car was put it neutral. RPM remain the same. And after a few second with a bump, speed start to increase again as it was put into gear again. What can be the problem?
column2: In the exploration of vehicle performance issues, a user inquired about the implications of a car becoming neutral, questioning whether high RPMs and decreased vehicle speed indicate such a state. Another user delved into the potential complexities, suggesting that a speed limit issue might arise from the ECU being stuck in limp mode, and raised concerns about the car's originality or potential modifications. The conversation shifted towards diagnosing the problem, with a suggestion to check the speed sensor, emphasizing its crucial role in preventing the ECU from entering limp mode. Further insights into the automatic transmission system were provided, detailing the hydraulic nature of the transmission and its speed governor's role. The discussion touched upon variations in diagnostics for ABS and non-ABS models, highlighting the significance of the Vehicle Speed Sensor (VSS) in the absence of ABS. Maintenance history was also addressed, specifically focusing on transmission fluid changes. In addressing potential causes for performance issues, considerations were given to fuel supply and electrical disruptions at higher speeds, prompting recommendations for testing fuel pumps, injectors, electrical wiring, and fuses. Finally, the clarification was made that RPMs remain constant while only the speed decreases in the reported scenario. This collective exchange offers a comprehensive exploration of various factors contributing to vehicle performance concerns.

column1: I recently bought xli 2006 from my cousin who bought zero meter, very low mielage just 30,000 Km & in good condition but i am surprised after seeing brakes performances, i felt it poor performance & took it to 4 mechanics(including 1 3s dealer), all said it is ok & normal with Xli mechanics told me that it was lack in these models ,brakes(while gli brakes r much better than this) i told them to servbice brakes they told no need, it is all geniune & rarely used so dont open it, it will have no effect so i just went to 1 thread where people r suggesting to install servo brakes in mehran to 1 brother i want to ask you that can in install servo brakes in 2006 Xli or this car already has servo brakes from factory.how to check & how can u tell that these r sevo brakes & these r ordinary( my car has all original, no modification at all) or another idea came in mind that i think it is 2 wheel disc brakes car in which there r 2 discs brakes on front while 2 brake shoe system on rear wheel, am i right? so can i change it to 4 wheel disc brakes(like honda) which is better option, i used car mostly with family so which option will be better to increase brakes performance
column2: To enhance the braking performance of your Toyota XLI 2008, consider checking for four-wheel disc brakes, a feature confirmed for this model. Users have reported issues with brake responsiveness, especially at speeds of 50-60, and suggested potential solutions. One recommendation is to inspect the entire braking system and explore the possibility of replacing it with ABS from the new GLi model, although this may come at a significant cost. Additionally, users have shared insights into adjusting the "T distribution valve" to address braking problems in XLi/GLi models from 2002 to 2008. Lowering the car's height has also been proposed as a potential remedy. Overall, these suggestions offer practical approaches to improving the braking system's efficiency in your Toyota XLI 2008.

column1: My Honda Civic oriel 03 is experiencing braking issues. While driving or idle i feel the brake pad is a bit spongy. when the car's engine is off then i feel nothing like spongy rather it feels as if it has been locked. 2nd issue is the sound of grrrrr even on a speed breaker where no emergency brakes are applied. i have done brake service but to no avail. i got my car's tyres installed in 2011, still they are in very good condition. please guide me
column2: Your concern with the braking issues in your Honda Civic Oriel 03 has various potential explanations. The sensation of a spongy brake pedal could be a normal characteristic, with the initial inch of brake application being softer before the pedal becomes harder, particularly in newer models. When the engine is off, the pedal feeling locked is a standard response as the hydraulic pump is inactive. The grrr sound, especially on speed breakers, might be attributed to the ABS system kicking in to prevent tire slipping during hard braking or on uneven surfaces. One recommendation involves changing the brake oil with a fresh one and bleeding the air from the system to address potential issues. Additionally, the grrr sound could be associated with inferior brake pads, so replacing them with higher-quality ones is suggested. It's advisable to rule out emergency brake concerns, as these explanations provide insights into potential causes and solutions for your braking issues.

column1: Hello everyone After getting scammed multiple times before and then learning a long with it. This is where I am currently Headunit: Pioneer DMH-ZS8250BT Front stage: Focal K2 Power K2P Rear stage: JL Audio C5-650XO Sub stage: Phase Linear Aliante Si 12 LTD in ported enclosure Speaker amplification: Rainbow Germanium Four Monoblock: Jl Audio XD600/1v2 Speaker wire: Stinger 12 gauge OFC Subwoofer wire: King Vox subwoofer wire Power wire: 8 gauge alpine CCA My main concern right now is the power wire. Need to change that but can’t find a 0 gauge OFC wire. Someone is selling 2/0 gauge ofc sky high audio wire 7 meter for 65K which to me seems a lot. For the amps will be upgrading to 4awg Kicker OFC silver tinned For Sound damping I have used Oriontech 2.2mm sheets with heat and sound isolation sheet which has foam and foil on top of the sound damping in doors. Trunk and Pillars have open cell foam sheets. Will properly deadened it with sound damping sheets , CCF and MLV. Getting MLV from aliexpresss does anyone have experience with MLV from aliexpress. Some upgrades that I have planned down the pipe is Focal utopia Be 3 way front with k2p in the back along with JL AUDIO 13w7 in IB, Brax dsp and MX4 pro amps. Will be using the phase linear for front subwoofer. Already got Focal Utopia Be midranges and have ordered the midbass need to find Be tweeters
column2: In optimizing my vehicle's audio system, particularly the power wire upgrade, I'm currently seeking a suitable 0 gauge OFC wire. A potential option is a 2/0 gauge OFC Sky High Audio wire offered by someone, but the price of 65K seems steep. I've considered changing the existing King Vox subwoofer wire and upgrading to 4 AWG Kicker OFC silver-tinned for the amps. Seeking advice on reliable options, a user recommended checking for kits from abroad, citing the DB Link kit as a viable option with 6 meters of 0 AWG wire for 25K. The discussion also touched on the quality of wiring kits in local markets, emphasizing the potential for overpricing by some shops. Additionally, welding wire was suggested as a cost-effective alternative, though it might lack flexibility. Overall, the focus is on finding a quality and reasonably priced 0 gauge OFC wire for the power upgrade in the audio system.

column1: Dear Pak Wheelers I need your sugesstion on the following scenario for Suzuki Swift DLX: 1 - Keep Original HU intact 2 - Not use any AMP 3 - Replace all 4 door speakers with some good speakers which work best with the Stock HU 4 - Dont want to do surgery; Just want a bolt to bolt door speaker change with a decent upgrade in sound Please advise the best speaker model I have checked local market Kenwood e715p component (6800 rs) for 2 Pcs,Sony XS-GTF1638 (2900 rs) for 2 pcs I was thinking to install (2)Kenwood e715p & (2)Sony XS-GTF1638 Please give your suggestions Thanks!
column2: Do you prefer to have component speakers in the front and coaxial speakers in the back? Or would you like to have all four speakers as coaxials? Also, what is your budget for this?

column1: Dear Pak Wheelers I need your sugesstion on the following scenario for Suzuki Swift DLX: 1 - Keep Original HU intact 2 - Not use any AMP 3 - Replace all 4 door speakers with some good speakers which work best with the Stock HU 4 - Dont want to do surgery; Just want a bolt to bolt door speaker change with a decent upgrade in sound Please advise the best speaker model I have checked local market Kenwood e715p component (6800 rs) for 2 Pcs,Sony XS-GTF1638 (2900 rs) for 2 pcs I was thinking to install (2)Kenwood e715p & (2)Sony XS-GTF1638 Please give your suggestions Thanks!
column2: Tech_guy;4443838: Yes i was thinking for component upfront nd coaxials in back . Sent from my GT-I9300 using Tapatalk You need to pump up the speakers for the components to be effective ... the RLC network has some losses of its own too .. the crossover it is. The normal HU has an out of 14-18W rms which is too low for the components. Components is an overkill without amp. But let me add here by changing all four speakers with some other speakers wont improve sound quality as per your expectations. If you want improvement , you have to have an amp with the components Sent from my GT-I9300 using Tapatalk 2

column1: Salaam brothers. Hope everyone's doing well. I've been wishing to some changes to my Kia Classic's interior and really wanted to install some door cards as shown in the picture below:  The ones installed at the moment are the regular cardboard/vinyl fabric door cards. Now I know the Classic doesnt have any cards as pictured above, so I'm looking for any other car's to fit in it. I'm confident that other cars such as the 88 Corolla, 94 Sunny, etc have the same door sizes and should work. But I would need some advice. Any help would be really appreciated folks. Jazak Allah
column2: Dude, I don't think it's a good idea because playing around with it might cause trouble. And if it backfires, you'll be left to deal with it. It's genuine, though. Get it customized with a two-tone color. But, what else will you remember? Your wish can come true. Get it made with fiber, according to your preference. It looks good in this picture too, with the speaker's placement and the light, similar to an Accord. All the best!

column1: Pak Suzuki Wagon R Model 2015. During the usage of 5 Years I haven't faced any issue regarding AC. Now all of a sudden recently I have faced issue while travelling on a highway, I got my Car AC tripped and lost cooling at a speed of 80-100 km/h after 30mins of running. I checked radiator was working fine. For about an hour after the issue risen-up I realised that when ever I try to run my car on a High speed i.e. over 80 km/h my car ac tripped for a very long time and I have to restart my car to Re-Run the AC. Although AC Cooling is absolutely fine. I also realized that at a low speed i.e. below 70 km/h and low rpm it didn't trip... Mostly I used my car in Karachi city and do not travel more than 20kms / trip. Can AnyOne guide about this issue to how to resolve this issue and make my AC working properly at high speed too...!!!!!!
column2: It seems that your Pak Suzuki Wagon R, model 2015, is experiencing AC issues specifically at higher speeds. One suggestion is to check the vehicle's cooling system for air pockets, recommending a purge of the system. Additionally, the use of plain water may lead to salt deposits causing cavitation, overheating the AC condenser, and triggering the cooling trip. Visiting Quick Cool or Sabir AC for resolution is advised. Another approach involves flushing the cooling system with a mixture of citric acid and water, followed by using a recommended coolant. The possibility of separate AC and radiator fans running simultaneously is mentioned. In a detailed continuation of the issue, the car exhibited temperature light signals during AC operation on a longer trip. The issue persisted with temperature light appearing at higher speeds, prompting stops and checks. Flushing the radiator with fresh water was attempted, and while some improvement was observed, intermittent AC operation issues persisted. Seeking further insights or professional assistance may be necessary to address the underlying cause and ensure proper AC functionality, especially during high-speed travel.

column1: Assalam alaikum fellow pakwheelers I have been having this very strange issue in my 2009 Corolla XLi, so this started back in September 2022 where I was once driving with my parking lights on (fog lights were off because it had blown a fuse) where I decided to flash my headlights (dipper) (Oem bulbs) and noticed that my subwoofer would make (pop noise) I flashed my lights couple more times and then the power steering light came up for 2 sec and then the subwoofer popping when I flash my lights was gone, one thing I also noticed that day was that whenever I’m flashing my lights, turning my lights high and low beams on the lights on the speedometer would flick like they would dim for 0.001 sec if this makes sense, I decided to ignore the issue as I thought its getting old these issues may show up every now and then but sometime later I was driving home and decided to indicate to the left, the music was playing not loud but was playing, this is at nighttime so I had my low beams on, the moment I turned my indicator on the subwoofer popped and the power steering light came on The very next day I decided to check its volts with a multimeter it turned out that with my high beams on and the ac running the volts at the battery were 13.33 volts, clearly showing that the alternator isn’t doing much, took to the electrician the very next day he serviced the alternator said nothing was out of the ordinary when he tore out and diagnosed that the battery was going bad, the battery was old like a 1.5 years old at that point, he charged the battery and I took the car home The problem got worse and worse to the point that whenever I would flash my high beams during the daytime with no lights on or with parking light on the subwoofer would pop and power steering light would came on, eventually the car stopped cranking and we got a new battery daewoo dl65 the problem wasn’t solved even with a new battery the subwoofer popping issue was gone for now but the speedometer were still flickering when flashing high beams, once the car took a long crank and was at the electricians again this time he cleaned the terminals with a machine put gel on them and for a month almost it became perfect until one day I noticed that the speedometer lights where flickering slightly when I flashed my high beams (around this time I had gone cheap 2k rupees leds on my low beams 35 watts because they looked cool lol and also the electrician did fix the fog lights by diagnosing that the fuse had blown, the fuse had blown multiple times at this point, first when I was installing grill glow a light that illuminates the grill area the led strip was powered by the left parking bulb wire and second it was blown when I was installing the leds) and again the car had the same issues the speedometer lights along with ac knobs lights would flicker when flashing lights (dipper) or whenever I would turn on my wiper, turn my steering wheel (the lights around the entire car would dim) and flick whenever I hit steering lock, my car has aftermarket power windows, central whenever I would use any of the light would flick I ignored these issues but untill now (6 month old battery) where when the music is being played at any volume over 32-33 with parking lights on and fog lights (100 watt bulbs) and I would flash my beams the subwoofer and speakers would pop and also when I hit steering lock with fog lights off the subwoofer or the speakers don’t pop but it pops when I hit steering lock The amp I am running is a presence 1600 watt rms and cerwin vega 12 mobile subwoofer 200 watt rms, speakers are being run the stock company fitted lcd Sorry for this extremely long post but it would mean a lot to me if anyone helps me diagnose this issue, do I need a bigger alternator or a bigger battery?
column2: Check the main cable and the grounding points on the A pillar too (have your mechanic do voltage drop test to identfy which is bad)

column2: Seems like your guy is shooting parts at range rovers and praying for a fix if he cannot do voltage drop tests on a grounding path and also load and freewheeling tests on a basic toyota alternator. Ask him if he knows what a loaded VDrop test is.

(fog lights were off because it had blown a fuse) where I decided to flash my headlights (dipper) (Oem bulbs) and noticed that my subwoofer would make (pop noise) I flashed my lights couple more times and then the power steering light came up for 2 sec and then the subwoofer popping when I flash my lights was gone, one thing I also noticed that day was that whenever I’m flashing my lights, turning my lights high and low beams on the lights on the speedometer would flick like they would dim for 0.001 sec if this makes sense, I decided to ignore the issue as I thought its getting old these issues may show up every now and then but sometime later I was driving home and decided to indicate to the left, the music was playing not loud but was playing, this is at nighttime so I had my low beams on, the moment I turned my indicator on the subwoofer popped and the power steering light came on The very next day I decided to check its volts with a multimeter it turned out that with my high beams on and the ac running the volts at the battery were 13.33 volts, clearly showing that the alternator isn’t doing much, took to the electrician the very next day he serviced the alternator said nothing was out of the ordinary when he tore out and diagnosed that the battery was going bad, the battery was old like a 1.5 years old at that point, he charged the battery and I took the car home The problem got worse and worse to the point that whenever I would flash my high beams during the daytime with no lights on or with parking light on the subwoofer would pop and power steering light would came on, eventually the car stopped cranking and we got a new battery daewoo dl65 the problem wasn’t solved even with a new battery the subwoofer popping issue was gone for now but the speedometer were still flickering when flashing high beams, once the car took a long crank and was at the electricians again this time he cleaned the terminals with a machine put gel on them and for a month almost it became perfect until one day I noticed that the speedometer lights where flickering slightly when I flashed my high beams (around this time I had gone cheap 2k rupees leds on my low beams 35 watts because they looked cool lol and also the electrician did fix the fog lights by diagnosing that the fuse had blown, the fuse had blown multiple times at this point, first when I was installing grill glow a light that illuminates the grill area the led strip was powered by the left parking bulb wire and second it was blown when I was installing the leds) and again the car had the same issues the speedometer lights along with ac knobs lights would flicker when flashing lights (dipper) or whenever I would turn on my wiper, turn my steering wheel (the lights around the entire car would dim) and flick whenever I hit steering lock, my car has aftermarket power windows, central whenever I would use any of the light would flick I ignored these issues but untill now (6 month old battery) where when the music is being played at any volume over 32-33 with parking lights on and fog lights (100 watt bulbs) and I would flash my beams the subwoofer and speakers would pop and also when I hit steering lock with fog lights off the subwoofer or the speakers don’t pop but it pops when I hit steering lock The amp I am running is a presence 1600 watt rms and cerwin vega 12 mobile subwoofer 200 watt rms, speakers are being run the stock company fitted lcd Sorry for this extremely long post but it would mean a lot to me if anyone helps me diagnose this issue, do I need a bigger alternator or a bigger battery?
column2: pwuser163992317180: Just say that this person is competent enough to understand the electronics of modern cars. However, he seems to only work on Range Rovers and Jaguars and can't seem to fix a Corolla. I can assure you that the owners of such vehicles are foolish enough to send their cars with a driver to this person. The drivers get bribed for every repeat visit. I can assure you that he has no clue about the number of ground points in a Range Rover or the correct wire gauge for any given location. He just thinks that as long as there is a wire, it should work. This auto electrician is a complete idiot.  -  - I had a short trip to Islamabad after Eid in April and my neighbor was complaining about his Range Rover. He said that it wouldn't start and the workshop suggested towing it there for inspection. I was shocked because it was a 2018 limited edition with only 79,000 km on the odometer. I went to his porch and asked him to lift the hood. He didn't even know where to open it from and told me to figure it out myself. I placed the key on the driver's seat and opened the main red breaker in the engine bay. I flipped it to green and the dashboard came to life. On the third crank, the engine started. My neighbor was completely speechless and shocked. I left him there to figure out what I had just whispered to myself. (If only he had bothered to educate himself and read the user manual, he would have found all this diagnostic information there, idiot!)

column1: My serpentine belt broke while being driven by my driver today. The driver drove the car for around 10KMs after the belt collapsed. column2: For your Corolla 2012 Altis 1.6 1ZR-FE, you can find a new serpentine belt at various auto parts stores or dealerships. It's advisable to opt for reputable brands like Mitsuboshi, Bando, Pirelli, or Continental to ensure quality and reliability. However, the priority should be to determine the cause of the belt failure. If it broke due to issues like oiling or other mechanical problems, those need to be addressed to prevent future failures. Since the car was driven for 10 kilometers after the belt broke, it's crucial to inspect for any potential damage to the engine. It's recommended to consult with a trusted mechanic or take the car to a professional workshop to assess the extent of the damage and perform necessary repairs, especially if there are concerns about overheating and AC issues.

column1: Can someone post measurement (lenght) of steel part of dipstick of H22A motor? I have following issue: H22a should take around 5 liters of oil. Mine takes 6.2 liters to reach the top mark of dipstick. I might have wrong dipstick, that is why I am asking for the measurement of dipstick of H22a. Also, I have oil pan from f18b (CF3), as my H22a oil pan was damaged at the time of swap. In case I ahve the correct dipstick, I will know that I am getting to fill more oil due to having a differnt oil pan. Does anyone know if f18b oil pan and h22a oil pan does not have any material difference in terms of capactiy? Do I need different oil pickup? I am running h22a on a CF3, ran it only 3K till now. Thanks
column2:
The length of the steel part of the dipstick for the H22A motor is approximately 18 inches. The part number for the dipstick is 15650-P13-000. However, there might be variations and conflicting measurements found on different forums due to differences in oil pans and engines across regions.
In your case, it seems that the oil pan from the F18B (CF3) might be causing the discrepancy in oil capacity. The best solution would be to repair the original H22A oil pan by removing dents and welding any cracks. If you can find a correct oil pan, it would ensure that the oil capacity aligns with the standard specifications for the H22A engine. Keep the oil level on the dipstick within the recommended range, even if it requires more oil due to the specific oil pan design.

column1: Assalam o Aluikum Hope all are fine so, Im having a new and 1st experience for speakers in my car thats why im asking if anyone does this before.. my ride is cultus 2016(old shape) I have EIGHT 8 ohms 4 inches Sony woofer speakers and 4 alpine tweeters and a Rockville american amplifier Now a help is needed for speakers.. An amplifier gives 80watts rms x 4 at 4 ohms and 110watts rms x 2 ohms... im planning to connect 4 speakers to channel 1 by parallel wiring to make a total load of 2 ohms and 100 watts and same for other 4 speakers in parallel to channel 2 and channel 3/4 for tweeters..... now please tell me will these 8 speakers give more powerful and clear sound or still 4 ohm speakers are better like 6x9s or other speakers ????? please help me... im having a first experience in this case ive never did that before..
column2: Connecting eight 8-ohm 4-inch Sony woofers in parallel to each channel of your Rockville amplifier, aiming for a 2-ohm load and 110 watts RMS, may risk overpowering the 25-watt rated speakers and potentially causing damage. Consider using purpose-built car audio components, like standard 6.5-inch components or 6x9 speakers with a 4-ohm impedance, for better performance and durability. Bench testing before car installation is advisable to ensure optimal sound quality and speaker safety.

column2: One thing a lot of folks get wrong with the coolant is that the total is written including the reservoir to full mark. In khyber case, the reservoir holds 300 ml or so and the engine holds 4000 ml So when refilling with concentrate, one has to take that into consideration.

column1: Hello everyone the term tuning or get your car tuned is something that you all read all over the web in different forums! The purpose of this thread is to share the tuning world with newbies for the sake of correction/learning/advice/a new start here in our country tuning cars is still young very few people actually know about tuning and because we don't have dynos in our country like most of the countries have we haven't been through all that yet so please share your views theories on how you think an engine should be tuned majority of people only know how to put an engine into a certain car and here mostly the theory is small car bigger engine which has many complications remember a powerful engined car is not always a fast car With that said! i request all the gurus(Xulfiqar/saadzae92/datpak/iceman1 and all the others with respect) to help the newbies any questions regarding tuning NA/Boost/Nitrous hondata/crome/standalones/HACKS please put forward QUESTION ANSWERS START FROM PAGE 4
column2: Tuning a car involves optimizing its engine performance for better power, efficiency, and drivability. For newbies, it's crucial to understand the basics. Tuning may include adjustments to fuel injection, ignition timing, air intake, and exhaust systems. The choice of ECU (Engine Control Unit) and understanding fuel and ignition maps play a key role. For NA (Naturally Aspirated) or boosted engines, proper air-fuel ratios, timing, and adequate cooling are essential. Questions about specific setups, mods, or troubleshooting can be directed to experienced individuals. Collaborative learning is encouraged to foster a better understanding of the tuning process.

column1: Hello, This is my first thread on Pakwheels, and I have recently had the engine of my 2006 Alto VXR overhauled. It has only been driven for 200km since then. The fan of my car is directly connected, and the temperature needle rises to the mid-level on highways. I want to know if this level of heating is normal or if there is an issue with overheating.
column2: Assalamu Alaikum! Welcome to Wheels!Masail For your Alto VXR 2006 with a recently overhauled engine, the mid-level temperature on the highway is generally normal. However, if the radiator fan is directly connected, it's recommended to wire it back to automatic mode. Additionally, installing a thermostat is advised to regulate the engine temperature effectively. Ensure the radiator is cleaned, and consider using quality coolant like Caltex. While adding coolant, double-check that there's no obstruction in the radiator. Lastly, during the break-in period, it's generally advisable to avoid high speeds. Keep it moderate, gradually increasing the speed to let the engine components settle in properly. If you encounter persistent overheating issues, consult a reliable mechanic for a thorough check.

column1: I am researching about headlights upgrade in our 2019 Altis 1.6. We have had a big crash in the past due to poor lighting on the road. The options I see are: Buy Grande headlights. However, at 90k per headlight (180k in total), it is unaffordable. Simple bulb replace with SMD or HID. This is unethical as we will blind others and possibly damage the electronics + fire risk. Buy aftermarket projector headlights. I have been unable to find these; they are only available for 2014- 17 corolla. If anyone is selling for 2018-21 corolla, I would be interested. If anyone can tell me where to look for it, I will be very thankful. Also, would I also need a ballast and custom wiring with this? Retrofit projectors in existing headlights. This seems a little complicated for me. Does anyone offer these services including the supporting parts such as ballast, shroud, wiring harness etc. Someone is selling projectors from Grande for 12k. What supporting parts will it need? Will be very thankful for any help I can get. Regards
column2: The weather conditions in the area are varied: visibility is low at H11, high at HB3, and there's fog at H8/16/11. Typically, H11 bulbs are used for fog lights, while HB4 bulbs are used for low beam headlights. For the low beam, an H11 bulb is required, while an HB3 9005 bulb is needed for the high beam. If you're considering replacing your headlights, you can opt for kabli Grande headlights, which cost around 100k-125k per pair. Alternatively, you could retrofit them yourself with assistance from KeiWorks, sourcing the necessary components like ballasts, bulbs, and projector lens, and then have them retrofitted by a professional.

column1: I came across a person in Pindi who is going to start selling Hydrogen Fuel saving kits in cars to give upto around 35% savings in fuel consumption.He has got along with him some foreigners as well and they have installed kits on experimental basis in Islamabad last week on Saturday I guess.I asked him to provide me literature of the said product and the company's website so that I can check out full details but still havent got from him any details.He says that it will cost around Rs.44k.I checked on net and I got different kits with different prices available in US and Canada. Does this kit really work?And is it safe to install in vehicles? //MOD EDIT:  WARNING: Please note that the HHO fuel saving kit is a PROVEN SCAM and DOES NOT WORK. Pakwheels is NOT responsible if any member losses are incurred as a result of falling for this SCAM.  //
column2: While some consider the idea of using an HHO kit to generate hydrogen from water as workable with an educated approach, it's essential to exercise caution, especially considering our tendency to wash our cars' engines, electronics, and interiors excessively. However, there's a consensus that if the HHO kit is the type that claims to generate hydrogen from water, it's likely a scam, and it's advisable to protect both your money and your car. Despite some proponents arguing for its feasibility and cost-effectiveness compared to full electric conversions, skepticism remains due to the fundamental laws of thermodynamics. These laws apply universally, making it challenging to justify claims of efficiency or safety with HHO technology. While experiments may be conducted to test its efficacy, the scientific community generally remains skeptical about its practicality.

column1: Hi, I recently bought 2010 vitz. Somehow this great car doesn't have rear door speakers12 (strange). Now I'm thinking of installing amplifier but as this car doesn't have rear door speakers and/also it doesn't have boot cover (shelf), where I could install new speakers. Therefore I only left with the choice of installing subwoofer alone as I don't want to do any modification to car (i.e drilling or cutting side boards for speakers or boot shelf). The reason I brought this issue to this forum because Im confused and need your guys advice before I invest into any equipment. Will only subwoofer be enough as front speakers sound quaily is amazing. Or should I somehow put couple of speakers at rear? Suggest me a good amplifier and subwoofer. And if any of you done similar to your car then please do share your experience and suggestions. I was thinking of getting sub woofer alone with peak power of 1200w and RMS 400w. Will this kit be good for this car or its too big? Finally, as my car is 1.0 auto so will I need to put bigger battery in and do any alteration to alternator? Or will I need capacitor. Looking forward for your replies Nomi
column2: It's essential to maintain balance in your car audio system, especially when adding a powerful subwoofer. Consider upgrading your front speakers to components and adding an amplifier and subwoofer in the back to maintain balance. Alternatively, you can opt for a small subwoofer with a built-in amp that blends well with your existing setup. If you're concerned about drilling holes in the back doors for speaker installation, explore options like aftermarket rear shelves. Additionally, avoid placing tweeters on the seat belt pillars; instead, install them on the A-pillars, dashboard, or kicks for better sound distribution. Some users have successfully installed additional speakers in their Vitz without compromising rear space, showcasing that with proper planning and installation, you can enjoy quality audio without sacrificing functionality.

column1: Hey guys any audiophile out there or any enthusiast that wants a great spl setup, please contact me. Details Woofers, amplifiers sundown, rockford Component focal and rockford Twitters ds18 bullet
column2: When discussing 0 AWG wiring, it's important to understand that it refers to a gauge size for electrical wiring, also known as 1/0 or one-aught wire. This wire size indicates a larger diameter wire capable of carrying higher electrical currents. The length of the wiring can be customized based on specific requirements, typically depending on the distance between the power source and the device to be connected. When choosing the type of wire, options include OFC (Oxygen-Free Copper) and CCA (Copper-Clad Aluminum). OFC is preferable due to its superior conductivity and durability compared to CCA, which may be more affordable but less effective over long distances. A typical 0 AWG wiring kit includes wire, connectors, terminals, fuse holders, and sometimes a fuse, necessary for proper installation and connection to audio systems or other electrical devices. Specific kit contents may vary by manufacturer. For more detailed information or specific inquiries, feel free to send a private message for further assistance. Additionally, one user mentioned using a Sundown amp kit with OFC wire for their setup, which included two X12 v2 d2 12-inch subwoofers, an SFB 8000 monoblock amplifier, a Rockford R300x prime 4-channel amplifier, Focal coaxial speakers, and DS18 bullet tweeters.

column1: I heard it differs from car to car or make. I'm still figuring it out with my Corolla Se Saloon. Can anyone shed some light ?
column2: The amount of reserve fuel a car holds before the low fuel warning light comes on can indeed vary from one car to another. It's not only make-specific but also model-specific, and sometimes even within the same model, it can vary between different years. For example, in your Corolla SE Saloon, it may be helpful to refer to the owner's manual or contact the manufacturer to get specific information on the reserve fuel capacity for your particular model year. In general, the reserve fuel is a safety feature to ensure you have some fuel left for essential functions even when the low fuel warning comes on, and it's a good practice not to rely too much on it to avoid running out of fuel unexpectedly.

column1: Assalam o Alaikum Pakwheels, Dear all I have recently bought a Toyota Corolla Gli 2016 and looking to upgrade its sound system. I don’t need too much bass I am more inclined towards surround sound and better sound quality. I already own a amplifier and Subwoofer (Sony Xlod) from a previous car.
column2: It all depends on your budget and preferences. You can start by listening to various car audio setups from members or visiting reputable shops like Soundvalley in Pindi Saddar. If you're in Islamabad, you can even demo my cars to see if you like the setup. Regarding amplifiers, if you have a 4-channel amp and prefer surround sound, focus on getting a good set of components for the front and rear coaxials, along with dampening the doors and rear shelf for better midbass punch. Alternatively, you can power the front components and sub through the amp and run the rear speakers through the Android unit, especially if it's a Chinese unit with limited power. Regarding speaker options, Infinity Alpha series is a budget-friendly and good sounding option. Be cautious of fake products; reputable shops like Soundvalley ensure authenticity. In Lahore, Soundworks is a good albeit pricier option, while Lazersound has had mixed reviews lately.

column2: meh1;4091646: both types of vehicles come with different type of chassis. will they change chassis or do cutting and welding on old one? and as placement of engine components will change, it will be a mess. wiring of both type of vehicles is different, so it will take new wiring. new driver and passenger side controls on doors. is possible but cost will be too high.  In my opinion you are wrong in such assumption. if you get a chance to get hold of 2 Japanese vehicles of same make & model but 1 RHD other LHD open up the hood and inspect closely. chassis ( frame ) is common, punch holes for bolts are same on both sides. Vigo double cab, Hilux double cab, Fortuner, Prado 5 door are all on common chassis design and left hand to right hand conversion is matter of parts availability PLUS - the cabin can be pulled out for swap between chassis check physical specs for above and you will have a smile. locate the members in list - SHARABHI --- & --- CrashD send them a PM or email, they will reply both are BUSY dudes but always reply to PW members promptly.

column1: As the title suggests, I would like to ask all the tire experts out there for their opinion on Chinese tires. I am looking to replace the tires on my Santro and have the following options: -  - 1) Chinese Ratolla Tires 175/70/r13 for 16,000 rupees (4,000 each) - 2) Chinese Evergreen Tires 165/65/13 for 15,600 rupees (3,900 each) - 3) Chinese Bolex Tires 165/65/13 for 16,000 rupees (4,000 each) - 4) Bridgestone 155/65/13 for 18,800 rupees (4,700 each) -  - I am a bit concerned about the Bridgestone tire. It is not in its original packaging and the shopkeeper mentioned that it is smuggled. Additionally, it was manufactured in 2011. Please assist me in making a decision regarding which tires to choose. Should I go ahead with the Chinese tires or not?
column2: Regarding tires, there are various options available based on your preferences and budget. Eurostar 185/70/13 tires are priced at 4k each and come with a lifetime warranty, which could be a good option for some. However, if you're specifically looking for Chinese tires, A One Chinese tires have been recommended by one user for a Daihatsu Mira, with positive feedback on grip, noise levels, and durability, even after driving 10k kilometers. On the other hand, there are concerns about smuggled or used tires masquerading as renowned brands like Bridgestone. It's advised to avoid these and invest in tires from reputable brands like Dunlop, Bridgestone, and Yokohama, especially considering the weather conditions and road quality in Lahore. While Hankook and Kumho offer more affordable options without compromising on quality, it's generally recommended to prioritize quality over cost when it comes to tires to ensure safety and performance, particularly in extreme weather conditions.

column1: Hello guys my car is giving p0741 code can you please help me to sort out this problem or recommend me some good mechanic in lahore.
column2: this is bad news sometimes. P0741 is sometimes caused by low ATF level (find the leak) or bad ATF (worn out oil) and most of the times caused by a hydraulic leak in the valvebody or a bad torque converter too. It will take a transmission expert to resolve this for you. Do not think this will be a quick repair because its not. Do not drive at high speed at all with this code as the torque converter clutch isnt locking and the nonlock condition will severely overheat the transmission to its death.

column1: During the running period of a fully or semi-overhauled car engine, several precautionary measures should be observed. These measures include: -  - 1) Speed Limit: It is important to adhere to a specific speed limit to allow the engine components to properly break-in. The specific speed limit may vary depending on the type of transmission (4 or 5-speed). It is recommended to follow the manufacturer's guidelines regarding this. -  - 2) Number of Passengers: It is advisable to limit the number of passengers during the running period of an overhauled engine. This helps reduce the load on the engine and allows it to adjust to the new components more effectively. It is generally best to keep the number of passengers to a minimum. -  - 3) Kilometer Limit: There is usually a recommended minimum distance (kilometers) that should be covered during the break-in period of an overhauled engine. This distance allows the new components, such as rings, valve seals, and gaskets, to properly settle and function optimally. It is essential to follow the manufacturer's guidelines and ensure that the recommended distance is covered before subjecting the engine to more demanding conditions. -  - It is important to note that these precautionary measures may vary depending on the specific car model and manufacturer. Therefore, it is always recommended to refer to the car's manual or consult with a professional mechanic for accurate and detailed guidance during the running period of an overhauled engine.
column2: The mechanic's installation of oversized rings on polished cylinders and the addition of "helper rings" could lead to premature engine failure, as the rings require a rough bearing surface to properly mate with the cylinder walls, typically achieved through cylinder honing. During a correct engine rebuild or re-ring process, the engine should be started and allowed to fully warm up while checking for leaks and testing oil pressure. The mechanic should then gradually load the engine through various driving steps to seat the rings properly against the bore, ensuring they lose their rough edge. However, oil helper rings may sometimes cause issues, such as flooding the second compression ring with oil, resulting in cylinder wall polishing. Despite these initial steps, the engine should be driven normally. Running at 4000 rpm is not excessively high, but if the engine is running unusually cool without a thermostat or with the fan direct and lacks coolant, or if the tappets are left loose, it could indicate other issues. To address abnormal engine behavior, it's essential to drive normally, ensure the engine is perfectly tuned, and maintain proper operating temperatures. Following these steps, including running the engine only when fully warmed up and using the correct engine oil as specified in the owner's manual, are crucial for prolonging engine life.

column1: Rust proof your car for free The cause of automotive rust Most perforation rust (perforation means the rust has eaten right through the metal) starts from the inside of an automotive panel, not the outside. What you see on the surface is usually just the tip of an iceberg. Any observant motorist travelling overseas in a warm, dry climate soon notices the absence of perforation rust in the local vehicles. Obviously moisture is the major cause of rust. Moisture from dew, rain, or condensation becomes trapped for long periods in dirt crevices, especially along the bottoms of doors and around the inner edges of guards. Even without dirt, lack of factory paint can result in perforation rust, especially in car roofs due to condensation. Parking your car outdoors every night without shelter in rain and dewey nights can speed up this process three fold. So how how can you stop existing rust and prevent new rust long term? Preventing rust How often you have seen a rusty steel gearbox, or a steering knuckle? Or when was the last time you heard of a car engine sump rusting through? Most likely never. But these parts are all subject to moisture, salt etc, and are bare unpainted steel. Why don’t they rust? The answer is oil and grease. These parts tend to pick up a thin layer of oil or grease. Oil and grease repel moisture. Rust is not a living thing like cancer, it requires moisture to continue. Deprive it of moisture and it stops forming, or never begins in the first place. This is the basis of the free rust-proofing secret. Smear some oil or grease on a piece of metal and try washing it off with water. Virtually impossible without detergent. Whether the oil or grease is dirty or clean it still has this same property of repelling water and sticking to metal. So all you need do to ensure that existing rust does not continue, or ever take hold in the first place, is to treat the inside crevices of automotive panels with oil or grease. Oil is easier to work with and has the added advantage of continuing to creep deep into crevices and cracks for months afterward. Don't waste money buying new oil. The oil drained from the engine or transmission of your car will work fine. Most garages will fill a can for you if you don’t like to change your own oil. How to do it Using oil for rust proofing must of course be left until after any intended rust repair and painting is completed, or the adhesion of filler and paint will be seriously affected. (If you want to stop rust in the meantime, etch paint primer both sides will generally do the job, and also provide an ideal key for filler on the outside.) A paintbrush is usually all that is required to apply oil to the insides of doors and other easily accessible panels. But some areas will require a bit of ingenuity. A spray-gun can be useful. However most oils will need to be thinned 10-15% with kerosene in order to spray. You can buy an accessory for the Wagner airless electric spray gun that consists of a long thin plastic 6mm (¼ inch) tube with a tiny spray nozzle in the tip. These are ideal for rust proofing hard to get at places like inside sills (the two bottom panels that run along below the doors) and roof edges. Just drilling a hole in a concealed area to gain access is all that is required Whichever method you use, don't worry about overdoing it. Saturation is the key word. Surplus oil will find its way out, just be careful where you park the vehicle for a few hours. Oil may continue to seep out of cracks and drainholes for days afterwards but normally does not drip and can easily be wiped off with a rag. Sills can be difficult to treat. Sometimes kickplates or carpet can be removed and holes drilled, or cut with a chisel, and a spray gun used (see above). If this fails, a professional rust-proofer can treat them for you. In easily accessible areas such as boot floors, or where a dry finish is desirable, etch priming and painting both sides of a panel can be the best solution. Exterior crevices Deep exterior crevices which are sometines found around windscreens etc, trap salts that can cause surface rust. This is especially noticeable in vehicles exposed to sea winds, or in areas subject to heavy air pollution. A simple way to prevent this type of rust is to fill these crevices with grease. The firm water resistant type designed for marine use is best. For a cleaner finish you can use a clear or black silicon. (Use masking tape along either side of the crevice when applying for a neat finsh.) If rust has already started, a combination of both can be used. Make sure the crevice is dry, then forcing in oil or grease deeply to saturate the rust and deprive it of moisture. Then thoroughly clean and dry the surface area and apply a thin layer of silicon to seal it in. Again use masking tape to keep a clean edge. Welding in new steel versus filling? Most motorists believe that the only effective way to rid their vehicles of rust is to weld in new steel panels. This is effective if the new metal is butt welded, ie, welded edge to edge to existing panels without any overlapping. However this is seldom done as it is too time consuming and costly. What usually happens is that the new panels being welded in are overlapped with the old and then the edge of the new panel welded on the outsid only. This however sets up ideal conditions within the overlap for continued rusting, and also makes it difficult if not impossible to rust proof effectively. The chemical reactions of welding can also chase rust along even faster. Often within two years the rust is showing through again. column1: Rust proof your car for free The cause of automotive rust Most perforation rust (perforation means the rust has eaten right through the metal) starts from the inside of an automotive panel, not the outside. What you see on the surface is usually just the tip of an iceberg. Any observant motorist travelling overseas in a warm, dry climate soon notices the absence of perforation rust in the local vehicles. Obviously moisture is the major cause of rust. Moisture from dew, rain, or condensation becomes trapped for long periods in dirt crevices, especially along the bottoms of doors and around the inner edges of guards. Even without dirt, lack of factory paint can result in perforation rust, especially in car roofs due to condensation. Parking your car outdoors every night without shelter in rain and dewey nights can speed up this process three fold. So how how can you stop existing rust and prevent new rust long term? Preventing rust How often you have seen a rusty steel gearbox, or a steering knuckle? Or when was the last time you heard of a car engine sump rusting through? Most likely never. But these parts are all subject to moisture, salt etc, and are bare unpainted steel. Why don’t they rust? The answer is oil and grease. These parts tend to pick up a thin layer of oil or grease. Oil and grease repel moisture. Rust is not a living thing like cancer, it requires moisture to continue. Deprive it of moisture and it stops forming, or never begins in the first place. This is the basis of the free rust-proofing secret. Smear some oil or grease on a piece of metal and try washing it off with water. Virtually impossible without detergent. Whether the oil or grease is dirty or clean it still has this same property of repelling water and sticking to metal. So all you need do to ensure that existing rust does not continue, or ever take hold in the first place, is to treat the inside crevices of automotive panels with oil or grease. Oil is easier to work with and has the added advantage of continuing to creep deep into crevices and cracks for months afterward. Don't waste money buying new oil. The oil drained from the engine or transmission of your car will work fine. Most garages will fill a can for you if you don’t like to change your own oil. How to do it Using oil for rust proofing must of course be left until after any intended rust repair and painting is completed, or the adhesion of filler and paint will be seriously affected. (If you want to stop rust in the meantime, etch paint primer both sides will generally do the job, and also provide an ideal key for filler on the outside.) A paintbrush is usually all that is required to apply oil to the insides of doors and other easily accessible panels. But some areas will require a bit of ingenuity. A spray-gun can be useful. However most oils will need to be thinned 10-15% with kerosene in order to spray. You can buy an accessory for the Wagner airless electric spray gun that consists of a long thin plastic 6mm (¼ inch) tube with a tiny spray nozzle in the tip. These are ideal for rust proofing hard to get at places like inside sills (the two bottom panels that run along below the doors) and roof edges. Just drilling a hole in a concealed area to gain access is all that is required Whichever method you use, don't worry about overdoing it. Saturation is the key word. Surplus oil will find its way out, just be careful where you park the vehicle for a few hours. Oil may continue to seep out of cracks and drainholes for days afterwards but normally does not drip and can easily be wiped off with a rag. Sills can be difficult to treat. Sometimes kickplates or carpet can be removed and holes drilled, or cut with a chisel, and a spray gun used (see above). If this fails, a professional rust-proofer can treat them for you. In easily accessible areas such as boot floors, or where a dry finish is desirable, etch priming and painting both sides of a panel can be the best solution. Exterior crevices Deep exterior crevices which are sometines found around windscreens etc, trap salts that can cause surface rust. This is especially noticeable in vehicles exposed to sea winds, or in areas subject to heavy air pollution. A simple way to prevent this type of rust is to fill these crevices with grease. The firm water resistant type designed for marine use is best. For a cleaner finish you can use a clear or black silicon. (Use masking tape along either side of the crevice when applying for a neat finsh.) If rust has already started, a combination of both can be used. Make sure the crevice is dry, then forcing in oil or grease deeply to saturate the rust and deprive it of moisture. Then thoroughly clean and dry the surface area and apply a thin layer of silicon to seal it in. Again use masking tape to keep a clean edge. Welding in new steel versus filling? Most motorists believe that the only effective way to rid their vehicles of rust is to weld in new steel panels. This is effective if the new metal is butt welded, ie, welded edge to edge to existing panels without any overlapping. However this is seldom done as it is too time consuming and costly. What usually happens is that the new panels being welded in are overlapped with the old and then the edge of the new panel welded on the outsid only. This however sets up ideal conditions within the overlap for continued rusting, and also makes it difficult if not impossible to rust proof effectively. The chemical reactions of welding can also chase rust along even faster. Often within two years the rust is showing through again. Whereas filling the rusted areas with a good quality water-resistant filler, applied over an etch primer or sound paint, not bare metal and rustproofing afterward can result in a permanant repair. However for areas that are too big to fill, or require the strength of steel, welding panels is the only option. If a long lasting repair is required, only butt welding should be used. Rustproofing should be rechecked and if necessary retreated every two years.

Sometimes kickplates or carpet can be removed and holes drilled, or cut with a chisel, and a spray gun used (see above). If this fails, a professional rust-proofer can treat them for you. In easily accessible areas such as boot floors, or where a dry finish is desirable, etch priming and painting both sides of a panel can be the best solution. Exterior crevices Deep exterior crevices which are sometines found around windscreens etc, trap salts that can cause surface rust. This is especially noticeable in vehicles exposed to sea winds, or in areas subject to heavy air pollution. A simple way to prevent this type of rust is to fill these crevices with grease. The firm water resistant type designed for marine use is best. For a cleaner finish you can use a clear or black silicon. (Use masking tape along either side of the crevice when applying for a neat finsh.) If rust has already started, a combination of both can be used. Make sure the crevice is dry, then forcing in oil or grease deeply to saturate the rust and deprive it of moisture. Then thoroughly clean and dry the surface area and apply a thin layer of silicon to seal it in. Again use masking tape to keep a clean edge. Welding in new steel versus filling? Most motorists believe that the only effective way to rid their vehicles of rust is to weld in new steel panels. This is effective if the new metal is butt welded, ie, welded edge to edge to existing panels without any overlapping. However this is seldom done as it is too time consuming and costly. What usually happens is that the new panels being welded in are overlapped with the old and then the edge of the new panel welded on the outsid only. This however sets up ideal conditions within the overlap for continued rusting, and also makes it difficult if not impossible to rust proof effectively. The chemical reactions of welding can also chase rust along even faster. Often within two years the rust is showing through again. Whereas filling the rusted areas with a good quality water-resistant filler, applied over an etch primer or sound paint, not bare metal and rustproofing afterward can result in a permanant repair. However for areas that are too big to fill, or require the strength of steel, welding panels is the only option. If a long lasting repair is required, only butt welding should be used. Rustproofing should be rechecked and if necessary retreated every two years.
column2: Any area where water collects and is stopped that area is prone to rust.

column2: When storing engine oil, ensure the cap is tightly sealed and store the bottle in a shaded area to maintain its viability for up to a year. It's essential to verify the authenticity and quality of any product before purchasing, especially engine oil, by checking with reliable shops. Stick to reputable brands like Shell Helix, Caltex Havoline, and Castrol GTX, purchased exclusively from authorized fuel stations. While 5W-30 oil is better suited for winter use and 10W-40 for summers, users should consider their operating conditions when selecting the appropriate viscosity. column1: Couple of years ago my car got dent on left front door. As I used to do all my ride work from Toyota Township so i went there. They charged me around 2500-3000 for the said dented door. column1: Hi, I have FJ70 (Rkr) with 1HZ (4200 CC, Diesel, manual transmission) engine. My jeep is giving low fuel mileage (6-7KM/L local ) with 4*4 lock (front wheel) in-active/free, on the other hand with active 4*4 locks it's giving 9 - 9.5KM/L local. This is strange thing I'm experiencing. As per my knowledge (mostly got from the mechanics ) when lock is on/active, vehicle is on 4 wheel drive and consumes more fuel compares to when locks are free/in-active. I got the jeep checked by multiple mechanic, everyone has their version of problem which does not makes sense to me at all. Some are saying, locks are not attached properly: This is not the case, because I'm unable to use 4*4 gear when locks are free/inactive: I suspect the clutch-plate: any recommendation would be appreciated. Also please recommend good/reliable mechanic in RWP/ISB.

column1: Actually I am here on this forum to know the First Japanese Car Brand imported to Pakistan, Kindly help to share the Brand Name as well as the year of Import.
column2: The first official imports I think were the likes of the old Subaru 360 and the very first Dai Berlina etc, Hino Contessa etc. Before that - some people did actually privately ship the Toyota AA or AC (cant confirm) sedans (2 existed in North Nazimabad Karachi in the B block area in the same house) - both green and very interesting complete with wooden battery box outside. Both not in running condition though - literally banged up panels everywhere as if they threw it off a hill twice Mind you these cars ended production before the birth of Pakistan. They were literally driven into Pakistan from Iran I think - They had no official import papers either, just a rudimentary file of documents with hand written and signed stuff - in India Ink (the sweet smelling kind). The stamps on them were blotter roller type. If you are a car enthusiast, you may know of this house, they also had volvos - (one of them was the james bond model ) The other famous volvo was in the haunted house near Capri cinema.

column1: Asalam o Alaikum, pakwheelers! Hope y'all are doing great, I'm already working on a Suzuki but then again, I JUST CAN'T GET ENOUGH OF BUYING MORE AND MORE PROJECT CARS! YES, ANOTHER PROJECT CAR OR MAY I SAY, ANOTHER SUZUKI? This time, I got my hands on a SUZUKI SWIFT MK2 SEDAN 16V, locally known as SUZUKI MARGALLA Just like Suzuki Swift MK1, the MK2 was also sold internationally with different names, this generation came in production in 1988 with different body selections which included a 3 DOOR HATCH, 5 DOOR HATCH, A CABRIOLET and a SEDAN The names this car was sold internationally included SUZUKI SWIFT, SUZUKI ESTEEM, SUZUKI CULTUS (hatchback), MARUTI ESTEEM, GEO METRO, CHEVROLET SPRINT, and CHANGAN SWIFT, The car was globally launched in 1990 and remained in production until 1995 whereas in Pakistan, it was sold as Suzuki Margalla until 1998 when finally Baleno replaced it. The car I will be working on is a Suzuki Margalla, the pre-facelift version! SPECS? , ORIGINAL G13A . A WORKING AC . A WORKING SPEEDOMETER . A CHINESE PRE THAT IS FITTED UPSIDE DOWN WORK REQUIRED? . COMPLETE ENGINE OVERHAUL . COMPLETE BODY RESTORATION I'm posting some pictures of the car I clicked yesterday before handing it over to the workshop P.S; DON'T WORRY, I'M WORKING IN KHYBER AS WELL AND THERE'S ANOTHER SURPRISE TOO DON'T KNOW ME YET? CHECK OUT SOME OF MY PROJECTS THAT I DOCUMENTED HERE! DAIHATSU CHARADE 1989 - CB100 The Rebuild - Daihatsu Charade CB100 D.I.Y Projects Asalam o Alaikum fellow Pakwheelers I'm starting this thread on behalf of my brother @ranahamza89 who is going to be rebuilding his Daihatsu Charade CB100 1989 from scratch. The car's condition is all rusty and rough, running on Toyota 1KR FE (Vitz 1000cc) The interior requires a lot of work as well, the pictures will be enough to tell, but things will start getting better with time and we both have decided not to rush it. We both have been planning on getting the car done but since both of u… MAZDA RX8 Bringing my RX back to life - Mazda RX8 1JZ VVTi Mazda Asalam o alaikum everyone. Months ago, I got my hands on a Mazda RX8 2005. The car was swapped with a 2JZGTE by the previous owner but I bought the car without any engine under the hood. It was parked in a plot for months and the owner wasn't willing to sell it but after 2 months of procrastination, I finally got my hands on it. The car was and still is in a pretty bad condition, the last owner had the car showered in matte blue, then matte pink and currently the car is showered in matte yellow … HONDA ACCORD 1989 - CA5 Built Not Bought - Honda Accord CA5 1989 3G D.I.Y Projects Salam everyone! I hope everyone's doing well, my Mazda RX8 is finally home & now? It was finally time for myself to get another car to play with, after throwing in money for those huge bills on the RX8, I was looking to get an affordable, yet a different project, I honestly was thinking of getting a Suzuki Swift MK1 (2 door) for myself but as I was going through my routine pakwheels surfing, I came across an ad that blew my mind & I actually made a blind deal, here she is! The Honda Accord 3G it… HONDA CIVIC EK3 Built Not Bought S2 - PROJEKT Honda Civic EK3 Technical Forums Asalam o Alaikum, pakwheelers! I was already undergoing a project on my BMW E39 but it needs a lot of time and tbh, a lot of money too, therefore, I thought of pausing it for a while, meanwhile, I have started working on this Honda Civic EK3. The specs of this specific car are listed below . Powered by a Honda D15A SOHC motor . Stick shift . Nothing fancy except for the mesh grill and the front bumper lip . 15" Vossen replicas . The car is originally finished in New Vogue Silver Metallic . The… BMW 540i E39 Built Not Bought 2.0 - BMW E39 540i M62 4.4L V8 D.I.Y Projects Asalam o Alaikum, fellow pakwheelers! Hope you all are doing great, this is going to be my 5th project that I'll be documenting on pakwheels but 11th in general. I was in search of the perfect budget V8 that I could use on a daily basis and maintaining it wouldn't be a pain in the ass. A car that I can drive everyday but enjoy on weekends. This is our 8th german but this E39 holds a special place in my heart as this is the first BMW that I bought from my own earnings. Coming to the specs, let's … SUZUKI KHYBER Built Not Bought S3 - Suzuki Khyber/Swift MK1/Chevrolet Sprint Technical Forums Asalam o Alaikum, Pakwheelers! Keeping the project cars streak alive since 2016, I'm back with another interesting, fun yet AFFORDABLE project. The legendary Suzuki Khyber a.k.a Suzuki Swift MK1 a.k.a Holden Barina a.k.a Chevrolet Sprint a.k.a Pontiac Firefly. Introduced as Suzuki Swift globally in 1983 at the 25th Tokyo Motor Show, this generation was around for over a decade and was sold under different badges thanks to the alliance between Suzuki and GM. I've always wanted a 2 door CLUB CULT… Now wish me luck and STAY TUNED FOR ANOTHER DOPE BUILD! 🏻
column2: Have your guy take off the front mudguards completely, if you see rust on raintray drains, you need to remove the dashboard too to rebuild that part. The wiring will also be beyond dead by now. And i hope your denter/welder knows that the bulkhead/firewall lower section requires very careful repair as overheating can warp the area out of shape and make the body flex like an empty cardboard box.

The car I will be working on is a Suzuki Margalla, the pre-facelift version! SPECS? , ORIGINAL G13A . A WORKING AC . A WORKING SPEEDOMETER . A CHINESE PRE THAT IS FITTED UPSIDE DOWN WORK REQUIRED? . COMPLETE ENGINE OVERHAUL . COMPLETE BODY RESTORATION I'm posting some pictures of the car I clicked yesterday before handing it over to the workshop P.S; DON'T WORRY, I'M WORKING IN KHYBER AS WELL AND THERE'S ANOTHER SURPRISE TOO DON'T KNOW ME YET? CHECK OUT SOME OF MY PROJECTS THAT I DOCUMENTED HERE! column2: Its not about supervision as you are not the one holding the welding torch and hammer.. The guy with them needs to understand how those areas need to unstressed before even thinking of welding, otherwise you will have an avalanche of interesting looking cracks.

column1: This thread is specifically created to discuss about the Tire Pressure Monitoring System (TPMS). For those who don't know about the TPMS, it is a small electronic device that monitors tyre pressure and temperature. The device constantly measures the air pressure inside the tyre and it alerts the driver about the low / high pressure or sudden deflation of tyres or high temperature. There are two types of TPMS: 1) Internal TPMS Internal systems use sensors that are strapped around the wheel or replace the valve stem and are inside the tire. 2) External TPMS External systems are those which have sensors that read from outside of the tire.
column2: Major manufacturers across their model lines utilize various types of transmitters and receivers. However, the prominent ones primarily employ either 433 MHz (mainly German manufacturers) or 315 MHz (such as GM, Toyota, and others) transmitters and receivers.
