I came across three cheap options including Flamingo, Guard, Osaka and Afla Prime coolant. Can any brother with his experience mention which is best from all these mention coolants? and after how much month/years we should replace the old coolants?
column2: with havoline you will end up with a perfect mix of 50% in the system, with the ZIC super, you will end up with something like 30% all you need to do with concentrate is (assuming your system holds 4 litres) after cleaning system, let it drain out as much as it can, measure what came out, if its more than 50% (2 litres) of the systems total capacity then you open up the two concentrate bottles you bought and pour them in directly, then top up with water and start the engine, till the thermostat pops open or starts to pop open, let it bleed out any air. - cap it and you are done. With premix you will always end up with less than 50% mixture as the already premixed coolant will mix with water already present in the system. To raise the concentration again you will need to buy another large container of premix and waste the old weaker premix unless you can find the same coolant as concentrate. btw - the ZIC coolant is more expensive than havoline as you only get 1.5 litres of coolant concentrate for Rs 2610/- with buying the ZIC coolant, (water is free/almost free) while with the havoline you only pay Rs 2532/- for 2 litres concentrate coolant (which yields 4 litres) So - in a nutshell, you could have spent Rs 2532/- (plus some clean water) and have 4 litres of ready to use coolant. while you spent Rs 2610/- and only got 3litres of ready use coolant, that too of inferior quality. (seems like shopkeeper made a nice sale (they get paid more by ZIC than by Havoline/Chevron). in short ZIC charging you Rs 2610/- for 3 litres ready mix actually cost you Rs 1740/- per litre concentrate (there is only 1.5 litres concentrate in that bottle)) Havoline is available for Rs 1266/- per litre concentrate. But its your money - you may wish to spend as you wish,

column1: I'm driving an old Daihatsu move 2007. I need to replace radiator water with coolant. The coolant market is very saturated and some are very expensive. Can't decide which is better. I came across three cheap options including Flamingo, Guard, Osaka and Afla Prime coolant. Can any brother with his experience mention which is best from all these mention coolants? and after how much month/years we should replace the old coolants?
column2: The recommendation of that was based on very old designs with gasket materials and manufacturing porosity that were not fully up to spec compared to todays cars, For those the IAT coolant was used as it coats the system with a layer of silicates and fills micro gaps. Older cars also were designed with an airgap in the top of the cooling system and this coupled with the original formulation of OAT coolant caused gelling. however nowadays the formulations have changed for better and OAT coolants can be used in such systems (provided you dont buy NOS items from some guy who sells it from a shack in the woods) - The manufacturing and gasketing materials have also changed for the better. If you have a real old machine and require an IAT due to some oddball reason - I would suggest to buy a Si HOAT like glysantin G05 or G48 - they work great in such system and have a 5 year service life.

column1: This windy morning, i got a chance to drive my Manager son's car, was a normal car but with a beast roaring under the hood.. The ride was EE90 2.0 Diesel.. When i poped the hood. The engine was swapped to 3SGTE mated to 2C diesel gearbox... Is this possible, becoz i also own a 2C diesel, the gearbox of that EE90 was too much fimilar to mine... So my question is 3sgte can be mated to a 2c gearbox... Similarities are both the engines are tilted.. and my secong question is what the engine weight of 2c and 3sgte?
column2: yep - C and S are the same bell pattern and share most of their stuff. The reduction ratios are engine specific tho.

column2: toqeerahmad: is their any difference between both gears as i heard c & s series have same gears? you most probably have an early 1C gearbox mated to your engine and the tunnel would be hammered in. The problem with mazda 808 is that it was never made for a piston engine, its made for rotary engine and in rotary everything sits very low and is quite small too. The original 1.3 litre piston engine for it also sits a bit forwards to the gearbox can clear the bulkhead properly. So to accomodate fatter transmissions, you need to broach the floorpan.

column1: this is not a complete DIY at the moment, im posting this because im stuck (6) UPDATE: Page 2 contains the remaining part of the DIY Rear Defogger Repair ( honda city ) Skill Level: Low Tools: 2x hands with atleast 3 fingers in each, a multimeter, conductive marker / paint/ tape/ glue. Time: 60 minutes only 3 bottom lines of my cars defogger work, rest of them i assume got scratched somehow. i read couple of DIYs on the internet, and did my own. heres it. step 1  note the lines which are damaged step 2  remove C pillar molds if required to access main joints of defogger. turn on the car and defogger. check voltage between both joints to comfirm its not a power or blown fuse issue.        step 3  identify the broken link on each damaged line. procedure: 1. set your multimeter upto 15 dc volts 2. turn on your car and defogger 3. make sure the main joints are getting voltage 4. place positive node of multimeter on the positive end of your defogger. 5. place negative node of multimeter on the positive end aswell, the meter should read 0 volts. (make sure the nodes/pins of multimeter are round tipped. sharp pointed tips can damage the defogger further ) 6. Now start moving your negative node away from the positive footprint onto the damaged line. 7. meter reading should remain at 0 volts until u cross the broken area, the moment u cross the broken / scratched area, you reading should jump upto 12-14 volts. ( this is when assuming u have only one scratched area per line, if u have 2 or more, the meter will jump to 12volts only after crossing the last broken area ( closest to ground, furthest from positive node ) ) 8. now u have identified the damaged area on the line. 9. repeat this procedure on all lines. and note   step 4  now that you know whr the damaged areas are, we can apply the fix., namely Conductive tape ( not sure if available in Pakistan ) LINK29 Conductive Marker ( suggested by Ghuncha, not easily available ) LINK25 Conductive Glue or paint, need carbon graphite or better copper powder to make this at home, my first attempt did not work as i hoped. it gave me a resistance of 500 ohms, i was hoping something under 50 ohms LINK 1 to DIY28 LINK 2 to DIY13 this is where i will leave u ppl, my experiment with home made glue did not work quiet well, im gonna search the market for marker or tape, if any of u know whr i can get them, plz do post. i will update this thread in a day or two. UPDATE: Page 2 contains the remaining part of the DIY ps at jag, can u make the edit box retain its text, i pressed submit and error showed up, i pressed back, and all the text was gone
column2: i discussed this a long time go and nobody believed it would work (Y)

column1: I need assistance in deciding between three car models: Nissan Dayz, Daihatsu Mira, and Kia Picanto. I am specifically looking for the following criteria:  - 1. Excellent fuel efficiency in city driving with an air conditioning system. - 2. Good acceleration performance. - 3. Easy availability of spare parts. -  - Please provide your recommendations based on these factors. Thank you.
column2: In the current scenario, considering the fuel prices, you should consider purchasing a hatchback. Hatchbacks offer more space, have higher resale value, and their shorter bonnet makes them easier to handle. They also have better fuel efficiency compared to sedans.  -  - If your budget is between 2 to 2.4 million, you can choose between imported and local cars. While your budget is limited, it is advisable to go for a local car. However, I will also mention some imported car options for your consideration. -  - Imported options include: -  - 1. Toyota Vitz 2010-11 - 2. Suzuki Wagon R 2012-2014 - 3. Toyota Passo 2012-2015 -  - For local cars within your budget, you can consider the following options: -  - 1. Suzuki Alto latest 2023 VX, VXR, VXR AGS (VXL AGS might be slightly out of your budget) - 2. Suzuki Cultus VX, VXR 2019-2020 - 3. Suzuki Wagon R 2017-2018 - 4. Suzuki Swift 2018-2020 (Note: it consumes more fuel) - 5. Honda City 2013-15 (Sedan) - 6. Honda Civic Reborn Generation (Note: it consumes more fuel and has expensive spare parts) - 7. Toyota Corolla 1.3 Manual 2012-14 (Sedan) -  - If you can increase your budget to 3-4 million, some additional options to consider are: -  - 1. Nissan Note E - 2. Suzuki Alto JDM - 3. column1: I have recently bought 2004 Toyota Corolla Se saloon 1.6 At Overall the car is in really good shape and condition (the engine health is good however i am getting really bad fuel average Also I am facing misfire or jerk when my car hits around 100 Km/h and engine check light appears upon slowing down the speed from 100km/h the jerking and check engine light goes away 1st time I got it scanned no error found. 2nd time i got it scanned right away the check again light came it showed an error coil issue (ignitor) Note : The mechanic said is mai coils mira gari kai dalae huay hain I did the basic tuning but the fuel consumption is still the same approx 6km/L on 50% AC Changed engine oil (used Toyota 20W50) Changed Oil filter and Ail filter (leppon) Spark plugs cleaned Coil cleaned MAF sensor cleaned Throttle body cleaned What should I do to get better fuel average ?
column2: u already know the reason, replace coils with OEM. ur car has manual trim pot for AFR, if its fiddled with then use exhaust gas analyser to adjust according to factory specs.

column1: hello people.. my city steermatic is on cng.. (not gud) visited several mechanics past week.. majority of them said cng is not successful in city cuz of its transmission .. and also said that of we keep on using cng for an year more or so... the cvt transmission wud get destroyed . . . want to ask.. is this true?? help
column2: the above posted literature cannot be subjected to CVT, the internals and its operating principles are completely different.

column1: hello people.. my city steermatic is on cng.. (not gud) visited several mechanics past week.. majority of them said cng is not successful in city cuz of its transmission .. and also said that of we keep on using cng for an year more or so... the cvt transmission wud get destroyed . . . want to ask.. is this true?? help
column2: yes - if the transmission is controlled by the ECU, the ECU parameters are designed to work with the available torque of the petrol engine, if you fool the ECU to advance timing etc, the CVT will grip harder in lower gear and cause high pressure shift patterns which can seriously heat it up or even damage some mechanical parts too.

column1: hello people.. my city steermatic is on cng.. (not gud) visited several mechanics past week.. majority of them said cng is not successful in city cuz of its transmission .. and also said that of we keep on using cng for an year more or so... the cvt transmission wud get destroyed . . . want to ask.. is this true?? help
column2: the CNG system required to run on CVT is a multi - injector system with proper ECU reflashing to accomodate a different torque curve of the engine. The "gas setting kardo bhai - aisee ke 1 kilo mein poora Karachi ghoom lein" wont work. The engine should produce near to the same amount of power it was making on petrol at the same rpm, Hence it wont "soongh" gas but rather swill it.The transmission take up and variator movement is pre-fed into the ECU to refer to the running parameters, Fiddling with the input is a sure fire way to burn your cheque book. I drive a CVT here in US and the fluid operating temperature spikes really easily on a climb with full accelerator and 4 passengers, Enough temperature that any conventional autobox with DX3 would start to eat itself away.

column1: I just got new Honda Civic RS 2023 black color, alot of people recommending me to get PPF on it, please give advise if its worth it and how effective it really is.
column2: "How much does it cost? 1-2 lakh? It's all just a show. If you have money that you want to spend frivolously, then sure. But you should weigh the pros and cons and make your decision. Self-healing paint protection film (ppf)? Is it worth the extra money to prevent scratches on your paint? Think about it, when you sell a car, does anyone care if the paint is marred? Beads? Just spend the weekend waxing your car, brother. If you're in Lahore, can you go without getting your car dinged and scratched? If yes, then go for it. If not, ask yourself what is the true benefit of this ppf? I had heard about using ppf on high-end cars to protect the paint from road chips, but now they're trying to make us crazy about it for Civic and Sportage. Maybe someone else sees more value in wrapping their car in ppf, but for me, the cost outweighs the benefits. In 2019, I ordered a 12""x72"" sheet of 3M Scotchgard Pro Series, cleaned my old Vitz headlights, and covered them with this ppf, and to this day, the sheet hasn't oxidized and the headlights are clear and sharp. It cost me $43, but it was somewhat worth the money for me. But even back then, it was quite expensive, and now it has become even more expensive."

column2: Waalaikum Assalam! Sure, I'll assist you with performing a compression test, both wet and dry. -  - To carry out a compression test, you will need a compression tester. Here are the steps: -  - 1. Ensure that the engine is off and the ignition key is out. - 2. Locate the spark plugs and remove them using an appropriate spark plug wrench. - 3. Connect the compression tester to the spark plug socket of the first cylinder. Make sure it is securely attached. - 4. Have an assistant fully depress the gas pedal to open the throttle plate. - 5. Crank the engine for a few seconds using the starter motor. Note down the reading on the compression tester gauge. - 6. Repeat this process for each cylinder, noting down the readings. -  - Now, let's move on to the wet compression test: -  - 1. With the engine off, add a small amount of engine oil (about one teaspoon) into the spark plug port of the cylinder being tested. - 2. Repeat steps 3 to 6 of the dry compression test. -  - Keep in mind that the compression readings should be relatively higher in the wet test compared to the dry test. This indicates that the piston rings or valves may be causing low compression, which gets temporarily sealed with the added oil in the wet test. -  - Make sure to consult a professional mechanic if you are not confident or unsure about performing the compression test.

column1: Well, the summer season is here and the car ACs are running once again. What do u think guys that should we remove the hot water heater pipe or it should remain there as it is ?
column2: There is absolutely NO reason to stop coolant from running through the heater core during the summer months; unless you have a leak in the heater core. Also, it can help cooling your engine in an emergency if you have a blockage problem in main radiator. As Cateyez mentioned earlier, removing the pipe does not help increase A/C efficiency and it is quite possible that you may end up damaging the connectors by unnecessarily fiddling with them.

column1: Well, the summer season is here and the car ACs are running once again. What do u think guys that should we remove the hot water heater pipe or it should remain there as it is ?
column2: An answer supported with logic: when you turn hot/cold knob (or lever in some cars) a flap moves and seals the hot air path. Hot air still at times get mixed with your AC's chilling air due to any of the following reason: The flap didn't shut one path completely The foam type insulation on flap has worn off The flap is metallic(though very rare) Now there's a check before you plan to get you heater pipes plugged. When your car engine is slightly warm turn on freash air, turn the cooling knob or lever to coolest and feel the air coming from ducts if you think there is hot air added in it you've got to get the heater pipes plugged...note AC was not turned ON in this experiment. Hope I helped

column1: Hello everyone! What is the best solution for installing a subwoofer in a Vigo? I would prefer a 12-inch subwoofer, but I could compromise and go with a 10-inch one as well. Where should I place the enclosure in the vehicle?
column2: You pay make a custom fit enclosure to fit under the rear seat bench. In that case, people usually go for 8" subs. You can look up some idea's on the net and depending on which city you are, visit one of the reputed shops so they can prepare the enclosure If a 10" sub fits down there, you can go for it but 1 or multiple 8" subs is the way to go usually in trucks

column1: Hello everyone! What is the best solution for installing a subwoofer in a Vigo? I would prefer a 12-inch subwoofer, but I could compromise and go with a 10-inch one as well. Where should I place the enclosure in the vehicle?
column2: An amp will make a night and day difference. A reputed unit ( not a Chinese or android unit ) will make around 20-22 rms each channel. Most component sets start with 40-45 W rms. Simply put, your unit won't have enough juice to run your components with good clean power, meaning you'll be able to hear your music but you'll never hear the actual potential of how good the components sound when they run off an amp

column2: makhdoom123;5156395: i have no problem with age of equipment unit , my car does not wobbles at 190kmph but most of the time Age of equipment matters in pakistan because the people here do not worry about the maintenance of the equipment itself. if the equipment itself is not calibrated , how can it balance a wheel properly. every person balanced wheels in front of me with 0 - 0 weights. Still the car wobbles. so it means equipment is faulty. Yes i also got wheels balanced from toyota in rahim yar khan , he washed the alloys properly , filled them with air properly and then balanced the wheel properly and their machine was also newer. Car was good at even 200kmph. The proper procedure is important for a good balance. You are right in that clean wheels and tire pressure are important. The main issue comes with careful centering of the wheel on the machine. If it is not mounted exactly correctly, the machine will read 0-0 but the car will wobble even if the machine is calibrated properly. Using a backconing method with a correctly sized taper cone or a collet, with a flange plate for the front is far better at accurate centering, but most shops do not use these methods.

column2: kkoool;5156415: The first and foremost thing is the rotational alignment of the filling nozzle marker . It should be perfectly aligned with the filling valve. The manufacturers always inserts a small weight opposite of the filling valve. Most of the sheeda tairre waalas just installs the tire on rim without paying any attention to that small patch of paint and the problems starts from day 1 on new tires This is done to keep the customer coming again and again and to rip him off of his hard eard money . It is also done to sale more leaded weight to customer at higher rate . I have seen many famous balancers using weights on outside of alloy rims. Or putting poor quality sticker weights which just go flying in wet weather. Sent from my SM-A710F using Tapatalk The rotational alignment with the red (or yellow) dot is only to reduce the total amount of weight needed to balance an assembly. Sometimes, for proper roadforce balancing, this mark may need to be shifted 90, 180 or 270 degrees to achieve a smooth ride. Further, some tires do not have this mark at all. Clip on weights can be used on alloys, providing they are the correct profile, for example many Japanese rims take the FN contour. Adhesive weights work well, but only if they are applied after cleaning the wheels very well, and applying them with clean hands. If done properly, adhesive weights will stay put permanently.

column1: Hello, I would recommend you to go for the Carrozzeria TS-C1710a components as they are available for a lower price of 20,000 DB drive euphoria e6 SPL components. Both options are available in a used condition. Since you are from Karachi, it would be convenient for you to purchase these components.  -  - For your Nissan Cedric Station wagon, I suggest the following setup: -  - Head Unit: Kenwood KDC BT600u - Amplifier: Kenwood KAC HQR8400 - Rear stage: JVC 6x9 five-way coaxial speakers -  - For the front stage, the Carrozzeria TS-C1710a components would be a suitable choice. However, if you are looking for a subwoofer, I recommend the Pioneer TS W307 D4. It will complement the overall sound system. -  - If you have any other suggestions within your budget, that would also be valuable. You mentioned that you wish to have a beginner SQ (sound quality) setup, considering your limited budget.
column2: I really hope you didn't get these in the price bracket that you are being told and that too if you are planning a sq setup.

column1: Hello, I would recommend you to go for the Carrozzeria TS-C1710a components as they are available for a lower price of 20,000 DB drive euphoria e6 SPL components. Both options are available in a used condition. Since you are from Karachi, it would be convenient for you to purchase these components.  -  - For your Nissan Cedric Station wagon, I suggest the following setup: -  - Head Unit: Kenwood KDC BT600u - Amplifier: Kenwood KAC HQR8400 - Rear stage: JVC 6x9 five-way coaxial speakers -  - For the front stage, the Carrozzeria TS-C1710a components would be a suitable choice. However, if you are looking for a subwoofer, I recommend the Pioneer TS W307 D4. It will complement the overall sound system. -  - If you have any other suggestions within your budget, that would also be valuable. You mentioned that you wish to have a beginner SQ (sound quality) setup, considering your limited budget.
column2: You have a good headunit and amplification. Kenwoods usually have a warm signature tone compared to the likes of Sony and Pioneer amplifiers. If you are aiming for a SQ setup (be it a beginner setup), my suggestion would be to ditch these components. Instead, you can easily get yourself some infinity referance or jlb gto components. If you can spend between 30-35k, I'd suggest you get the Helix F62C (their mid tier 2 way components). Haroon Radio in Karachi stocks all three of these components As for the sub, ditch it. The 307 was a great sub back in the day (hell I was running 4 of them for a short period of time) but it's not a sq or even a sql sub. Get a jbl cs1214 or the more similarly matched jbl club 1214 or infinity reference 12 sub. Put them in a 0.75-1 cu-ft sealed enclosure and fill it with polyfill. I'd ditch the rear speakers. SQ setups are usually front stage focused. If you still want your rear fill, run the rear speakers directly from your headunit. The 4 channel amp is good for your front stage components and sub

column2: The dB drive? I'd still suggest you return them. They are too bright. Great for spl setups but nothing near what you'd want for a sq setup Run the rear fill from the pre direct. You want the full potential of the amp to power the front stage and the sub. If you ever want to go multiple amp setup, get a mono and you can run the sub from there I'd suggest you also do the work once and properly. Also look into sound deadening. That's a great way to isolate metal resonance inside the cabin

column1: Hello Friends, I was looking for some body who has successfully connected the Multimedia Controls (Steering Wheels) to the Factory fitted OEM Navigation system in Honda CiviC. I want to know the connections. Following are the pictures for reference.
column2: "It is quite simple. I have connected it in my Civic too. It is not the original equipment manufacturer (OEM) navigation, but the process is similar. I had it installed by a place called ""Disco"" in Blue Area. Additionally, if you wish to do it yourself, you can refer to Zunny Bhai's thread on the same topic."

column1: Hello Friends, I was looking for some body who has successfully connected the Multimedia Controls (Steering Wheels) to the Factory fitted OEM Navigation system in Honda CiviC. I want to know the connections. Following are the pictures for reference.
column2: Spano;4398803: For your reference, I am Electrical Engineer and have installed Cruise Control/Multimedia Buttons in around 7 to 8 CIVIC and two AXIO in Factory fitted 6 CD Changer as well as in PIONEER Head Units. When you go into the details there are many things which you can't see from far. Engineer Sb. You should be telling us about the procedure then. Hats off to @zunny bhai who has nothing to do with electronics but did a fabulous DIY! These head units have got proper dedicated connections for these multimedia buttons. All you have to do is connect the right wire from the clock-spring to the right pin on the head unit. There are people who have connected these buttons to the units that don't have dedicated pins by playing with the resistance every button gives. Anyways, contact Zammurd @ 0300 5277137 in Blue Area. He will take 1500 - 2000 PKR and will do it for you. P.S. I am also an Electrical Engineer with Masters in Telecommunication. Therefore, I said it's no rocket science.

column2: "Sure, I can assist you in troubleshooting and making the ""Eclipse AVN5504D"" functional. If it is not operating properly, there could be several reasons for the issue. Let's go through some troubleshooting steps: -  - 1. Check the power supply: Ensure that the device has a proper power connection and that the power source is functioning correctly. Verify that all cables are securely connected. -  - 2. Reset the device: Try performing a reset on the Eclipse AVN5504D. Look for a reset button or an option in the menu settings. Refer to the user manual for specific instructions on how to reset the device. -  - 3. Check the fuse: If the device is not receiving power, check if the fuse in the wiring harness is blown. Replace it if necessary. -  - 4. Update the firmware: Check if there are any available firmware updates for the Eclipse AVN5504D. Visit the manufacturer's website and download the latest firmware version. Follow the instructions provided to update the firmware. -  - 5. Check the display and controls: Ensure that the display is working correctly and that all buttons and controls are responding. If not, there may be an issue with the internal components or the wiring harness. It may require professional repair or replacement. -  - 6. Seek professional assistance: If the above steps do not resolve the problem, it is recommended to contact the manufacturer's customer support or consult a professional technician who specializes in car audio systems. -  - Remember to refer to the user manual for specific instructions related to your model of the Eclipse AVN5504D."

column1: Assalam o alaikum (Peace be upon you), have a nice day. I have a 86 Corolla with a 1NZFE automatic engine for the past 3 years. I got the AC fully serviced yesterday, including changing the condenser and recharging it with Genetron gas. However, the AC keeps tripping repeatedly.
column2: Wa Alaikum Assalam. If you have received a service from someone, please go back to them. It's possible that they have installed a local (desi) thermostat.

column1: Assalam o alaikum (Peace be upon you), have a nice day. I have a 86 Corolla with a 1NZFE automatic engine for the past 3 years. I got the AC fully serviced yesterday, including changing the condenser and recharging it with Genetron gas. However, the AC keeps tripping repeatedly.
column2: Yes. Best is to get amplifier as well. And wire everything according to 1nzfe.

column1: Assalam o alaikum (Peace be upon you), have a nice day. I have a 86 Corolla with a 1NZFE automatic engine for the past 3 years. I got the AC fully serviced yesterday, including changing the condenser and recharging it with Genetron gas. However, the AC keeps tripping repeatedly.
column2: Feel free to ask. Ac amplifier controls the all operations of ac. It's like a separate unit with which thermostat and other sensors are connected. Further it communicates with engine ecu.

column1: Assalam o alaikum (Peace be upon you), have a nice day. I have a 86 Corolla with a 1NZFE automatic engine for the past 3 years. I got the AC fully serviced yesterday, including changing the condenser and recharging it with Genetron gas. However, the AC keeps tripping repeatedly.
column2: Definitely...this issue usually occurs in desi thermostats...you should get an AC amplifier (referred to as an AC kit locally)...ensure it is correctly wired and you'll be good to go.

column1: Hello everyone... I have reserved a Fortuner Legender 2022 in January 2022 and made a partial payment of 3 million. Now I need to make the full payment. The price of the Legender on the website is 10,842,000, but Toyota Frontier is requesting 11,095,000, which is an additional 254,000. Can someone explain this difference? Regards.
column2: The price mentioned on the web is the Ex-Factory price, which is without the Advance Tax and the Freight Charges. If you add the With Holding Tax for Filer, which is, Rs. 200,000/- and the remaining amount is the Freight charges. That would justify the amount that Toyota Frontier is asking for. I hope it helps.

column1: Hello everyone... I have reserved a Fortuner Legender 2022 in January 2022 and made a partial payment of 3 million. Now I need to make the full payment. column2: This is natural behaviour when ECU goest to close loop after 60c temp and engines rpm set down by IAC , at close loop idle should be around 700 to 800 in N shift , you can adjust more or lest Rpm by adjusting IAC value

column1: I have bought a Cultus recently and found its radiator fan is direct. Now i am wondering wheather to keep it as it is or make it indirect. ? Your openion plz.
column2: if you run your fan directly all the time, you will affect alternator life fan motor life you will warp the cheap plastic fan blade burn the fan relay and sometimes wiring in less than a year Kill your engine by running dead cold (if you or your mechanic lost the thermostat valve too) heres a test you can do, when going 40 km/h stick your hand out the window and check for air turbulence and how far it shoves your arm backwards - now stop and check the cooling fan air push.. you'll get the idea that you are doing no good running it direct. Most good european cars come equipped with a resistor to reduce maximum radiator fan speed to 90% when running on A/C in hot climates to preserve motor life. If your cooling system is good and clean, and the gauge remains ok, you will not need to fiddle with the fan circuit ever. Even Suzuki IFXs cool themselves easily on automatic fan with a thermostat valve in place

column1: I have bought a Cultus recently and found its radiator fan is direct. Now i am wondering wheather to keep it as it is or make it indirect. ? Your openion plz.
column2: running a cold engine with reduce its life to 20% - a cold engine has greater clearances and also has a lot of fuel going into it compared to a hot engine. - the lots of fuel results in blackening of the oil due to excess fuel burning washing away fuel from the cylinder walls etc etc. mechanics who dont know how to fix cars or want you to visit them every month take out the T stat, hot wire the fan and do all other stupid stuff to kill your car shortly

column1: I have bought a Cultus recently and found its radiator fan is direct. Now i am wondering wheather to keep it as it is or make it indirect. ? Your openion plz.

column2: "Brother, there is no authorized dealer of Bridgestone. It is sold in the open market, and anyone can import containers from Thailand or Indonesia. The authorized dealer for Yokohama in Lahore is ""Sheikh Brothers,"" and for Michelin, it is ""Aness Tyres."" However, they now mainly deal in truck tires. The authorized dealers for Yokohama, Michelin, Federal, Birla are now ""Mushtaq"" in Peshawar. Mushtaq also sells Bridgestone, Hankook, Goodyear, BF Goodrich, GT tires. Do you have the contact number for Mushtaq and his office address?"

column1: Hello! I remember someone mentioning an authorised Bridgestone dealer in Lahore. However, I searched the internet and couldn't find any information about it. Could you please let me know if there are any authorised tire dealers in Lahore, Islamabad, or Rawalpindi? I am interested in dealers for brands like Bridgestone, Pirelli, Michelin, Yokohama, Toyo, or Dunlop. Thank you, HG.
column2: "Brother, there is no authorized dealer for Bridgestone. It is sold in the open market, and anyone can bring 2 or 1 container from Thailand or Indonesia. The authorized dealer for Yokohama in Lahore is ""Sheikh Brothers"", and for Michelin, it is ""Aness Tyres"" in Lahore. However, now they both only deal with truck tyres. The authorized dealers for Yokohama, Michelin, Federal, and Birla are now ""Mushtaq"" in Peshawar. He also sells Bridgestone, Hankook, Goodyear, BF Goodrich, and GT tyres."

column1: If I change the body of a 1984 Toyota Crown to a 1997 model, what would be the custom and excise duties? Additionally, what is the legal procedure for this modification?
column2: Is Body Change Legal? General Car Discussion I have talked to quite few people all say yes its legal. One of my friends was travelling from Quetta to Karachi in his Crown (body change) and was stopped by Quetta Custom. They told him to Pay Rs. 25000 in Quetta then only its legal. My Friend checked with Collector of Custom Karachi, he told him it’s legal but if you want to drive in Quetta you have to pay them Rs 25000 to 80000 as Duty/fees. I personally have not seen any document saying that it’s legal. I myself was stopped in Sukkur, t… Go through this thread and its child threads... Hope you will get your answer...

column1: I am new to cars i want to buy prius 2007 model but some of my frnds told me that there are some big issues with abs and battery in this model Kindly guide me please
column2: Yes when hybrid gets older their batteries wears out.Here people replace the cells in battery but it's not proper way and issue won't get resolved.Better option is to get brand new battery from dealership but it costs alot of money to replace.I,d say look for another non-hybrid car in ur budget.

column1: Got this player removed from prius 2012 ,and planned to install it in Honda city 2012. But the f****** mechanic stole this cable during dismantling from prius. Later told me that I gave u everything back. Anyways From one side its usb and aux and from other side its kinda different connector. Now I cannot even install it in my honda nor in prius. Please confirm me the availability of this special type cable and its price.
column2: Lesson to be learned Asim bhai: Never leave the audio guys on their own when they are handling such things. Its happened to me long before when I started my audio fanaticism.... The guy blew a hole in my sub while installing it with a screw driver. Its best to just stand on their heads. They always tell u kai "sir go inside and relax we will do this, np" but my answer is always the same. I stick around until they are done with the work. About the cable, this is what you are looking for. It is expensive but there are cheaper alternatives to it and I'm sure you can find it in Islamabad. Ask DiscoMusic and SoundValley, they can arrange it as long as you show them this picture. Amazon.com: Pioneer Avic USB iPod adapter Cable CDP1425, CDP-1425, CDP-1357, CDP1357: Computers & Accessories325

column2: Asim510;4796916: I need this product. It is a 3.5mm AUX input cable that can connect to a Pioneer headunit with an IP Bus AUX input adapter cable. You can find it in the Consumer Electronics section on Aliexpress.com. It is a CD changer aux audio cable specifically designed for Pioneer CD players and compatible with iPod and iPhone. You can find it in the Cables, Adapters & Sockets category under Automobiles & Motorcycles. Another option is an AV cable adaptor for Pioneer car stereo that has iPod and AUX inputs. You can find it in the Consumer Electronics section on Aliexpress.com. Here is the link to the product I found: [link]. It is the closest one I could find. Another option is this CD-IU201N App Radio Mode USB 30-pin Interface Cable for Pioneer iPod and iPhone 4/4S: [link].

column1: Looking for a reliable place for repair of automatic transmission of 80series LC in Karachi.
column2: Repairing transmissions is not a commonly used term in Pakistan. However, there is a service called SWAPs that offers financial assistance and chances to win jackpots. Qaiser from Kaizr Cruiser specializes in 4x4 vehicles and can provide assistance. You can contact him at 0313 160 6924. @consigliori may have more information since he has met him in the past. Please make sure to call between 10 am to 7 pm and schedule an appointment before visiting as the location is quite far in the Korangi Industrial area, near the national refinery. You can find more details at https://kaizrcruiser.com/13. @ausaf_khan @hash4u

column1: Looking for a reliable place for repair of automatic transmission of 80series LC in Karachi.
column2: Another option is Mr. Usman in FB Area Block 9. His phone number is 0300 827 2720.

column2: Dear Managing an Auto gear box with all the extras needed for integrating it with the current engine might cost the same as getting a complete set with engine and gear box. besides your ride will likely improve along with G15 series engine since they have much better torque to manage auto box. Further to that considering superior consumption figures for G15 engines your milage issue might get addressed with auto box as well.

column2: 1-Autobox with Axles, mount wiring and ECU 2-Gear lever console complete with control cables. 3-Pedal set 4-Speedometer 5-Ignition switch if u want that key wont come out unless u shift in park. 6-radiator, as for autobox u need radiator with cooling lines for auto txn. as suggested above, its better to do a nosecut swap from a donor car, it will be hassel free and cost effective to, as u wont be needing to hunt for each and every part separately, and might get benefit of installing ABS unit as well as

What about maintenance? How much does the setup cost and are the parts readily available? Additionally, I'm also looking for a suspension upgrade for my 2004 SE Saloon.
column2: tilsim;3266548: agreed.. 2zzge is sufficient if you are stepping up from a 3zzfe.. if more, add a trd bolt on super charger.. as said above by ser it'll chern out 240 horses.. somehow.. and it'll still be a daily driver.. if you wanna go reallllll big, then as said by wasay get a 3sgte (3rd or 4th generation) along with its compatible turbo.. engine itself is less powerful than a 2zzge, but when the turbo is added, you can go quite higher.. its a low compression engine that supports upto 6-7psi.. maybe even more if internals are custom built accordingly.. but the shape of 2003-8 corolla would require quite some suspension and brake upgrade, since the stock 1.3 litre doesn't stop in time, let alone a custom built.. Shahjee 3sgte is turbocharged from factory. Yea 3sge is N/A but it has better compression

column1: Hi All Hope you all are doing well, One of my close friend has a corolla saloon model 1.6 auto transmission, There is an issue with the transmission of this car, The car sometimes never move from its position when we try to accelerate it in 'D' gear, the engine sound increases but it never moves, we have to shift it to 'D1' or 'D2' then move back to 'D', this issues come sometimes not regularly, rest of the car is fine in all aspects, we never face any issue once it starts to accelerate. Any idea what may be the possible issue. One of the mechanic said its transmission needs to be replaced.:'( Your opinions are most welcome. ( Car is 2003 Corolla SE Saloon 1.6 )

column2: haali;5241100: Thanks @Xulfiqar, Do you recommend any place in Karachi that rebuilds\\repair it, its getting worse now What will be the estimated cost? nopes. I used to rebuild them in Pakistan with new parts which I used to get from usa, dubai or thailand. All others just installed scrap items and prayed it worked. The new rebuild I used to do consisted of new seals new moulded pistons new clutches new steels new bands refreshed valve body reconditioned torque converter. The gearboxes would be great and behaved like new units. Toyota showrooms in Karachi could never supply me with new parts for the auto gearbox even when provided with part numbers as they were more busy with small parchoon items like plugs and oil filters.

column1: Hello Guys, I am doing a search on CAN BUS Protocol, long story short, I am able to receive CAN Packets from my car although we usually get packets on OBD pin6 (CAN-H) and pin14 (CAN-L) but I'm receiving CAN-L packets on pin11 anyway that's not an issue the issue is I am not able to transmit packets. So I need direct access to CAN-H and CAN-L wires where i can find these wires BTW my car is Daihatsu Mira Model 2015
column2: what are you trying to achieve with sending a packet? - do you have all the PID ping and start information and are wanting to emulate something thats not on the vehicle? and you are getting traffic on pin 11? - thats a bit odd, is it the same traffic as the CAN-L?

column1: Hello Guys, I am doing a search on CAN BUS Protocol, long story short, I am able to receive CAN Packets from my car although we usually get packets on OBD pin6 (CAN-H) and pin14 (CAN-L) but I'm receiving CAN-L packets on pin11 anyway that's not an issue the issue is I am not able to transmit packets. So I need direct access to CAN-H and CAN-L wires where i can find these wires BTW my car is Daihatsu Mira Model 2015
column2: You dont have a gateway per se in your car, the can lines on the dlc are taps not terminus. Find the wiring diagram of your car, it will also show the can flow chart, or you can start digging it yourself and see which module has can wiring.

column1: Hello Guys, I am doing a search on CAN BUS Protocol, long story short, I am able to receive CAN Packets from my car although we usually get packets on OBD pin6 (CAN-H) and pin14 (CAN-L) but I'm receiving CAN-L packets on pin11 anyway that's not an issue the issue is I am not able to transmit packets. So I need direct access to CAN-H and CAN-L wires where i can find these wires BTW my car is Daihatsu Mira Model 2015
column2: What are you trying to achieve? Adding new modules/functions to the vehicle?

column1: Hello Guys, I am doing a search on CAN BUS Protocol, long story short, I am able to receive CAN Packets from my car although we usually get packets on OBD pin6 (CAN-H) and pin14 (CAN-L) but I'm receiving CAN-L packets on pin11 anyway that's not an issue the issue is I am not able to transmit packets. So I need direct access to CAN-H and CAN-L wires where i can find these wires BTW my car is Daihatsu Mira Model 2015
column2: if you are trying to showcase vulnerabilities in vehicles and working on CAN-BUS then you are on the wrong avenue, because the bus traffic only starts with awake systems. Once the car shuts down the systems go to sleep after a few minutes. And the only way to awaken them is by providing the security hash that is in the key itself which is RF. You are putting the cart before the horse here.

column1: Hello Guys, I am doing a search on CAN BUS Protocol, long story short, I am able to receive CAN Packets from my car although we usually get packets on OBD pin6 (CAN-H) and pin14 (CAN-L) but I'm receiving CAN-L packets on pin11 anyway that's not an issue the issue is I am not able to transmit packets. So I need direct access to CAN-H and CAN-L wires where i can find these wires BTW my car is Daihatsu Mira Model 2015
column2: So basically you are doing what we mechanics do everyday with our 2 way scan tools that have a bluetooth dongle connected to the DLC3 under the steering. To send a specific message you need to know the exact request header and the command sequence at the correct speed. This information is not available from the manufacturer, you can however try to decipher it by sniffing the data being exchanged on a scan tool like techstream.

column1: Hello Guys, I am doing a search on CAN BUS Protocol, long story short, I am able to receive CAN Packets from my car although we usually get packets on OBD pin6 (CAN-H) and pin14 (CAN-L) but I'm receiving CAN-L packets on pin11 anyway that's not an issue the issue is I am not able to transmit packets. So I need direct access to CAN-H and CAN-L wires where i can find these wires BTW my car is Daihatsu Mira Model 2015
column2: From obd2 port. You need to filter the data from each module then send headers before sending any pid. What you are receiving right now is the communication between different modules.

column1: Hello Guys, I am doing a search on CAN BUS Protocol, long story short, I am able to receive CAN Packets from my car although we usually get packets on OBD pin6 (CAN-H) and pin14 (CAN-L) but I'm receiving CAN-L packets on pin11 anyway that's not an issue the issue is I am not able to transmit packets. So I need direct access to CAN-H and CAN-L wires where i can find these wires BTW my car is Daihatsu Mira Model 2015
column2: Sending packets doesn't work like that. Ecu will discard it. You have to put ecu in listening mode using initialization bytes then it will list to your demand and reply. Not easy though. Follow sir Xulfiqar instructions. Between can h and can l are inverted images of same sequence. Which device you are using?

column1: Installing spark plugs Torque is one of the most critical aspects of spark plug installation. Torque directly affects the spark plugs' ability to transfer heat out of the combustion chamber. A spark plug that is under-torqued will not be fully seated on the cylinder head, hence heat transfer will be slowed. This will tend to elevate combustion chamber temperatures to unsafe levels, and pre-ignition and detonation will usually follow. Serious engine damage is not far behind. An over-torqued spark plug can suffer from severe stress to the Metal Shell which in turn can distort the spark plug's inner gas seals or even cause a hairline fracture to the spark plug's insulator...in either case, heat transfer can again be slowed and the above mentioned conditions can occur. The spark plug holes must always be cleaned prior to installation, otherwise you may be torquing against dirt or debris and the spark plug may actually end up under-torqued, even though your torque wrench says otherwise. Of course, you should only install spark plugs in a cool engine, because metal expands when its hot and installation may prove difficult. Gapping Since the gap size has a direct affect on the spark plug's tip temperature and on the voltage necessary to ionize (light) the air/fuel mixture, careful attention is required. While it is a popular misconception that plugs are pre-gapped from the factory, the fact remains that the gap must be adjusted for the vehicle that the spark plug is intended for. Those with modified engines must remember that a modified engine with higher compression or forced induction will typically require a smaller gap settings (to ensure ignitability in these denser air/fuel mixtures). As a rule, the more power you are making, the smaller the gap you will need. A spark plug's voltage requirement is directly proportionate to the gap size. The larger the gap, the more voltage is needed to bridge the gap. Most experienced tuners know that opening gaps up to present a larger spark to the air/fuel mixture maximizes burn efficiency. It is for this reason that most racers add high power ignition systems. The added power allows them to open the gap yet still provide a strong spark. With this mind, many think the larger the gap the better. In fact, some aftermarket ignition systems boast that their systems can tolerate gaps that are extreme. Be wary of such claims. In most cases, the largest gap you can run may still be smaller than you think. Indexing This is for racers only !! Indexing refers to a process whereby auxiliary washers of varying thickness are placed under the spark plug's shoulder so that when the spark plug is tightened, the gap will point in the desired direction. However, without running an engine on a dyno, it is impossible to gauge which type of indexing works best in your engine. While most engines like the spark plug's gap open to the intake valve, there are still other combinations that make more power with the gap pointed toward the exhaust valve. In any case, engines with indexed spark plugs will typically make only a few more horsepower, typically less than 1% of total engine output. For a 500hp engine, you'd be lucky to get 5hp. While there are exceptions, the bottom line is that without a dyno, gauging success will be difficult. Heat Range selection Let's make this really simple: when you need your engine to run a little cooler, run a colder plug. When you need your engine to run a little hotter, run a hotter spark plug. However, FAIRSALE AUTOS strongly cautions people that going to a hotter spark plug can sometimes mask a serious symptom of another problem that can lead to engine damage. Be very careful with heat ranges. Seek professional guidance if you are unsure. With modified engines (those engines that have increased their compression) more heat is a by-product of the added power that normally comes with increased compression. In short, select one heat range colder for every 75-100 hp you add, or when you significantly raise compression. Also remember to retard the timing a little and to increase fuel enrichment and octane. These tips are critical when adding forced induction (turbos, superchargers or nitrous kits), and failure to address ALL of these areas will virtually guarantee engine damage. An engine that has poor oil control can sometimes mask the symptom temporarily by running a slightly hotter spark plug. While this is a "Band-Aid" approach, it is one of the only examples of when and why one would select a hotter spark plug. Using "racing" spark plugs Be cautious! In reality, most "racing" spark plugs are just colder heat ranges of the street versions of the spark plug. They don't provide any more voltage to the spark plug tip! Their internal construction is no different than most standard spark plugs. There are some exceptions, though. Extremely high compression cars or those running exotic fuels will have different spark plug requirements and hence FAIRSALE AUTOS deals in spark plugs that are well-suited for these requirements. They are classified as "specialized spark plugs for racing applications". Some are built with precious metal alloy tips for greater durability and the ability to fire in denser or leaner air/fuel mixtures. However, installing the same spark plugs Kenny Bernstein uses in his 300+ mph Top Fuel car (running Nitromethane at a 2:1 air/fuel ratio and over 20:1 dynamic compression) in your basically stock Honda Civic (running 15:1 a/f ratios with roughly 9.5:1 compression) will do nothing for you! In fact, since Kenny's plugs are fully 4 heat ranges colder, they'd foul out in your Honda in just a few minutes. FAIRSALE AUTOS as a fair and ethical parts supplier tries to stay clear of saying that a racing spark plug (or ANY spark plug) will give you large gains in horsepower. While certain spark plugs are better suited to certain applications (and we're happy to counsel you in the right direction) we try to tell people that are looking to "screw in" some cheap horsepower that, in most cases, spark plugs are not the answer. To be blunt, when experienced tuners build race motors, they select their spark plugs for different reasons: to remove heat more efficiently, provide sufficient spark to completely light all the air/fuel mixture, to survive the added stresses placed upon a high performance engine's spark plugs, and to achieve optimum piston-to-plug clearance. Some of these "specialized racing plugs" are made with precious metal alloy center/ground electrodes or fine wire tips or retracted-nose insulators. Again, these features do not necessarily mean that the spark plug will allow the engine to make more power, but these features are what allow the spark plug to survive in these tortuous conditions. Most racers know screwing in a new set of spark plugs will not magically "unlock" hidden horsepower. Using high power ignition systems Many of the more popular aftermarket ignition systems are of the capacitive discharge type. They store voltage, or accumulate it, until a point at which a trigger signal allows release of this more powerful spark. Companies like Mallory, MSD, Crane and Accel, to name a few, offer such systems. They affect spark plugs in that they allow the gaps to be opened up to take advantage of the increased capacity. The theory is that the larger and the more intense the spark you are able to present to the air/fuel mixture, the more likely you will be to burn more fuel, and hence the more power you will make. We encourage the use of such systems, but only on modified or older non-computer controlled vehicles. In reality, computer controlled vehicles do such a good job of lighting off the air/fuel mixture (as evidenced by the ultra-low emissions), added ignition capacity would do little to burn more fuel since the stock configuration is doing such a good job. Older non-computer controlled vehicles or those that have been modified with higher compression or boosted (nitrous, turbo, supercharged) engines can certainly take advantage of a more powerful ignition system. =========================================================
column2: "ahsanonline: Since I am unable to create a new forum thread, I have a question for the experts regarding spark plugs. Which Denso spark plugs should I use for my 1995 Corolla XE with a 1.3 carburetor, 12-valve engine? Some mechanics are suggesting the ""lambi tip walay plugs,"" while others recommend the ""choti tip walay plugs."" I am confused about which ones to choose. Can you please explain the difference between them? Also, for your Corolla XE, it is recommended to use NGK platinums BPR5EGP as they will provide reasonable fuel economy. The ""lambi tip wala"" plugs are designed for carburetor-equipped vehicles like yours. Please check your private messages for more information."

column1: Installing spark plugs Torque is one of the most critical aspects of spark plug installation. Torque directly affects the spark plugs' ability to transfer heat out of the combustion chamber. A spark plug that is under-torqued will not be fully seated on the cylinder head, hence heat transfer will be slowed. This will tend to elevate combustion chamber temperatures to unsafe levels, and pre-ignition and detonation will usually follow. Serious engine damage is not far behind. An over-torqued spark plug can suffer from severe stress to the Metal Shell which in turn can distort the spark plug's inner gas seals or even cause a hairline fracture to the spark plug's insulator...in either case, heat transfer can again be slowed and the above mentioned conditions can occur. The spark plug holes must always be cleaned prior to installation, otherwise you may be torquing against dirt or debris and the spark plug may actually end up under-torqued, even though your torque wrench says otherwise. Of course, you should only install spark plugs in a cool engine, because metal expands when its hot and installation may prove difficult. Gapping Since the gap size has a direct affect on the spark plug's tip temperature and on the voltage necessary to ionize (light) the air/fuel mixture, careful attention is required. While it is a popular misconception that plugs are pre-gapped from the factory, the fact remains that the gap must be adjusted for the vehicle that the spark plug is intended for. Those with modified engines must remember that a modified engine with higher compression or forced induction will typically require a smaller gap settings (to ensure ignitability in these denser air/fuel mixtures). As a rule, the more power you are making, the smaller the gap you will need. A spark plug's voltage requirement is directly proportionate to the gap size. The larger the gap, the more voltage is needed to bridge the gap. Most experienced tuners know that opening gaps up to present a larger spark to the air/fuel mixture maximizes burn efficiency. It is for this reason that most racers add high power ignition systems. The added power allows them to open the gap yet still provide a strong spark. In most cases, the largest gap you can run may still be smaller than you think. Indexing This is for racers only !! While this is a "Band-Aid" approach, it is one of the only examples of when and why one would select a hotter spark plug. Using "racing" spark plugs Be cautious! In reality, most "racing" spark plugs are just colder heat ranges of the street versions of the spark plug. They don't provide any more voltage to the spark plug tip! Their internal construction is no different than most standard spark plugs. There are some exceptions, though. Extremely high compression cars or those running exotic fuels will have different spark plug requirements and hence FAIRSALE AUTOS deals in spark plugs that are well-suited for these requirements. They are classified as "specialized spark plugs for racing applications". Some are built with precious metal alloy tips for greater durability and the ability to fire in denser or leaner air/fuel mixtures. However, installing the same spark plugs Kenny Bernstein uses in his 300+ mph Top Fuel car (running Nitromethane at a 2:1 air/fuel ratio and over 20:1 dynamic compression) in your basically stock Honda Civic (running 15:1 a/f ratios with roughly 9.5:1 compression) will do nothing for you! In fact, since Kenny's plugs are fully 4 heat ranges colder, they'd foul out in your Honda in just a few minutes. FAIRSALE AUTOS as a fair and ethical parts supplier tries to stay clear of saying that a racing spark plug (or ANY spark plug) will give you large gains in horsepower. While certain spark plugs are better suited to certain applications (and we're happy to counsel you in the right direction) we try to tell people that are looking to "screw in" some cheap horsepower that, in most cases, spark plugs are not the answer. To be blunt, when experienced tuners build race motors, they select their spark plugs for different reasons: to remove heat more efficiently, provide sufficient spark to completely light all the air/fuel mixture, to survive the added stresses placed upon a high performance engine's spark plugs, and to achieve optimum piston-to-plug clearance. Some of these "specialized racing plugs" are made with precious metal alloy center/ground electrodes or fine wire tips or retracted-nose insulators. Again, these features do not necessarily mean that the spark plug will allow the engine to make more power, but these features are what allow the spark plug to survive in these tortuous conditions. Most racers know screwing in a new set of spark plugs will not magically "unlock" hidden horsepower. Using high power ignition systems Many of the more popular aftermarket ignition systems are of the capacitive discharge type. They store voltage, or accumulate it, until a point at which a trigger signal allows release of this more powerful spark. Companies like Mallory, MSD, Crane and Accel, to name a few, offer such systems. They affect spark plugs in that they allow the gaps to be opened up to take advantage of the increased capacity. The theory is that the larger and the more intense the spark you are able to present to the air/fuel mixture, the more likely you will be to burn more fuel, and hence the more power you will make. We encourage the use of such systems, but only on modified or older non-computer controlled vehicles. In reality, computer controlled vehicles do such a good job of lighting off the air/fuel mixture (as evidenced by the ultra-low emissions), added ignition capacity would do little to burn more fuel since the stock configuration is doing such a good job. Older non-computer controlled vehicles or those that have been modified with higher compression or boosted (nitrous, turbo, supercharged) engines can certainly take advantage of a more powerful ignition system. =========================================================

I dont know if this is the correct price but I dont get much time out of office for such things so I paid. I will install those in my new Alto soon and lets hope I get some better result on CNG :).

column1: Installing spark plugs Torque is one of the most critical aspects of spark plug installation. Torque directly affects the spark plugs' ability to transfer heat out of the combustion chamber. A spark plug that is under-torqued will not be fully seated on the cylinder head, hence heat transfer will be slowed. This will tend to elevate combustion chamber temperatures to unsafe levels, and pre-ignition and detonation will usually follow. Serious engine damage is not far behind. An over-torqued spark plug can suffer from severe stress to the Metal Shell which in turn can distort the spark plug's inner gas seals or even cause a hairline fracture to the spark plug's insulator...in either case, heat transfer can again be slowed and the above mentioned conditions can occur. The spark plug holes must always be cleaned prior to installation, otherwise you may be torquing against dirt or debris and the spark plug may actually end up under-torqued, even though your torque wrench says otherwise. Of course, you should only install spark plugs in a cool engine, because metal expands when its hot and installation may prove difficult. Gapping Since the gap size has a direct affect on the spark plug's tip temperature and on the voltage necessary to ionize (light) the air/fuel mixture, careful attention is required. While it is a popular misconception that plugs are pre-gapped from the factory, the fact remains that the gap must be adjusted for the vehicle that the spark plug is intended for. Those with modified engines must remember that a modified engine with higher compression or forced induction will typically require a smaller gap settings (to ensure ignitability in these denser air/fuel mixtures). As a rule, the more power you are making, the smaller the gap you will need. A spark plug's voltage requirement is directly proportionate to the gap size. The larger the gap, the more voltage is needed to bridge the gap. Most experienced tuners know that opening gaps up to present a larger spark to the air/fuel mixture maximizes burn efficiency. It is for this reason that most racers add high power ignition systems. The added power allows them to open the gap yet still provide a strong spark. With this mind, many think the larger the gap the better. In fact, some aftermarket ignition systems boast that their systems can tolerate gaps that are extreme. Be wary of such claims. In most cases, the largest gap you can run may still be smaller than you think. Indexing This is for racers only !! Indexing refers to a process whereby auxiliary washers of varying thickness are placed under the spark plug's shoulder so that when the spark plug is tightened, the gap will point in the desired direction. However, without running an engine on a dyno, it is impossible to gauge which type of indexing works best in your engine. While most engines like the spark plug's gap open to the intake valve, there are still other combinations that make more power with the gap pointed toward the exhaust valve. In any case, engines with indexed spark plugs will typically make only a few more horsepower, typically less than 1% of total engine output. For a 500hp engine, you'd be lucky to get 5hp. While there are exceptions, the bottom line is that without a dyno, gauging success will be difficult. Heat Range selection Let's make this really simple: when you need your engine to run a little cooler, run a colder plug. When you need your engine to run a little hotter, run a hotter spark plug. However, FAIRSALE AUTOS strongly cautions people that going to a hotter spark plug can sometimes mask a serious symptom of another problem that can lead to engine damage. Be very careful with heat ranges. Seek professional guidance if you are unsure. With modified engines (those engines that have increased their compression) more heat is a by-product of the added power that normally comes with increased compression. In short, select one heat range colder for every 75-100 hp you add, or when you significantly raise compression. Also remember to retard the timing a little and to increase fuel enrichment and octane. These tips are critical when adding forced induction (turbos, superchargers or nitrous kits), and failure to address ALL of these areas will virtually guarantee engine damage. An engine that has poor oil control can sometimes mask the symptom temporarily by running a slightly hotter spark plug. While this is a "Band-Aid" approach, it is one of the only examples of when and why one would select a hotter spark plug. Using "racing" spark plugs Be cautious! In reality, most "racing" spark plugs are just colder heat ranges of the street versions of the spark plug. They don't provide any more voltage to the spark plug tip! Their internal construction is no different than most standard spark plugs. There are some exceptions, though. Extremely high compression cars or those running exotic fuels will have different spark plug requirements and hence FAIRSALE AUTOS deals in spark plugs that are well-suited for these requirements. They are classified as "specialized spark plugs for racing applications". Some are built with precious metal alloy tips for greater durability and the ability to fire in denser or leaner air/fuel mixtures. However, installing the same spark plugs Kenny Bernstein uses in his 300+ mph Top Fuel car (running Nitromethane at a 2:1 air/fuel ratio and over 20:1 dynamic compression) in your basically stock Honda Civic (running 15:1 a/f ratios with roughly 9.5:1 compression) will do nothing for you! In fact, since Kenny's plugs are fully 4 heat ranges colder, they'd foul out in your Honda in just a few minutes. FAIRSALE AUTOS as a fair and ethical parts supplier tries to stay clear of saying that a racing spark plug (or ANY spark plug) will give you large gains in horsepower. While certain spark plugs are better suited to certain applications (and we're happy to counsel you in the right direction) we try to tell people that are looking to "screw in" some cheap horsepower that, in most cases, spark plugs are not the answer. To be blunt, when experienced tuners build race motors, they select their spark plugs for different reasons: to remove heat more efficiently, provide sufficient spark to completely light all the air/fuel mixture, to survive the added stresses placed upon a high performance engine's spark plugs, and to achieve optimum piston-to-plug clearance. Some of these "specialized racing plugs" are made with precious metal alloy center/ground electrodes or fine wire tips or retracted-nose insulators. Again, these features do not necessarily mean that the spark plug will allow the engine to make more power, but these features are what allow the spark plug to survive in these tortuous conditions. Most racers know screwing in a new set of spark plugs will not magically "unlock" hidden horsepower. Using high power ignition systems Many of the more popular aftermarket ignition systems are of the capacitive discharge type. They store voltage, or accumulate it, until a point at which a trigger signal allows release of this more powerful spark. Companies like Mallory, MSD, Crane and Accel, to name a few, offer such systems. They affect spark plugs in that they allow the gaps to be opened up to take advantage of the increased capacity. The theory is that the larger and the more intense the spark you are able to present to the air/fuel mixture, the more likely you will be to burn more fuel, and hence the more power you will make. We encourage the use of such systems, but only on modified or older non-computer controlled vehicles. In reality, computer controlled vehicles do such a good job of lighting off the air/fuel mixture (as evidenced by the ultra-low emissions), added ignition capacity would do little to burn more fuel since the stock configuration is doing such a good job. Older non-computer controlled vehicles or those that have been modified with higher compression or boosted (nitrous, turbo, supercharged) engines can certainly take advantage of a more powerful ignition system. =========================================================

column2: Dear Rafay, I talked to Mr. Tariq and asked him what plugs are good for Alto. He suggested Splitfire. I am not into racing or anything like that. Infact I drive slow but I need better result on CNG as I run AC all along. Lets hope I get better result with those plugs.

column1: Ma Alto radiator filled with tap water ! I want to fill it with colant.. Please tell me the Easiest way of doing this job safely! As I am not much technical Guy!! Click here for SOLUTION79
column2: drain the radiator and measure how much came out, now open the thermostat housing to remove thermostat valve, push a blower nozzle in it and start the blower, it will push out all dirty water from the engine, measure what came out again. Write it down. Put thermostat valve back, replace drain valve on radiator, add pure coolant to the engine, half of the quantity that came out, start engine and slowly add water, keep on adding until no more would go in, do not let it overflow, coolant is poisonous. Keep the engine running till the radiator fan starts, squeeze the rubber pipes to rid of any stuck air bubbles in the system. Once the system is stablized, put the cap back on, and observe any anomaly.

column1: Ma Alto radiator filled with tap water ! I want to fill it with colant.. Please tell me the Easiest way of doing this job safely! As I am not much technical Guy!! Click here for SOLUTION79
column2: 5 gallons? The Toyota Corolla has a coolant capacity of about 6 or 6.5 liters. To make 6 liters of coolant, you would require 3 liters of concentrate. On the other hand, the Toyota Vitz has a coolant capacity of approximately 4.5 liters. Normally, 5 gallons is equivalent to 20 liters, a capacity that is commonly seen in heavy-duty trucks.

column1: Ma Alto radiator filled with tap water ! I want to fill it with colant.. Please tell me the Easiest way of doing this job safely! As I am not much technical Guy!! Click here for SOLUTION79
column2: toyota coolant isnt all that special, I prefer the caltex over it as its proven to be serviceable longer and has the best resistance to electrolysis and cheaper too. In USA I buy PEAK branded coolant (their global product) - In all cars that I used it in, it has performed flawlessly.

column1: Ma Alto radiator filled with tap water ! I want to fill it with colant.. Please tell me the Easiest way of doing this job safely! As I am not much technical Guy!! Click here for SOLUTION79
column2: running the engine dry cannot get coolant out of engine as the water pump is not a positive pump but an impeller pump - meaning it needs a full volume on intake side to work. (e.g. your home water pump for overhead tank is also impeller pump and doesnt work if the footvalve is faulty) a regular hose pipe from your garden water tap is used to flush out the remainder of dirty liquid from the engine block.

column1: Ma Alto radiator filled with tap water ! I want to fill it with colant.. Please tell me the Easiest way of doing this job safely! As I am not much technical Guy!! Click here for SOLUTION79
column2: if you will not be removing the valve (which takes 2 minutes literally on a mehran) - you will have to backflush from one of the heater pipes and empty the system from the radiator drain at the same time. Flush with that tap water for about 10 minutes after the acid has worked Once all acid is removed, use a blower or air compressor to remove any stagnant water, install the T stat valve back (buy new one if old is stuck open) then fill 100% concentrate to half the capacity of the total system and top off the rest with distilled/RO water. Fill the overflow tank with 50% mix to hot mark

column1: AoA I have honda grace 2014 DX decided to add tweeters since this car variant doesn’t have tweeters from the factory in the end I went ahead with upgrading the whole system since I had my fathers subwoofer and amp. Idk if it’s the amp or subwoofer. My amp blows the fuse whenever the subwoofer is connected but works fine only speakers are connected. I did install sound deadening foam in pillar, mirror caps, under rear seat, doors sills, front kick panels, trunk lid, rear board, and whole trunk from sides and floor made huge difference in outside sound and panel rattles. Want to change the head unit it can be a old screen just need Bluetooth, aux, subwoofer settings, crossovers, 3 pre amp rca out and steering control. Should I get a separate monoblock someone is selling Sony XM-D1000P5 asking 13k My setup is Headunit Azur ANX-F714CH costed me 5K Front stage Pioneer TS-C1710A costed 17K Back stage Pion TS-C016A costed 20k Amplifier Kicx audio 4 channel 1600 watts amps my father had it so reused it Subwoofer Pioneer TS-W307D4 also reused it
column2: pwuser162411347231: Pioneer FH-9100DVD So you want to get rid of the current headunit ( which I assume you bought second hand since the 9100 is a japenese version ) for the 8750? negotiate the price if you want that particular headunit. You have pioneer components front and back. Have you considered where you are placing the rear tweeters? A busted coil on a sub is repairable. But unless it's done professionally, consider it junk. It will keep giving you issues in the future so why not upgrade the sub too? And 5k for a coil change on a 10+ year old sub is absured You actually spent 12k on repairing an amp? What was done to it? alien technology infusion? If your amp needs to pushed that hard to get the sub going, the amp is a goner and underpowered. you would need atleast 150-200rms to run a 400rms sub. ~300rms is what most 4 channel amps will do on bridged and thats best you can get out of them considering you have 12V+ Kicx audio is another generic chinese brand that write big numbers like 2000watts on their amps when they can only push about 100-150 on bridged. I'd suggest to get a good branded ( even if they are older gens ) 4 channel amp for the speakers and a mono or 2 channel for the sub i'd suggest to gather these things. When you have everything, do the install

column2: Get a hold of the jbl cs1214. But not from peshawar. Only a handful of shops actually sell authentic jbl products. The rest are really good knockoffs. The thing with jbls are, they are much more punchier when it comes to bass meaning they sound more accurate. The 307 you have is a spl sub. Only good with ported enclosures and only good for high pressure setups where going loud is the aim. It's not a sub you would want to have to enjoy music. Pioneer does make the prs series but those are either very expensive or almost non-existent Do you know the model number for the nakamichi amplifier? Where are you buying these things from? What shop? I live in pesh/isb so I know which of the shops try to rip people off in both cities. An amp repair won't cost more than a couple of K's. That too for a generic chinese amp. So whoever you did the repair from was hella happy after he got 12k from you The speakers and sub have different power demands. the 307 is a 400rms sub. Most high end speakers are 100-150 and the usual ones between 50-100rms. With 100rms, your speakers (if they are 100rms) will be running at full potential while your sub will only be getting 1/4 the power it needs. I hope that clarifies the issue. Best to invest in a new 4 channel amp ( along with the mono for the sub ) and a sub

column1: So after a long time I am.posting anything on Pakwheels.com and this is what every civic 05 must be interested in reading Genuine 05 CF steering are now retired and do work as other models and make cars. They make noises, power pump fails, steering rack leaks and all hard feel. So after a hard research I convinced my self to go for a EPS conversation . Spent whole day and 13000 rupees in bilal gunk and got my baby converted ... and after all the hard work Alhumdulillah the steering is like silk smooth.... full malaiiii Just be aware that you get all three parts i.e steering rack 'kangi' , computer unit, and wiring from the same unit/ nose cutt. DON'T GO FOR MIX AND MATCH EVER !!!
column2: what was wrong with your original hydraulic setup? rebuilding the rack is not to difficult for a workshop and neither is resealing the pump, the pump is also available brand new if its faulty.

column2: open the power steering fluid bottle cover and try turning steering left to right n then right to left completely, it will help release any trapped air in PS lines n help pump function....

column2: Seems like the power has been tapped in the accessories wiring. Get the wiring sorted. The fuse box in engine bay has the port for eps fuse, you need to procure the wiring connector and 60amp fuse for it. Route the power through the fuse and make sure to use good quality wire and insulate properly (its live all the time and you dont want to short it to body/ground).

column1: Salam, I have a 93 Nissan Serena Diesel which has been slowly giving up on me. I am thinking about either swapping the engine to a Toyota C Diesel engine or something similar. column1: Dear Friend, I am facing a strange issue with my car's AC. At times, it trips on high speed and i can fell only fan air. In case i turn AC OFF and then turn it ON, it starts working. Its a bit different from normal AC tripping where i keep getting cool air. Its Margalla 96 car with Genuine AC. AC is serviced recently and gas is filled too. I am not facing any heat up issues. Can anybody advise me on this? Is it something to do with the Battery as its pretty old now? Additionally, i can feel ICE COOL condenser pipe etc but cooling is not that much inside car. Thanks in advance.
column2: if your condenser pipes are cool - then your system is beyong choked. I think you are referring to the evaporator return pipe which usually gets very cold and even sweats. The tripping could be of high head pressure (if the system is fully original and not cut up)

Thanks in advance.
column2: waseef;4789794: Sorry for digging!! Relevant question! how do i know my car ac trips, need to understand the mechanism of tripping, is there temperature sensor in cabin whcih trips ac or it depend on fan speed.? car in question is 1oth gen corolla. @Xulfiqar there is a thermostat in the evaporator core which cuts the system off when the temperature goes to freezing point of water.
