Sort of similar problem is faced by me too... When the blower is set upto 2(medium) flow the ac keeps on switiching on and off at regualr intervals whether the car is idle or cruising...but when set on 3 or 4 (hi fan speed) the problem resolves.. Moreover, I've noticed that the rpm on idle doesnt increase a little bit when the ac is turned on, as normally cars do, rather it decreases a little bit.. The ac is Sanden 508 and enfine is 2kdftv...

column1: Repair of alloy rims<o:p></o:p> Hi , I have a set of ally rims , they are used and slightly out of shape, does any one know any good place in <st1:city><st1:place>Lahore</st1:place></st1:city> where I can repair then and paint then new . <o:p></o:p> Please help <o:p></o:p> Regards:) <o:p></o:p> <o:p></o:p> <o:p></o:p>
column2: please note that nobody in pakistan has the correct machines and training to repair bent alloy wheels. it'll be alot safer for you to replace them.

column1: Repair of alloy rims<o:p></o:p> Hi , I have a set of ally rims , they are used and slightly out of shape, does any one know any good place in <st1:city><st1:place>Lahore</st1:place></st1:city> where I can repair then and paint then new . <o:p></o:p> Please help <o:p></o:p> Regards:) <o:p></o:p> <o:p></o:p> <o:p></o:p>
column2: There is a guy in Karachi who has the skills to repair bent wheels. His name is Mohammad Miya. His workshop is located behind the PTV station. He specializes in fixing alloy wheels and his workshop is quite large. He has even repaired wheels that have been broken into two pieces. He has been doing this work for approximately 25 years and is a highly skilled expert in this field.

column2: well iv never been to this person personally..coz i always give my wheels to zafcom and they manage it ahead as in getting them sent to him and getting them back! i would even recommend giving ur damaged wheels to zafcom theyl have it fixed for you and they will be as good as new again (although the wheels strength wont be the same anymore if they are were badly bent bcoz the wheel is heated and then dented and then on a lait ka machine a few mm's are shaved off the wheel)

column2: Aamir, there is a guy in Karachi who has the expertise to repair bent wheels. His name is Mohammad Miya, and his workshop is located behind the PTV station. His main specialization is fixing alloy wheels, and he operates a large workshop. He is even skilled enough to repair wheels that have been broken into two pieces. Mohammad Miya has been in this profession for approximately 25 years and is considered a highly experienced and professional expert in this field.  -  - Aamir Bhai, could you please provide the name of his workshop, its proper address, or his mobile number so that I can contact him? I have an urgent need to get an alloy rim repaired.

column1: So the system SD card for the head unit in my car (Vitz '10) was missing, I searched PW and found the correct system files to use and got my unit to go past the initial screen. But now the unit is asking for two new types of inputs. First one i have no idea about and the second one is the ERC code. Can anyone who is experienced with these systems suggest what I can do? Each headunit has a unique code on the erc screen which i cannot figure out. I have searched online but only found people selling the codes for $25+ so there is definitely some way to get these codes. Also going to an audio shop is a last resort for me as I want to try and figure this out for myself first. I would really appreciate any help as I'm sure a lot of other people may be facing the same problem who will need info on how to get the codes. Attached are images of the two screens which ask for codes.
column2: AOA Faizan Sb, I have the exact same issue & same model of Vitz with the W66 just like you. Were you able to find a solution? I know that for the ERC code, you have to find an unlock code but that initial password, I have no idea about.

column1: Aoa Everyone I am looking for an IOS App which should maintain car service log and also suggest services. Like it should suggest that Check brakes after 10k Electrical checkup after 20k Transmission oil after 40k
column2: Use google calendar to maintain your log, or a literal book and manila folder, use the folder to save all receipts of purchases and the book to write what was done when.

column1: Aoa Everyone I am looking for an IOS App which should maintain car service log and also suggest services. Like it should suggest that Check brakes after 10k Electrical checkup after 20k Transmission oil after 40k
column2: No app gives suggestions I think. Most are log-keeping apps. You enter your data and enter the next date/milage at which the next service will be required and then the app will suggest you on that date or around that milage to go for service. Fuelio is a good app, its free. Drivvo is a paid app but has very good interface.

column1: Aoa Everyone I am looking for an IOS App which should maintain car service log and also suggest services. Like it should suggest that Check brakes after 10k Electrical checkup after 20k Transmission oil after 40k
column2: Yes. But don't rely on this free app solely. Once you've put much data of your car, the developer will block/suspend your account or suspend the syncing of data. Then either you'll lose your data or forced to buy the subscription. I have gone through this.

column1: Aoa Everyone I am looking for an IOS App which should maintain car service log and also suggest services. Like it should suggest that Check brakes after 10k Electrical checkup after 20k Transmission oil after 40k
column2: There is a feature of 'My Garage' on Pakwheels app where you can add services/maintenances carried out at a certain mileage or date and you can save all your car's data in it but it won't suggest services after a certain mileage or time.

column1: Aoa Everyone I am looking for an IOS App which should maintain car service log and also suggest services. Like it should suggest that Check brakes after 10k Electrical checkup after 20k Transmission oil after 40k
column2: Drivvo, road trip mpg are the apps i use. Both can give reminders on your periodic maintenance, tire change, etc based upon your data input.You can setup reminders for yourself for different tasks/checkups but it would require you to constantly update your app.

column1: Aoa Everyone I am looking for an IOS App which should maintain car service log and also suggest services. Like it should suggest that Check brakes after 10k Electrical checkup after 20k Transmission oil after 40k
column2: Yes but looking for an app with suggestions.

column1: Hi Focal Fans, Focal Fan Club is for all of you to share your success stories, participate in discussions no matter if its install or tune related, share your photos, test tracks, experiences good or bad, educate and motivate people, last but not the least.. your love for the Music. If you really appreciate music, really want to listen deep to it and hear all those nuances, all the dynamics, and just hear music how it was originally performed ? you need to get to know Focal. They're a company truly obsessed with doing the same. This summer, the upgrade season is in full swing, everyone's making his move. Lets start a fan club so that we show the world our passion for Focal - The Spirit of Sound. I welcome you all, lets inspire the next and make our fan club a success.. Focal, "Listen to your music not to your speakers". Cheers IMPORTANT NOTICE  Requesting all members to go to Focal.com, and send your product serial number to Focal as a query, they will reply back if the product is original or fake, along with it's dealer information who imported it and sold it.  You still need to register you product with true information and get that auto generated certificate for future use, in case there is a warranty claim you'll be required to present it with your speakers.  You can post your questions and comments here if you need any support from us. Attention Guys, share your gusta photos, and the best one would make our forum cover.  Two new sections are coming up, Focal Police, Focal Victims. Both ideas are great, FP would hunt the FVs, I would update lists. This way we can invite/motivate more people to join our club. For now I need your input regarding the best guys who can make squad of FP.  Focal Police  Bad_Cheeta Roms (Suggest Squad Members) Focal Victim Talhadon (Most Wanted) Finally caught!  Jz (Most Wanted)   Focal Recent Club Members  Ali Raza aka Slash (recently been added to our club by the help of Bad_Cheeta, pictures of setup awaited, we wish him Gusta-luck, and happy SQing..) DJ_denom (recently been added to our club by the help of Roms, pictures of setup awaited, we wish him Gusta-luck, and happy SQing..) Shuaib (non-pw'er friend has recently been added to our club by the help of Moonjee, pictures of setup coming soon, we wish him Gusta-luck, and happy SQing..) Talhadon (has recently been added to our club by the help of all the Focal members, pictures of setup coming soon, we wish him Gusta-luck, and happy SQing..) His build log is here Wakky (has recently been added to our club by Moonjee, we wish him gusta luck on his way to SQ World, his build log can be reviewed here. CoLd_FuSiOn has recently been added to our club, by an unknown force of SQ, we wish him all the best with his build and pursuit of SQ Heaven. His build log can be reviewed here.
column2: wow... excellent stuff you guys have got urselves... amazing!! though im totally noob at these things but i now have started taking interest and hopefully i ll learn it slowly gr8 going guys...

column1: Hi Focal Fans, Focal Fan Club is for all of you to share your success stories, participate in discussions no matter if its install or tune related, share your photos, test tracks, experiences good or bad, educate and motivate people, last but not the least.. your love for the Music. If you really appreciate music, really want to listen deep to it and hear all those nuances, all the dynamics, and just hear music how it was originally performed ? you need to get to know Focal. They're a company truly obsessed with doing the same. This summer, the upgrade season is in full swing, everyone's making his move. Lets start a fan club so that we show the world our passion for Focal - The Spirit of Sound. I welcome you all, lets inspire the next and make our fan club a success.. Focal, "Listen to your music not to your speakers". Cheers IMPORTANT NOTICE  Requesting all members to go to Focal.com, and send your product serial number to Focal as a query, they will reply back if the product is original or fake, along with it's dealer information who imported it and sold it.  You still need to register you product with true information and get that auto generated certificate for future use, in case there is a warranty claim you'll be required to present it with your speakers.  You can post your questions and comments here if you need any support from us. Attention Guys, share your gusta photos, and the best one would make our forum cover. column1: Hello everyone,hope y'all r doing good...I want to install sound system in my mehran and needed your help/opinion in a few things. The setup includes:- 2x Sony Xplod XS-N6940 4 way speakers(85rms/500w peak) 1 Pioneer TS-W308D2 Dual coil Subwoofer. 1 Sony XS-NW1200 1800w(300rms) Subwoofer. 2x Sony XS-FB103E 4'' speakers already installed in front doors. Planning to install component speakers as well in front.(not purchased yet) 2x 4 channel Amplifiers(One is JEC 800wRMS 2ohm stable and other is some chinese 4 channel amp my bro bought for around 7k couple of years ago) Headunit will also be upgraded to a good pioneer HU.(not purchased yet) NOW THE PROBLEM IS,I got this car recently and everything is stock(battery/alternator/wiring).I am a student with very limited budget left after spending all my savings on the above mentioned things,Please tell me what do I need to upgrade/change in order to run the sound system smoothly without the risk of killing or underpowering the amps due to low power...As I am quite new to all this and dont know much about alternators or battery(Only read a few forums about the BIG 3 upgrade and all),Please guide me if you have done any of this or have any experience regarding this...Also if I need to change alternator,what can be the estimated price for an alternator that fits in my mehran(euro 2).Also wiring experts,kindly guide me which guage wires would I need for the BIG 3 and the amps. Looking forward...Thanks
column2: So your aim is to go loud I assume since you want 2 12" subs? First up, don't mix and match. Either get the same 2 12" subs or go big with 1 15" sub. You are better of with 1 box for the 2 subs. Different subwoofers in different sized box's is just not the right way. You should also invest in a good ( min 4 AWG ) ofc wire for the big 3. Shops that have the wire also have the ring terminals for them. The hard thing to find is the inline fuse which usually is a part of the kit. I think Sound Valley in pindi saddar had some kit's. Pretty sure Hamza will have them too in Lahore. You have to mention what city you live in The alternator upgrade will need to be done. I'm sure even Big3 or Big4 won't help a Mehran's electronics

column1: Hello everyone,hope y'all r doing good...I want to install sound system in my mehran and needed your help/opinion in a few things. The setup includes:- 2x Sony Xplod XS-N6940 4 way speakers(85rms/500w peak) 1 Pioneer TS-W308D2 Dual coil Subwoofer. 1 Sony XS-NW1200 1800w(300rms) Subwoofer. 2x Sony XS-FB103E 4'' speakers already installed in front doors. Planning to install component speakers as well in front.(not purchased yet) 2x 4 channel Amplifiers(One is JEC 800wRMS 2ohm stable and other is some chinese 4 channel amp my bro bought for around 7k couple of years ago) Headunit will also be upgraded to a good pioneer HU.(not purchased yet) NOW THE PROBLEM IS,I got this car recently and everything is stock(battery/alternator/wiring).I am a student with very limited budget left after spending all my savings on the above mentioned things,Please tell me what do I need to upgrade/change in order to run the sound system smoothly without the risk of killing or underpowering the amps due to low power...As I am quite new to all this and dont know much about alternators or battery(Only read a few forums about the BIG 3 upgrade and all),Please guide me if you have done any of this or have any experience regarding this...Also if I need to change alternator,what can be the estimated price for an alternator that fits in my mehran(euro 2).Also wiring experts,kindly guide me which guage wires would I need for the BIG 3 and the amps. Looking forward...Thanks
column2: That's a lot of stuff you have. Was the aim to go loud (spl)? Different products, different characteristics, different sounds isn't really a great way to set up a setup. Regardless, I'd suggest you up your wiring. Is it 0/4 or 8 gauge? Do a big3 and add some inline fuses. Are you power/gnd wires ofc or cca? Even if you upgrade your alternator or add another battery, a mehrans wiring can only take so much beating. For a setup of this caliber, you would need atleast true 4 gauge ofc wiring. Do the big3 with 1/0 gauge and if it's in your budget, run 1/0 gauge or 4 gauge to your amps. Make sure the pwr and gnd wires are the same size. Get the wiring upgrade done, then figure out your next upgrade

column1: Hello everyone,hope y'all r doing good...I want to install sound system in my mehran and needed your help/opinion in a few things. The setup includes:- 2x Sony Xplod XS-N6940 4 way speakers(85rms/500w peak) 1 Pioneer TS-W308D2 Dual coil Subwoofer. 1 Sony XS-NW1200 1800w(300rms) Subwoofer. 2x Sony XS-FB103E 4'' speakers already installed in front doors. Looking forward...Thanks
column2: I still get my things and installs done by sherry bhai. He's probably one of the few people who has stayed legit. But like you said, a big3 is a must and the amplifier wiring too. SQ setups won't pull that much current since it's more about the listening experience and that can be achieved with very little power compared to an spl setup as the member above has. I can only imagine why his amps keep clipping

column1: Hello everyone,hope y'all r doing good...I want to install sound system in my mehran and needed your help/opinion in a few things. The setup includes:- 2x Sony Xplod XS-N6940 4 way speakers(85rms/500w peak) 1 Pioneer TS-W308D2 Dual coil Subwoofer. 1 Sony XS-NW1200 1800w(300rms) Subwoofer. 2x Sony XS-FB103E 4'' speakers already installed in front doors. Planning to install component speakers as well in front.(not purchased yet) 2x 4 channel Amplifiers(One is JEC 800wRMS 2ohm stable and other is some chinese 4 channel amp my bro bought for around 7k couple of years ago) Headunit will also be upgraded to a good pioneer HU.(not purchased yet) NOW THE PROBLEM IS,I got this car recently and everything is stock(battery/alternator/wiring).I am a student with very limited budget left after spending all my savings on the above mentioned things,Please tell me what do I need to upgrade/change in order to run the sound system smoothly without the risk of killing or underpowering the amps due to low power...As I am quite new to all this and dont know much about alternators or battery(Only read a few forums about the BIG 3 upgrade and all),Please guide me if you have done any of this or have any experience regarding this...Also if I need to change alternator,what can be the estimated price for an alternator that fits in my mehran(euro 2).Also wiring experts,kindly guide me which guage wires would I need for the BIG 3 and the amps. Looking forward...Thanks
column2: if the provided wiring kit had 2 awg cables, can you check if they are cca or ofc? The dimming is a common occurance in any setup if there isnt enough current flow. The stock wiring in the engine bay ( alternator + battery ) is pretty thin. So despite the fact that you install a bigger battery/alternator, the stock wires won't be able to cope with the demanded current flow. Youtube what a Big3 is and get that done before anything else. What city are you living in btw? The inline fuse is only there for protection. It wont solve the problem of your current flow

Looking forward...Thanks
column2: Yup, go to sherry bhai. The wiring needs to be upgraded with ofc + do a Big3. Once done, you can look into upgrading the alternator. There were some spl build threads long back here on PW ( the good old days ) by members like blacklist1, splfanatic etc where discussions were done bout suitable alternator upgrades for small cars like mehrans, santros etc. You might find some info there

column1: Hello everyone,hope y'all r doing good...I want to install sound system in my mehran and needed your help/opinion in a few things. The setup includes:- 2x Sony Xplod XS-N6940 4 way speakers(85rms/500w peak) 1 Pioneer TS-W308D2 Dual coil Subwoofer. 1 Sony XS-NW1200 1800w(300rms) Subwoofer. 2x Sony XS-FB103E 4'' speakers already installed in front doors. Planning to install component speakers as well in front.(not purchased yet) 2x 4 channel Amplifiers(One is JEC 800wRMS 2ohm stable and other is some chinese 4 channel amp my bro bought for around 7k couple of years ago) Headunit will also be upgraded to a good pioneer HU.(not purchased yet) NOW THE PROBLEM IS,I got this car recently and everything is stock(battery/alternator/wiring).I am a student with very limited budget left after spending all my savings on the above mentioned things,Please tell me what do I need to upgrade/change in order to run the sound system smoothly without the risk of killing or underpowering the amps due to low power...As I am quite new to all this and dont know much about alternators or battery(Only read a few forums about the BIG 3 upgrade and all),Please guide me if you have done any of this or have any experience regarding this...Also if I need to change alternator,what can be the estimated price for an alternator that fits in my mehran(euro 2).Also wiring experts,kindly guide me which guage wires would I need for the BIG 3 and the amps. Looking forward...Thanks
column2: Start by upgrading your car generator to something from Liana or Balona... I think Nissan will also fit... Find generator that fits without modification. Get something above 80 Amperes! (Mehran generator is around 45 to 50 Ampere = (50 Amps x 13 Volts x 0.6 Class AB efficiency) = 390 Watt RMS) For 2 Subwoofers you need at-least 100 Ampere generator... Your amplifier does not produce power, it just converts power from car into sound... It needs power which your Mehran generator can not produce! This results in lights dimming, battery damage and low output sound!

column1: Aoa Guys, I am going to try and install JL Audio C1-650 components in our City 2004. I am a complete beginner and this might take some time. Nonetheless I am going to make the attempt. I am new to this and this will be my first install hopefully. I would like some guidance here to help me through the process. For now I just have the components. Current Equipment: - JL C1-650 - Some stock pioneer two din pre Need some input on speaker rings. Where to get them from. Any recommendations? I am looking at some 3M rings from daraz. I might need to upgrade the pre, any suggestions on what to pair it with? I would like to install a screen, I am okay with Chinese aftermarket products provided they are okay for my components, otherwise will save up to get something better. So please suggest what should I look at. Thanks
column2: Hay Qurban, are you living in islamabad/rawalpindi? Might I suggest you check out a few build threads here on pakwheels to get an idea The C1 are good components. It would be best to give them proper power through an external amp. A branded headunit will provide more clean power to the components than a Chinese android unit ( stay away from that ) The speaker rings are a great feature to isolate the speakers from the door. But combine that with some sound deadening on the door to really get the best out of them. An external amp will provide more clean power and you'll love the way your components play You can check my Sunny/alto builds. There are other great sq sql builds by the likes of yawar, stj, docshaggy etc Just a heads up, I also have a pioneer6 avh-x5550bt double din headunit for sale along with some sq amps and more goodies

column1: Aoa Guys, I am going to try and install JL Audio C1-650 components in our City 2004. I am a complete beginner and this might take some time. Nonetheless I am going to make the attempt. I am new to this and this will be my first install hopefully. I would like some guidance here to help me through the process. For now I just have the components. Current Equipment: - JL C1-650 - Some stock pioneer two din pre Need some input on speaker rings. Where to get them from. Any recommendations? I am looking at some 3M rings from daraz. I might need to upgrade the pre, any suggestions on what to pair it with? I would like to install a screen, I am okay with Chinese aftermarket products provided they are okay for my components, otherwise will save up to get something better. So please suggest what should I look at. Thanks
column2: First up, the speaker rings you have are pretty good and do the job they are meant to do. No need to get anything branded. I had the same rings initially in my Nissan build and only switched to the stinger kit cuz it was a 3 layer setup. The 3m backing adhesive is really good on these. Just make sure when you are sticking the outer ring, place it around the speaker edge and not over the speaker itself. This way, the speaker is serviceable The x5550bt has been researved by another member now. If the sale doesn't go through, you may buy it. The asking price was 35k. I also had the rainbow ipaul amps for sale, great sq amps but they are a bit pricey. Please check my sale thread. All info is available And lastly, since you are in islamabad, I'd suggest you get in touch with Shehryar @ soundvalley in pindi saddar. He has some good equipment and can arrange also some good branded wiring. You may also ask haroon radio in karachi

So please suggest what should I look at. Thanks
column2: Are you not adding an amplifier? The c1s will perform better if its given proper power from an external amp If you still insist on running them from the pre on the stock wiring harness, you can simply tap into the stock wire with a wire tapper and solder some extra length speaker wire. The other option is to simply cut the speaker grip off but leave enough wire so incase in the future you plan on reinstalling the stock speakers, you can easy reattach the old wire and grip

column1: Aoa Guys, I am going to try and install JL Audio C1-650 components in our City 2004. I am a complete beginner and this might take some time. Nonetheless I am going to make the attempt. I am new to this and this will be my first install hopefully. I would like some guidance here to help me through the process. For now I just have the components. Current Equipment: - JL C1-650 - Some stock pioneer two din pre Need some input on speaker rings. Where to get them from. Any recommendations? I am looking at some 3M rings from daraz. I might need to upgrade the pre, any suggestions on what to pair it with? I would like to install a screen, I am okay with Chinese aftermarket products provided they are okay for my components, otherwise will save up to get something better. So please suggest what should I look at. Thanks
column2: If you buy a headunit which can go active, e.g pioneer pres that have the network mode, you can power the tweeters in the front channel and the midbass on the rear channels making it a complete active setup. Otherwise you would have to attach the crossover. You can check youtube on how to wire a 2 way components set directly via the headunit itself. In a passive setup, you would have to run new wires from the crossover to the midbass and tweeter anyways

column2: Your factory speaker wire ( front right and front left ) will simply be the inputs to the crossovers. You will need to run new wiring from the crossovers to the midbass and tweeters. A 16 or 14 awg ofc wire will suffice

column1: Team NUST Automotive Group (NUSTAG) is a student research organization based in NUST CEME that has been researching and fabricating energy efficient vehicles for International competitions such as Shell Eco-Marathon. Last year we participated in Shell Eco-Marathon Pakistan and came first in the Urban Concept Gasoline Category by achieving a milage of 101km/liters. This year we have qualified to represent Pakistan in Shell Eco-Marathon Asia which is to be held in Lombok, Indonesia in October. We are currently facing a challenge of funding. The whole project costs about 50 lakhs and we still need to arrange half of this amount. Funding Breakdown: 2,000,000 PKR - Car Shipping 1,800,000 PKR - Team Travelling 900,000 PKR - Team Accommodation 300,000 PKR - Car Expenditure (For further information you can contact us) We have long been the #1 Team in Pakistan and we need your support to help us keep this title. If you can support/ sponsor us in any fashion or know someone that can be of help. Kindly connect with us. The details are given below. We would love to have a meeting and discuss options. For a brief overview, you may check out our: NUSTAG Pitch Video2 We would also appreciate any technical expertise that will help us perform better. Especially advice related to EFI Tuning. This year we used an Engine Dynamometer to properly tune our engine. The EFI kit that we use is ECOTRONS. Looking forward to a positive response! Team Manager: M. Saad Sohail +92 306 5357593 saadsohail619@gmail.com Marketing Lead: Daniyal Ziafat +92 324 5233389 daniyalziafat123@gmail.com Team NUSTAG Official Email: nustag.official@gmail.com Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/nustagofficial1 LinkedIn: linkedin.com/company/nustagofficial Facebook: @NustagOfficial

column1: just wanted to share my experience getting a vehicle showing incorrect fuel level fixed its a vigo which used to show quarter tank fuel in it but ran out of fuel and did not lit up the reserve light showed to meter guy in saddar. with full confidence he said this vehicle has electrical issues.meter is perfectly fine. went to electrician and after checking couple of things he said its meter issue and all electricals are fine. finally ended up with this dude "Mithu" in glass factory road- khoo....saw meter behaviour and in 30 seconds said its meter problem. took ic's from donor meter and fixed it.very skilled guy. got quoted 40-50,000 for kabli meter...meter fixed in 8000
column2: the chips/ic's from the meter which were replaced

column1: Dear friends I just got bought new facelift corolla and the driver side door got dented. I got it repainted(my mistake) from 3s dealer two times and still there is mismatch. What should I do
column2: Even if u install a new door from another corolla which is factory painted the paint won't match. You can check with insurance companies who might have totalled cars with brand new doors in silver color. And replace your door. But a slight difference would still be there. OEM paint is baked on the metal door for that finish first of all you need a fresh door and then matched color. For a door already painted you are respraying which means thickness increases so it will never match even if someone tells you 100% guarantee. For 100% result and not catching by a naked eye the first thing you need to do is that you need to get a fresh door and then get it painted.

column1: Dear friends I just got bought new facelift corolla and the driver side door got dented. I got it repainted(my mistake) from 3s dealer two times and still there is mismatch. What should I do
column2: It will never be 100%. There would be angles in which it will be more difference. Check in broad day light . Also compound the car to match colour. It improves a lot .

column1: Dear friends I just got bought new facelift corolla and the driver side door got dented. I got it repainted(my mistake) from 3s dealer two times and still there is mismatch. What should I do
column2: Quite prominent. I guess they only painted one panel therefore this difference will always be there. The problem with Silver colour is whole side has to be showered with lacquer to match. Even in that case a slight difference is visible under certain angles and light conditions. Leave it as it is. Going to other painters will cause unnecessary expenditure and the result will still never be 100%. Silver is the worst colour to match.

column1: Dear friends I just got bought new facelift corolla and the driver side door got dented. I got it repainted(my mistake) from 3s dealer two times and still there is mismatch. What should I do
column2: Thats good. But your experience doesnt negate the fact that Silver is the worst colour when it comes to matching. I have a Silver car that has always gone to different Honda dealerships in Lahore for paintwork over the past 12 years of ownership. There has always been a difference in the colour after a repaint. For example I am yet to see a Silver repainted bumper on any car that matches 100% with the body. Not every body can recognise these mismatches neither they visible in all kinds of light conditions. Some match nearly perfect some poorly. But the difference is always there. He can give it a try but there is a high probability that it will not match.

column1: Dear friends I just got bought new facelift corolla and the driver side door got dented. I got it repainted(my mistake) from 3s dealer two times and still there is mismatch. What should I do
column2: I would believe what Toyota Airport said. Without showering the whole side with lacquer it is almost impossible to match silver.

column1: Dear friends I just got bought new facelift corolla and the driver side door got dented. I got it repainted(my mistake) from 3s dealer two times and still there is mismatch. What should I do
column2: Why not. I have a pre facelift corolla 2016 and i had one piece sprayed and not even from toyota i got it sprayed from HONDA Dealership as the guy is an old friend of mine and i didnt mind paying exorbitant prices as insurance was going to cover it And even toyota painters couldn't tell which panel was resprayed I can post pictures if you want and you wont be able to tell the difference

column1: Hi All,, As summers are here ! Most of the cars would be getting their cooling system serviced so thought to share this here.Just wanted to share what i got to know few days back regarding Denso A/C Compressors. Maybe i can save someone ending up destroying their AC compressor just because of lack of knowledge among the A/C service guys!  Denso Compressors should only be filled with ND-OIL 8 compressor oil.  I have Alto 660CC which has Denso Compressor, the A/C compressor was giving a strange noise while the car idles. As soon as i give accelarator the sound goes. In short the compressor becomes soundless on 1.5K RPM and above. Got it inspected from 3 - 4 wshops and all said to change the compressor as the noise is from inside the compressor. So got the old compressor out and took it as a sample to buy the exact thing. There On the compressor it was mentioned "Only Use ND-OIL 8" on the side of the compressor which would not have been visible to read if the compressor had not been taken out , bought the compressor from Bilal gunj and back to the wshop, when came the turn to put oil in it , the A/C guy brought a 1.5 liter water bottle which had oil in it to put it in the compressor.. I asked him which oil is this and he simply replied "Compressor Oil hai ji" ... I asked haaan leikin kya grade hai , koi code wagaira ? he said nai sir bas compressor oil k naam say milta hia Temple road say .. Hmmmmmm.... Asked 2 - 3 other A/C wshops and they also replied the same k jinaaab aik hi cheez hai , bas Oil daalna laazmi hota hai jo marzi daalo.. Lol.. Anyways I had already decided to only fill my compressor with ND OIL 8 as soon as i read it on the compressor, as there must have been a reason why it was mentioned on the compressor,, finally the oil was available at Punjab Car A/C.. Bought the oil from there and got it filled in the compressor.. Now if i wouldve gone for a normal A/C service, I wouldve never know that ND OIL 8 needs to be filled in it and eventually I wouldve ended up getting the desi oil filled eventually the compressor might go Bad OR Cease. As the A/C compressor is not taken out in case of just servicing the unit. From another source, i got to know that these 660CC cars have rotary compressors, So maybe thats the reason that they should only be used with specifically ND-OIL 8.. Just like NO SYNTHETIC OIL in rotary engines of Cars! only Mineral Motor oil should be used.. Still Not Sure. Maybe experts can tell.. ND-oil 8 is used in the following DENSO Compressor types: 10PA, 7SB, 6SE, SC, 6CA series
column2: suniso make the compressor oil you mention and its quite pricey, expect to pay really high prices for it, good A/C shops invest in this and charge you appropriately, using the wrong oils in the system can severely damage it. Google R134a refrigeration lube and R12 lube, you will find out.

There On the compressor it was mentioned "Only Use ND-OIL 8" on the side of the compressor which would not have been visible to read if the compressor had not been taken out , bought the compressor from Bilal gunj and back to the wshop, when came the turn to put oil in it , the A/C guy brought a 1.5 liter water bottle which had oil in it to put it in the compressor.. I asked him which oil is this and he simply replied "Compressor Oil hai ji" ... I asked haaan leikin kya grade hai , koi code wagaira ? he said nai sir bas compressor oil k naam say milta hia Temple road say .. Hmmmmmm.... Asked 2 - 3 other A/C wshops and they also replied the same k jinaaab aik hi cheez hai , bas Oil daalna laazmi hota hai jo marzi daalo.. Lol.. Anyways I had already decided to only fill my compressor with ND OIL 8 as soon as i read it on the compressor, as there must have been a reason why it was mentioned on the compressor,, finally the oil was available at Punjab Car A/C.. Bought the oil from there and got it filled in the compressor.. Now if i wouldve gone for a normal A/C service, I wouldve never know that ND OIL 8 needs to be filled in it and eventually I wouldve ended up getting the desi oil filled eventually the compressor might go Bad OR Cease. As the A/C compressor is not taken out in case of just servicing the unit. From another source, i got to know that these 660CC cars have rotary compressors, So maybe thats the reason that they should only be used with specifically ND-OIL 8.. Just like NO SYNTHETIC OIL in rotary engines of Cars! only Mineral Motor oil should be used.. Still Not Sure. Maybe experts can tell.. ND-oil 8 is used in the following DENSO Compressor types: 10PA, 7SB, 6SE, SC, 6CA series
column2: Using Wrong Oil Is Simply Wasting Your Money Time And Call A Disaster Upon Compressor And A/C Components.....No Wonder Why Compressor Shaft Seals Are Broken Every Year

I think he was checking the pressure being built by the compressor.. As he denied 2 compressors after this pulley spin test. thanks for responce today i took my car to ac mech and we took out comperessor it was dry not running jammed then he just wanted to test my old comperessor with nd 8 oil as it was dry when it came out of car i already had bought a new sanden unit but he did not installed ran pully with oil and he turned the comp over for 30 mins or so and to every ones surprise original comperessor started working he said why u spending new sanden for 7k lets install it and check if it does not work then new one will be installed got that original comp in car testing for leaks and no leaks after that he filled gas and then it started cooling with Gas Alhumdulillah oem comp in my alto started working took it on motorway to check but cooling getting better and better returned brand new comp and original one is working again with no sounds or load on engine

column1: Most of the time sulf works fine but sometimes when I start it wont start on the first sulf and when it does on the second it start very poorly (like low RPM) but after pressing paddle it works fine
column2: sir ji please check for the clutch bearing it may need replacement. also please add extra 6mm black ground wire between battery negative and the engine. sometimes a weak battery ground connection to starter motor malfunction as well.

column1: Hi Everyone, I have a car Suzuki Baleno in Maroon Color. It was already showered and the paint quality is good but the painting labor and denting work was not done properly on doors so they are full of unnecessary Poteen and still there are dents on them. Fenders and rest of the body is good. I need to get all poteen removed from them, get the denting done properly and get them repainted again with no or very very minimal poteen. I visited an expert painter in my area in Rawalpindi and he said that it will take approx 35 thousand rupees to repaint both sides of car and around 60,000 if I do the whole car. Denting charges (for removing current poteen and dents) are separate. Really painting costs this much? I checked the market and a very good quality paint costs around PKR 7000 per liter. Isn't 1 liter paint enough to repaint just both sides of a car? Lacquer will cost what? 4000?? Even then, the cost of material becomes around 11,000 rupees. So, it means only the painting labor is around 25 thousand rupees, when the denter is doing all work of removing poteen and fixing dents?? Can anyone give me an idea about expected cost of labor for 4 doors or both two sides of the car if I buy all paint materials by myself and the denter removes all poteen and fix the dents?? Also, can anyone recommend me any good workshop to get denting and painting done in Rawalpindi or Islamabad? Thanks
column2: There is a car repair shop on Peshawar Road, Rawalpindi, near Chor Chowk. The name of the owner is Juma Khan and his contact number is 03165144453. He is highly skilled and his rates are very reasonable. I have been getting my car repaired by him for a good ten years now, and I can confidently say that his repairs are unbelievably good. The paint job he does is also phenomenal. The cost for repainting a panel will be around 5,000 rupees, at the maximum.

This rate is not justified. If a very good quality paint costs 2000 per panel and lacquer 1000 per panel (which I bet costs less than this), then they are taking labor of 4.5K to 9K per panel. This is too much! Plus there is no guarantee that they will use such good quality paint. Many of them always try to get as much cheap paint as possible... I think it is best to buy paint and other stuff by yourself and pay only the cost of labor to the painter.

column1: The main fuse, which is for Ignition system and gauges, warning lights etc. melts again and again due to heating. The point where fuse is installed has also melted. I got it checked by electrician, but he was not able to identify any issue. Can someone please guide how to diagnose the problem? Attached picture should the position of fuse I am referring to.
column2: Some sort of Grounding of Ignition wire, Check for any tape wiring.

column1: The main fuse, which is for Ignition system and gauges, warning lights etc. melts again and again due to heating. The point where fuse is installed has also melted. I got it checked by electrician, but he was not able to identify any issue. Can someone please guide how to diagnose the problem? Attached picture should the position of fuse I am referring to.
column2: Its an old car with lot of alternations over the course of its life. But mainly parking/fog lights are installed only. The fuse melts despite the parking or fog lights are running or not.

column1: My civic rebirth's suspension has started making squeaking noises when going over speed bumps. Since its almost 10 years old, I'm pretty sure either bushings need to be replaced or lubricated. Took it a Honda dealership and also a mechanic recommended by a friend, but both said everything is fine and to just get it washed using diesel. The thing is diesel actually destroys rubber components and is not a good lubricant. So need recommendation for a good suspension mechanic/shop in Lahore?
column2: Firstly stop visiting shops who even mentiom “lubricating” the bushings, the bushings are rubber and they “flex/bend” as the component moves. There are no moving parts there requiring lube

column1: My civic rebirth's suspension has started making squeaking noises when going over speed bumps. Since its almost 10 years old, I'm pretty sure either bushings need to be replaced or lubricated. Took it a Honda dealership and also a mechanic recommended by a friend, but both said everything is fine and to just get it washed using diesel. The thing is diesel actually destroys rubber components and is not a good lubricant. So need recommendation for a good suspension mechanic/shop in Lahore?
column2: the silicone lube/oil is only used as installation aid to press in bushings or as a water barrier (e.g. the rollbar bushing outer side) You cannot lubricate installed/pressed in bushings in any way shape or form. If you are experiencing squeak from an installed and torqued in place torsional bushing then you probably have the metal core torn away from the rubber and is causing the squeak. squeaky bushings require replacement. They are torn up or rotten.

column1: I plan on flushing my 2012 swifts radiator and heater core ( previous owner was using water). The likes of zic, caltex and toyota coolant frankly are out of my budget. Has anyone used sega car coolant available on pakwheels autostore? Thoughts on it?
column2: Why not buy the factory suzuki coolant? And cutting corners on such a critical item will cause extreme expense later on. Good thing about buying basf and havoline coolants is that you only need to buy half of the quantity. IMO havoline is best as its available almost in all cities of Pakistan and has a very good service life. If your car takes 6 litres you only need 3 litres of it.

column1: I plan on flushing my 2012 swifts radiator and heater core ( previous owner was using water). The likes of zic, caltex and toyota coolant frankly are out of my budget. Has anyone used sega car coolant available on pakwheels autostore? Thoughts on it?
column2: The suzuki blue coolant is the same material as nissan blue coolant, which is the same as Honda type2 but with a bittering agent.

column1: Blower cannot work when i select speed level of 1 2 & 3 but at maximum / 4th level it works. Kindly help regarding this what is the problem & how i solve it?? I have Cultus 2002 Model. Every thing is working well but i dnt know how it happened.
column2: you guys have to seriously pay attention to a cars workings before posting. If your blower is only working on full speed and not lower - your selector resistor is dead, the full setting is operated by a relay. Buy a new resistor block and you'll be all set, you can also put it in yourself, its housed on the ducting of the blower motor output with a couple of screws - usually its a bunch of round wire coils but sometimes its also the shape of a credit card (nissan, new toyota etc)

column1: It pains a lot if you buy a car and end up hearing its main bigen (main bearing) either making sound while starting in the morning or making it all day... So when you visit your mechanic and he finds you dumb, he is clever enough to suggest you a full overhaul and you feel so pissed off at your car then and why you brought it... Well here is a simple solution which will neither take you to an overhaul and I have done it not only myself but a couple of friends followed me back as well... If your main bigen starts to make noise, Ask your mechanic to remove the crankshaft without lowering your headgasket (Simply putting your engine out and crankshaft will be present at the bottom)... Once your crankshaft is out, If you're in Lahore go to Ittefaq refinery to Keynchi brigde road and drive in the direction i pointed out. Towards your left you will find Bhai Bhai Kharaadia... For other cities, go to a Kharadia that does Engines only (Bores, seals, walls, and blablabla)... Ask them to grind and polish the crankshaft and add a new main bearing Bigen set oil seal kit and whatever more they advice... Once done get your engine fitted back and you will see it will be all done for without any major overhaul... Because a major overhaul would be required in a case the car is eating up oil, if not follow this partial overhaul. Standard mechs advice full overhaul so they get labor for piston fitting and can strip u off budget.. So remember, everything has a solution.. THis is what i tried once and then a couple of friends followed it.. The kharadia expenses wont be more than 2k for a small 1000 cc car excluding parts....
column2: firstly the correct name is Main and Big end bearings, the main bearings are which the crank spins on and the big ends are the big ends of the connecting rods, the other end of the connecting rods are called small ends which are called gudgeon pin. If your engine has cold start rattle firstly check that you are using the correct oil filter for your engine with a working antidrain back valve, using incorrect filters will cause bleed down and rattle. To correctly diagnose main and big end bearing failure, you are supposed to do an oil pressure test with the correct lubricating oil in the sump and the engine at correct normal operating temperature. If your oil pressure spikes on startup and then falls to below 10 psi pressure at normal temperature, and does not rise correctly when revved the clearances between the bearing journals is causing loss of pressure and eventual wear on the crank Such noise is also caused by ommitting the oil control orifice in the block which regulates flow volume between the block and head (if OHC engine) - What you posted is an acceptable practice only if the top end is certified to be good. I mean checked with tools not dancing around fire, voodoo, andaaza, noise etc etc. I can give you a rattle example of old 84-87 Honda civic 1.2 engines, they require an oil filter with a pressure relief valve which means that unless the oil pressure is high enough the oil filter will not allow filteration, this was done by Honda to ensure oil gets to the crank oiling holes immediately and when the entire oil system is full and the main oil gallery starts to pressurize the filter opens up and allows oil to be filtered. A mitsubishi filter (cheaper compared to Honda) also fits perfectly but lacks this function, this causes the crankshaft to rattle on startup, and your mechanic then tells you that engine "over all" required. :). Think wisely - there are factors in Pakistan that do not make sense anywhere else, they are caused by our love of shortcut, bypass, jugaar etc etc.

column2: This process is good to work, but requires the engine to be separated from the gearbox, the clutch/flex plate taken off, the timing system (belt/chain) taken off which in actual fact means that you are only leaving the head bolted to the block. Cranks usually dont wear off like that unless its a design fault or some other fault like missing oil control orifice etc. Best practice is to completely check the health of the engine with proper gauges etc and then choosing your step.

column2: all gauges are available in Pakistan, you might need to make some adapters though, they are cheaply done. Your writing for the post right above recommending is not completely correct, big and main bearing noise is a rumbling sound and minor cases are heard on startup and in major cases can be heard while accelerating hard, in such cases the oil pressure warning light may also illuminate at hot idle due to massive oil pressure loss through the worn out bearing shells. The oiling circuit through an engine is very simple if you study it, and once you do, its easily identifiable what component is bad or badly adjusted.

column2: firstly your engine has a loud timing belt shriek by the timing belt being too tight. Secondly such mechanical noise has a rasp in it that is caused by worn out tappet rockers. (maybe my speakers are daft) If the noise were rumbly like a can full of ball bearings it would be big end bearings for sure.

column2: reset the timing belt tension on a dead cold engine, adjust the valve tappet clearances then recheck. For main bearing diagnosis, you need to install an oil pressure gauge to the oil pressure switch port. The pressure would peak on cold and if it drops to below 10 psi on hot and cannot raise properly when revved - it shows bad crank bearings. Such failure can also be caused if the oil pump pickup tube was removed and installed without replacing the O ring, its supposed to be renewed everytime the oil pickup tube is dismounted. Silicone etc wont work and will cause the pump to cavitate and kill the crank bearings in short time.

column2: tauseef;3185301: this thread could be very useful to subaru owners. EJ20T and EJ20TT are famous for throwing big end bearings. the crankshaft of the EJ engines are trapped inside the crankcase webbings, the entire engine needs to be taken apart to remove the crank.

column1: Hello guys! Out of curiosity, I'm making this thread to get some insight about cheaper imported car audio equipment prices in Khi. Basically, I live in the west and recently was in touch with someone in Khi who seems like deals in audio stuff. The prices he gave me was mind boggling as they're way cheaper as compare to prices here in Canada. I checked the prices at different U.S websites as well and still the rates he quoted was less. I got curious that how come this stuff sells for cheaper in Khi or maybe all over Pakistan than their country of origin?
column2: Even if u pay a high price for a original brand instead of chinese, there are still chances that the item purchased is still a high copy.

column1: I will be sharing the details of engine swap in my Alto PKDM 2001. The engine which I have already swapped is M13A. I know this sound ridiculous and not so practical but it has been done before you can check out this link https://www.pakwheels.com/forums/t/alto-engine-swap-m13a-swift-engine-installation/24806430. Now why did I select M13 for the swap? My previous engine was K10A also swapped which is a DOHC 1.0 4 Cyl engine which was a bolt on swap this particular engine had good fuel consumption 14km in Karachi city with Air Con but it lacked the grunt which I needed reason I was moving from a Starlet which had a 4efe. Now every one please bear in mind this swap is not bolt on and major alterations were done to swap this engine. I will be sharing my experience of this successful swap in this thread. Alterations which were made are as follows Brake Booster Swap Chassis Reinforcement and Modifications Custom Mounting Plates for Foundations Custom Strut Bar This was the old engine K10A New Engine M13A
column2: Very nice swap actually. Share what you planned for chassis reinforcement. Make mounting brackets and nut bolt it with the chassis or weld it. Only tie bar wouldn't be enough. Reinforce the location which control arm bolts on. Alto already go a sway bar/anti roll bar. Reinforce the strut towers then install strut bar. Reinforce the wall behind the wheels. It starts cracking. Recently welded our alto's.

column2: Great. Don't make a T shape bar. It will roll as well. Weld 2 bars near the edges and nut bolt it under the firewall.

column2: Bro jisko ap grip kehrahay ho na, that's not grip ajao mere sath 170kph cutting and stability check kartay hain.. I've done this many times, throwing in a big powerful engine in light weight chasis... But I've come to the conclusion that chasis should at least be that heavy to support at least 300 horses if you're adding 400 in it.. But if it's not handling 100horses then throwing in a 200horses is very dangerous.

column2: The ECU does not control the fuel flow. The return line is connected to its fuel pump where the fuel pressure regulator (FPR) is installed. If the fuel pump has a return line, like the one in the Swift, then it is okay to have it connected to a single line without the need for a return. However, if there is no return line near the fuel pump, then install the return line used in the Liana rail.

column2: your oil consumption sounds normal, but still 3000 kms is a bit early for change.

column2: hash4u;4396082: 20-50 is the lowest grade cheapest oil available in all the lot how much do you think one should use it in a old busted engine?when companies in pk recommedn 5k change interval with mineral oils for brand new cars If you buy a branded product like caltex, Shell, FUCHS, etc, you are buying into quality - a good filter and a proper temperature engine with 3 litre sump for approx till 1000cc displacement engine will easily run the oil to 5000 kms. If your engine is really sloppy and is running stone cold with blocked breather on trash oil filter then even using a full gp IV synthetic will not do any miracles.

column2: hash4u;4396848: my car is 240, 000 km's done and reduces oil/gives no smoke using caltex 20-50 if i stretch the oil change to 5000 i would have to fill in a ridiculous amount of oil to keep it to the up level going and buying 1 litr oil packs for top ups aint cheap either ! better drain at 3k your working model is not economical, you need to repair this problem which is 90% of the time bad valve seals. If you are burning more than 1 litre per 1000 kms - you should not be driving this car until its repaired. If you are very tight on money at this moment then buy the oil in bulk - approximately 20 litres, you will save a lot of money that way.

Still using 10W40 but thinking of switching to heavier oil next oil change. Oil is need leaking or burning. Engine is a bit noisy because of tappets tuk tuk but compression is good and the car drives really well. Where is the breather port located on a D13? must be clogged because i am unable to traces how the oil is leaving the system... there is no smoke or leaks... Should i add stp? you maybe owning a engine with leaking valve seals, they get hard after about 160,000 kms and your engine starts to use oil. adjust the valve tappets on your engine, they are not very hard to do.

API SG and SH oils worked for me for 5000 kms as long as the engine was operating at normal warmup temperature.

column1: Should i get ceramic coating to my new car?? As i heard it wear off and u have to take care with microfiber cloth in one direction And many companies offering different rates from 12k to 30k or more... Plz tell products or company or differences in price and product to select
column2: Think of Ceramic coating as a sacrificial layer of clear coat, only harder. The time duration of the guarantee/ warranty the applicator gives depends upon the quality of product, its application and follow up maintenance. And usually a careful applicator will promise you a reduced life span than what is advertised or claimed by the product manufacturer. Ceramic coat or not.....either way.....you should maintain your ride with microfiber cloths. Another option is PPF (Paint Protection Film) which IMHO seems to be a better option but expensive.

column1: Should I aim for good vacuum pressure or AFR at idle while adjusting / tuning carburetor of a car? I get the most stable vacuum pressure of 18inHg at 12.5:1 AFR. At stoic, my vacuum pressure gauge needle is unstable at 17-18inHg. Its a non turbocharged engine. Emission standards are not important for me. The engine has non-stock carburetor, I am using both AFR & Vacuum Pressure gauges for its tuning. Throttle response at load & cruise is tuned to be acceptable and close to stoich. But the matter to resolve is tuning at idle as mentioned in the question; high & stable vacuum pressure at richer afr or otherwise? Ignition timing is already advanced but not enough to cause pinging or knocking. I read online that for idle, give engine what it wants to achieve higher & stable vacuum pressure in manifold, stoic afr should not get priority. But this needs confirmation.
column2: What cylinder head temperature are you running? And how much spark advance are you running?

column1: Should I aim for good vacuum pressure or AFR at idle while adjusting / tuning carburetor of a car? I get the most stable vacuum pressure of 18inHg at 12.5:1 AFR. At stoic, my vacuum pressure gauge needle is unstable at 17-18inHg. Its a non turbocharged engine. Emission standards are not important for me. The engine has non-stock carburetor, I am using both AFR & Vacuum Pressure gauges for its tuning. Throttle response at load & cruise is tuned to be acceptable and close to stoich. But the matter to resolve is tuning at idle as mentioned in the question; high & stable vacuum pressure at richer afr or otherwise? Ignition timing is already advanced but not enough to cause pinging or knocking. I read online that for idle, give engine what it wants to achieve higher & stable vacuum pressure in manifold, stoic afr should not get priority. But this needs confirmation.
column2: Is the idle advance set to 20 degrees? Has the engine reached a temperature above 80 degrees Celsius indicating that it is fully warmed up? Is the hot idle compensator on the carburetor opening up?

column1: Should I aim for good vacuum pressure or AFR at idle while adjusting / tuning carburetor of a car? I get the most stable vacuum pressure of 18inHg at 12.5:1 AFR. At stoic, my vacuum pressure gauge needle is unstable at 17-18inHg. Its a non turbocharged engine. Emission standards are not important for me. The engine has non-stock carburetor, I am using both AFR & Vacuum Pressure gauges for its tuning. Throttle response at load & cruise is tuned to be acceptable and close to stoich. But the matter to resolve is tuning at idle as mentioned in the question; high & stable vacuum pressure at richer afr or otherwise? Ignition timing is already advanced but not enough to cause pinging or knocking. I read online that for idle, give engine what it wants to achieve higher & stable vacuum pressure in manifold, stoic afr should not get priority. But this needs confirmation.
column2: What engine is this and what carburettor is installed, hot idle compensators have been on asian carbys since the 60s. You are running way too much advance and are stabilizing at 12 afr with that much advance and no knock leads me to believe you have other mechanical issues like bad valves or bad valve timing even. The carburetor is the very last object to adjust on an engine, you first have to make sure everyrhing else is top notch, check the Intake for leaks Engine operating temperature (in ancient days we checked with multimeter or even heat marker) Correct valve timing and clearance - make sure the damn thing actually is on tdc when it says it is (sometimes the pointer mark/scale is also wrong) Correct pcv working, including no leaks on engine Correct distributor working (centrifugal and vacuum advance both) Airbox correctly seated to carb Carby with correctly levelled float and correct, idle, low and high jets, working and good sealing powervalve etc and clean emulsion passages. Good luck - carb engine tuning used to be standard work 3 decades ago, now its fading off.

column2: Check valve timing by the oldschool method of making a dead stop through the spark plug hole and then using some tailors inch tape on the crank pulley, Once you are sure the crank is good, check the cam timing as to where the lobes are to determine if you are near or off true tdc, then verify with the timing marks (if multiple) What engine is this? Once you determine that the timing of the crank is also off, then make a new mark or make a note of where its actually on tdc compared to the provided scale/point/mark

column2: So actually it was loose nuts of cylinder head and it seemed that the water from the channels entered the plug area and resulted in starting issues. So after the head nuts were tightened the problem was gone.

column2: Do Rats Love Benz? -  - I came across this interesting post on a Pakistani automobile forum. The post discusses whether or not rats are attracted to luxury cars, particularly Benz. The user is curious to know if rats have a preference for high-end vehicles. -  - The discussion revolves around the possibility of rats being fond of the wiring and components inside luxury cars, such as Mercedes-Benz. Some forum members share their personal experiences of finding rat-infested cars and the damages caused by these rodents. -  - While there is no solid scientific evidence to confirm or deny this claim, the general consensus among the forum participants seems to lean towards supporting the idea that rats do indeed find luxury vehicles appealing due to their intricate wiring system. -  - Given that rats are notorious for chewing on various objects, it is not surprising that they may be attracted to the wiring found in vehicles. Moreover, luxury cars like Mercedes-Benz are equipped with more advanced electrical systems, which could be more enticing to the rodents. -  - To prevent rat infestation in their cars, some forum members suggest taking certain precautions like keeping the vehicles clean, parking in rodent-proof garages, and using repellents. Others recommend having regular maintenance check-ups to detect any signs of damage caused by rats. -  - In conclusion, while the idea of rats having a preference for Benz cars may seem unusual, the forum discussion highlights the potential risk of rodents causing damage to luxury vehicles. It is always advisable to take precautions to protect your car from any kind of infestation, be it rats or other pests.

column1: I have seen poor owners of AGS, CVT, and DCT based vehicles get shocking surprises during their ownership. They get disappointed after facing issues with these transmissions, and I get sad when I see owners and their transmission failures or when they blame the vehicle for not performing as they intended and the problem was their transmission choice, not the vehicle itself. So, I am writing this to help people make an informed decision about the transmission choice before purchasing a vehicle. 1: Early Transmission Failure These modern automatic transmissions are not as reliable as manual transmission or traditional 4-6 speed automatic transmissions. These new automatics can fail much earlier than you expect. You can prolong the life of the transmission by following some precautionary measures and changing driving behavior, which is different for each type of transmission, hence that's a topic of a different thread. For now, let's focus on ownership shocks. In case of AGS, the clutch plates can fail as early as 20,000-30,000 km. On the positive side, complete transmission failure is not common for AGS. Premature clutch failure can happen with dry clutch DCT as well. Early failures of CVT and DCT are observed between 60,000-100,000 km. You can search the PakWheels forums as a reference. 2: Transmission Repair/Replacement Cost AGS clutch and pressure plates are easily replaceable, and they can be replaced for approx PKR 40,000 from Suzuki dealerships. I am not sure about the complete AGS transmission price since whole transmission failure is not common as mentioned previously. Similarly, clutch replacement for DCT could be done, but I am not sure about the cost. Honda Vezel owners can contribute here. Time will tell how far Changan’s DCT based vehicles can go. When an issue is faced in CVT or DCT, dealerships will ask you to replace the transmission and according to them, it's not repairable and this is an international practice. Usually, dealerships don't repair CVTs and DCTs. New transmission won't be cheap. New Honda Civic CVT cost PKR 700,000 and Alsvin DCT cost PKR 1200,000 at the time of this writing. There are transmission shops outside of Pakistan who rebuild CVTs, but first the shop will access the condition of the damage and provide estimates for labor and parts. Sometimes this cost get closer to new transmission. In such cases, it's better to replace the transmission. I am not aware of any good transmission rebuilding shop in Pakistan. If there's any, do let us know in this thread. 3: Transmission fluid is expensive Gear oil for AGS, DCT and transmission fluid (referring CVTF as gear oil is wrong terminology) for CVT are very expensive when compared to gear oil for manual transmission and ATF for traditional automatics. They usually cost between PKR 7,000 - 15,000 at the time of this writing. Not only that, the frequency of the fluid change for CVT and DCT is much higher than manual transmission. Suzuki AGS and Alsvin DCT gear oil cost PKR 15,000 and Honda HCF-2 costs about PKR 7,000. Toyota CVT fluids also cost close to Honda. 4: DCT heats up in stop & go traffic Usually people complain about transmission heat up issue in Alsvin, but this issue is common in all DCT based vehicles. If you don't let the vehicle release the clutch fully in stop and go driving, the clutch will heat up, and a warning sign will appear in the dashboard cluster. This issue can happen with Suzuki AGS as well, but Suzuki vehicles don't show any heat up indicator in the dashboard cluster. You can avoid this issue by adjusting your driving technique, specially in stop and go traffic. Avoid frequent accelerations and let the distance between your vehicle and the one in front of you increase. This should be done to give the transmission a chance to fully release the clutch. Apart from that, it's better to use manual/sports mode in such situations to avoid frequent changing of gears in stop and go traffic. If you don't use manual mode, the computer will not shift to lower gear and tries to pick speed by slipping the clutch. 5: AGS and DCT are jerky Both AGS and DCT jerk in some driving situations, especially in low gears when you accelerate. It's more noticeable in slow moving traffic where you use brakes/accelerate frequently and specially with hard acceleration. This could be controlled with driving behavior as explained in point 4 above. Using manual mode and light acceleration reduce these jerks and when done properly could be eliminated. Remember, if the gear oil is cold, the jerk will stay no matter how you drive. It goes away once the gear oil warms up and with correct driving techniques. 6: CVT delay in initial acceleration When people move from any other transmission to a CVT based vehicle for the first time, they don't like the initial acceleration of the vehicle. When you press the accelerator, the actual acceleration starts with slight delay. This is known as the rubber band effect. Many manufacturers have fine-tuned their transmissions to reduce this as much as possible. So it depends how much rubber band effect you face based on the vehicle you drive. Some have negligible for a common man, and some have a lot. 7: CVT don't climb hills with ease There are a lot of complaints of fully loaded CVT vehicles not being able to climb very steep hills like Babusar Top in the Kaghan Valley. I remember one owner reported he had a hard time climbing a steep incline in the basement parking of some mall. CVT is not the favorite transmission for people who drive a lot in hilly areas. Conclusion All of these issues are not explained to fear you or the new car buyers. The point is to help you make an informed decision and choose the right transmission by knowing the common issues and maintenance and replacement (in case of failure) cost in advance, or leave these transmissions in the first place if you don’t want to spend hefty money on them. Many people sacrifice the reliability, maintenance cost, fuel economy, less power (transmission power losses) for the ease of driving these transmissions provide when compared to manuals. It all comes down to personal preference.
column2: ifadey: Right now, Mazda is the only Japanese manufacturer who didn't move to CVT or DCT due to reliability issues. They are still using 6 speed autos. but not everyone likes to own a mazda, they use a smallish torque converter and engage its clutch almost too quickly - and then the fact that mazdas are very involved in driving - they provide a lot of road feedback - while most users want a car that floats - mazdas never floated. anyway - CVT are the cheapest transmissions to manufacture and ensure the manufacturer can get ultra great MPG numbers. The manufacturers using CVT dont give a hoot to user experience of it.

column1: I have seen poor owners of AGS, CVT, and DCT based vehicles get shocking surprises during their ownership. They get disappointed after facing issues with these transmissions, and I get sad when I see owners and their transmission failures or when they blame the vehicle for not performing as they intended and the problem was their transmission choice, not the vehicle itself. So, I am writing this to help people make an informed decision about the transmission choice before purchasing a vehicle. 1: Early Transmission Failure These modern automatic transmissions are not as reliable as manual transmission or traditional 4-6 speed automatic transmissions. These new automatics can fail much earlier than you expect. You can prolong the life of the transmission by following some precautionary measures and changing driving behavior, which is different for each type of transmission, hence that's a topic of a different thread. For now, let's focus on ownership shocks. In case of AGS, the clutch plates can fail as early as 20,000-30,000 km. On the positive side, complete transmission failure is not common for AGS. Premature clutch failure can happen with dry clutch DCT as well. Early failures of CVT and DCT are observed between 60,000-100,000 km. You can search the PakWheels forums as a reference. 2: Transmission Repair/Replacement Cost AGS clutch and pressure plates are easily replaceable, and they can be replaced for approx PKR 40,000 from Suzuki dealerships. I am not sure about the complete AGS transmission price since whole transmission failure is not common as mentioned previously. Similarly, clutch replacement for DCT could be done, but I am not sure about the cost. Honda Vezel owners can contribute here. Time will tell how far Changan’s DCT based vehicles can go. When an issue is faced in CVT or DCT, dealerships will ask you to replace the transmission and according to them, it's not repairable and this is an international practice. Usually, dealerships don't repair CVTs and DCTs. New transmission won't be cheap. New Honda Civic CVT cost PKR 700,000 and Alsvin DCT cost PKR 1200,000 at the time of this writing. There are transmission shops outside of Pakistan who rebuild CVTs, but first the shop will access the condition of the damage and provide estimates for labor and parts. Sometimes this cost get closer to new transmission. In such cases, it's better to replace the transmission. I am not aware of any good transmission rebuilding shop in Pakistan. If there's any, do let us know in this thread. 3: Transmission fluid is expensive Gear oil for AGS, DCT and transmission fluid (referring CVTF as gear oil is wrong terminology) for CVT are very expensive when compared to gear oil for manual transmission and ATF for traditional automatics. They usually cost between PKR 7,000 - 15,000 at the time of this writing. Not only that, the frequency of the fluid change for CVT and DCT is much higher than manual transmission. Suzuki AGS and Alsvin DCT gear oil cost PKR 15,000 and Honda HCF-2 costs about PKR 7,000. Toyota CVT fluids also cost close to Honda. 4: DCT heats up in stop & go traffic Usually people complain about transmission heat up issue in Alsvin, but this issue is common in all DCT based vehicles. If you don't let the vehicle release the clutch fully in stop and go driving, the clutch will heat up, and a warning sign will appear in the dashboard cluster. This issue can happen with Suzuki AGS as well, but Suzuki vehicles don't show any heat up indicator in the dashboard cluster. You can avoid this issue by adjusting your driving technique, specially in stop and go traffic. Avoid frequent accelerations and let the distance between your vehicle and the one in front of you increase. This should be done to give the transmission a chance to fully release the clutch. Apart from that, it's better to use manual/sports mode in such situations to avoid frequent changing of gears in stop and go traffic. If you don't use manual mode, the computer will not shift to lower gear and tries to pick speed by slipping the clutch. 5: AGS and DCT are jerky Both AGS and DCT jerk in some driving situations, especially in low gears when you accelerate. It's more noticeable in slow moving traffic where you use brakes/accelerate frequently and specially with hard acceleration. This could be controlled with driving behavior as explained in point 4 above. Using manual mode and light acceleration reduce these jerks and when done properly could be eliminated. Remember, if the gear oil is cold, the jerk will stay no matter how you drive. It goes away once the gear oil warms up and with correct driving techniques. 6: CVT delay in initial acceleration When people move from any other transmission to a CVT based vehicle for the first time, they don't like the initial acceleration of the vehicle. When you press the accelerator, the actual acceleration starts with slight delay. This is known as the rubber band effect. Many manufacturers have fine-tuned their transmissions to reduce this as much as possible. So it depends how much rubber band effect you face based on the vehicle you drive. Some have negligible for a common man, and some have a lot. 7: CVT don't climb hills with ease There are a lot of complaints of fully loaded CVT vehicles not being able to climb very steep hills like Babusar Top in the Kaghan Valley. I remember one owner reported he had a hard time climbing a steep incline in the basement parking of some mall. CVT is not the favorite transmission for people who drive a lot in hilly areas. Conclusion All of these issues are not explained to fear you or the new car buyers. The point is to help you make an informed decision and choose the right transmission by knowing the common issues and maintenance and replacement (in case of failure) cost in advance, or leave these transmissions in the first place if you don’t want to spend hefty money on them. Many people sacrifice the reliability, maintenance cost, fuel economy, less power (transmission power losses) for the ease of driving these transmissions provide when compared to manuals. It all comes down to personal preference.
column2: You need an engine to spin the transmission.

column2: Wait till you see some “driver hazraat” who hold the car on an uphill ascent with the clutch at bite point claiming that they are “saving” the brakes. 🤪 I usually have a special LOL moment when I see people dance the lever side to side to check neutral in order to start the engine, while never pressing in the clutch pedal. To the point that they have the clutch interlock disabled because “kya faltoo system hai” A simple one position check to check for a gear engagement and then out of it confirms neutral position. No need to dance the lever and cause the shift fork detents to work dry.

column2: They are trying to make a jake brake of the engine but actually causing issues because the engine oil will get sucked past the rings into the combustion chamber and being a side canted engine, will falter. Better engine braking can be had by using a very low gear. (1st gear)
