column1: AOA Everyone. I recently purchased Toyota Alpha 2014 (7 seater) model from a relative. The Odo-meter reads about 180K Km s, we imported the car ourselves, so I'm pretty sure about original mileage. Anyways, once I purchased the car, I changed spark plugs, transmission fluid, engine oil, oil filter, air filter and AC filter. The coolant for radiator is still within decent limit. Also got new Michelin tyres 215/65/16 and drive with 31 front and 30 PSI rear wheel air pressure. ( mentioned in the car door along with wheelbase information) Now with regular fuel I’m getting 14km/L, which is low average given my experience with 3rd Gen and 2nd Gen Prius. I was hitting 20+ with my 3rd Gen 1.8 Prius. I asked mechanic and he said that drive few tanks of High Octane and the average will start to improve. I did that, and on High Octane the average (Highway + city), I am getting is around 16.5Km/L or something. I usually drive in city and over the weekend I go to my hometown Okara from Lahore. What else I should look for to improve mileage ?
column2: To address the fuel weeping issue, it's recommended to schedule a diagnostics appointment at Obama Car Care Centre in Tipu Block, Garden Town, by dialing 0321 4106898. The culprit may be a faulty fuel filter in the fuel tank. 2) Prioritize checking the condition of the batteries, especially since you're familiar with Prius operations. This assessment can help determine if the charging or discharging process is functioning correctly. 3) The average fuel efficiency of the Alpha model, as provided by the original equipment manufacturer (OEM), is 17 kilometers per liter. Considering its hybrid nature, anything above 13 kilometers per liter is deemed acceptable. However, factors like size and aerodynamics can lead to a 4 kilometers per liter decrease in fuel efficiency. This information is based on personal experience with the model. 4) Regarding tire size, the 215/65R16 may be too big and heavy. Alternatives like the 205/60R16 or 215/55R16 could be more suitable. 5) Acknowledging a previous mistake, the correct tire size is 215/60/R16. Gratitude is expressed to @capsat for assistance, and the issue will be addressed promptly. 6) An update reveals that after cleaning the throttle and applying grease, fuel consumption has improved. Refueling with RON97 and RON92 yielded mileage of 17KM/L and 20KM/L, respectively, indicating a positive impact on efficiency, especially for daily commuting within Lahore.

column1: Assalam-o-Alaikum. Does the Toyota 3L (2.8L) diesel engine have an EGR valve?
column2: Waalaikum Assalam. EGR, which stands for Exhaust Gas Recirculation, is reliant on the market it operates in. This is because different countries have their own specific emission standards that need to be complied with.

column1: Dear Pakwheelers, -  - I am in need of a wiring diagram for the 4efe 2nd generation model (without crank sensor). I am eagerly awaiting your response. Thank you. -  - Sincerely,
column2: open up the ECU, write down all the pin markings. post here and I'll tag them for what they are, The wiring is simple. btw if your engine is distributor type you have a 4 pole crank sensor but no cam phase or TDC sensor. For a reference. The engine markings you may find 10 - injector batch 1 (ground control) - injectors are fed with 12V positive from the key or main relay. 20 - injector batch 2 (ground control) NE+ - crank sensor NE- crank sensor IGT- Ignitor trigger IGF - Ignitor feedback STA - starter 12V+ signal E1 - main ground lines OX - oxy sensor input HT - oxy sensor heater circuit control to ground (if equipped) RSO - rotary solenoid open RSC - rotary solenoid close (idle control motor, it has 12V+ from main relay or key wiring to the centre pin) PIM - MAP sensor signal THA - air temperature sensor signal THW - water temperature sensor signal VTA - Throttle position sensor signal IDL - idle switch signal in Throttle position sensor W - check engine light ground signal VC - 5V ref for TPS and MAP sensors and heated OXY sensor (if equipped) E01 - sensor ground SPD - vehicle speed BATT - live B+ switch ON AC1 - A/C on signal FC - fuel pump control circuit cant remember more right now, too many phones going off on my desk, grrrrr

column1: Dear Pakwheelers, -  - I am in need of a wiring diagram for the 4efe 2nd generation model (without crank sensor). I am eagerly awaiting your response. Thank you. -  - Sincerely,
column2: Hello everyone, hope you're all having a good day. Could someone here please help me understand Pin # 20, Connector 1 of the 4EFE ECU box? This pin is marked as the Radiator Fan relay. I would like to know more about it. -  - Here is the pinout for the 4E-FE ECU: - - Pin 1 (RSC Gray): Rotary Solenoid Close - Cold Idle Speed Control - - Pin 2 (NSW Red): Neutral Starter Switch - - Pin 3 (THW Green-Black): Water Temperature Signal - - Pin 4 (PIM LightGreen): Pressure Intake Manifold - - Pin 5 (THA LightGreen-Black): Intake Air Temperature - - Pin 6 (IGT Black-White): Ignition Timing - - Pin 7 (IGF Yellow): Ignition Feedback from the ignitor coil - - Pin 8 (IGF Yellow): Ignition Feedback from the ignitor coil - - Pin 9 (NE- Blue): Part of the IIA (Integrated Ignition Assembly) - - Pin 10 (OX White): Oxygen Sensor (Lambda Sensor) - - Pin 11 (STA Red(M/T) or Red-White(A/T)): Engine Cranking Signal (Starter Switch) - - Pin 12 (#10 Green): Injector Pulse 1 & 3 - - Pin 13 (E01 White-Black): Computer Ground - - Pin 14 (RSO Black-Red): Rotary Solenoid - Cold Idle Speed Control - - Pin 15 (HT Pink-Blue): Heated Oxygen Sensor - - Pin 16 (E2 Brown-White): Sensor Ground - - Pin 17 (PSW Yellow-Red): Throttle Position Sensor (pin 3) - - Pin 18 (VCC LightGreen-Red): Throttle Position Sensor (pin 1) - - Pin 19 (IDL ~): Throttle Position Sensor (Signals ECU throttle position is at idle) - - Pin 20 (FAN Unknown): Radiator Fan Relay - - Pin 21 (NE Green): RPM Signal - - Pin 22 (ELS3 ~): ~ - - Pin 23 (IPV ~): Vacuum Switching Valve - - Pin 24 (E1 Brown): Computer Ground - - Pin 25 (#20 Yellow): Injector Pulse 2 & 4 - - Pin 26 (~ ~ ~): ~ -  - I am currently using a 4EFE, 2nd generation engine from the 4EA carb type. The issue I am facing is that my Thermo-switch is malfunctioning. Even when the engine is cold, the radiator fan sometimes turns on. I have already checked and confirmed that the Thermo-switch is the problem. My question is, can I use Pin # 20 to control my cooling fan?

column2: RN427;3888930: Hello Pakwheelers!!! Today I also went to change tyres for my new Honda City 2013 White but sadly couldn't find the ASAD TYRES SHOP...Went to 2 other shops in Saddar, Rawalpindi, well don't remember the shop's names but I came to know that they were selling Yoko A-Drive, C-Drive and AVS DB V550 (All Japanese)...When I asked about ADVAN DB they say that this tyre is very short in the market so didn't wasted even one second more of my life for the thing which I can not find from the other millions of shops in Saddar, Rawalpindi!!! Now guys just want to know from you guys...If you can help your brother seeking little assistance from you all...One tyre shop quoted me price of Yoko AVS DB 195/65R15 Rs.7,400...I just want to know that is this price correct or it is less because I guess an AVS DB can not be that much cheap because it is a very superior tyre...I mean it would be around Rs.8,800 to Rs.9,000...Why he said me so less price I mean is it smuggled or fake or what...Please help me get out of this dilemma!!! Thanks i have no idea why u didnt find Asad tyres in sadar....its very very simple in direction....coming from GHQ side on murree road, take the FOURTH left turn (the one approx 50 meters after the KFC junction). once u have turned left, asad tyres is about 200 meters ahead onto ur right. now how difficult can that be ??? secondly, the size you are looking for 195/65 is too big for the car. it exceeds 3% allowable tyre difference. either stick with 195/60 or 185/65...no other size. would badly affect ur fuel economy and meter reading

column1: Aoa PakWheelers, I need bit of advice, I am thinking of upgrading sound system of my Corolla GLi 2015, it has stock speakers and a nightmare of a head unit installed which will not allow me to listen anything. Its touch system is so bad that you cannot listen to a song through the list. I have added photos for your reference. What I already have which I want to put into my car: 1. Kenwood Old Amp KAC-8401 640W max power 2. Kenwood two KFC HQ-718 (Originals which I had in my Suzuki Cultus in 2007-8) I love them.... What I need: 1. Names of few good online shops of Pakistan who sell original products and charge a reasonable price. I am based in Bahawalpur so I am going to place the order online. 2. I need 2 x front speakers suggestions, I only have https://shaharyartraders.com/7 and https://sehgalmotors.pk3 who I think are reasonable online stores. In my experience Karachi is best for variety and availability of good quality original electronic gadgets, products etc. 3. I would request if anyone can put me through to a good store who sells online. Summary again: Need to buy a head unit for Toyota Corolla GLI 2015 - (Android Auto and Apple Car Play) 2 x front door speakers who can fit into the door holes and produce good acceptable sound my budget is around 10-15K for speakers and 20 - 25K for a head unit. I will be very thankful for your advice. I am newbie so any advise for me is truly valuable and save me from trouble. Best Regards Farhan Maqbool Bahawalpur +923218680600(WhatsApp)

column1: Salam Pak wheelers. Could some one give me information about the honda civic exi engine. And whats about the modifying chips that are replaced in the modulator that increases the performance of the cars? would appreciate your feedback.
column2: It is a 1500cc, 4-cylinder, 16-valve SOHC engine that produces a maximum of 110 horsepower at 5800 rpm and a maximum torque of 135 Nm. I am not aware of any modifications involving chips.

column1: Friends, the injector of my Baleno 2003 is not working. There is proper current on the plug, but disconnecting it does not have any effect on the car. I have removed the injector and manually tested it, and it is working fine. I have also tried replacing it with another injector in the same position and it is working fine. The issue is only with that specific location. But the current supply is adequate.
column2: If you know injector is ok and wiring as well then check the spark.

column1: Hi. First post I believe. Ive been a long time lurker here. So here's the deal, I have a City 2004, manual. And the road and especially the engine noise lately has started to drive me crazy. You can hear the engine over the stereo as soon as the revs hit 2.5 and above. And the road noise on 60kph and above is quite loud as well. Gets insane on speeds above 80. Drives me crazy, and is generally very very irritating. So basically Im looking for someone here in Islamabad or Pindi who could sound-proof this thing. Suggestions please? Any people you know who do this here? How much am I looking at in terms of 'kharcha'?
column2: F10 Markaz - A few shops do it but they are unprofessional with big claims and crappy work. They use Chinese sheets which they sell for the same price as Infinity and Caliber sheets but get the job done Disco Music Blue Area - Havn't installed anything from them but they had CV sheets for 2.5k each. Thats a bit steep Sound Valley Pindi Saddar - Good stock, very professional ( owner is a member here and has done some crazy ICE installs ) I do most of the sound deadening myself because it's not that hard to do. I've mentioned this in quite a few threads now so this info should be easily found

column1: Hi, I wondered if anyone knew that if a 2003 vti oriel manual ecu can be repaired. There was a short circuit and stupid electrician removed a fused which kept blowing and made it direct. That small problem turned big with smoke from the engine wiring. I got wiring working again but the ecu doesn't seem to be working normally, there is no visible sign(No burning smell or burned circuit)though the circuit solding seems to be affected a little. IS it repairable? And is it possible to use a automatic civic ecu.My mechanic said that he connected a auto one and started the engine it worked but I was wondering will it create some problem? Thanx!

column1: Hi, I wondered if anyone knew that if a 2003 vti oriel manual ecu can be repaired. There was a short circuit and stupid electrician removed a fused which kept blowing and made it direct. That small problem turned big with smoke from the engine wiring. I got wiring working again but the ecu doesn't seem to be working normally, there is no visible sign(No burning smell or burned circuit)though the circuit solding seems to be affected a little. IS it repairable? And is it possible to use a automatic civic ecu.My mechanic said that he connected a auto one and started the engine it worked but I was wondering will it create some problem? Thanx!

column2: I had this experience ecu of my civic exi burnt or something but visibly its ok if we start car rpm was not stable and jumping up and down after alot of magahz mari finally ecu was the culprit I got one for 25k for pkdm civic from a guy whose new exi got accidented I did search for some repair guys and gave to bilal electrician on railway road saddar rwp he couldnt fix it too and i ended up buying that ecu for 25k I also searched for kabli ones they were for jdm cars and they didnt work too as they were for auto and always showed checkengine light I still have that ecu lying around Sent from my iPhone using Tapatalk

column1: Yesterday while I was at A/C workshop to refill R134 gas in my Khyber (the gas was discharged during engine rebuilt) the A/C mechanic suggested to install a relay with radiator fan. Now the functionality is as under: When A/C is ON: Radiator fan is ON, with an increased speed (fan RPM) When A/C is OFF: Radiator fan is automatic with normal speed. The battery of my car is new. AGS-50 bought last month. I conducted some tests with a digital multi-meter. Battery voltage (overnight): 12.55 volts Alternator voltage when car is idling with no load: 14.2 volts Voltage with headlights only: 14.03 volts Voltage with A/C only (blower at speed 3) : 13.93 volts Voltage with headlights and A/C: 12.31 volts Voltage with headlight (high beam) + A/C + radio: 12.22 volts. All the readings are at CNG and idle. I wanted to know that 12.22 volts is Okay under full load? The last battery of my car lasted 4 years and seven months.
column2: add a grounding strap to the alternator case and also make sure your engine is properly grounded. Loss of ground will cause silly problems on the alternator. You mention the mitsubishi alternator boiling the battery over, this happens when a self exciting 2 wire type alternator is used and the sense wire is connected to the ignition switch. This causes voltage drop and the alternator never sees proper battery voltage and proceeds to murder the battery. The original alty in your car is a small 40A mitsubishi unit (car with FF A/C unit) with 3 wires which are the big B+ , one lamp and one switch (which is wired through a fuse and also acts as sense) the very early SA310 and swift had a hitachi 35A alternator

column2: speedster_101;5088517: The following picture shows my alternator with front and back view.  this is called 3 wire type, the stud and nut take the battery cable, the connector has switched power and lamp. a wire type only has a battery stud and a lamp wire, Some old mitsubishi 3 wire type take the "S" wire from a relay in the engine room or directly tapped to the B+ lug. you will need to add a grounding strap the mounting lug on this alternator.

column2: what is your idling speed? on suzuki khyber its 950 rpm in any condition, that means, adjust the load vacuum pod that it only raises it back to 950 rpm and adjust your A/C one that it keeps idling rpm on 950. Rpm increase should be only to "compensate" the load and raise to original value not overshoot it.

Sent from my D2502 using PW Forums mobile app suzuki 3s are morons if they did this, when the car was new it was set as I mentioned. Its very easy to adjust it though.

column2: speedster_101;5090837: I am not sure about 950 RPM because the car doesn't have RPM meter and the mechanic also does not have gun. Yes, when there is some electrical load, the RPM drops and this increase in RPM should be just to take it back to normal RPM but this is not how its working right now. The RPM shoots when the headlights, blower, defogger or radiator fan is ON. Since the vacuum solenoid is working now, I will take the car to some mechanic who has gun and will ask him to set 950 RPM under load and no-load conditions. But only a few mechanics have that gun, rest all adjust RPM by guess. a multimeter that can read Hz can be your rpm meter for setting idle speed.

column1: Assalamualaikum! I recently had problem in my BMW X1. I fuelled up my car with super from PSO defence main boulevard and went to office. Usually i always filled the car with high octane ron 97 but this time since they did not had it and my car was empty, i had to fill it up. But before doing so i emptied an entire bottle of octane booster of ’STP’ brand in the fuel tank. The car drove normal until the reserve light came on, then the knocking started. At first i thought it was not a biggie. But then after i went and parked at home, the car wouldn’t start. When i would hit engine start button , engine would start for 2 seconds then shut down immediately. I kept repeating this and engine kept shutting down. I didn’t know what to do so i called DEWAAN BMW MOTORS office in Lahore. Told them about the situation, they said they would need to get it checked and i would need to send the car to their showroom through carriage. When I asked them to send their technician, they refused, saying that they did not had relevant equipment fpr mobile workshop. So i asked another mechanic INH EXPRESS near airport road to come and check. Preliminary investigation revealed that their was some problem with piston. I couldn't believe it so I sent the car to their workshop. Turns out, 1 of the 3 piston was damaged beyond repair! I was SHOCKED! My car had only +22,000 kms on it, it was only 2 years old! So i called DEWAN MOTORS once again and apprised them about the situation. They told me that they cannot do anything without looking at the car themselves. Meaning, i would have to ask INH EXPRESS to close up my engine and send the car to them so they can come to same conclusion. I asked them about spare parts, if they had any pistons available, to my surprise, they did NOT had any parts! What kind of after sale service is this? They sold thousand of cars and still did not had any spare party in inventory? I was told that the showroom would have to order parts from Germany! Since my brother already had a bad experience with them earlier, they took very long and charges were too high, I asked INH EXPRESS to order them and fix my car. It took 2 months for me to drive again and i had to pay roughly 325k! I was so enthusiastic to buy X1 as i’m an old BMW fan. But this incident and the pathetic service has taught me a lesson! I would HIGHLY advise everyone NOT to buy BMW from Dewan motors to avoid sheer disappointment and despair in future! I can’t seem digest the fact that why do they still have the agency? How can a dealership function without spare parts? I will also write to BMW head quarter and apprise them of this situation. How can we expect to enjoy this machine with this kind of service? Simply deplorable!
column2: I have seen faliures of a lot of bmw, gm and toyota engines with the variable type oil pumps, the damage is not due to wrong fuel unless you fill it with 75 octane fuel, it wont even run smoothly after that, that stp octane booster is a joke. Never use that even in a cheap brand. It can severely damage stuff. The ecu literally signals the half check light and shuts off boost build from the turbocharger (wastegate wide open) and kills valvetronic too (if equipped) and goes to throttle blade mode. As soon as knock while running is detected. The knock you heard was probably the connecting rod slapping around due to oil starvation, bmw n55 are also seeing this even after oil change done by idiots. The filter is installed dry on those engines, or you can have an airbubble in the oil filter can or the pump itself (same issue as 5cyl ford pickup engine from turkey). Or you tried to follow euro oil change interval in Pakistan and sludged the engine. The damage was already there, what you heard was the final call of death. The knock you heard was mechanical not spark knock. Bmw sell the pistons in complete sets only, if the crank is salvageable, rebuild it and install new timing casette too. Make sure to replace all bolts with new and make sure the workshop knows what to do, there is no timing mark on these engines, they are held in time by friction only which require tooling to lock timing and huge tools to tighten. Make sure shop has tools to work on the cyl head too (it can be removed as one piece but is difficult) Or just sell the vehicle and write off your loss as local agents dewan are "dewanay" even if you got the parts their techs wouldnt know their ass from their elbow, forget fix

column2: Its not new, its pretty old to be honest, these engines use diamond encrusted washers between the timing sprockets where they mount to crank and cam, and of course some massive tty bolts. Torque and yield loss is very critical here along with replacement of these when disturbed. Even the old mazda mzr/ford duratec is setup the same, Vry simple to build, install timing tools, hang chain over sprockets etc, spin up screws till contact, install tensioner, pull locking pin, torque down bolts, apply torque to yield loss angle to bolt. And job done. Engine timed dead zero degrees perfect.

column2: To loosen the main crank bolt on a BMW, you need to apply a force exceeding 450 lb/ft. Similarly, when working on the oil pump drives of older Nissan V8 engines, you will require a large 3/4 drive socket and counterholders.

It took 2 months for me to drive again and i had to pay roughly 325k! I was so enthusiastic to buy X1 as i’m an old BMW fan. But this incident and the pathetic service has taught me a lesson! I would HIGHLY advise everyone NOT to buy BMW from Dewan motors to avoid sheer disappointment and despair in future! I can’t seem digest the fact that why do they still have the agency? How can a dealership function without spare parts? I will also write to BMW head quarter and apprise them of this situation. How can we expect to enjoy this machine with this kind of service? Simply deplorable!
column2: and also have a delusion that lexus work perfectly with zero maintenance.. Its really funny and LOL moment to see people literally have stroke when looking at parts invoices for toyota genuine spare parts - specially lexus specific parts like LS460 suspension bushings etc (which it eats like free candy)

column1: Assalamualaikum! I recently had problem in my BMW X1. I fuelled up my car with super from PSO defence main boulevard and went to office. Usually i always filled the car with high octane ron 97 but this time since they did not had it and my car was empty, i had to fill it up. But before doing so i emptied an entire bottle of octane booster of ’STP’ brand in the fuel tank. The car drove normal until the reserve light came on, then the knocking started. At first i thought it was not a biggie. But then after i went and parked at home, the car wouldn’t start. When i would hit engine start button , engine would start for 2 seconds then shut down immediately. I kept repeating this and engine kept shutting down. I didn’t know what to do so i called DEWAAN BMW MOTORS office in Lahore. Told them about the situation, they said they would need to get it checked and i would need to send the car to their showroom through carriage. When I asked them to send their technician, they refused, saying that they did not had relevant equipment fpr mobile workshop. So i asked another mechanic INH EXPRESS near airport road to come and check. Preliminary investigation revealed that their was some problem with piston. I couldn't believe it so I sent the car to their workshop. Turns out, 1 of the 3 piston was damaged beyond repair! I was SHOCKED! My car had only +22,000 kms on it, it was only 2 years old! So i called DEWAN MOTORS once again and apprised them about the situation. They told me that they cannot do anything without looking at the car themselves. Meaning, i would have to ask INH EXPRESS to close up my engine and send the car to them so they can come to same conclusion. I asked them about spare parts, if they had any pistons available, to my surprise, they did NOT had any parts! What kind of after sale service is this? They sold thousand of cars and still did not had any spare party in inventory? I was told that the showroom would have to order parts from Germany! Since my brother already had a bad experience with them earlier, they took very long and charges were too high, I asked INH EXPRESS to order them and fix my car. It took 2 months for me to drive again and i had to pay roughly 325k! I was so enthusiastic to buy X1 as i’m an old BMW fan. But this incident and the pathetic service has taught me a lesson! I would HIGHLY advise everyone NOT to buy BMW from Dewan motors to avoid sheer disappointment and despair in future! I can’t seem digest the fact that why do they still have the agency? How can a dealership function without spare parts? I will also write to BMW head quarter and apprise them of this situation. How can we expect to enjoy this machine with this kind of service? Simply deplorable!

column2: ^ Mulitiple sources can fed the single load. Most of the UPS are not online means they swithced between Comercial Suppliy & Battery depending on conditions( Online UPS are exception) How ever in auto mobiles alternator & Battery are conected in very simple fashion & battery acts as online source. Since the alternator have relatively higher out put voltage so its takes the load wen engine is running but in case of poor alternator Battery shud be consumed in parallel.

column1: Assalam-o-Alaikum, I own a 2010 Suzuki Bolan. Can anyone assist me in determining the ratings of the alternator/generator installed in my vehicle, specifically the voltage and amperage? Thank you in advance. Regards, Roy Zafar.
column2: talhawaleed;3509319: Battery and alternator is wired in such a way, once alternator will kick inn then it will always charge the battery. True in case if the alternator is healthy but if the out put voltage of alternator some how got reduced then of battery Voltage then it will not charge it. follow this [LIST=1] [*]Once load is connected with battery then electrons moves from negatively charged terminal, through wires then into load then back into positively charged terminal. [*]What happens during charging [*]Polarity is reversed. How the polarity is reversed? Polarity never reversed Just the flow of Electron reverse due to Diffrence in potential during Charge & Discharge Cycle. [*]Current flows from alternator to negative terminal of battery then through electrolyte( chemical reactions which takes place) then comes out from positive terminal of battery and back to alternator . [/LIST] In no case do the two power supplies work simultaneously Mulitiple Power Sources (Source type cud be the same or diffrent) Can fed the same load if their out put volatges are same, Let me qoute u typical Example of Auto mobiles. Regardless of the size alternator & Battery a good Alternator shud gives 13.8~14.1 volts to charge the Battery This much volatge is required becoz a 12V Battery is designed to e operate at more than 13 Volts & Health battery shud miantain atleast 13.5 V float Voltage, Now typicall case found in Cars with weak alterantor which wud have definately be experienced by most us, "The car works almost fine in day time & some how Battery is also got charged but in night Wen car is used with head lights ON for a long period the battery got discharged & car disnt crancked at next sart up" So wat happens then is the Weak alterantor May be Giving out put ~12 V Maintans Float volatge ~12V on battery Which is considered to be poor charged Condition. Then wen we put extra load like Head lights etc On in that case Out put Voltage of alternator got droped further & in that case Battery is being cosumed parallel with in such cases Extensive use use may led to deep discharged Battery

column2: ceecix;3494834: The output of alternator is tested by switching ON an engine, it should read around 13.8 to 14 volts, amps depends on your alternator, mehran usually have a 40 amp alternator so then bolan will also have something closer, the volts of alternator must be higher then battery so that once engine have started then current will be drawn for higher output source that should be the alternator or else all of the battery will be consumed, . higher output source, who told you that. its fine but concept can be corrected. can we have two different sources operating simultaneously. once alternator kicks inn then it charges the battery while also powering every electrical equipment. once alternator is gone then battery takes entire load just like a UPS system. like once WAPDA line is on then we are not taking any thing from battery but we definetly are charging it. then once wapda is goes then UPS batteries kicks inn.

column1: As the title suggests I am interested in taking my car (2009 Corolla 2.0d) to a reliable workshop in Karachi to check out its suspension and power steering rack/assembly. For the past several weeks I have heard a faint sound coming from the front right hand side of the car but only when driving over a bad or rough patch of road. I don't THINK its the suspension. I have a feeling something is not right with the steering rack/assembly as the car tends to drift towards the left even though I recently had the alignment redone. Several months ago the front right tyre went into an open manhole at some speed. The impact was enough to slightly bend the rim (stock toyota rim) of the front right tyre. At the time everything else seemed fine with the car so I had the rim replaced (eventually bought new tyres too) and continued driving without any problems. But now I feel that I sometimes hear a sound coming from the same area which took the impact many months ago. Can't describe the sound exactly. Not like something is obviously broken because the sound is not continuous. Sounds almost as if something is loose and needs tightening. The reason I feel it could be the steering rack is because a few times I have felt a slight vibration in the steering wheel. Click here for SOLUTION249 Any tips on what to look out for or recommendations of mechanics/workshops who would be good with this type of thing?
column2: The one we all trust is Afzal from Lines Area. You can reach him at 0300 211 60 69.

column1: aoa a friend of has recently purchased a mark x but his navigation system is in japnese so he wanted to know can he change language to english. Mark X owners help him out. Thanks
column2: Ok try one thing. Not sure if work, but worth a try. Go to some online English-Japanese translation site. Write the world English and get it translated in Japanese. 3. Now take a print out of the result and open the navigation screen of your vehicle. Try to find a similar word in different menu screens If you see a matching word press it. If the navigation system comes in different languages, it should change. If it comes only in Japanese (one language) then you cannot. You can also get Japanese words for language, settings etc and find them in your navigation system, I hope it works. I don't understand why people are charging so much just for clicking a menu in the navigation system to change the language.

column1: My Mini Pajero does not accelerate in winter even when I give full throttle. Someone said it's an issue with leaked head (and showed me a dent on the engine). I replaced 660cc engine with 1100cc along with 'lacchay' ). But in winter even 1100 cc engine does not pick. Keeps going on 20km per hour with full accelerator. When it picks some speed then there is a turn, speed breaker or signal and I am back to 20km per hour for next couple of minutes. Some mechanic did something with computer setting and it improved for some time but now back to the same state. I always use 'L' gear to start from zero instead of 'D'. Due to the same reason I put right foot on accelerator and left on break . Can an expert just let me know what can be the REAL issue and what needs to be looked at. Thank you.
column2: Please share the scan tool data and error codes.

column1: How good are Valvoline Lubes? currently im using Petromin and not satisfied was thinking to switch to Mobil but received e-mail from Valvoline dealer so thought lets give it a try? SOLUTION26

column1: How good are Valvoline Lubes? currently im using Petromin and not satisfied was thinking to switch to Mobil but received e-mail from Valvoline dealer so thought lets give it a try? SOLUTION26
column2: wasay_ahmed;3176760: they havent introduced coolant asper their leaflets. 3 4 grades on diesel engine oil n only 1 grade of Gasoline oil. yet im staisfied wth response.Ideling has improved specialy it use to create loud sound on cold start now better. @cummins gensets dont hav good experience wth those we prefer Caterpillar n use OEM lubes parts etc I have the opposite in diesel experience - cummins are pretty beefy engines, I mean just look at the their BT engines, the old ones which displace 1000cc per cylinder, their connecting rods are the size of my forearms. with extra meaty cross sections. They are a little finicky with their fuel injection system but if you get some literature and proper tools its not all that hard. btw - too bad they are not selling any of their coolants, which makes me believe they are nothing more than a khaipya system, They should be able to get coolant for you if they are authorised valvoline distributors of Pakistan.

column1: How good are Valvoline Lubes? currently im using Petromin and not satisfied was thinking to switch to Mobil but received e-mail from Valvoline dealer so thought lets give it a try? SOLUTION26
column2: for your 70cc motorcycles, a bare minimum grade engine oil is required - something like API-SF with a viscosity of minimum 20 - not lower than that or you might hear timing chain noise. if the carburettor is in proper tune and not stupidly fiddled with to run rich - the oil change interval should be at 2000 kms - not more, and where do you get your 19 motorcycles maintained?

column1: How good are Valvoline Lubes? currently im using Petromin and not satisfied was thinking to switch to Mobil but received e-mail from Valvoline dealer so thought lets give it a try? SOLUTION26
column2: wasay_ahmed;3179892: Yea fueling is big time issue in Cummins. A bit feasable only on full load a used JDM denyo , Aktio, nippon denso genset specialy for small requirements are best option.We have some trained cummins engineer atound in Pak who are also on Payrole on Pakistan Navy but he even failed to proper tune a little 65KVA genset which is coupled wth Garret turbine LING LING adjusting the injectors on a cummins is fiddly business no doubt but when the engine is adjusted nicely nothing torques like a cummins. There are some cummins guys who can tune your engine, ask DPS, they are authorised cummins and Bosch repair centres. Adjusting a cummins has 0% tolerance of shortcut or feel aka andaaza. And it bites back if you ignore this. In Pakistan it is nearly mandatory to add some fuel stabliser to the diesel tank to keep moisture in control.

column1: How good are Valvoline Lubes? currently im using Petromin and not satisfied was thinking to switch to Mobil but received e-mail from Valvoline dealer so thought lets give it a try? SOLUTION26
column2: DANY_KHANN;3194459: I got all 19 of it maintained at a local motor cycle workshop but i am not satisfied with the work he do so might be changing the workshop in little while. Can you suggest me a brand name for oil? Hire a good workshop to repair your bikes and make sure they follow correct repair procedures even involving proper sealants, you should buy a case of spray chain lubricant and have someone/riders spray it on the chain every 2 weeks for proper service life. Similarly a small supply of WD40 and some proper degreaser and shampoo will keep the bikes like new. For oils buy an old 20 litre oil bottle/drum - and get it filled at a proper licensed depot with the oil brand of your choice bearing oil quality marking of API SG 20W50, caltex, Total, Shell all sell it. It will be considerably cheaper than buying small bottles. You can even get wholesale prices for disposable spares if you are constantly maintaining them e.g. air filter, gasket sets, clutch friction set, chain case, brake shoes, buffers, bulbs, lens covers. But it all depends on how you have your system setup, If its all dependant on mechanic ustaad then there is a pretty high chance that your parts will get nicked.

column1: How good are Valvoline Lubes? currently im using Petromin and not satisfied was thinking to switch to Mobil but received e-mail from Valvoline dealer so thought lets give it a try? SOLUTION26
column2: The oil filter you are showing is either old stock picked from a liquidation of a dealership or not genuine, this packaging and sticker shape was used in the mid 90's when the filters were supplied by various vendors including life, union <<--(the best), all filters produced after 2005 should say made in Thailand or Made in China. and have a slimmer sticker. Some original batches even have the instructions etc as a sticker pasted on the filter. For correct filters I would suggest you pool in or buy yourself an entire case of MANN, Donaldson, Fleetguard etc. oil filters for your engine. You will know the difference. and btw 2500 kms is nothing to measure - even "qadeem" oils dont breakdown till 4000 kms, also your engine should slightly consume oil, about a cup every 5000 kms at least, otherwise I would go about checking why it is not.

column1: How can I know if the release/throw-out bearing is in contact with the pressure plate all the time i.e spinning continously even when the clutch pedal is fully released?
column2: It only spins when you press in the clutch.

column1: How can I know if the release/throw-out bearing is in contact with the pressure plate all the time i.e spinning continously even when the clutch pedal is fully released?
column2: If your clutch is all the up, it usually means you are at wear limit of the friction plate and yes the bearing can be spinning in this case if the setting is so bad that the clutch never fully releases.

column1: How can I know if the release/throw-out bearing is in contact with the pressure plate all the time i.e spinning continously even when the clutch pedal is fully released?
column2: a worm out thrust bearing will be very noisy. That worn bearing can produce rattling noises. These noises are most noticeable when the clutch pedal is pressed down. Difficulty changing gears – If the bearing lacks proper lubrication, the clutch may not fully release, resulting in difficulty shifting gears.

column1: How can I know if the release/throw-out bearing is in contact with the pressure plate all the time i.e spinning continously even when the clutch pedal is fully released?
column2: what car do you have? hydraulic or cable type clutch?

column1: How can I know if the release/throw-out bearing is in contact with the pressure plate all the time i.e spinning continously even when the clutch pedal is fully released?
column2: theres a level on your gearbox, that attaches to clutch cable. that cable goes to the clutch pedal. keep your car in neutral adjust your cable so that its loose, and lever is in its original position. at that original position the bearing is not rotating. if its still rotating at that point, you have damaged/bent components. then you can start tightening the cable to where you find your preferable driving position. not exactly sure, but adjustments should be possible both at lever end and clutch pedal end.

column1: How can I know if the release/throw-out bearing is in contact with the pressure plate all the time i.e spinning continously even when the clutch pedal is fully released?
column2: how many times you have to turn it will be based on Feel. as one cannot judge how much deformation is there in the lever or how much the cable is stretched out, or even if the cable is an incorrect part.... etc also check at the clutch pedal. freeplay is normally set at the clutch pedal.

column1: How can I know if the release/throw-out bearing is in contact with the pressure plate all the time i.e spinning continously even when the clutch pedal is fully released?
column2: But let's say if there's zero freeplay in clutch, then won't the bearing spin even when clutch pedal is all the way up? Basically I want to know if there is any relation between freeplay adjustment and the clearance between this bearing and pressure plate when clutch is all the way up

column1: My khyber (on CNG)' 99 is consuming oil about 1 litre every 1000km. Things i have done already: 1. Ensured that all seals are OK. Replaced main seal of engine and O ring at distributor. No more oil leaks. 2. Observed car on cold start, very very little blue smoke/smoke - indicating valve seals are OK. 3. Observed exhaust, no smell of Oil burning. But smell of CNG. 4. Switched to Petrol, observed exhaust again, no smell of oil but steam like exhaust. In my opinion, engine is now weak and consuming oil slowly. I am using shell 10w40. I was wondering if I can use 10w40 along with 20w50 in 50 50% quantity. Because I have read that 20w50 causes wear n tear to engine in long run. What do u guys suggest? Also advice if shall use shell fully synthetic? @xulfiqar , the guru bhai. @all
column2: Driver41;4627728: Problem is that 20w50 causes wear n tear in long run. And on cold start, 20w50 causes more damage as compared to 10w40. Thats why I am not using 20w50. Btw thanks for the input. 20-50w oil will protect your engine from wear and tear yes becoz of 20-50w your car will perform less as compared to 10-40w,20-40w and pour lil less oil e.g if you pour 3.5l pour 3l it will prevent seal form leaking

column2: The Khyber manual recommends using semi-synthetic 10w-40 SG grade oil, with a caution not to exceed SL grade. You can also use 5w-40 oil if you prefer. However, it is important to note that 20w-50 oil is too thick for use during cold starts. If you really need to use a 50 weight oil, it is advised to choose 10w-50 or 5w-50 options instead.

column1: Hey every one! Assalamo Alikum! most of the accidents occur cause of faulty brakes!i tried to search for a thread abt the best brake pads on pw but could nt find any satisfactory answer, so i decided to start this thread for the benefit of all! can you share your experience abt the brake pads in your car. please also state the price and place you ve bought your brake pads from! Also abt the quality and performance as 2 no quality is so much prevailent! Share your experience abt the best brtands you ve come across. in my opinion some good brands in desending order are sumitomo(suzuki genuine ones) Asuki 3 MK TRW chineese Local brands ( totally unreliable) Now there are other brands like Hawk, brembo and monroe but i dont think that they are availible in Pakistan, or are they?:S Also any one having experience of ceramic brake pads, share please! Thanx
column2: buy good quality brake parts - always. And whenever you change your brake hardware be sure that you yourself buy some Antisieze for the back of the pads/shoes high temp silicone based grease or similar for the sliders and anti-rattle clips Flush brake fluid (takes about 2 bottles in a largish jap sedan) as the system is not cyclic (looped) the worn out brake fluid sits near the brake calipers/piston eating them away. Takes one empty jam jar - a hole in it the lid a piece of brake pipe leading to the bottom, some clear pipe, grease and some slow pumping for about 5 minutes on each wheel. And if your favorite mechanic does not have a large G clamp to push the brake pistons back into the calipers - make a deal in supplying him one or buy one for yourself and make him use it anytime he does a brake job on your car - The screwdriver technique usually used rips the protective dust boot on the piston

column1: This very good atricle was written by Omer Saleem, i am posting it here with his permission Quite recently I experienced a strange rise in transmission problems with most Toyotas running on the Super CVT-I transmission. I did some research and what I ended up discovering was shocking if nothing else. Most mechanics would not even know that these transmissions DO NOT run on Toyota T-IV or Toyota WS oil but instead require the TOYOTA CVT-TC oil and then there was the common problem I heard that the oil mysteriously disappears from most cars. However now that I have done my research that’s not true at all, infact the prime reason in most transmission failures is that the mechanics end up over filling the chamber, thus damaging the internal gearbox and pump seals. Here is what actually happened with my Belta 2 days ago: When you open up the drain plug for any of the K-series CVT transmissions which Toyota is putting in most of its newer models, only about 500ml or less of the transmission fluid drains out, leading one to believe that the transmission was running without oil, but that is absolutely not the case. The drain plug has an internal drain tube which extends about a little more than 2 inches inside the chamber, this causes the oil level to just drop till the mouth of this tube and hence the mystery disappearance behind the transmission oil. In order to fully drain the transmission oil, you will need to open up the oil chamber and drain out the fluid. This will also require you to replace the two gaskets which are firmly placed on top of the chamber. After completely draining the oil, about 3.8-4.0 liters of oil is taken up by the transmission. Then to make matters worse, Toyota hasn’t really provided with a dipstick or a gauge to check the level of the transmission fluid. The mechanics even at Toyota Southern argued that the side housing nut is the correct place to feed oil from and that it should be filled unless it levels off around that point. The truth is that if you do end up filling to that level you would be over-filling the chamber with about 3.5 liters of transmission oil and that can cause some serious irreparable damage. The correct way to fill the transmission fluid is via the oil feed port shown in the pictures attached below.My Belta had gone through all of the above but some timely research saved the car. I have also attached some detailed pictures and descriptions for the transmission oil change procedure. Last but not the least, the issue can potentially affect all Toyota CVT transmission system manufactured by AISIN. The following are the vehicle models and transmissions which might be affected by the same problem. This bulletin concerns the following Toyota models and transmission codes : Transmission Codes: K110, K111, K111F, K112, K112F, K210, P210, K310, K311, K311F, K410, K41A.  List of Toyota Super- CVT Models:  Aisis: ANM10G, ANM10W, ANM15G, ANM15W Allion: AZT240, ZRT260, ZRT261, ZRT265, NZT260 Alphard: ATH10W, ANH20W, ANH25W Auris: ZRE152H, NZE151H, ZRE154H, NZE154H Belta: SCP92, KSP92 Blade: AZE156H, AZE154H Corolla Axio: ZRE142, NZE141, ZRE144, NZE144 Corolla Fielder: ZRE142G, NZE141G, ZRE144G, NZE144G Corolla Rumion: ZRE152N, NZE151N, ZRE154N Estima: AHR10W, ACR50W, ACR55W iQ: KGJ-10 Ist: NCP110, NCP115 Mark X Zio: ANA10, ANA15 Noah: ZRR70W, ZRR70G, ZRR75W, ZRR75G, ZAR60G, ZAR65G Opa: ACT10 Premio: AZT240, ZRT260, ZRT261, ZRT265, NZT260 Ractis: NCP100, SCP100 RAV-4: ACA36W, ACA31W Sienta: NCP81G Vanguard: ACA38W, ACA33W Vitz: NCP91, SCP90, KSP90, SCP13 Voxy: ZRR70W, ZRR70G, ZRR75W, ZRR75G, ZAR60G, ZAR65G Wish: ZGE21G, ZGE22W, ZGE20G, ZGE20W, ZGE25G, ZGE25W, ANE11W, ANE10G
column2: you can achieve this by unscrewing the tube from the pan only, thats how I did it - no need to replace the gasket or open up the oil sump. Someone PMed me about the change and I advised the same. you use the same allen key in the tube that you used to remove the main sump plug, unless someone has broken it internally. The first car I ever changed the fluid on was a Belta and Toyota Eastern Motors had filled it to the brim, it had severe slippage issues. the good part of removing the pan is that you can clean out the swarf in it and replace the filter too, BUT PLEASE make sure that NOTHING and absolultely nothing contaminates the transmission, not even fine lint. always use a lint free cloth and extremely clean workshops to remove the tranny oil pan.

column2: Your trans sounds dead, if you can hear rough engagement then most probably the variator assy is now duff, to overhaul the unit it would cost you about 2000 USD in parts, its better to gamble on a used transmission and install a transmission oil cooler too with an additional fan. It really helps in Karachi heat waves.The correct diagnosis is done with pressure gauges on the test ports and the toyota intellitester connected to the system.

column1: This very good atricle was written by Omer Saleem, i am posting it here with his permission Quite recently I experienced a strange rise in transmission problems with most Toyotas running on the Super CVT-I transmission. I did some research and what I ended up discovering was shocking if nothing else. Most mechanics would not even know that these transmissions DO NOT run on Toyota T-IV or Toyota WS oil but instead require the TOYOTA CVT-TC oil and then there was the common problem I heard that the oil mysteriously disappears from most cars. However now that I have done my research that’s not true at all, infact the prime reason in most transmission failures is that the mechanics end up over filling the chamber, thus damaging the internal gearbox and pump seals. Here is what actually happened with my Belta 2 days ago: When you open up the drain plug for any of the K-series CVT transmissions which Toyota is putting in most of its newer models, only about 500ml or less of the transmission fluid drains out, leading one to believe that the transmission was running without oil, but that is absolutely not the case. The drain plug has an internal drain tube which extends about a little more than 2 inches inside the chamber, this causes the oil level to just drop till the mouth of this tube and hence the mystery disappearance behind the transmission oil. In order to fully drain the transmission oil, you will need to open up the oil chamber and drain out the fluid. This will also require you to replace the two gaskets which are firmly placed on top of the chamber. After completely draining the oil, about 3.8-4.0 liters of oil is taken up by the transmission. Then to make matters worse, Toyota hasn’t really provided with a dipstick or a gauge to check the level of the transmission fluid. The mechanics even at Toyota Southern argued that the side housing nut is the correct place to feed oil from and that it should be filled unless it levels off around that point. The truth is that if you do end up filling to that level you would be over-filling the chamber with about 3.5 liters of transmission oil and that can cause some serious irreparable damage. The correct way to fill the transmission fluid is via the oil feed port shown in the pictures attached below.My Belta had gone through all of the above but some timely research saved the car. I have also attached some detailed pictures and descriptions for the transmission oil change procedure. Last but not the least, the issue can potentially affect all Toyota CVT transmission system manufactured by AISIN. The following are the vehicle models and transmissions which might be affected by the same problem. This bulletin concerns the following Toyota models and transmission codes : Transmission Codes: K110, K111, K111F, K112, K112F, K210, P210, K310, K311, K311F, K410, K41A.  List of Toyota Super- CVT Models:  Aisis: ANM10G, ANM10W, ANM15G, ANM15W Allion: AZT240, ZRT260, ZRT261, ZRT265, NZT260 Alphard: ATH10W, ANH20W, ANH25W Auris: ZRE152H, NZE151H, ZRE154H, NZE154H Belta: SCP92, KSP92 Blade: AZE156H, AZE154H Corolla Axio: ZRE142, NZE141, ZRE144, NZE144 Corolla Fielder: ZRE142G, NZE141G, ZRE144G, NZE144G Corolla Rumion: ZRE152N, NZE151N, ZRE154N Estima: AHR10W, ACR50W, ACR55W iQ: KGJ-10 Ist: NCP110, NCP115 Mark X Zio: ANA10, ANA15 Noah: ZRR70W, ZRR70G, ZRR75W, ZRR75G, ZAR60G, ZAR65G Opa: ACT10 Premio: AZT240, ZRT260, ZRT261, ZRT265, NZT260 Ractis: NCP100, SCP100 RAV-4: ACA36W, ACA31W Sienta: NCP81G Vanguard: ACA38W, ACA33W Vitz: NCP91, SCP90, KSP90, SCP13 Voxy: ZRR70W, ZRR70G, ZRR75W, ZRR75G, ZAR60G, ZAR65G Wish: ZGE21G, ZGE22W, ZGE20G, ZGE20W, ZGE25G, ZGE25W, ANE11W, ANE10G
column2: Cat convertors rarely choke out, it would take about 10 years worth of driving to do that, or if you drive around with a misfiring engine, that can lead to cat convertor overheating and meltdown, It cannot block itself with soot - the operating temperature is way too hot for any soot to stick.If you can accelerate the engine at a standstill and feel a solid rush from the exhaust pipe then the cat is probably OK, you have issues elsewhere, You should post correct diagnosis, not andaaza sounds. To test the CVT - gradually move off in D and apply full throttle - the rpms should shoot to near redline and the car should start to accelerate hard.

column2: My way of draining and filling the toyota CVT fluid was the one like mentioned in the manual, not the one on top of this post, The fluid is drained by removing the strainer from the sump, it just unscrews out, put it back then fill from the side fill port. (large plug), wait till it runs out, allow to trickle, plug up sump and fill hole, done. The strainer in place makes it a level check, removal of it allows fluid drain, just like nearly all RWD toyotas now have two holes in the sump one for checking one for draining. anyway... The people who have built the thing are better qualified to determine the service procedure, so best follow them. And you did just the right thing of asking procedure from the service tech.

column2: zeshoo;3697063: 100,000 Maintenance Interval — Inspection only; ATF-WS does NOT require any flushing or changing during the life of the vehicle. That recommendation from Toyota or any other manufacturer is to ensure your transmission goes bad at 160,000 kms at max. After which they say - "THE LIFE OF THE TRANSMISSION IS OVER" they can also say that anytime the transmission goes bad after warranty. There is no hydrocarbon known that can survive shear, temperature, stress etc and still remain perfect.

column1: I had sprayed Fluid Film on undercarriage of my car through some spray cans I got someone to bring from the US. But it's not feasible to cover the whole undercarriage with just cans. Are some similar products available in Karachi and someone who undercoats your car using those here? Rubberized coating won't work for me so that's not an option. Please suggest.
column2: You probably have severe sinus issues or some fake fluid film, I have used hundreds of containers of it, it smells like a sheep. Spray some on any vehicle part and your workshop smells like a sheep barn. So for that reason I spray it outside. Noxudol is great though, creeps like crazy into everything and has an acceptable crayon/waxy smell.

column1: AOA, need expertise opinion guys. Im using TOYOTA original 20W50 PETRON oil since two years in my 2010 XLI (75000km) totally petrol driven, car is in excellent condition in every aspect. But now i think why not to switch to any good oil available in the market like SHELL ultra 5W40 fully synthetic. Is it wise to switch to fully synthetic oil from mineral oil, as i have heard that it can damage engine seals. If not, then which oil u would like to recommend for my car? Thanks Sent from my iPhone using PW Forums
column2: LM are not all that good, They seem to be charging money for no specific reason I can see meanwhile shell, castrol and caltex blend great engine oils and are far cheaper too. Why pay more money?

column1: Salam dear Pakwheelers. Presenting Pakwheels first D.I.Y on Service of Catalytic converter of Civic 8th Gen. All Credit goes to fellow Pakwheeler "mwanwar" Tools you need. 22 no. Ring Wrench.   Long flat screw driver.  Lets get start. 1. First disconect the conecter.   2. Now you need to break the corners of conector because u have to pass the conector from ring wranch. Dont worry it will not damage the conector.    3. Now pas the conector from ring wranch and open the oxygen senser.     4. Now take any type of torch and look inside. U will see the mash which will chowck due to rust.   5. Now take a screw driver and rub it slowly on mash which is inside.   Dont rub too much.. rub it for 5 second and then look inside. Then rub to taht side which have still rust. Then look inside again. Do this process till you remove the rust from mash. After cleaning the rust mash will look like this.   6. Now start the engine for 1 minutes and give race to 3 rpm after every 5 sec.. 7. Now switch off the engine. Now mash will look more clean.   8. Now install oxygen senser on its place and conect the conector on its place. Congrags! You have serviced the Catalytic Converter sucessfully! If check engine light appear then dont worry. Just disconect Positive + panel of battery for 1 minute and then conect it. ALL DONE! Sent from my Samsung Galaxy Note 3 using PW Forum app
column2: as Abbasi sb said - take a hacksaw and cut the spanner head. In proper way use an oxygen sensor socket. Its built for this and wont damage the connector either. btw - dont touch the honeycomb with something like a screwdriver unless you want to damage it. You could have probably redlined the engine under load in 2nd gear and it would have cleaned it really nicely. please get a proper screwdriver, the one you have looks like scrap.

column2: msabbasi;4338136: Nice DIY. Only thing I'd do differently would be to take a hack saw and cut a slot in the 22mm ring spanner wide enough to allow the wire of the connector to pass rather than damage the grip. Open ring spanners are available: Also crow's foot ring spanner could have been used. On my car the acceleration had dropped considerably so I took the car to Honda Classic and they determined that the cat was chocked badly. They removed the cat, scraped the "rust" and blew it out with compressed air. Huge amounts of red smoke came out. They used a special sensor removal tool that did not require the grip to be cut. This resulted in huge improvement in acelleration. very good

column1: Salaam, I am new in here. This is my first post. Hope everyone is doing fine. I have got a problem in my Prado's dashboard. It was left untouched for 5 months all covered up. The dashboard cracked up. Its a hairline crack. I thought before i can go to anyone here in karachi I should ask the pros. So what should I do ? all suggestion and advices are welcome. (if anyone knows professional experts for dashboard do also let me know thank you in advance, brothers !!!
column2: it can be refinished with new vinyl stretched over it with glue and steam. There were some dash repair guys really good at this. btw to prevent cracking do not use diesel, son of gun, armor all or any other weird agent, if you can get some 303 protectant then nothing better (it prevents UV damage that cracks it) otherwise clean it with a mix of a couple of jugs of water and an entire bar of DOVE soap dissolved in it - apply with a spray bottle, scrub with towels and dab off with a clean damp towel - really keeps it nice, clean and soft.

column2: I had a ok experience with AAA. I had a maroon swift which got rear ended and had to get the rear bumper repainted , talked to the owner of the establishment Haji sb he assured me it will match 100%. After I came to collect the car the colour of the bumper was a lot lighter than the maroon of the rest of the car , I called the owner and told him this is not what we agreed , they told me it will get darker with time and blend in perfectly , as in earlier cars they had matched in start and it got alot darker than the oem maroon , and it did get darker and matched the car 17/20. Job was satisfactory but my car was drity from inside , dust on matts seats, had cigarette smell inside car probably workers , all my audio settings were changed to I guess match the workers tastes , so I had to get the car detailed. Overall paint work was good , but make sure you talk to them clearly that if car is dirty etc they will pay for the detail , also take pictures of your car inside out at their facility before handing it over to them , as they have alot of cars they ask that you leave the car with them, so that any other nick scratch while the car was there can be identified.

column1: Aoa Pakwheelers, I have Corolla 2012 in Use but i am facing oil reduction issue with no smoke on cold start up/acceleration. Currently i am using zic oil 10W 40 in my car and the redution is approx 700-900ml after 3000kms. I have to topup approx 300ml after every 1000kms. Some one suggested me to shift from 10w 40 to 20w 50 Api SM as it is thicker. So should i shift to thicker oil or stick on same viscosity. Also advise me that can i use API SN or Plus in my engine in this situation. Help from senior pakwheelers is much appriciated. @Xulfiqar Thanks.
column2: Take out the spark plugs and check them for oil burning. Then consider a compression and leakdown test.

column1: The car in discussion here is civic 2006 VTI Oriel. The purpose of this thread is to share the findings and resolution and help others stuck in such situation. Issue: The brake pedal sank on brake application. It was happening whether the car is stationary or moving. It did sink little when the car was shut off (no booster assist). This was dangerous as the car was not stopping properly, and lunged forward even on full brake application even on lower speeds. The abs kicked in randomly on braking, everytime on hard braking (even on slower speeds with medium braking force while the wheels werent even close to locking). Checked brake oil level, it was full. Cheked for leaks, none found in lines, calipers, master cylinder. Flushed and bled the system to no avail. The most obvious cause in this case is Master cylinder itself (having an internal leak and bypassing fluid via cup seals). Without giving it much thought, replaced it with new Honda genuine part. New parts was bench bled and then bled the system again and lo and behold, the pedal is still sinking. Bled again and again, actuating ABS aswell, wasting couple litres of brake fluid (must have cleaned the lines good lol). Doubted that the new master cylinder is faulty aswell. Tested it by blocking the two outlet ports with cutup line ends with ends shut (desi blockers). The pedal was rock solid. Well, put it all back together and back to sinking. Disassembled all 4 calipers and verified for working, found nothing wrong. The brake pads were nearly new from the last brake job. Searched around on internet and people were having similar issues, a video pointed that it could be the ABS. Will be updating the proceedings in below posts.
column2: And this is why you flush your brake fluid yearly on an abs vehicle

column2: The searches pointed that there is a way to check ABS for this behaviour. There are two ports on the ABS hydraulic system block itself, a stick is put in these ports and then the brake is applied on static car. If even one of the stick is pushed out, there is the fault. However, i looked hard at the abs module of civic was unable to find such ports. Otherway is to isolate the system, take out all 4 wheel lines from ABS module and block the ports, leave the 2 lines coming from Master cylinder, if the pedal is still sinking, its the ABS. As I had already ruled out remaining components, decided to procure one and slap it on. Bought one from junk yard for 4k. The catch is it has to be the exact same part. The shopkeepers want to frankenstine it by swapping hydraulic body to existing solenoid acutators (peddling out oddball parts). For PKDM 7th gen civic VTI oriel, the ABS module part code is BA, some other origin has J. Here is how the parts look:

New parts was bench bled and then bled the system again and lo and behold, the pedal is still sinking. Bled again and again, actuating ABS aswell, wasting couple litres of brake fluid (must have cleaned the lines good lol). Doubted that the new master cylinder is faulty aswell. column2: Replaced the ABS Unit, and voila, no more sinking pedal. Here is the explanation of the issue: ABS unit regulates (open/shut) the brake line pressure as per the wheel sensor input during braking. If the wheel locks up, ABS unit actuates respective wheel solenoid and reroutes the brake fluid pressure to free up the wheel momentarily. While doing so, the pressurised brake fluid has to go somewhere, thats where fluid reservoir comes into play. These reservoirs (2 of them for civic) are built into the hydraulic body of ABS unit and have a spring loaded piston present in them. (picture from youtube video):  When ABS is actuated for a wheel, a return solenoid actuates and releases the pressure to this reservoir. In my case, the solenoid was sticking open and dumping the fluid in reservoir all the time, hence causing sinking pedal. Later on I opened up the old ABS module to find the reservoirs: Notice the two circular holes above actuator valves, these are the reservoirs, opened up one of them, opened one of them up, the piston is stuck inside still but you get the idea:

column2: Get it replaced. Also when caliper pistons are pushed back without loosening bleeder, the gunk and rust present in calipers is pushed back to Proportioning valves/ABS module and clogs up the ports.

column1: AOA all PWs, Honda Civic and experts need your attention plz I hv 2015 civic prosmatic oriel first owner and after 20 k kms i am feeling vibration when first gear changes to second (30-40 km/h speed) and also pick problem as it was before odo meter is 28 k, I went to honda north in peshawar for check up the said problem the mechanic says it may be gear oil problem or excel problem but my car is only 28 k driven and gear oil changing time is 60k km, no accident even didnot drive roughly. the mechanic told me that now we feel the same vibration problem in every civic after your noticing vibration problem with this reply from mechanic, i am confused and shocked that does it an manufacturing fault? what you guys says do you have the same problem? if you guys have the same problem please share it. I am really worried about this problem because its a new car the vibration is really irritating to me.
column2: your car is under warranty. tell them to fix it and don't pay them a penny.. if they don't.. write a letter to atlas honda, if they don't give a damn, then file a case in consumer court.

column1: So this is the Mitsubishi I, a weird quirky 660cc that not people know about..including myself. Even though I own one. Everyday I have atleast one bewildered bike rider that gazes at the front of the car in other disbelief. "Where is the bonnet" says his face as he nearly crashes into me, only swerving away at the very last second. The I is a difficult car to own, it's thirsty, only gives around 13 km-l. It's a tad noisy due to the fact the engine in underneath the rear seats and worst of all is the maintenance. If you don't have a mechanic that understands these cars, they'll only make your problem worse. Spare parts are rarer than a period of political harmony in Pakistan. It takes as much oil as a Honda City, it takes more coolant than a Honda Civic X. But there's just something about this car that just causes you to get attached to it. It has a personality, it's different and more exciting than most 660cc hatchbacks. So if anyone here has a Mitsubishi I, leave a comment down below. I'd love to know where you get your maintenance done from, do you have a guy that can source space parts. This cars comes equipped with keyless entry and go but the keyless remote has long been lost. Does anyone know where I might be able to get a new one made, obviously I don't have the original so I can't make a clone. Any help would be greatly appreciated
column2: Its a nice little car. share more pictures and from inside too.

column1: As the title says, what grease do you guys use for various jobs, I know newer cars have cartridge bearings and are prefilled, but many other older cars and most SUV, truck, use greaseable hubs. And you need grease for brakes too. I usually had a few selection of grease for myself in Pakistan, which included high moly content CV joint grease (left over from Total fina bucket) - nice for long life loaded sliding application smooth (very short thread) high temperature NLGI2 wheel bearing grease (castrol LMX) (260*C drop point with good pumpability) sticky (long thread) high temp and high load NLGI2 grease for greaseable parts like hinges, joints etc. permatex brake caliper grease (obvious) any brand copper antisieze any brand nickel antisieze silicon grease, electrics and bushings etc. NLGI-0 fluid grease for door lock mechanisms and similar have the same here too. - The right lube for the right job makes for good repairs.
column2: This verron grease firstly has too much thickener and has no moly content, its a very bad choice for your CV joint (axle) - correct CV joint grease has a minimum moly content of 15% and is of NLGI1 or 2 consistency with extreme pressure additives, which means its quite soft. The moly in the grease actually gets deposited on the metal and provides lubrication even when its pressed out in extreme pressure. You can buy the correct CVJ grease in unbranded packets or in branded 1 kg jars in Pakistan, its not cheap and once is stains your clothes you have to throw them away, no detergent can remove those stains. This is a plain lithium soap grease which would not have a high drop point either, and it says MP, which means its a slap on every time grease - something I would never use even if given for free. Its meant for oldstyle door hinges etc on ancient cars, old style truck water pumps etc. The TDS on their website is very unimpressive, and I personally would never use it in a CVJ

column2: metalhead;3613122: Here we get our work done from mechanics and they have only 'grease'. ask them about the type and they will laugh in return... That is why YOU YOURSELF have to buy and keep such greases, mechanic ustaad is least concerned about anything except his quick buck.

column1: As the title says, what grease do you guys use for various jobs, I know newer cars have cartridge bearings and are prefilled, but many other older cars and most SUV, truck, use greaseable hubs. And you need grease for brakes too. I usually had a few selection of grease for myself in Pakistan, which included high moly content CV joint grease (left over from Total fina bucket) - nice for long life loaded sliding application smooth (very short thread) high temperature NLGI2 wheel bearing grease (castrol LMX) (260*C drop point with good pumpability) sticky (long thread) high temp and high load NLGI2 grease for greaseable parts like hinges, joints etc. permatex brake caliper grease (obvious) any brand copper antisieze any brand nickel antisieze silicon grease, electrics and bushings etc. NLGI-0 fluid grease for door lock mechanisms and similar have the same here too. - The right lube for the right job makes for good repairs.
column2: @ margallar - greases should never ever be mixed with any oils, the soap may not accept the oil and eventually will completely break down the grease into a runny mass that will destroy the item in short order, the LM grease you show is made for CV joints and will last a very long time. Do not overfill the joint, weigh out about 90 grams and use it per side, it may seem low but its enough as the centrifugal force of the spinning axle will cause the grease to roll in the joint - which is exactly what you want. Make sure all traces of old grease are removed first, wash with kerosene petrol mix and dry with acetone for at least 15 minutes before repacking the joint. @rizkhan - if your joint has started to click and the boot it not ripped, remove the joint immediately and fill with correct CVJ grease like this LM product. You can also buy it of other brands, The Fina lube bucket of 5 kg I had was good for years. One car outer joints take 180 grams only for both sides. Please note that you dont want this grease in spider type tripod inner joints because the rollers spin at high speed within the spider bearings and the moly in the grease can separate out and cause dragging. A 1-5% moly content NLGI2 li-complex Exteme pressure grease with adhesive and smooth texture is good for that purpose, Or even no moly content but very impressive loading spec grease will work.

column1: As the title says, what grease do you guys use for various jobs, I know newer cars have cartridge bearings and are prefilled, but many other older cars and most SUV, truck, use greaseable hubs. And you need grease for brakes too. I usually had a few selection of grease for myself in Pakistan, which included high moly content CV joint grease (left over from Total fina bucket) - nice for long life loaded sliding application smooth (very short thread) high temperature NLGI2 wheel bearing grease (castrol LMX) (260*C drop point with good pumpability) sticky (long thread) high temp and high load NLGI2 grease for greaseable parts like hinges, joints etc. permatex brake caliper grease (obvious) any brand copper antisieze any brand nickel antisieze silicon grease, electrics and bushings etc. NLGI-0 fluid grease for door lock mechanisms and similar have the same here too. - The right lube for the right job makes for good repairs.
column2: There is a problem in Pakistan of car wheel bearings getting submerged in rain water, to counter this problem you can choose to source some marine grade high temperature (above 250C drop point) waterproof sticky bearing grease. Castrol, Fuchs, mobil etc all make make such a product. - I did buy one tube of it in Pakistan but was pricey as the item was not imported through a dealer channel. To use, you have to take a fresh front wheel bearing cartridge, remove the inner race halves wash out the original grease and fill about 50% of the races with this waterproof grease and assemble back then install in the car.

column1: As the title says, what grease do you guys use for various jobs, I know newer cars have cartridge bearings and are prefilled, but many other older cars and most SUV, truck, use greaseable hubs. column2: speciality lube shops and industrial supply shops on Marriot road Karachi stock them, you can also call up the local agencies for Mobil, Emarat, Fuchs, ZIC, Total etc. and ask them for their available greases. If the vendor has no idea what you are talking about then you have to look at the grease spec yourself. cars are being built in Pakistan, they use correct greases - that means they source it from the local lubricant distributors and you can too.

column1: AOA...! with all due respect i am here to share my problem with all of you , soliciting your expert opinion. i have Cressida Grande Mark II , engine was swap with 1G -Fe with Automatic transmission. thinking of 6 straight engine i expected to touch 130-140km/h easily on highway in CNG but never find it above 120, unless i press the full throttle. Keeping the issue infront i changed wiring, ECU, Differential and later the transmission even all at different stages, but the desired result hasnt been achieved. The later Transmission i installed is double OD A/T . i need suggestion in this regard , what am i missing ? Transmission/Differential or what ? i have found Crown/ MarkII the newer version run past 150km/h on highway with same engine. kindly put light on it . Regards
column2: saam596;4448764: it is worth noting that as i mentioned earlier i have Automatic transmission with 2 Over Drives , Double O/D. Mean 5 speed Auto gear box installed with this engine and ECU. double O/D? what model of gearbox is this? - the ECU you have usually has the basic 4 speed shifts (4th = overdrive) and then final torque converter lockup, Are you calling the lockup as the "double overdrive?" please install the correct airbox setup for this engine - the insane elbow and the stove pipe type setup is literally ghetto rig extreme. The cressida even with basic 22R engine can easily achieve 180 km/h with manual 5 spd manual gearbox, With the 7MGE and plain 4 spd auto I have sped ahead of 200 km/h in a 1988 cressida (square block shape). the 1G-FE is not a very good engine - I prefer the 22R-E over it as it has more punch to it.

column2: Rajaatta;4458111: He has an A42D with ECT. Is it the same as the 42D ECT? - The 42D is a 4-speed automatic transmission with a lockup converter that is operated hydraulically. On the other hand, the 43DE is an ECT with electric control. It is commonly found in vehicles like Cressida and Cresta.

column1: Never ever use Kixx The oil is not what they claim it to be and the engine will get noisy after using Kixx. also they never get back to you with the test results. Zic is recommended and reliable also the Caltex , total and liqui molly oils are reliable.
column2: i think that you've been had by a fraudster. your feedback seems t show that the oil wasn't the real deal. problem with Kixx is that there is no place where you can find a list of authorized dealers. Zic is here on PW and they tell you the names of thier stockists where you are guaranteed to get the real stuff. they too have fallen victim to "fake oil" whic is being put in their repackaged cans. but this in itself does not mean that Zic is a bad oil. Same applies to GS oil. i've tested our oil against them and i have to admit our results showed that it wasn't that bad. A few months back a member bought "ultra9" (which doesn't exist) in peshawar and was satisfied with it. when i explained to him that it's fake he was quite surprised. sadly in PK people will do anything to make a fast buck. best thing we can do is make a hole in our used oil cans so that they cannot be reused. I'm sorry to hear that one of my competitors is getting a bad review, but they must be very careful of this "fake oil" practive which is happening in PK. As for you switching to Zic XQ, it's a very good synthetic oil if you can afford it.

column1: I have recently bought suzuki kei and i m having a problem with my AC. It's cooling power in intense heat is very low. it's engine is 650cc turbo. i want to know whether it z normal for this type of engine to support the AC like this???Also one of my friends told me that it gets converted to 1300cc after attaining a certain speed that is y your AC is nt working(plz if anyone can clear the truth of this statement??)
column2: The price of Cuore is 850, not 800, and please have the AC inspected.

column1: I have recently bought suzuki kei and i m having a problem with my AC.
