column2: well first off its a 660cc... dont expect much from it.. in terms of the heatwave now adays.. along side the turbo.. u can only expext so much from a 660cc.. as for what ur friend said about the speed thing.. that thing just flew over me.. all u car has is a turbo.. which means that u get a certain (kick/boost) of power to ur car in the high RPM range (i.e above 4000rpm perhaps).. which is highly unadvisable to rev a 660 turbo in heat because then u will start seeing the heat kanta go up.. as for the ac thing its working fine.. i remember my coure.. that being a 800cc... the ac on that was like what i have on my rolla with the ac off.. so no worries

column2: tintin1;5216236: I know a guy who is good in suspension work and they have proper machines (hydraulic lifters and not jacks). But first let me know which car/model you have and its problems. Thanks. Thank you for your reply, let me describe the complete history with the issues in details. The car under discussion is Chevrolet Joy 2007 This was happen back in July 2016 (Ramzan) when I felt serious issues in suspension and I headed towards Korea Motors , Punjab Society, Defense. The mechanic there checked, took test drive and told that its bearings needs to be changed along with shocks. He also said that CHIMTA (don’t know the real/exact name) also needs to be changed and he referred me to their shop located in Montgomery road for buying the required stuff. I got bearings and shocks along with the seals and headed again to mechanic’s work shop, the shocks opted were Kabuli (that was my mistake). The mechanic changed the things and I felt slight difference but I know that he has not done the required work. Later, right after one month August 2016 during raining seasons during my return trip from Islamabad I hear the bearings noise. I got that checked to another mechanic (who is from Chevrolet platinum motors and started his own workshop) and he said that its bearings needs to be changed and along with some suspension checkup. I got the original Japanese bearings from the wholesale dealer in badami bagh Lahore and headed to mechanic for replacement. When he opened the hubs she showed me that CHIMTA needs to be replaced or can be repaired since it was never repaired before. I asked him to check everything and let me know the required work upon which the following items were repaired. Shocks were repaired (as the Kabuli ones I bought was already repaired before) End was repaired Chimta was repaired Bearings were changed Now since that repaired I think was my mistake to get the things repaired, though the lath man (kharadia) told me that you will not face issues and the car run till it has already done e.g. for next 100k KMs. I was satisfied and enjoying as the noises was reduced car used to be smooth on bumpy road. But, right after two months the issues rises again, I was like WTF….. so this is the history… The car bounces a lot on bumpy roads, the car hits from back with thak sound when crossing speed breaker. I can feel the vibration in steering while driving on bumpy road like bumps are directly hitting the car body… I need a honest and good mechanic and this I will be replacing each and every part with new either GM manufactured or Korean…

column1: AoA, I am an engineering student and I need some data for a project. I want to know how long or how much distance do different cars take before coming to a stop. For example if it is traveling at 70km/h how long will it take to come to 0 after applying breaks. I only need some approximate values. Cars commonly used in pakistan like mehran, cultus, civic, city, corolla, prius, fortuner etc I only need data for these not mercedes or bmw. Is it possible to get this? Any help is appreciated.
column2: Wailaikum Assalam Got to youtube channel carwow. He does brake test of every car. Usually cars stops in 40-50 meter distance after applying brakes at 100km/h.

column1: I have been away from the audio section for quite some time due to my new job and other hectic everyday stuff. Anyways, I recently bought a new car a few weeks ago and the stock audio system is terrible. Especially these stock Japanese DVD players. It's time for some major upgrades (H). My plan is to start off slowly with a decent sound quality setup and gradually build it up. The car is a 2007 Vitz.  -  - So far, I have bought a Pioneer AVH-X5550BT Head Unit, a Pioneer AVH-A3100DAB Head Unit, JBL GTO-608C Front Stage speakers, and Helix F62C Rear Stage speakers. I have also ordered a JL Audio 12 W3v2 D-4 subwoofer with a sealed 1 cubic foot poly-filled enclosure, a Helix P8 Precision series subwoofer amplifier, an Addzest APA-4400G PowerGuard, and wiring including an Orion XTR 4 AWG OFC Power/Ground Cable, Oehlbach SP25-3000 OFC speaker cable, Focal ES4 11 AWG OFC Subwoofer Wire, and Focal ER5 Elite Series OFC RCA Inter-Connects.  -  - For the power source, I have a 55 Amp Battery and a Stinger 4 Gauge BIG3 Dampening. I have also purchased Stinger Roadkill Expert Series (2 x Bulk Packs) for sound dampening purposes.  -  - That's my setup so far. I would appreciate some help with anything else I might need.

column1: Been driving a 2013 Passo for the past 6 years now, first owner. The car is consuming engine oil for almost 2 years now atleast and I have been topping up since then. I had cat con cleaned by brush and since then the oil issue arised. I was using zic 10w40 before but then mechanic told me to use caltex 5w20 synthetic. After which the oil guy recommended me mobil 10w30 and till now I am using the same. After almost 1200 to 1500 km the dipstick shows only half. So I started wondering what could be done before it's too late. After reading many posts at PW, I read alot about compression test and got that done today. Results were 125, 120 and 105. Also there is blue smoke as well. Any experts can humbly guide me what should be done. Many thanks!
column2: compressoin numbers low needs overhaul or assembly change do update the thread how u eventually fix it

column1: AoA PWers, I hope you guys are well. I have been a german car fan mostly, however, on a whim, I acquired this Vauxhall Astra Twintop as a project to restore during the winter months, where afternoons, evenings are dark and depressing and you can not do much outside. A bit of background on the car: The Car on the whole: The car is a 2008 model in the Design trim. It is a twintop body type, which is Vauxhall's jargon for a hard-top convertible coupe. The car is attractive to look at, and, being a hard top convertible, it is very practical and usable in the British weather all year round. The car is compact in size, owing to the cleverly designed 3 pc folding roof, you really don't need a big boot to accommodate the folded roof when you have the top down. The weight of the roof in the boot along with the strut braces add weight to the rear end while adding rigidity to the chassis, once the roof is down. Being the not so basic model, I found that there's decent amount of kit added as standard on the car. I will discuss features and options in more detail further along in the post. The Engine & Transmission: The car has a 1.8L 4 Cylinder 16v petrol engine that produces 138 Bhp and 175 nm of torque. Official 0-60mph time is 10.7 seconds. The engine is rather punchy and can keep up with motorway traffic (70 mph) while it returns decent fuel economy (14 km/l local and 17.5 km/l on the motorway with AC). The transmission is a 5 speed manual transmission with a reverse gear on the opposite side ( Like most GM cars I suppose, Daewoo racer in Pakistan had that kind of a shifter layout) Interior: The interior is well kitted out with comfortable half leather seats with height adjustment and lumbar support, MP3 / Aux enabled audio with a monochrome display. Push start with Key-less entry. The cabin is a mix of leather and piano black plastic with silver accents. Steering wheel controls for audio and the on-board computer. There's decent legroom given the size of the car both on the front and rear. a 6ft tall adult can comfortably be accommodated in the rear seat with the front seats less than half way forward. There are powered mirrors for both front and rears and the wing mirrors are powered and heated. It has automatic lights and wipers on the front. However I do miss the rear wiper which is not there as the rear screen obviously needs to fold with the roof. The car does not have Cruise Control, however it is a very easy retrofit and a quick upgrade, in the case of my car, just a matter of replacing the indicator stalk and enabling Cruise control on the ECU. The wind breaker was an optional extra offered by Vauxhall and is not included on this car. Hence, wind makes it slightly difficult to drive at high speeds with the roof down. Exterior The exterior is finished in Star Silver metalic with matching bumpers, door handles and wing mirrors. 17 inch alloy wheels with relatively low profile tyres mean that the car sits on the road very nicely and handles very well. Fog lamps are standard on the front and rear of the car. There's chrome trim on the front grill and the boot lid that compliments the car very nicely and a 3rd brake lamp (LED) is mounted on the boot lid as well. A chrome exhaust tip is a nice looking addition to the rear of the car.
column2: The To-Fix List so far: New Battery - Installed Coolant level sensor to be replaced as it raises a false alarm. Full Service (Oil, Filters, Plugs). Wing mirror cover replacement on the Driver's side. Upgrade low beam bulbs to brighter ones. Horn does not work. This is a common fault on these where the control interface module goes funny. However, in my case, I think the module is okay and it is either the fuse or the horn itself that has packed up. Minor Scratches and scuffs on the body will be sorted ( It is an old car after all) Upgrades that i have planed for: I am looking to restore / improve the car keeping it OEM+. Here is what i have planned so far OEM Cruise Control retrofit OEM Satnav retrofit 18" Alloy wheel upgrade with OEM Vauxhall Twintop wheels. Upgraded High Strength rear braces - Already installed as the previous owner was able to bend the rear brace on one side. Roof folding mechanism upgrades- replacing plastic cogs with copper ones. If i am able to find a complete interior / dash panels, I may upgrade the interior with heated full leather seats.

column1: hi..my khyber when strted in morning after like standing for whole night,misses n i have to keep foot on paddle to keep it running.. both on cng and petrol,it does he same..i thought might b cng but its same on petrol... wat cud b reason? it does only for one minute or so n then temp goes to normal n it goes normal too but it misses heavily when strtd inn morning?? reason?? ATTENTION:THE CAR IS BETTER NOW ON COLD>>BUT PROB IS NOW ON PETROL>SO INSTEAD OF MAKING A NEW THREAD<IM PUTTING PROB IN SAME THREAD>>
column2: the engine is rather clean - dont worry as long as your engine has a Thermostat valve and correct functioning PCV - it will keep the oil and the engine clean. and 3500 kms is toooo soon, Run at least 5000 kms before changing oil. Adjust valve clearances dead cold - it requires the engine not to have run in the past 6 hours at least. The cam profile ramps should be correctly positioned at compression TDC. and adjust clearances with the feeler gauge - take your time, and recheck - the feeler should have a slight drag between the screw and valve stem.

column2: when your engine is dieseling on shudown - check the positive side of the ignition coil that its not getting current from somewhere. If its not - then your engine is pre-igniting the mixture itself from excess heat. Check spark plugs - they are most probably too hot heat range for your engine.

column1: Greetings, how is everyone? I have come across multiple discussions regarding HID/Led, but recently I learned about H4 LED. I am curious to know the difference between LED and H4 LED. column2: Asim510: There is a difference between HID (High-Intensity Discharge) and LED (Light-Emitting Diode) headlights, which is evident from their names. H4 LED refers to an LED light that can be used as a replacement for your car's headlight. H4, on the other hand, is the name of the grip or connector that is installed at the back of the LED. Cars like Mehran, Alto, City, and Baleno have H4 grip, which allows for both high and low beam settings in the same bulb. -  - The second picture shows the LED with H4 grip, while the last picture provides an option to change the grips. Okay, now I understand that. Can you tell me which type of LED is better, the first type or the last two? Personally, I think the last two options are better. But in what sense are they better?

column1: Salam Dear's, I need expert comments regarding some people & mechanic's saying that CNG cylinder can be used for LPG with some modification/installation of device with estimated cost of Rs.1000/- I want to know its possibility, advantages, disadvantages, LPG consumption, and safety factor. Kindly also advise using home LPG cylinder in car as well. Please reply on early basis.
column2: in Karachi there IS only 1 know LPG station at shahrae faisal on down track towards city. I took a test drive of a Corolla 2011 over LPG kit with CNG cylinder and it was wonderfully smooth and according to owner of corolla Rs. 1700 fuel churns out approx 325 kms city run. I have to take it on face value, (with some doubts). I may switch to LPG if CNG stations convert to LPG.

column1: i want all Pak Wheelers to inform dem about serious draw backs by direct connection of radiator fan in ur ride Direct Connection of the Radiator Fan In PAKISTAN most of the cars have this problem that their radiator fan starts directly when the car is started regardless of the water temperature in the radiator, because the fan (electrically driven) circuit is by passed from the thermostat switch. Well our mechanics do this because they think that by keeping the water temperature (indicated at the control panel by temperature gauge) to the minimum possible level will help engine perform well. Actually the normal operating temperature of the engine, referred with respect to the water temperature in the radiator is 82 ± 3 °C. It is important to note that the water in the radiator boils at 115 to 120 °C .The radiator cap keeps the water under pressure and that is why the water boils above the its normal boiling point. The calibration of the gauge starts from 50°C .So the total range on the dial of the gauge is from 50°C to 120°C. So when needle reaches the middle of the gauge, engine is actually at its NORMAL WORKING TEMPERATURE {average temp of the gauge (as averages fall in the middle) is (115+50)/2=82.5 °C}. So at the normal working temperature the needle should be somewhere in the middle of the gauge. Whereas our so-called skilled mechanics interpret this as over-heating of the engine.THIS IS TOTALLY WRONG! In a moment I will be listing the disadvantages of having your radiator fan direct .But first I would like to tell the readers about the cooling system of the engine in brief . In water circuit of the engine (water circuit means the path of the water in engine) the effort is made to keep the water away from radiator till the water temperature in the water jacket reaches the 82°C mark. Simply you can say that water is not allowed to go in the radiator and is made to circulate inside the water jacket. This is done by using a device called THERMOSTAT VALVE. This thermostat valve when closed does not allow the water to circulate in the radiator. As soon as the temperature starts to go beyond 78°C the valve opens. This allows the water to be circulated in the radiator. If the heat dissipation of the radiator cannot keep the temperature at about 82°C the THERMOSTAT SWITCH completes the circuit of the electrically driven radiator fan to keep the temperature at 82°C by circulating air. IT IS IMPORTANT TO NOTE that if temperature goes beyond 82°C it is comparatively acceptable as the most likely disadvantage is the increased potential of the engine to knock at higher gear and low engine rpm . But if the temperature is less than the normal operating temperature then it will cause not only the deterioration of the engine performance but also shortening your engine life. So in most of the cars the thermostat valve is removed, making the water circuit complete all the times and also bypassing the thermostat switch to keep fan running with engine regardless of engine temperature . The problems that can arise as a result are discussed below: Problems associated with Carburetion Mixture Preparation The petrol air/mixture preparation in the carburetor is a temperature dependent function. To keep the mixture preparation efficiency maximum the water in the radiator and water jacket is fed to the outer walls (around venturi) of the carburetor to keep it warm. This increase of the temperature helps to mix up the petrol/air. If the temperature of the water is not at optimum, the petrol air mixture preparation in the carburetor will be effected .This will cause the engine to run on non-homogeneous mixture causing engine to misfire and vibrant engine operation is resulted. One must have noticed the vibrant engine operation on cold starting in the morning. This is also due to the same reason as engine temperature is very low and mixture preparation is not good. So by keeping the fan direct you are going make the engine run with vibrations and it will not deliver its full power as the mixture (petrol/air) is not homogeneous (well prepared) . Mixture Distribution If the temperature of the radiator water is kept low then the carburetor temperature also keeps low as the water circulates around the carburetor venturi (the cylindrical passage down the carburetor where air/petrol gets mixed) .The optimum carburetor operation is achieved at higher temperature. So by keeping the fan direct temperature is kept around 55 to 60 °C. This not only effects the mixture preparation but also the mixture movement as well. The mixture is prepared in carburetor and burnt in the cylinder. To get to cylinder the petrol/air passes through carburetor venturi and inlet manifold. If the temperature of venturi and manifold is low then the condensation of the petrol takes place. This will also cause the engine to run on non-homogeneous mixture and the engine running results will be the same as discussed in the above case . It is important to note that if the mixture fed to the cylinder is not homogeneous then the combustion will not produced the desired amount of power .By meaning the homogeneous mixture it is assumed that the mixture strength expressed by weight ratios is same through out the mixture volume .The combustion is so fast that in non homogeneous mixture the petrol will not burn in the areas where not enough air is not present .This results in loss of fuel and engine produces less power .So by keeping your fan direct you will actually be doing the same thing as discussed above as water temperature will be low. Problems associated with Engine Four Stroke Cycle As the engine temperature is not measured directly but is measured with respect to water temperature in the radiator so when the temperature of the radiator water reaches somewhere around 115 to 120°C, the temp. of the engine is enough to cause serious engine damage and it can even result in ceasing the engine . The point here which I would like to emphasize is that engine temperature is never measured directly but the water temperature is measured. So if water temperature is low so is the engine temperature.The discussion to follow will be carried taking the radiator water temperature as reference. When engine is started the temperature at the piston top or piston temperature is very low, same as atmospheric temperature. During engine operation it reaches hundred of degrees centigrade. No metal or alloy is developed yet which has zero expansion rate. So to accommodate the expansion the piston is made oval shaped. At cold starting the piston does not completely seal the cylinder, but as temperature rises the piston expands and seals the gap. At water temperatures above 115 to 120 °C the expansion is so great that the piston gets stuck resulting in serious engine damage. Below temperatures of say 75°C the piston is loosely fit in the cylinder. We will discuss engine condition keeping in mind that water temperature as it is less than 75°C as fan is made to operate directly preventing the engine to operate at its normal working temperature. Intake stroke When the normal operating temperature of the engine is not achieved then the piston is not complete fit in the cylinder. During intake stroke piston descends from TDC(top dead center) and reaches BDC (bottom dead center). So if the piston is not completely fit than the petrol/air will not be sucked in properly. This will result in low engine volumetric efficiency Compression Stroke During compression stroke piston reaches from BDCto TDC. If the temperature of the piston is below normal then it will not fit the cylinder. So the petrol air sucked in prior ot compression, when compressed during compression stroke will bypass the piston and piston rings into the crankcase (It will be discussed in detail later on). So full compression is not achieved and this results in lower engine output and higher fuel consumption . Power Stroke During power stoke the rapidly expanding gases pushes the piston down giving power. If the piston does not fit completely then the expanding gases will by pass the piston rings thus resulting in incomplete power transfer making the engine H.P to decrease and fuel consumption to increase . Exhaust Stroke During exhaust stroke if piston is not complete fit then the exhaust will not be good. The exhaust air will by pass the piston, rings and will reach the crankcase causing oil fouling (it will also be discussed in detail later on) . Engine Oil Fouling (a) If the engine is made to run on low temp than optimum then the compression stroke is not fully efficient. The petrol/air mixture instead of being compressed, by passes the piston and piston rings. On its way to crankcase it passes the cylinder wall. The cylinder walls are soaked with engine oil to lubricate piton and rings. So when petrol by passes the piston rings it mixes with the oil on the cylinder walls. Petrol being excellent organic solvent dissolves and dilutes the engine oil, promoting engine wear . (b) During power and exhaust stroke the burnt gases which are normally non metallic oxides (acidic in nature) bypass the piston rings and enter the crankcase. Here these gases mix with the water vapors. This forms acidic compounds that get mixed with engine oil resulting in altering the oil PH. It makes the engine oil acidic and corrosion always takes speeds up in the acidic medium. For this reason the engine oils are made buffers (which can retain there PH although some amount of acid is added to them). But they can retain there PH only if a small amount of acid is added. So if engine is run consistently on low temperature then it will promote engine wear as engine oil will get acidic . (c) The unburnt particles from the combustion chamber also by pass the piston as they are very small in size. When they enter the crankcase they get mixed with the oil. The engine oil are made detergents. That is they can accumulate small amount of these particles and hold them in suspension or you can say dissolve them. But this tendency is limited to a small amount. If prolonged use of engine at low temperature is carried out then it will cause pre mature engine wear. As these particles do not completely dissolve in oil, they narrow down the small channels in engine lubrication circuit. This effects the engine lubrication as proper amount of oil is not fed to the moving parts resulting in engine wear. Summarizing The Above Discussion The following are the problems summarized keeping in mind that if engine is not running on its normal working temperature. (1) It will decrease the air/petrol mixing efficiency . (2) It will effect the distribution of petrol/air mixture to each cylinder. (3) This will decrease the volumetric efficiency of the engine resulting in increased fuel consumption . (4) The engine oil will get fouled prematurely resulting in more oil changes . (5) The fouled engine oil will result in the premature engine wear shortening the engine life. (6) Vibrant and rough idle (low speed running). (7) Engine will never give its full power and torque . (8) It will increase the fuel consumption without increasing the output of the engine . Rear wheel Drive Cars In rare wheel drive cars the radiator fan is not electrically driven but it is belt driven. It starts running as soon as the engine is started. To keep the engine temperature at optimum level the water is not allowed to circulate (when cold) in the radiator as the THERMOSTAT VALVE remains closed. As soon as the temperature starts to rise the valve is opened and the belt driven fan keeps the air circulating making the water temperature stick to an optimum level. So in rear wheel drive cars the Thermostat valve should NEVER BE REMOVED. As it will result in the same problems as discussed above (by removing thermostat valve and making fan direct in front wheel cars) . MOVED TO CNG/MECHANICAL/TECHNICAL/PERFORMANCE
column2: From what i know, exact middle point denotes 100 degrees and not 82.5

For this reason the engine oils are made buffers (which can retain there PH although some amount of acid is added to them). But they can retain there PH only if a small amount of acid is added. So if engine is run consistently on low temperature then it will promote engine wear as engine oil will get acidic . (c) The unburnt particles from the combustion chamber also by pass the piston as they are very small in size. When they enter the crankcase they get mixed with the oil. The engine oil are made detergents. That is they can accumulate small amount of these particles and hold them in suspension or you can say dissolve them. But this tendency is limited to a small amount. If prolonged use of engine at low temperature is carried out then it will cause pre mature engine wear. As these particles do not completely dissolve in oil, they narrow down the small channels in engine lubrication circuit. This effects the engine lubrication as proper amount of oil is not fed to the moving parts resulting in engine wear. Summarizing The Above Discussion The following are the problems summarized keeping in mind that if engine is not running on its normal working temperature. (1) It will decrease the air/petrol mixing efficiency . (2) It will effect the distribution of petrol/air mixture to each cylinder. (3) This will decrease the volumetric efficiency of the engine resulting in increased fuel consumption . (4) The engine oil will get fouled prematurely resulting in more oil changes . (5) The fouled engine oil will result in the premature engine wear shortening the engine life. (6) Vibrant and rough idle (low speed running). (7) Engine will never give its full power and torque . (8) It will increase the fuel consumption without increasing the output of the engine . Rear wheel Drive Cars In rare wheel drive cars the radiator fan is not electrically driven but it is belt driven. It starts running as soon as the engine is started. To keep the engine temperature at optimum level the water is not allowed to circulate (when cold) in the radiator as the THERMOSTAT VALVE remains closed. As soon as the temperature starts to rise the valve is opened and the belt driven fan keeps the air circulating making the water temperature stick to an optimum level. So in rear wheel drive cars the Thermostat valve should NEVER BE REMOVED. As it will result in the same problems as discussed above (by removing thermostat valve and making fan direct in front wheel cars) . MOVED TO CNG/MECHANICAL/TECHNICAL/PERFORMANCE
column2: Sorry, but another question. Does the thermostat start opening at 82 degrees Celsius in many cars, right?

column1: i want all Pak Wheelers to inform dem about serious draw backs by direct connection of radiator fan in ur ride Direct Connection of the Radiator Fan In PAKISTAN most of the cars have this problem that their radiator fan starts directly when the car is started regardless of the water temperature in the radiator, because the fan (electrically driven) circuit is by passed from the thermostat switch. Well our mechanics do this because they think that by keeping the water temperature (indicated at the control panel by temperature gauge) to the minimum possible level will help engine perform well. Actually the normal operating temperature of the engine, referred with respect to the water temperature in the radiator is 82 ± 3 °C. It is important to note that the water in the radiator boils at 115 to 120 °C .The radiator cap keeps the water under pressure and that is why the water boils above the its normal boiling point. The calibration of the gauge starts from 50°C .So the total range on the dial of the gauge is from 50°C to 120°C. So when needle reaches the middle of the gauge, engine is actually at its NORMAL WORKING TEMPERATURE {average temp of the gauge (as averages fall in the middle) is (115+50)/2=82.5 °C}. So at the normal working temperature the needle should be somewhere in the middle of the gauge. Whereas our so-called skilled mechanics interpret this as over-heating of the engine.THIS IS TOTALLY WRONG! In a moment I will be listing the disadvantages of having your radiator fan direct .But first I would like to tell the readers about the cooling system of the engine in brief . In water circuit of the engine (water circuit means the path of the water in engine) the effort is made to keep the water away from radiator till the water temperature in the water jacket reaches the 82°C mark. Simply you can say that water is not allowed to go in the radiator and is made to circulate inside the water jacket. This is done by using a device called THERMOSTAT VALVE. This thermostat valve when closed does not allow the water to circulate in the radiator. As soon as the temperature starts to go beyond 78°C the valve opens. This allows the water to be circulated in the radiator. If the heat dissipation of the radiator cannot keep the temperature at about 82°C the THERMOSTAT SWITCH completes the circuit of the electrically driven radiator fan to keep the temperature at 82°C by circulating air. IT IS IMPORTANT TO NOTE that if temperature goes beyond 82°C it is comparatively acceptable as the most likely disadvantage is the increased potential of the engine to knock at higher gear and low engine rpm . But if the temperature is less than the normal operating temperature then it will cause not only the deterioration of the engine performance but also shortening your engine life. So in most of the cars the thermostat valve is removed, making the water circuit complete all the times and also bypassing the thermostat switch to keep fan running with engine regardless of engine temperature . The problems that can arise as a result are discussed below: Problems associated with Carburetion Mixture Preparation The petrol air/mixture preparation in the carburetor is a temperature dependent function. To keep the mixture preparation efficiency maximum the water in the radiator and water jacket is fed to the outer walls (around venturi) of the carburetor to keep it warm. This increase of the temperature helps to mix up the petrol/air. If the temperature of the water is not at optimum, the petrol air mixture preparation in the carburetor will be effected .This will cause the engine to run on non-homogeneous mixture causing engine to misfire and vibrant engine operation is resulted. One must have noticed the vibrant engine operation on cold starting in the morning. This is also due to the same reason as engine temperature is very low and mixture preparation is not good. So by keeping the fan direct you are going make the engine run with vibrations and it will not deliver its full power as the mixture (petrol/air) is not homogeneous (well prepared) . Mixture Distribution If the temperature of the radiator water is kept low then the carburetor temperature also keeps low as the water circulates around the carburetor venturi (the cylindrical passage down the carburetor where air/petrol gets mixed) .The optimum carburetor operation is achieved at higher temperature. So by keeping the fan direct temperature is kept around 55 to 60 °C. This not only effects the mixture preparation but also the mixture movement as well. The mixture is prepared in carburetor and burnt in the cylinder. To get to cylinder the petrol/air passes through carburetor venturi and inlet manifold. If the temperature of venturi and manifold is low then the condensation of the petrol takes place. This will also cause the engine to run on non-homogeneous mixture and the engine running results will be the same as discussed in the above case . It is important to note that if the mixture fed to the cylinder is not homogeneous then the combustion will not produced the desired amount of power .By meaning the homogeneous mixture it is assumed that the mixture strength expressed by weight ratios is same through out the mixture volume .The combustion is so fast that in non homogeneous mixture the petrol will not burn in the areas where not enough air is not present .This results in loss of fuel and engine produces less power .So by keeping your fan direct you will actually be doing the same thing as discussed above as water temperature will be low. Problems associated with Engine Four Stroke Cycle As the engine temperature is not measured directly but is measured with respect to water temperature in the radiator so when the temperature of the radiator water reaches somewhere around 115 to 120°C, the temp. of the engine is enough to cause serious engine damage and it can even result in ceasing the engine . The point here which I would like to emphasize is that engine temperature is never measured directly but the water temperature is measured. So if water temperature is low so is the engine temperature.The discussion to follow will be carried taking the radiator water temperature as reference. When engine is started the temperature at the piston top or piston temperature is very low, same as atmospheric temperature. During engine operation it reaches hundred of degrees centigrade. No metal or alloy is developed yet which has zero expansion rate. So to accommodate the expansion the piston is made oval shaped. At cold starting the piston does not completely seal the cylinder, but as temperature rises the piston expands and seals the gap. At water temperatures above 115 to 120 °C the expansion is so great that the piston gets stuck resulting in serious engine damage. Below temperatures of say 75°C the piston is loosely fit in the cylinder. We will discuss engine condition keeping in mind that water temperature as it is less than 75°C as fan is made to operate directly preventing the engine to operate at its normal working temperature. Intake stroke When the normal operating temperature of the engine is not achieved then the piston is not complete fit in the cylinder. During intake stroke piston descends from TDC(top dead center) and reaches BDC (bottom dead center). So if the piston is not completely fit than the petrol/air will not be sucked in properly. This will result in low engine volumetric efficiency Compression Stroke During compression stroke piston reaches from BDCto TDC. If the temperature of the piston is below normal then it will not fit the cylinder. So the petrol air sucked in prior ot compression, when compressed during compression stroke will bypass the piston and piston rings into the crankcase (It will be discussed in detail later on). So full compression is not achieved and this results in lower engine output and higher fuel consumption . Power Stroke During power stoke the rapidly expanding gases pushes the piston down giving power. If the piston does not fit completely then the expanding gases will by pass the piston rings thus resulting in incomplete power transfer making the engine H.P to decrease and fuel consumption to increase . Exhaust Stroke During exhaust stroke if piston is not complete fit then the exhaust will not be good. The exhaust air will by pass the piston, rings and will reach the crankcase causing oil fouling (it will also be discussed in detail later on) . Engine Oil Fouling (a) If the engine is made to run on low temp than optimum then the compression stroke is not fully efficient. The petrol/air mixture instead of being compressed, by passes the piston and piston rings. On its way to crankcase it passes the cylinder wall. The cylinder walls are soaked with engine oil to lubricate piton and rings. So when petrol by passes the piston rings it mixes with the oil on the cylinder walls. Petrol being excellent organic solvent dissolves and dilutes the engine oil, promoting engine wear . (b) During power and exhaust stroke the burnt gases which are normally non metallic oxides (acidic in nature) bypass the piston rings and enter the crankcase. Here these gases mix with the water vapors. This forms acidic compounds that get mixed with engine oil resulting in altering the oil PH. It makes the engine oil acidic and corrosion always takes speeds up in the acidic medium. For this reason the engine oils are made buffers (which can retain there PH although some amount of acid is added to them). But they can retain there PH only if a small amount of acid is added. So if engine is run consistently on low temperature then it will promote engine wear as engine oil will get acidic . (c) The unburnt particles from the combustion chamber also by pass the piston as they are very small in size. When they enter the crankcase they get mixed with the oil. The engine oil are made detergents. That is they can accumulate small amount of these particles and hold them in suspension or you can say dissolve them. But this tendency is limited to a small amount. If prolonged use of engine at low temperature is carried out then it will cause pre mature engine wear. As these particles do not completely dissolve in oil, they narrow down the small channels in engine lubrication circuit. This effects the engine lubrication as proper amount of oil is not fed to the moving parts resulting in engine wear. Summarizing The Above Discussion The following are the problems summarized keeping in mind that if engine is not running on its normal working temperature. (1) It will decrease the air/petrol mixing efficiency . (2) It will effect the distribution of petrol/air mixture to each cylinder. (3) This will decrease the volumetric efficiency of the engine resulting in increased fuel consumption . (4) The engine oil will get fouled prematurely resulting in more oil changes . (5) The fouled engine oil will result in the premature engine wear shortening the engine life. (6) Vibrant and rough idle (low speed running). (7) Engine will never give its full power and torque . (8) It will increase the fuel consumption without increasing the output of the engine . Rear wheel Drive Cars In rare wheel drive cars the radiator fan is not electrically driven but it is belt driven. It starts running as soon as the engine is started. To keep the engine temperature at optimum level the water is not allowed to circulate (when cold) in the radiator as the THERMOSTAT VALVE remains closed. As soon as the temperature starts to rise the valve is opened and the belt driven fan keeps the air circulating making the water temperature stick to an optimum level. So in rear wheel drive cars the Thermostat valve should NEVER BE REMOVED. As it will result in the same problems as discussed above (by removing thermostat valve and making fan direct in front wheel cars) . MOVED TO CNG/MECHANICAL/TECHNICAL/PERFORMANCE

column1: Assalam-o-Alaikum. Hi everyone, I have a Honda Accord (H) of the 88 model, and I am looking to replace the engine. I need suggestions regarding a fuel-efficient and powerful engine for my car. Currently, it is in its original condition with the stock engine, which is a CNG 1.6cc 12 valve A16A engine.
column2: rohaansaeed;3282953: Here is how it sits in the 3rd Generation Accord engine bay These pictures are off the net for reference purposes. There is only one of these engines in Shershah and its partially damaged (broken tappet cover, missing lifters, missing distributor, missing cam sensor etc. I had the original PH4 ECU for this engine at my home in Karachi along with the original gearbox, original exhaust muffler for this engine (it was an SS item). Sold them off last year. It is very very rare to find this engine,in Pakistan. The scrappie whom I bought this engine from bought these engines by accident thinking they were the van B20. There were two of these engines, one complete to the last plug (including vacuum forest box) and one broken, The complete one was sold off. Your best option would be to find the twin carb B18 engine for this car. There used to be quite a few of them in shershah.

column1: Assalam-o-Alaikum. Hi everyone, I have a Honda Accord (H) of the 88 model, and I am looking to replace the engine. I need suggestions regarding a fuel-efficient and powerful engine for my car. Currently, it is in its original condition with the stock engine, which is a CNG 1.6cc 12 valve A16A engine.
column2: rohaansaeed;3284338: That's a very informative reply I bought off one from Shershah as well, it was complete with the intake box and resonator as well from the 91 Prelude. Currently the car is with a relative and the car is running great MashAllah. B18 will be a very good choice as well, A20A3 and A20A4 aren't bad either, but yeah again, depends upon availability The prelude B20 cants backwards like the F and H series engines, this type B20 was only installed in this model year accord and its immediate cousin prelude. Thats why its so damn rare. The 91 prelude is completely different. I have driven an accord with this engine - its love I tell you, solid torque that can spin wheels like mad - while making sure the engine roar note never gets too rough. But the exhaust box (original one) makes it sound like a much bigger engine at high rpm - The car behind you can hear the exhaust note, but you cannot.

column1: Assalam-o-Alaikum. Hi everyone, I have a Honda Accord (H) of the 88 model, and I am looking to replace the engine. I need suggestions regarding a fuel-efficient and powerful engine for my car. Currently, it is in its original condition with the stock engine, which is a CNG 1.6cc 12 valve A16A engine.
column2: rohaansaeed;3285259: Yes I might be wrong, I think it was the sister Integra. I never had a chance to experience the B20 with the original exhaust as mine was a swap and the exhaust was better suited for the A16, so yeah I grabbed a Toyota Chaser exhaust and enjoyed driving with that on, it had a distinct roar in the mid range RPM's as well Really good engine in my opinion, loved it on long routes and the car felt great with it compared to the clumsy A16. This model accord does not have a transmission mount, the engine bears on 3 mounts, for weight and 2 for torque twisting. The 3 are: timing side, front and back on the subframes, the torque twisting ones are the one long dogbone at the top of the engine and one small rectangle piece under the transmission. Its sister prelude is incredibly rare in Pakistan, I know of one only in Quetta, the Integras share the civic platform and utilise completely different mounting points.

column1: Assalam-o-Alaikum. Hi everyone, I have a Honda Accord (H) of the 88 model, and I am looking to replace the engine. I need suggestions regarding a fuel-efficient and powerful engine for my car. Currently, it is in its original condition with the stock engine, which is a CNG 1.6cc 12 valve A16A engine.
column2: the B20A that you will usually see in yards is the prelude one that sits backwards like an h series, its best to take a picture with you of the accord 3rd generation B20A engine, its engine nos. should either be in 1 million series or 5 million series and should be falling forwards if sitting on the floor. I have had so many people mistake the early 90s Prelude B20A which were quite in abundance in shershah jyard godowns for 3rd gen accord B20A engines.

column1: Assalam-o-Alaikum. Hi everyone, I have a Honda Accord (H) of the 88 model, and I am looking to replace the engine. I need suggestions regarding a fuel-efficient and powerful engine for my car. Currently, it is in its original condition with the stock engine, which is a CNG 1.6cc 12 valve A16A engine.
column2: B20A Hands down Don't even think about swapping a B16, H22 or the D16. Give priority to the B20A engine as it's bolt on. It's PGM-Fi so make sure you get the complete setup (uncut wiring and ECU included). This engine came in the JDM Accords, Preludes and Vigors Never gave me any trouble, car always ran smooth as silk and it's a LOT better option compared to the A-series There were two variants, one is the Black top and one is the Golden top, you're more likely to find the Black top over here, both have an output of a very decent 160hp. You can even give consideration to the B18 series. Whatever you do, stick to the B-series. Do NOT swap the D15 as it will disrupt the weight distribution of the car. B20A and B18's are mostly PGM-Fi so yes you'll be switching from Carby to PGM-Fi, more fuel efficiency and more power. Oh and PGM-Fi stands for Programmed Fuel Injection

column2: Here are some tips that may be helpful: -  - 1. Prioritize self-care: Take care of your physical and mental well-being. Get enough sleep, eat healthy, and engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. -  - 2. Set clear goals: Define what you want to achieve and break it down into smaller, manageable tasks. This can help you stay focused and motivated. -  - 3. Seek support from others: Don't hesitate to reach out to friends, family, or mentors for advice and assistance. Sometimes, just having someone to talk to can provide valuable insights and encouragement. -  - 4. Stay organized: Create schedules, to-do lists, or use productivity tools to keep track of your tasks and deadlines. This can prevent overwhelm and help you stay on top of things. -  - 5. Learn to manage your time effectively: Prioritize your tasks and avoid procrastination. Identify your most productive times of the day and allocate them for more demanding or complex tasks. -  - 6. Embrace a growth mindset: Be open to learning and embracing challenges as opportunities for growth. Don't be discouraged by setbacks; instead, use them as learning experiences. -  - 7. Take breaks and practice self-reflection: It's essential to take regular breaks to recharge and reflect on your progress. This can help you identify areas of improvement and make necessary adjustments to your approach. -  - Remember, everyone's journey is unique, so find what works best for you and adapt as needed.

I'm not crazy about bass, just want to add a bit of lows, that's it. I visited wheel on entertainment and they said it's not possible / helpful. Then, got the quote of 85K to replace front 2 speakers, amp, sub and what not & then I walked away. I only want to install bass tube like jbl or pioneer. Is it possible? Any shop recommendations in Lahore? FYI - Yaris Ativ 1.3 stock Kenwood headunit is pretty good and so are stock 4 speakers. I listen to ONLY 256Kbps songs vis Bluetooth and for some select songs, even rare view mirror vibrates if you look carefully so adding a sub will help. Thoughts on it?
column2: JBL Bazooka Bass tube (non-active) and underseat (active) woofers are currently available. For more information, please contact Mr. Aaqib Arkam at +923214877172 in Wapda Town, Lahore. You can mention the reference of Mohsin Ali from Pakwheels. He offers a wide range of car audio equipment at reasonable prices.

column1: Hello & Salam to All PakWheelers! I own a Cultus and currently I have removed the CNG Cylendir from the Trunk because shortage and long lines of CNG and to add some space for luggage. I put the stock speakers and parcel board back in the car. Before that i was using a chipboard 0.75" speaker board aka phatta with a pair of 6x9 and they were doing the job. Now the stock speakers sound very pathetic as compared to the ones I have before. Now suggest me ideas for getting better audio quality without sacrificing on trunk space. One idea i have in my mind is making adding two pairs of speakers at some moveable sealed MDF cubic box which work just like the stock fiber board, by using some kind of angel iron brackets and base so the weight can be beared. The second thought which is being used by many Cultus owners, put a pair of 6x9 speakers on the stock fiber board. Is it a good idea to add the speakers directly on the stock parcel tray? will it bear the constant weight of speakers around 5kg or more. Along with this 1 pair, how about adding another pair for front underseat speakers, by either using ready made or either using custom made. Have any one tried underseat speakers in Cultus. I am using the underseat space for front speakers because the stock fittings for sepeakers is not good. PS: Suggest me which speakers to use Ovals or Circulars, which can be run directly on Head Unit Stereo. Stereo is Pioneer / Carrozzeria FH-P530 roughly 50Wx4. If someone has any other idea then kindly share. Or please guide me in this regard. Regards, Shahid
column2: irfanor;5208432: Try this, both caddies will cost around 2k. Add any components & let the party jumping. Sent from my OnePlus 2 Nicely done. How is the result?

column2: chshahid2k;5216547: Nice decision i must say. Because there are many fake copies of Kenwood and Pioneer in the market. Sony has the least fake copies in market because ppl go crazy for Kenwood. And authorized sony dealer told me that this speakers has no copy in market yet. He was suggesting me a speaker of Kenwood in 4500, that also has no copy arrived yet. I dont remember its model that pair was lighter in weight than this one. I asked because I was looking for decent pair in light weight as i was going to install it on stock fiber board of Cultus. From where you bought them? was he an authorized dealer?

column1: Hello, my fellow PakWheelers! This is Muhammad Salman from BubbleWaves. We are pleased to offer premium car wash services right at your doorstep, specifically in Lahore. For an exceptional cleaning experience, we utilize NanoSkin products. If you want further information, please feel free to visit our Facebook page at www.facebook.com/bubblewaves.  -  - To ensure convenience, I will personally come to your location to wash your car. The charges for sedan-sized vehicles are 350/- while 4x4 vehicles will be charged at 450/-. Additionally, if you're interested in waxing your car with NanoSkin, the cost will be 500/-.  -  - Moreover, we provide detailed packages for different types of vehicles. For hatchbacks, the package is priced at 9000/-, for sedans it is 12000/-, and for SUVs it is 15000/-.  -  - For booking or any other inquiries, you can contact me directly at 0300-0630141 via call or WhatsApp.
column2: are you doing it yourself Salman, or have hired someone for the job.. please do post photos/videos here so you can get more interest.

column1: Asslam u alaikum brothers, I am already posting in one more forum regarding my 1974 PROJECT KE35. i m literally in do or die situation at the moment coz my mechanic told me to go for beams 3sge engine in my 1974 corolla, it's 2.0 L with 6fwd speed. It was in October 2015, but since then till now more then 1.5years he failed to start my car and my car is in stationary position since that long time. I have met one person today his name is umer and he had a v v v v v bad experience in beams while he was trying to fit that engine in RX8. As he shared all his bad experiences with me related to beams and in the end he spent more then 2 lacs just on engine electrician works and he failed to run that engine properly coz of his unadjustable missing air intake sensor. (Which is missing in my engine too) and there is no such single beams in Pakistan who is working properly with dual vvti cos our mechanics n electricians are totally shit and they don't even know how to run n start this engine properly and these people already made my life miserable. As my car is kind of unique, it's 2 door coupe 1974 looks like 1976 corolla. And he advised me to get rid of this engine n go for 3SFE engine which is use to be in RAV4 n many other Toyota models like MR2. And is much more easy to use and will fit on the same foundation of beams engine, even I don't need to change my gear assembly. So plz I m looking for good advice, especially from some experienced n professional members on this pakwheels forum who can help me out and advise me shall I go for 3SFE engine with gear assembly of beams or should I change the both or shall I stick with beams. Which is most beneficial for me? It will be really kind of u guys if u can take me out of this madness U can help me out while replying in this forum, leaving me a text msg ( with ur name n ref of pakwheels forums) or just call me. May Allah Pak will bless u all on that Regards Masood Alam 0333-5275278
column2: Bhai you know our mechanics one will say no its impossible can't be done bla bla and the one next to him will do it. So be sure before changing. And bhai you got the engine with uncut wiring right? Then there's shouldn't be any problem.

column2: Brother thanks for the daigram, Let me tell u the main issue, air intake sensor only works with it's own intake of beams which have multi layer and maintain the RPM according to the inflow of air. But I don't have it's intake and I don't have anyone in states who can bring me these things

I am so happy as I found iGO the best navigation software but other like sygic or navitel is crap and boring.

column1: Hello everyone, I am currently residing in Japan and I am in need of the most recent maps or SD card for a NSCP-W62 (Prius). I require the original Japanese version from Toyota, preferably from 2017, but versions from 2016 or even 2015 will suffice to get started. Is there anyone who can provide me with an image or downloadable files? Thank you, Tesman
column2: "IGO Primo 9.8 navigation is available for free, including maps of Pakistan and TTS voice. Additionally, Sygic 2015 maps are also included for In-Car Entertainment (ICE). Enjoy the benefits of free navigation and avoid the expense of purchasing a new SD card. Follow the instructions below: -  - 1. Make sure you have a Wince Device (Car LCD) capable of navigation, such as City Aspire Caska or any other compatible device. - 2. Obtain a micro SD card with a minimum capacity of 1 GB. - 3. Download either the Sygic or IGO Primo software from the following links. - 4. Extract the downloaded file using WinRar on your PC or mobile device. - 5. Copy and paste the extracted files onto the SD card. - 6. Insert the SD card into your car's LCD device. (Note: If your City Aspire Caska LCD has a default path, the main folder should be named ""MobileNavigator"" and contain an .EXE file.) - 7. Set the path as ""MobileNavigator"" in the LCD device."

column1: I am opening this thread to get the feedback regarding quality of Clutch Plate set available in Market, brands available, OEM sets and their make. I want to install it in Corolla 2007 and had a bad experience in past where either Mechanic has made the bad installation or quality of set installed was not good. 1) Vibrations on Clutch Release, not smooth transition and on uphill during release, one can easily smell the burning of Clutch. Vehicle travelled around 24000 km since previous clutch Plate, Pressure Plate and Clutch Throw out bearing change. Clutch does not slip but I am not liking the symptoms and considering replacement. Vehicle tested by many Mechanics and all of them recomended opening the entire thing and correcting the fault. But, if i have to get the entire job done again then its better i re-install every thing again. Your feedback, experience will be very helpful for all the members.
column2: my 2 cent advise - please check the master cylinder & slave cylinder kit of your clutch hydraulics before dismantling the power train ASCO [aisen seiki] is OEM for Toyota Clutch parts

column1: Can any battery expert here tell me how long AGS battery last? What are the key points to extend the life of battery Thanks All Click here for SOLUTION254
column2: If prepared with distilled water and lab grade acid and maintained correctly it will last a surprisingly long time.

column1: Can any battery expert here tell me how long AGS battery last? What are the key points to extend the life of battery Thanks All Click here for SOLUTION254
column2: As Omron posted, good input = good output. good electrolyte = long life bad electrolyte = short life.

column1: Can any battery expert here tell me how long AGS battery last? What are the key points to extend the life of battery Thanks All Click here for SOLUTION254
column2: If you had that battery prepped with distilled water and lab grade acid (contact process product) the battery would have lasted much much longer. You only topped with distilled water, while your battery seller prepped it with tap water and impure acid.

column1: Can any battery expert here tell me how long AGS battery last? What are the key points to extend the life of battery Thanks All Click here for SOLUTION254
column2: when I had my workshop in Karachi, I prepped batteries myself. Every single one worked strong as an ox and would crank the engine like it was a childs toy. It didnt lose charge overnight either. Customers had the same batteries for 4 to 5 or more years in Karachi - in all sorts of cars. I charged more than a regular shop as the acid I bought had to be purchased personally - while distilled water was supplied to me for very little surcharge over its actual price. The results were spectacular. I usually maintained the SG between 1.26 to 1.28 - checked with scales not a hydrometer. You also need to protect the batteries from heat - so make sure you have some insulation or heatshield to protect from the brunt of heat. Also make sure your battery terminals are of excellent quality, not those screw press sheet metal trash you see in almost every other car in Pakistan.

column1: Can any battery expert here tell me how long AGS battery last? What are the key points to extend the life of battery Thanks All Click here for SOLUTION254
column2: Almost every battery has a lifespan of 2-3 years...

column1: Can any battery expert here tell me how long AGS battery last? What are the key points to extend the life of battery Thanks All Click here for SOLUTION254
column2: "You see, it is better to use ""distilled water"" as it does not contain the minerals that are found in drinking water. Avoid using mineral water like Nestle Kinley, etc. The 19-litre water bottle from Nestle is filtered water, not mineral water."

You may for sure spend only 10k, but my point is that is gonna land u in the middle of nowhere very soon God Forbid Cars, Weapons and Printers : i STRONGLY believe they have a mind of their own if you dont spend on them or take care of them, they have the tendency to fail when you need them the most Cars: Will fail in the middle of a desert, not outside your house Weapon: Will fail when enemy is at the gate, not when you are targetting water bottles Printer: Will fail when boss is screaming on the phone for that annual report, not when you are printing car sketches for your kids to colour but then, thats just me Hope u end up spending wisely, wherever it is

column2: the problem with all Altezza engines in Pakistan is that they have been beat to death and then some more, because of one or a combination of the following. 1 - aasum pick 2 - rwd hai iss pe drift maarenge 3 - egzaast lagake limiter maarenge - dhamakay wala. there are more but it would become R rated then. no auction scrapyard in other countries is interested in these anymore as they are obsolete and dead weight - specially when shipping stopped during covid19, any engines lying at those auction yards in dubai, sharjah, malaysia etc, became rusted solid and almost all were sold as scrap by weight to foundries.

column2: quite right. its also called "bro tax" - e.g. buy anything for a supra 2JZ engine and suddenly its very expensive while the same part on it is found on other toyota engines for less than half of "supra bro tax pricing" then you have the "one up" culture in Pakistan where people pay premium to outbid other buyers to become first buyer of item regardless of actual price of item. The only person winning in such situation is the scrap dealer selling the engine.

column2: Check/test the cold start Injector (the red marked area over the intake manifold, it has a fuel line running to it). At cold engine Remove the wiring connector from the Injector and check the resistance between its terminals. If the engine is cold the resistance should be between 3 - 5 ohms. Also, check for voltage at the terminals of the wiring harness (with ignition switch on). Caution: Be sure that the ignition switch is "off" during the resistance check, battery voltage (12v) can ruin your ohm meter. Also check if the fuel line is primed at ignition key ON. Perhaps injector rail does not have enough fuel pressure, check for fuel pump and the filter in fuel tank.

column1: Guys, I have purchased 2016 Toyota Passo that came with company fitted rear camera and rear bumper parking sensor but it's missing the LCD so I have installed 7-inch china made LCD its working fine with rear company fitted camera but not working with parking sensor. I want to know if its possible to make parking sensor workable with china LCD? I suppose parking sensor should work independently with beeping sound only. Any help in this regard will be highly appreciated. Thanks
column2: I also have the same car model with company fitted back camera, integrated LCD working fine and original parking censors but they don't work either.

column1: The car is Civic 2006 oriel manual with stock D16W9 engine. The issue is engine stops during driving. Its ECU relay clicks like 5 times at like 1 second interval, engine too stalls, restarts, stalls.... till the last click and the car shuts off. Cluster lights work. Check engine light comes on during this duration. when ignition is switched off, check engine light goes away, yet the engine cranks but not start. After few minutes, all is back to normal and car starts just fine just for few more KMs and issue occurs again. Have scanned it and there are no DTCs. (both when car exhibits this behaviour and normal working too). Here are the findings so far: 1- Checked the wiring, under dash, there are 2 PGM FI relays, one is for fuel pump/injectors, this relay stops working when the issue occurs. 2- Some jugaaru previously tried to resolve it by jumping the second relay (PGM FI 2, fuel pump relay) via Main PGM FI relay. With this jugaar, when the issue occurs, CEL blinks, relay 2 clicks but car stays driving (as the relay is directly powered). I have removed this jugaar and wiring is back to stock state, now car shuts off when issue occurs. As there are no DTCs, banging my head as where to start. Have cleaned and properly attached ground terminals: body, engine, battery. Here are the things i suspect: 1. Crank/Cam sensor 2. Alternator (It seems to be doing when there is electrical load, i.e. headlights AC on) but not sure, as happened without it too once. 3. ECU is malfunctioning Btw, will Honda HDS be able to read more DTCs? as currently generic scanner is being used. Any good in taking it to honda? Dont want it to be destroyed at the hands of street side "lektrishuns". Your help is highly appreciated. @capsat @Xulfiqar @SER_GTR
column2: Have you check the power wires of ecu? And fuse box? If your ecu turns off fuel pump relay will turns off as well. Any shortage in sensors wiring can cause ecu to turn off as well. And same problem appears.

column1: Hey all, This thread is dedicated to the restoration of my first car, a 1961 Morris Mini Minor,simply 'Mini' for convenience. My infatuation with vintage and classic cars goes far back,how far even i'm not sure of.But this story starts with summer vacations and two of my closest friends,enthusiastic car knuts themselves and fellow pakwheelers,saadsmalik and bilaltq,heres a shoutout to both of you,YOU'RE THE BEST FRIENDS EVER!! I found this car on pakwheels in the summer of 2007.thankyou for finding it bilal and since then its been with me,although the project didn't start till last month,which was partly due to studies and disencouragement from my peers.yes,all of you critics are worthless and should buy and restore mehrans,because at least they sell!!.ridicuolous As with all passions, there isn't much rational explanation to the time and effort spent on these cars and i feel theres no need.this is a warning to all those people who think its a waste of time and money and whatnot STAY OUT!! this place is not for you(and believe me-i'm being polite here) from here on, i shall let the pictures tell the story,feel free to comment/suggest and this thread goes with a call out to everyone and anyone who can help me find parts for this car in pakistan,key word being pakistan.
column2: bloody hell!! the previous owner had nearly destroyed it,.. glad to see this car finally make it into the right hands (Y) keep the updates coming.

column2: Here are the specifications for the 1961 Mini 1000. I hope you find them useful: -  - - Wheelbase: 2038 mm (80.2 in) - - Track: Front 1213 mm (47.8 in), Rear 1165 mm (45.9 in) - - Length: 3048 mm (120 in) - - Width: 1397 mm (55 in) - - Height: 1346 mm (53 in) - - Length-to-wheelbase ratio: 1.5 - - Ground clearance: Not specified - - Kerb weight: 584 kg (1288 lb) - - Fuel capacity: 25 litres (5.5 UK Gallons) - - Bore x Stroke: 62.43 mm x 81.30 mm (2.46 in x 3.2 in) - - Bore/stroke ratio: 0.77 - - Cylinders: 4 in-line - - Displacement: 997 cc (60.841 cu in) - - Unitary capacity: 249.25 cc/cylinder - - Type: Overhead Valve (OHV), 2 valves per cylinder (8 valves in total) - - Sump: Wet sump - - Compression ratio: 9:1 - - Fueling: 2 SU HS2 carburettors - - Maximum power (Net): 55.8 PS (55.0 bhp) (41 kW) @ 6000 rpm - - Specific output: 55.2 bhp/litre (0.9 bhp/cu in) - - Maximum torque (Net): 73.0 Nm (54 ft·lb) (7.4 kgm) @ 3600 rpm - - bmep: 920.1 kPa (133.5 psi) - - Specific torque: 73.22 Nm/litre - - Coolant: Water - - Aspiration: Natural (non-turbocharged) - - 0-50 mph: 11.80 seconds - - 0-60 mph: 17.20 seconds - - 0-100 mph: Not specified - - Standing ¼ mile: 21.10 seconds - - Top speed: 135 km/h (84 mph) - - Power-to-weight ratio: 94.18 bhp/ton - - Engine location: Front - - Engine alignment: Transverse - - Drive: Front-Wheel Drive (FWD) - - Steering: Rack & Pinion - - Turns lock-to-lock: 2.250 - - Turning circle: 9.60 m - - Suspension: Front Independent Rear Suspension (I.RS.) with Coil Springs - - Tyres: Front 5.20-10, Rear 5.20-10 - - Brakes: Front Disc, Rear Drum - - Brake Diameter: Front 178 mm, Rear 178 mm - - Transmission: 4-speed manual - - Top gear ratio: 1.00 - - Final drive ratio: 3.77

column1: AoA, One of my friend claim he had a great solution of cleaning the dashboard. He got some stuff and put it on my car dashboard. I noticed some whiteness the other day. I thought it was just the solution he used not completely wiped off the dashboard. In short, I tried to clean it with water and then with dashboard sprays but to no avail. On closer examination, to my dismay, I noticed the black paint on dashboard has came off on certain parts. Repainting can be only viable solution, no? Any suggestion where can I get it restored at a decent price to original state? I am in Rawalpindi by the way.
column2: very common complain in city if in twin cities visit carbographics

Any suggestion where can I get it restored at a decent price to original state? I am in Rawalpindi by the way.

column1: Hello Everyone, I was looking for a budgted automatic vehicle for sometime after surveys and considering available alternatives i choose Daihatsu Coure. Reasons for choosing this vehicle is, 1. Hatchback 2. Parts are readily available 3. Parts are cheap 4. I have personally used coure in the past and i loved it Now, after choosing coure i went to local scrap yards and looked for the parts i would require to complete my project and to my surprise they were dirt cheap. Started to look for a decent vehicle which falls in my budget (My aim was to build a Automatic reliable daily runner under 4 lacs). So with respect to my budget and then spending on it i started to search for a coure around 3 lacs. I was quoted a vehicle (Coure 2001 M/T) for 350,000, went to inspect it and it seemed okay and after negotiations i bought it for 325,000. Details of the vehicle : Model : 2001 Color : Maroon Transmission: Manual CNG : Yes Air Con : Working In short this vehicle was in perfect running condition, The most amzing thing about this vehicle was it had JDM Mira Power Windows (All 4 doors had power windows), JDM Mira Upholstery, JDM Mira Cluster, JDM Mira wooden trims and JDM Mira Front bumper grill. Plan: My plan is to 1. First swap Auto Transmission 2. Sort out all mechanical and electrical issues 3. Fix Suspension issues 4. New tires and stock rims and wheel caps. P.S. This wont be a fancy build with loud exhaust's, customs paint jobs or polio cambers so sorry in advance
column2: Great Project undertaken flush the transmission fluid when it is still out. clean engine & engine bay with scotch brite & dish washing liquid. Keep all items removed from your vehicle in safe place. It is your own property nothing to be kept by the workshop doing swap. keep this thread updated.

column2: a dirty engine bay after swap is sign of charsi mechanic and lazy owner i can see you left it to mechanic to wash & clean the engine bay and he skipped it. TOLD you to ensure its done before engine is moved in . - now you need to do it yourself 1 sachet of any shampoo in 1.5 liter of water be mixed n sprayed over engine bay i suggest remove the hood do it over cold engine and left for 10 minutes before washing with clean water blow dry the engine.

column1: @xulfiqar I did... Xulfiqar;4235646: Now go buy a leppon filter and cut it open, you will have your quality test. I am not impressed. For Toyota users, genuine Thai made filters are better alternative if you cannot opt for Japan made filters. I should probably give it benefit of the doubt as I have no idea how a genuine LePPON can be differentiated from a fake LePPON. I took it apart to see if it is good quality as in 200 Rupee range, it is cheap compared to Genuine Toyota filters of Thai origin (400 Rupees) or Japan origin (800/850 Rupees). If I had found the quality good enough, I would opt for it in future since it is cheap but I think we can get a good conclusion about filters, if it is cheap, it missing something i.e. cheap filter media/no proper pressure plate/no proper relief valve/cheap anti-drain back valve. This is not only true with LePPON but even between Toyota's Thai and Japan made filters. I know there are fakes available in the market of Toyota as well but we do know reliable part shops and have got reference of original to compare them with. (You can simply shine a light in the filter hole before purchase and confirm the filter media colour, valve's presence etc.) I will be taking the Toyota filters apart as well, not new though since they are expensive. I don't think there is any need since I have already posted photos of genuine filters taken apart from another site but just to confirm, that the filters sold here have got the same mechanism inside as the originals shown in the other topic. The pictures speak for themselves. I may be wrong about pointing some parts of the filter. Please keep the discussion healthy. Visual exterior comparison  Visual exterior comparison  I hate insects and they creep me out, no shame in admitting it. For a moment my heart was racing when I saw this inside the LePPON filter because it looked like an insect...  and it begins  A spring that pushes against the filter cartridge, no idea what the purpose is. Then it is the filter element. The empty shell. Anti-drain back valve/cheap rubber feel. The bottom which connects inside the vehicle.  Close up of the empty shell  Close up of the anti-drain back valve sitting on the holes.  Close up of the inner part with anti-drain back valve removed.  The part which connects with vehicle. Rubber seal/ring removed.  Close up of the rubber valve/seals, cheap?  This is how it sits in the filter cartridge. @xulfiqar , please explain this to me. The spring is used instead of a pressure plate? and that small dot under the spring can actually be pressed inside. This is supposed to be the relief valve? Close up coming in the end. What are cons of the filter set like this???  Close up view from several angles of the filter element. I am honestly not sure whether it was my brute force while putting it inside the pipe wrench, which distorted the filter i.e. not straight or this is how a cheap filter comes? Since the housing was bending after I reached the half point with saw.  Size of the empty filter housing in comparison to the filter element. It is TINY!  I couldn't wait to use the digital caliper which I purchased recently. Genuine Toyota Thai made filter cartridge height is 54 mm!! You need MORE filter area, more = better!  There's that creepy thing again inside filter... which turned out to be glue!!!  MORE PHOTOS IN SECOND POST
column2: the filter media is half the required area, the bypass valve is not all impressive, it relies on a ball to seal against a stamped sheet metal cap. thats like trying to seal a pipe a rusty plate. The antidrainback also looks like its not able to withstand high temperature. As I said before, OE filters are the best way to go. leppon, pokemon, chinchao filters etc look like filters but usually are not.

column2: mianaasim;4255757: With all due respect I disagree with some of the conclusions derived: More filter media does NOT mean the oil stays cleaner longer....it is the quality of paper material. Was there a material analysis done to determine if filter paper used is an appropriate one or upto the mark?? Second thing which could have determined the quality is a flow analysis...how much dirt is actually being filtered over a given amount of time at given pressure/temperature. Dont want to drag the discussion to the fact that if all the filter other than japanese are rubbish then we'd be seeing thousands of engines dying every year because of the bad oil filters...and turning whole country into junk yard. There are few things on which filter performance is dependent. These includes oil viscosity, oil temperature, oil pressure and oil flow rate. Taking apart a new oil filter can present some findings but not conclusions. So, if we want to study something we will have to do: 1- Material Analysis 2- Flow Analysis 3- Comparitive Analysis - Take apart Leppon, Guard, Japs, Thai filters after use in same type of engine with same type of engine oil in same conditions after same mileage. This is my opinion, no offense to any1 or any brand. Just a fruit for thought. Thanx. First step to analyse a filter is that you actually measure the medial sq cm and inspect the construction. In this case we see that the manufacturer was a little shy in packing the media in place - The filtration test is done at a whole level and a controlled amount of "contaminant" is injected into the oil and the filter run. Usually if the surface area of the media is short and the filter is low cost to purchase one can easily deduce that the filter wont be upto its job - unless its being manufactured by United Nations. I have run into some filters that actually were simply flushing oil in bypass - because the valves were so poorly made they lifted with 10 psi pressure -normal oil pressure in an engine at idle is about 14 psi at minimum. If you remember the old K series toyota engine with upside down oil filters - It was mandatory to use a genuine item unless you liked to hear the crank rattle. The antidrainback valve should seal tight and prevent the big 600 ml oil filter from emptying out while parked. We all have seen a lot of those engines fail in Pakistan. (Blame = aail 2 no. hai meray bhai - no matter if the filter was literally an unmarked item with no brand whatsoever) I once posted a fiiter media here that was cotton waste + twigs + dead bugs + saw dust. Those are used in old mercedes benz diesel engines and do a remarkable job of cleaning up the oil because the only thing you replace in that engine is literally the filter media, the antidrain back and bypass are in the engine. anyway - long n short is that you get what you pay for. and such paper media does not work beyond approx 5000 kms of service, it will eventually start to tear up. If you want long life from an engine use proper filters and change at correct interval.
