If I had found the quality good enough, I would opt for it in future since it is cheap but I think we can get a good conclusion about filters, if it is cheap, it missing something i.e. cheap filter media/no proper pressure plate/no proper relief valve/cheap anti-drain back valve. This is not only true with LePPON but even between Toyota's Thai and Japan made filters. I know there are fakes available in the market of Toyota as well but we do know reliable part shops and have got reference of original to compare them with. (You can simply shine a light in the filter hole before purchase and confirm the filter media colour, valve's presence etc.) I will be taking the Toyota filters apart as well, not new though since they are expensive. I don't think there is any need since I have already posted photos of genuine filters taken apart from another site but just to confirm, that the filters sold here have got the same mechanism inside as the originals shown in the other topic. The pictures speak for themselves. I may be wrong about pointing some parts of the filter. Please keep the discussion healthy. Visual exterior comparison  Visual exterior comparison  I hate insects and they creep me out, no shame in admitting it. For a moment my heart was racing when I saw this inside the LePPON filter because it looked like an insect...  and it begins  A spring that pushes against the filter cartridge, no idea what the purpose is. Then it is the filter element. The empty shell. Anti-drain back valve/cheap rubber feel. The bottom which connects inside the vehicle.  Close up of the empty shell  Close up of the anti-drain back valve sitting on the holes.  Close up of the inner part with anti-drain back valve removed.  The part which connects with vehicle. Rubber seal/ring removed.  Close up of the rubber valve/seals, cheap?  This is how it sits in the filter cartridge. @xulfiqar , please explain this to me. The spring is used instead of a pressure plate? and that small dot under the spring can actually be pressed inside. This is supposed to be the relief valve? Close up coming in the end. What are cons of the filter set like this???  Close up view from several angles of the filter element. I am honestly not sure whether it was my brute force while putting it inside the pipe wrench, which distorted the filter i.e. not straight or this is how a cheap filter comes? Since the housing was bending after I reached the half point with saw.  Size of the empty filter housing in comparison to the filter element. It is TINY!  I couldn't wait to use the digital caliper which I purchased recently. Genuine Toyota Thai made filter cartridge height is 54 mm!! You need MORE filter area, more = better!  There's that creepy thing again inside filter... which turned out to be glue!!!  MORE PHOTOS IN SECOND POST
column2: mashriqain;4260178: @Xulfiqar, can quality and toughness of the filter paper be checked like this: Take equal measurements of paper from two oil filters (or put the whole thing after removing from the casing), then AIM & FIRE at them from the same distance, with a paintball gun? What are we trying to deduce here?

column1: Dear PWers, I need help with my audio setup. I have 2 pairs of Hertz Uno 165 components and 12" Hertz Sub installed. For player, I have Nakamichi NAM5230 Android headunit. For Amp, I have Nakamichi 4 channel chinese amp. Although the setup is not very expensive and one can only expect moderately decent sound, my problem is that I am not getting a linear sound when raising or lowering the volume. For e.g, at low volumes, I can feel the thumping from the sub but very low mids. slightly raising the volume lowers the bass but increases the mids and highs. not unless I go beyond 65% volume I get good amount of bass but the mids r still high. What could be the issue? I have tried different amps but same result. Speakers and sub came from my old car so it is tried and tested.
column2: What city are you based in? If the issue is the same with different amps, the problem could be with the headunit

Problem is, a lot of the older shops that a few years back were selling good quality audio equipment have moved to selling copies/fakes etc etc. Chinese products have flooded the market for a while now. FOCAL was a bit hit. Sehgal was selling focal comps which were a knockoff but any second person who hasn't put in the research will think they're getting a great deal because the shop guy will tell them these are French big brand speakers when in reality, almost all the big name brands have their entry level speakers being manufactured in China under their regulations and standards Morel, Helix (AF), Focal are a few known names which make products that cost thousands of USDs but their entry level speakers and amps are made in China (maximo, maximus, auditor, access, B,F etc etc) The Chinese knockoff will probably be made in the factory next door over there, and they'll pass for the real deal unless you have a keen eye

column1: Dear PWers, I need help with my audio setup. I have 2 pairs of Hertz Uno 165 components and 12" Hertz Sub installed. For player, I have Nakamichi NAM5230 Android headunit. For Amp, I have Nakamichi 4 channel chinese amp. Although the setup is not very expensive and one can only expect moderately decent sound, my problem is that I am not getting a linear sound when raising or lowering the volume. For e.g, at low volumes, I can feel the thumping from the sub but very low mids. slightly raising the volume lowers the bass but increases the mids and highs. not unless I go beyond 65% volume I get good amount of bass but the mids r still high. What could be the issue? I have tried different amps but same result. Speakers and sub came from my old car so it is tried and tested.
column2: ne5532 opa2164 jrc6058 these r commonly available opamps locally and can be replaced with socket

column2: if you are referring to parts coming from Aliexpress, then rest assured 99.99% are fake, the scrap the surface and laser itch the intended part number. I have tried lots of OPamps and caps from aliexpress, and then tested them, only a few which were USED 2nd hand parts were founfd to be original but again faulty. rest all of them were fake. You can also check youtube regarding legitimacy of such parts, use an alcolohol dip swap to dissolv the printing or magnetic test. as far as OPAMPs are concerned, the reliable source is pulling from the old faulty CD Players and other equipment involving audio output. I ususaly visit the reapir market to get hold of boards having good opamps, or ask the tech to remove them for me.

column1: It was Feb 2018 (when I was almost done restoring my 1963 bug) that someone told me that there is a 1961 VW Bug (Totally Rusted/gutted) near Rawal Town in Islamabad and the owner is even willing to sell it to a Kabaria as many potential buyers had rejected the car. Having restored a 63 Bug as a test case i was really confident that we can restore any bug in Pakistan provided we have correct panels available and a right body work ustad. Having worked with Mr Safdar from Pir wadhai i was really confident that if i provide him correct panels he can do any grafting work. So i decided to contact the seller and bought the bug for PKR 70,000, he was more than willing to help me relocate the car as he wanted to get rid of it ASAP. Here comes Nasir Shaikh bhai to my rescue and offered me his storage for safely parking the car till i plan on starting the restoration, i cant thank him more for all his valuable suggestions and insights. Initially i wanted to just restore it to its formal glory but with the passage of time I realized that it will need alooooooooooooot of work and body panels to correctly restore it because the whole front end was rusted to core, rain gutters were gutted with holes in it, both doors were rusted and nothing was left in them, whole rear apron was deshaped and rusted. Keeping in mind the current situation i decided to experiment with the car and decided to graft in an oval rear window and make it an Oval window Bug . As i started searching regarding differences between a 58-64 Bug and an Oval i came to know that it not just the rear window that was changed in 1958-1964 but many other small changes. Changes which were made on a bugs in 1958-1964 were, Front Window was increased in size by 17%, Rear window was changed from Oval to a bigger version, Trunk Liner area was redesigned, Wiper Assembly was changed, Icepick handles were changed to push button style in 1960, as my bug was 1961 so I needed those as well, Whole front end was redesigned with a new fuel tank and brake fluid reservoir area. Front Hood hinges were changed along with lifting mechanism (Springs were installed in 1958), Front apron was changed from 4 fins to 3 fins, Rear Apron was changed from H pattern to no pattern, Dashboard was changed, These above mentioned changes are just the visual changes not to mention the mechanic changes (which were of no concern to me as i want my bug to just visually look like an Oval). So i decided to look for panels and find out the cost of sourcing them, thats a story for the next time. Till then enjoy the pictures of when i rescued the car .
column2: if you want a true frankenstein from the actual pits of hell.. then find yourself a fresh built Mazda 13BREW and midship mount it in the VW bug. (This is like owning a literal attack dog as a pet) OR you can subaru it with a turbo boxer, (its like owning a tamed/domesticated hunting dog as a pet) OR you can leave it as it is and rebuild the original flat 4 (its like owning a Golden retriever as a pet) Choice is yours - I would prefer the golden though.

column1: I've encountered a lot of "mechanics" talking about using worm gear clamps on cooling, oil, etc. hoses because they allegedly perform better than spring clamps. On the other hand, you'll often see OEM hoses using a spring action clamp, like so: Now, I don't buy it. A spring clamp seems to distribute clamping force evenly across the circumference of the hose, reacting to expansion and contraction of the material with temperature changes. A worm gear clamp, by design, would bite harder on one point on the hose and would not evenly distribute clamping force. This effect would only grow worse as a hose expands and contracts. I would assume that after completing several thermal cycles, the clamp would begin to cause a leak or even bite into the hose and breach it. Many mechanics, like politicians, learn to confidently lie through their teeth to maintain business. I suspect that worm gear clamps are only used because they are adjustable, low cost, and don't require getting the sizing right, not because they offer any particular advantages. What do you think? P.S. Ever seen a rusted brake line jugaar fix with a couple-centimetre section of generic hose and two worm clamps?
column2: pwuser162557941033: A worm gear clamp, by design, would bite harder on one point on the hose and would not evenly distribute clamping force. This effect would only grow worse as a hose expands and contracts. THIS!!! I made a video once and shared it with my freinds on hose clamps, I showed a bunch of clamps which I recall were. spring clamp oetiker cinch clamp ABA blue hose clamps norma torro (Mercedes/BMW) clamp bellville washer loaded worm clamp regular perforated thread worm clamp The best are spring type as they self adjust constantly forever, The bad thing is that they are an exact size and dont work on aftermarket hoses. What I do with hoses that dont use spring clamps, I use a touch of hylomar or no.2 gasket maker (oldschool stuff) on the barb/nipple and then install the hose - it seals the hose and is removable in the future too, it prevents pitting of the barb which eventually leaks. The bellville washer type worm clamp work fantastic but are very pricey - used in HD diesels etc. They are worm clamps which are self adjusting too. The norma and ABA ones wont dig into the hose and apply a bit more even pressure compared to the perforated thread clamp. But are actually inferior to spring clamps in this regard, however they can easy accommodate aftermarket hoses too.

column2: permatex number 2 is sold at oldschool markets like plaza and no.3 (indian head shellac) is sold at almost every generic motorcycle and car spare parts store - its recalled as "shilik ki botall" - it comes with the oldschool foam/cotton head on the end of a stick. For the pitted aluminium, its best to use epoxy to build it up and refinish it, I do that for ancient stuff like oldschool BMW, Mercedes and Jag flanges which have been out of production for more than 3 decades now. (literally the foundries that made them are gone)

column2: Hylomar tip sounds like a good call, I'll use it on a hose that needs replacement. FWIW, I've seen Chinese spring clamps available in different diameters, worth trying out with locally available hoses once OD is measured properly to see how they perform under pressure and thermal cycling. +1 for mentioning Belleville washer clamps, thank you. Will try to see if I can find some Chinese "budget" executions. I'd love to see your video, too.

column2: Couldn't find Hylomar, used Harris (harris.com.pk) Genuine Gray Silicone Sealant Adhesive instead for my upper radiator hose secured with worm gear clamps. Sanded the pitted, rusted surfaces of the pipes as well. Are you talking about Permatex No. 2 Gasket Maker? It's all just "silly cone" here. Resistance to ethylene glycol is not a feature of all RTVs or sealants, but I can't find one that specifically mentions resistance, like Permatex' Water Pump and Thermostat Housing Specialty RTV.

column1: How and why is the hydraulic clutch system better than cable clutch in a car? Is there a difference between the driving feel of both these clutch types?
column2: Hydraulic system uses less force at the input and gives a soft feeling. Further it efficiently enhances the resultant force at receiver end to get the operation done, hence heavy engines are mated with hydraulic clutch system. Mechanically wired system will need a very big lever arm consuming more space if used in bigger applications.

column1: AoA, like every new person i had the same problem of idle stop not working and like others i had the same problem that green light of eco idle wasn't showing up i tried many things changed battery (There is no secondary battery in Mira Eis), reset of ECU many times shown to different electricians but no code was showing up in the scanner. Finally i came to know about Arshad Electrician in Chah Sultan Rawalpindi on Glass Factory Road he checked the car and told me that he will do the system calibration, he started the calibration process as he has a direct contact with the company people who guide him of different code solutions as i saw some snapshots and whatsapp messages in his cell phone but in any case after calibration and few test drives it started working but one thing is mandatory for idle stop to work a good quality battery minimum of 50 amperes as i was already using 48 amp phoenix but it was giving good amperes to engine but low amperes to cvt through which idle stop works. So if anyone in rawalpindi/Islamabad is facing the same issue he can straight go to this man for the solution for any further queries you people can also PM me Regards Zeeshan Saeed Ch.

column1: I am using 215/55R17 Dunlop on my Honda Vezel. The tyres are now driven for 51,000kms. Since day one when I received the car brand new, I had issues with tyre noise and comfort level. The tyres feel hard and even small cracks on roads are felt. Vezel’s suspension is notorious for being hard to give a sporty feel but I think the tyres are not good. Someone recommended Michelin Primacy 225/50R17 and said tyres are soft. My question is, will 225/50 fit propey in genuine Vezel Rims? Or shall I get 215/55 in Michelin Primacy? Please recommend other soft tyres which absorb the shocks and cracks of road. Help will be appreciated.
column2: The Yokohama Advan DB V551 is the best tire! I have tried Continental, Dunlop, Michelin, and although they are all fine, for a comfortable and quiet ride, you should choose the Yokohama Advan DB V551. You will thank me later!

column1: Dear PakWheelers I am browsing this forum's pages since last few days, especially related to Toyota Corolla 2.0D, because I might buy one in the near future. Now let's come to the topic of concern for me. I am a bit confused related to Toyota 2C engine oil recommendation that I discovered on the PakWheels forum pages. Most people recommend Caltex Delo Gold Ultra; ZIC 5000; and some people suggest putting any good diesel engine oil with API CI-4 rating. While checking the 2C's repair manual, I got to know that the recommended API rating for 2C engine is CF (CE and CD can also be used). Next, I checked various well-known engine oils that are famous especially for petrol engines, for example, Mobil 1 5W-50 Peak Life and OW-40 New Life, Shell Helix Ultra 5W-40, ZIC XQ 5W-40 and so on and so forth, they all have API rating of SN/CF or SM/CF. The "oil guide utility" or "oil selector utility" that is available on many oil manufacturers' websites (Mobil, Eurol, etc.) and they primarily used for choosing right engine oil for any particular car. The user provides the make, model, year and engine type to the utility and the utility, in response, recommends a particular oil based on the car manufacturer's recommendation. In European countries, 2C engine came in Toyota Carina E and perhaps in Toyota Avensis during 1990s. The oil guide utilities from different oil vendors recommend ONLY API CF oil for 2C engines. In these countries, 2C engines easily last for about 500,000 KMs and more without any major overhaul. And if you visit any automobile store, they don't recommend any CI-4 oil for 2C engines. So, here comes my question. Has any owner of Corolla 2.0D tried putting such engine oils with API SN/CF rating that are popular for petrol engines like Shell Helix Ultra 5W-40 fully synthetic, Mobil 1 5W-50, ZIC XQ or any other fully synthetic oil with API SN/CF rating? Why Pakistani 2.0D needs overhaul most of the time. One reason I know is our "Ustaads". Any other valid reasons for overhaul(s)? Why we put CI-4 oil?? Is this backward compatible? If yes, why so many problems with our 2.0Ds? Here, I am mentioning links of some oil selector guides from some manufacturers. Which Oil? - Mobil™ UK & Ireland25 Oil Advisor | Eurol B.V.11 CAR PARTS from Mister Auto - Your Parts at discount prices6
column2: AmeerUsman;4661844: 2C engine requires overhaul after 400,000 km if maintained properly. Our Ustaads advise every innocent man to get their 2Cs overhaul, coz they need money by any means and poor customer has no other choice due to his limited knowledge about diesels. Secondly, people listen to rumours spread by people who never owned diesel vehicles in their whole life, but always want to talk about bads of diesel engines becoz they heard them from one who again never owned a diesel vehicle. As far as I have seen diesel engine problems are highlighted much than actual. Im telling this whole story bcoz in the past I owned a 10 years old 2.0D Indus Corolla for 5 years and I claim that it was the best vehicle I ever owned and never gave me trouble in five years. Routine maintenance done for five years like Engine oil Delo Gold + filter, genuine Air filter, Best quality Fuel filter and Toyota Coolant (pink color) were only changed @ proper time. No doubt that Diesel is expensive than Petrol, still per km cost of diesel vehicle is lesser than that of petrol. very true Just because anyone is holding a spanner and a pliers means that they actually know what they are doing. Get in touch with the manufacturer (meaning read their repair manual). That manual will tell you in simplest form what is "NORMAL" and what is not, That book will also tell you "HOW" to get back to "NORMAL" e.g. lets take 2 diesel engines, one from an ancient 1975 200D benz and one from a corolla, both are 4 cyl and 2000cc - should one assume that both are repaired the exact same way?

column1: Dear friends I need ur valued suggestion. I have 2013 civic and its oil capacity in 3.7L and honda oil came in same 3.7 litter bottle. Today 1st time I changed my car oil from after market and put in zic a+ 5w20. Previously car is honda maintained so I was using honda genuine motor oil. Now coming to the point. My car capacity is 3.7L oil. But today mechanic put 4L in my car which is 300ml extra and its a fraction over on my dip stick. I want to ask is it ok for R18 engine to have 4L oil or should I remove 300ml extra from the engine.
column2: sikandaralivisionary: no it matters putting even a little bit extra oil than recommended in your car will overfill it which can cause damage to the engine if it was 200 ml less than recommended oil it woudnt have been a problem. 300 ml is no problem. You can go till a quart extra and then it will bust the seals.

column2: sorry for goin off topic....i noticed u r using Zic A+ 5w20 which is mineral oil why r u not using fully synthetic oil....u can try Zic XQ 5w40 n run upto 8-10k km easily one time i gave my honda civic reborn for oil service at the shell pump n they filled up whole 4L can with new oil filter.....it was running fine but next time i told the guy to filled upto 3.7L.....always follow your owner manual n yes sometime overfilling can damage seals n gasket

column2: umfa85;4206341: Actually Zic A+ is also Fully Synthetic (at least as per its label). I want a oil which i can change at 5000Km with Oil filter. Oil Zic XQ may be good for 10000 Km but i dont think so any filter can last for 10K Km. Honestly I am not in a favour of keeping the same oil filter for 10k Km. So that why I am not feeling comfortable with 8-10k Km mileage oil. In Pakistan we have very dusty environment with extreme temperatures, with cars running on low quality fuel. So I think 5000Km is more than enough for our environment. Also you know as per honda recommendation, High-octane is the right fuel for Civic Prosmatec, where as I am using only super. Initially in my 1st 10K Km I used to mix 50-50 High-octane and Super, but know using only super. actually A+ is not fully synthetic as i ve used myself before on my previous car, on the other hand m using fully synthetic shell ultra for last 2 years n always changed oil at 7-8k km was using Zic XQ but its hard to get original XQ nowadays n for my markx i used liqiu moly synthoil fylly synthetic 5w40...always check oil at 5k to see if it still gud to go for another 2-3k km.....even at 7k oil changed theres stickiness of oil.....in US fully synthetic can run upto 15k miles which is quite a lot for Pakistani environment but i think max u can go upto 8k why m saying coz even Audi dealer told me to bring my dad Audi A4 to change oil at 7k km so i think its better to get fully synthetic as they also use fully synthetic oil.....rest is upto u if u change at 5k theres no harm btw do check some threads on imported oil to get more info on fully synthetic oil n their usage time.

column1: When comparing the D16w9 (manual gear) and D15y3 (manual gear) engines, it is important to consider their low-end torque. Which engine has better low-end torque, or are they both equally good? -  -
column2: Bigger displacement will always return better low end. But gear ratio plays an important role here. Shorter return better low end. Long and weirdly gapped gears decreases it.

column1: AOA All, I am going to post the procedure to clean a MAF sensor. (You can check the details about MAF Sensors on the net) Basically it measures the Air Flow into the engine and adjusts the fuel ratio accordingly. If the sensor is covered with dirt (or oil from the cold air intake if installed) the sensor will give the wrong readings and this will effect the performance of the car, it is more noticeable in automatic cars. Most of the Mechanics advise to replace it as soon as they notice that the cars response is slow and not upto the mark. But actually you do not need to replace it, just cleaning the sensor CAREFULLY can solve the problem. I will post pictures and details below.
column2: i cleaned maf of my idsi..it was not that big,it was just a 1.5 inch needle like thing which was located at the back of air intake box...i disconnected the cable,took it out,cleaned wid a tissue paper nd put it back in it had a black greasy stuff on it...

column2: Oh, not again! We are also having the same problem. My father bought a new car for 2k and I would like to try it too. By the way, my cousin also has a Yaris, but it's a 2004 model. I love three things about it: the audio system, the screen on the dashboard looks very cool, and the RPM meter is also cool. The rear seats are adjustable, meaning you can recline them for a more relaxing experience.

column1: My car (Toyota Belta 1.3, 2SZ engine) AC compressor had gone bad with a lot of carbon in it. I have changed the condenser, discharge pipe and compressor. The replaced compressor is also releasing carbon and it turns off the engine on idle. I've been told by 2 AC mechanics that it's due to faulty compressor. Both have suggested to not use the sensor based compressor. They have suggested to use Deut clutch compressor ) which is hot item these days for AC related issues). My question is: 1) Would it be alright to use Deut clutch compressor? How can I check if the compressor is alright, before installing it and filling the AC gas) 2) Due to alteration required in order to install Deut compressor in Belta 1.3, I am concerned about configuration of pulleys alignment. Can this compressor be aligned correctly in order to make sure that it's pulley doesn't break the belt, and hence resulting in heat up problems. 3) Any other advice besides what I have anticipated in above two questions? Please suggest. @Xulfiqar
column2: Hi, You need to find better trained mechanics, the so called sensor is a pwm solenoid actually which controls the compressor stroke depending on system temperature and pressure. If your mechanics are not using scales to fill gas, the system will overcharge and then the solenoid starts to go crazy. Similar happens if the wrong oil is used and not filled correctly in the compressor, these variable compressors actually have oil in their crankcases.

column1: My car (Toyota Belta 1.3, 2SZ engine) AC compressor had gone bad with a lot of carbon in it. I have changed the condenser, discharge pipe and compressor. The replaced compressor is also releasing carbon and it turns off the engine on idle. I've been told by 2 AC mechanics that it's due to faulty compressor. Both have suggested to not use the sensor based compressor. They have suggested to use Deut clutch compressor ) which is hot item these days for AC related issues). Can this compressor be aligned correctly in order to make sure that it's pulley doesn't break the belt, and hence resulting in heat up problems. 3) Any other advice besides what I have anticipated in above two questions? Please suggest. @Xulfiqar
column2: You have incompetent mechanics. The PWM compressors used in the Middle East, Tropical Africa, the Southern USA (which is extremely hot) and all of South America work perfectly fine. This includes models like Corolla, Camry, and their variants. VW has been using PWM solenoid compressors since the early 2000s. I repair these cars in my shop and simply follow the service manual, resulting in perfect AC functionality even in average summer temperatures of 40C. @archon2001 - could you please confirm if the newer Corolla and Camry models have functioning AC systems in Miami?

column2: They are repaired - Infact I put in new front seals on them before installing - which requires the whole compressor to be disassembled first - the new sealing kit contains body O rings too. As I said the variable swash plate compressors are not built the same as direct drive type.

column1: My car (Toyota Belta 1.3, 2SZ engine) AC compressor had gone bad with a lot of carbon in it. I have changed the condenser, discharge pipe and compressor. The replaced compressor is also releasing carbon and it turns off the engine on idle. I've been told by 2 AC mechanics that it's due to faulty compressor. Both have suggested to not use the sensor based compressor. They have suggested to use Deut clutch compressor ) which is hot item these days for AC related issues). My question is: 1) Would it be alright to use Deut clutch compressor? How can I check if the compressor is alright, before installing it and filling the AC gas) 2) Due to alteration required in order to install Deut compressor in Belta 1.3, I am concerned about configuration of pulleys alignment. Can this compressor be aligned correctly in order to make sure that it's pulley doesn't break the belt, and hence resulting in heat up problems. 3) Any other advice besides what I have anticipated in above two questions? Please suggest. @Xulfiqar
column2: If you are dealing with such and have no other choice than to modify the mounting brackets etc then get a sanden 709C with serp belt fitting. It will pump even when there is grease in it instead of oil and refrigerant. Even in used form it will have a way way longer service life as its a commercial application compressor. The duet/vitz/corolla/camry compressor is also a direct clutch with the typical 10 cylinder denso layout.

column1: My car (Toyota Belta 1.3, 2SZ engine) AC compressor had gone bad with a lot of carbon in it. I have changed the condenser, discharge pipe and compressor. The replaced compressor is also releasing carbon and it turns off the engine on idle. I've been told by 2 AC mechanics that it's due to faulty compressor. Both have suggested to not use the sensor based compressor. They have suggested to use Deut clutch compressor ) which is hot item these days for AC related issues). My question is: 1) Would it be alright to use Deut clutch compressor? How can I check if the compressor is alright, before installing it and filling the AC gas) 2) Due to alteration required in order to install Deut compressor in Belta 1.3, I am concerned about configuration of pulleys alignment. Can this compressor be aligned correctly in order to make sure that it's pulley doesn't break the belt, and hence resulting in heat up problems. 3) Any other advice besides what I have anticipated in above two questions? Please suggest. @Xulfiqar
column2: I dont think its your choice what is fine and what is not as your techies are in charge - Get whatever they install. Reason to say that you are not in charge is that - they cannot get the PWM solenoid compressor to work correctly. As long as they can mount the compressor and bolt up the lines and show you a good service performance from the A/C - you would be alright. - As the compressors they would be sourcing are from scrap, get them to replace the front seal as it would be leaking.

column1: My car (Toyota Belta 1.3, 2SZ engine) AC compressor had gone bad with a lot of carbon in it. I have changed the condenser, discharge pipe and compressor. The replaced compressor is also releasing carbon and it turns off the engine on idle. I've been told by 2 AC mechanics that it's due to faulty compressor. Both have suggested to not use the sensor based compressor. They have suggested to use Deut clutch compressor ) which is hot item these days for AC related issues). My question is: 1) Would it be alright to use Deut clutch compressor? How can I check if the compressor is alright, before installing it and filling the AC gas) 2) Due to alteration required in order to install Deut compressor in Belta 1.3, I am concerned about configuration of pulleys alignment. Can this compressor be aligned correctly in order to make sure that it's pulley doesn't break the belt, and hence resulting in heat up problems. 3) Any other advice besides what I have anticipated in above two questions? column2: no probs, Make sure the system is oiled with correct oil (PAG 46), the system vacuumed with a vacuum pump and charged by weight (not pressure checking only) - otherwise you will be back at square one.

column1: AOA Everyone, I bought a 2012 Toyota Corolla GLi Automatic back in Jul 12. Out of the many things which i had in mind for the new car, the most important thing was the installation of Cruise Control in the vehicle as it shares the same engine (1ZR-FE), same transmission and most importantly the same engine control unit or the ECU. So after a year of research, importing of different parts and lots and lots of waiting Today finally by the help of Allah Almighty i have managed to make the cruise control work. Before we engage in the discussion that why i didnt go for the altis cruisetronic in the first place, well the answer is simple if i had the money i would have definitely bought it (The price diff was Rs 160k at that time dont know about now) A few parts that i had to change in order to make the CC work are: A used leather wrapped steering wheel with audio controls and built in cruise control switches (Came as a bonus) from ebay.uk Altis clock spring or spiral cable from Hamza Younis Auto in Rwp 2011-13 Altis speedometer from Indus motors karachi And then a few wiring issues sorted out by Arshad Auto Electrician in Rwp Here i would also like to thank Mr Zunny aka ZZ for his valuable input and help in procuring the parts for the car I found a complete DIY for installation of cruise control in toyota corolla on the net which helped me a lot in this installation
column2: M surprised how you got such clean second hand products. Stuff at the Sultan place is often rotten - or too pricey if any clean piece is available. The rates you have mentioned are just fine! Sent from my ST25a using PW Forums mobile app

column1: Anyone using 1G & 3S engines? Both are 2000cc petrol, produce more or less similar output. I am planning to swap in my car, want to know which one is more economical? If someone know the consumption on CNG, it will help more.. Kind Regards,
column2: you need to find a good mechanic - automatics are being overhauled in Pakistan - that too for a very very long time. If your mechanic says to replace the transmission on any little fault in it, find a competent one.

column1: Anyone using 1G & 3S engines? Both are 2000cc petrol, produce more or less similar output. I am planning to swap in my car, want to know which one is more economical? If someone know the consumption on CNG, it will help more.. Kind Regards,
column2: Speaking of 6-cylinder engines, I have swapped a few 1999 Galant GDIs with 6A12 and 6A13 engines. I replaced the entire setup, including the touch panel A/C and manual select (auto gears - also known as tiptronic). The 6A12 is a 2.0-liter V6 engine manufactured by Mitsubishi. It provides a very smooth performance, saving engine mounts and eliminating any vibrations while running. Moreover, it sounds really good. The fuel consumption, however, is slightly higher compared to its 4-cylinder counterpart, the 4G63 SOHC NA engine, resulting in a difference of approximately 1 km per liter. However, the tradeoff for this increased fuel consumption is the great sound and smooth acceleration provided by the 6A12 engine.

column1: Asalam o Alaikum fellow Pakwheelers  I'm starting this thread on behalf of my brother @ranahamza89 who is going to be rebuilding his Daihatsu Charade CB100 1989 from scratch. The car's condition is all rusty and rough, running on Toyota 1KR FE (Vitz 1000cc) The interior requires a lot of work as well, the pictures will be enough to tell, but things will start getting better with time and we both have decided not to rush it.  We both have been planning on getting the car done but since both of us are Chartered Accountants other than Car Enthusiasts, we just didn't get the proper time that a clean build requires. Finally, with the help of my dear uncle and a renown fellow pakwheeler @fouadhafeez, I got referred to a local painter who happens to be the lucky guy getting to paint the finest piece of Pakistani creativity, Fouad uncle's Sleipnir. Hamza handed over his Charade to Nona (painter) yesterday and we both decided to start a thread here to keep the Charade fans hooked up, of course, every enthusiast can subscribe. The recent pictures of the car are attached in the thread, therefore, I'll be keeping you all updated with all the work accordingly. Till then? Keep yourselves posted and your fingers crossed  Work Required Exterior: Denting - IN PROCESS Paint New Bonnet (Kabli) New Bumpers (Kabli) New Fenders (Kabli) Lights - PAGE 4 New set of wheels and tyres - WEDSSPORT SA70  Interior: New door inserts New seats poshish New carpet & mats New speed-o-meter
column2: AE110 and G100 are model numbers of vehicles. The AE110 refers to a model of the Toyota Corolla, while the G100 pertains to a model of the Honda Civic.

column1: While this story is longer and involves multiple wasted hours, expensive bottles of oil and miles of travel over the past few months, I've abridged it for clarity and to highlight my most recent outrageous experience with Imran Gearbox Repair5 in Liaquatabad (nee Lalookhet.) After having the 5MT and transfer case opened up on my '90s Suzuki Jimny, I was pleased to see both boxes in pristine condition. It certainly helped that the first thing I did when I got the car is replace the murky black fluids that hadn't been changed in 30 years with Toyota GL-4 and GL-5. After the shaft seals and a couple of bearings were inspected and replaced with new ones, the boxes were put back together and I was asked to put in the shop's "khulla" oil of unknown spec. Since there was absolutely no way I was going to do that, Warco or Delo Gear EP-5 was the alternative. While the Delo GL-5 would've been fine for my diffs, it wouldn't work for the transfer case and transmission, which both needed GL-4. "Sir ham toh dekhte bhi nahi hain, GL-4, 5, sab aik hi cheez hay. Ham dalte rahe hain, sab chalta hay, befikar rahain." I couldn't find a GL-4 Delo, so I bought some Liqui-Moly 85W-90 GL-4 - 1.2L in the transmission, 1L in the transfer case. 1.5L Liqui-Moly 85W-90 GL-5 each in the diffs. The owner at Imran Gearbox Repair insisted I fill 2 liters into the gearbox, and had their worker dump it into the shifter hole instead of using the fill bolt to verify the quantity. I was pissed and asked him why he did that without telling me. "Hamara experience hay, kam na ho, gearbox jal na jaye, aapki zimedari hogi." Straining synchros, hard downshift to 2nd and 1st, and sluggish response made me suspect the box was overfilled. The shifter shaft bolt at the very top of the gearbox was leaking, dripping onto my driveway. Output seal was weeping and covering my driveshaft with oil. Next day, the guy wouldn't respond to my calls or messages, including the pictures I sent him of the shifter shaft bolt dripping and leaking all over my driveway. I had a trusted shop open up the fill bolt, which immediately spouted oil all over the mechanic's arm and face. I thrust a beaker underneath to measure what came out. Remember: the spec calls for 1200ml, the gearbox had 2000ml in it. This is how much came out of the fill bolt. It's a good idea to: Take basic measurement tools with you for fluids, hose diameters, etc. Refer to this thread6 and contribute information for various engines, transmissions and differentials. Follow the manufacturer's specifications and read the technical briefs for information on exactly what is going in your vehicle.
column2: If they are relying on sae140 oil to stop oil leaks from seals, they are cartoons. Find some other shop. I can bet you apples to apples that they dont even grease the seals when installing.

I was pissed and asked him why he did that without telling me. "Hamara experience hay, kam na ho, gearbox jal na jaye, aapki zimedari hogi." Straining synchros, hard downshift to 2nd and 1st, and sluggish response made me suspect the box was overfilled. The shifter shaft bolt at the very top of the gearbox was leaking, dripping onto my driveway. Output seal was weeping and covering my driveshaft with oil. Next day, the guy wouldn't respond to my calls or messages, including the pictures I sent him of the shifter shaft bolt dripping and leaking all over my driveway. I had a trusted shop open up the fill bolt, which immediately spouted oil all over the mechanic's arm and face. I thrust a beaker underneath to measure what came out. Remember: the spec calls for 1200ml, the gearbox had 2000ml in it. This is how much came out of the fill bolt. It's a good idea to: Take basic measurement tools with you for fluids, hose diameters, etc. Refer to this thread6 and contribute information for various engines, transmissions and differentials. Follow the manufacturer's specifications and read the technical briefs for information on exactly what is going in your vehicle.
column2: Find the oil seal at plaza market at the oil seal wholesellers opposite to rimpa plaza, its a large shop in a hidden building compound next the the old suzuki showroom. 38x50x8 is a very common size on toyota engines too, (camshaft and crank pulley etc) To install the oil seal, pack the spring cavity of the seal with petroleum jelly or low temperature grease before pushing it in, if the seal requires hammering in use a socket or something like a pipe coupler and use a rubber or wooden mallet to prevent shocking the seal as it may deform. Slather some grease on the lip of the seal, the shaft that the seal protects should be smooth and free of nicks, rust and edges. If the seal has to ride over some teeth or a groove before seating into its boss, cover those sharp edges with electrical tape first.

column1: While this story is longer and involves multiple wasted hours, expensive bottles of oil and miles of travel over the past few months, I've abridged it for clarity and to highlight my most recent outrageous experience with Imran Gearbox Repair5 in Liaquatabad (nee Lalookhet.) After having the 5MT and transfer case opened up on my '90s Suzuki Jimny, I was pleased to see both boxes in pristine condition. It certainly helped that the first thing I did when I got the car is replace the murky black fluids that hadn't been changed in 30 years with Toyota GL-4 and GL-5. After the shaft seals and a couple of bearings were inspected and replaced with new ones, the boxes were put back together and I was asked to put in the shop's "khulla" oil of unknown spec. Since there was absolutely no way I was going to do that, Warco or Delo Gear EP-5 was the alternative. While the Delo GL-5 would've been fine for my diffs, it wouldn't work for the transfer case and transmission, which both needed GL-4. "Sir ham toh dekhte bhi nahi hain, GL-4, 5, sab aik hi cheez hay. Ham dalte rahe hain, sab chalta hay, befikar rahain." column2: By the way, the shifter bolt should be sealed using a copper washer. You can find these washers at vintage nut/bolt shops as they are commonly used in hydraulic repairs. And please don't tell me that the protruding substance is just generic orange RTV (Room Temperature Vulcanizing) silicone sealant! If it is, then it is quite humorous and shoddy work.

column2: Nice But holy shit on that Koyo package, koyo sold those packages probably when I was wearing diapers. Btw You can find copper washers at dedicated nut and bolt shops, or simply go to lawrence road screw/nut/bolt market and buy some, However you can also buy them near sindh madressah, some shops are there selling all kinds of fasteners, they are run by gujrati speaking bohra faith guys. I used to buy a lot from them, mind you they wont entertain any soot/inchi size or andaaza size, you will need to tell them exact metric or sae sizing, they also have all kinds of c clips, r clips, ring locks etc too. They also had the silken thread used to seal pratt and whitney engine casings.

column2: Dont buy oil filters just on size, you also need to match the bypass pressure and the drainback system and top it all with the filtration micron rating. Btw Buying in plaza is no different than buying anywhere else, the same usual jargon is used Anyway!!! The large dust lip oil seal is not exactly mandatory, you can use a regular oil seal too, dont go wide unless your seal housing boss allows it, and if the manual specs it, some housings actually specify a gap at the end of the seal boss so oil can flow there (keeps it cool and prevents cooking) For copper washers, if you were in plaza, just ask rando shops where the nut/bolt guys are in magazine lane, this lane is actually next to the oil filter market you visited. Ask for “taambay ki washer” and not “copper washer” - otherwise you wont find them. And dont ever throw away copper washers, they are reusable forever with just a simple annealing.

column2: If you want to do it properly 2 lac wouldn't be enough. Go through these threads. Suzuki Khyber 1989 Restoration Khyber Greetings brothers and sister. My family has owned khyber since 2011 and bought it from first owner. It is since been a "daily driver" for our family. We were unable to drive it on regular basis for the past year or two because of its routinely wiring failure and rust accumulation in body panels. Moreover, it was consuming some engine oil so, engine rebuild was also due. We finally decided to restore it. Our project khyber has now started... Restoring my suzuki khyber 1992 model Khyber Hello All, I'm Hassan, a slient member on pakwheels for a long time. I purchased a suzki khyber almost a year back. It was my first car so just fell in love with it. But after sometime passed i realized some rust in the body that alarmed me, so i started thinking of restoring it. Almost 3 months back i contacted a workshop owner (with some reference) who provides denting/painting/mechanical services. So i decided an initial amount with them and left my car at their workshop. The work started…

column1: This project started when my mechanic drove in this car to my home to top up fluids and check up my TATA Nano car. This car is a Maruti 800 ( Mehran in your market) that was made under licence from Suzuki Motor , Japan by Maruti Udyog LTD which was a state owned entity at that time. Today ofcourse things are different and those were the days. I saw this car liked it, drove it around the block and fell in love. The car was in running condition , had good pickup. I don't know if it was plain impulse buying or whatever i decided i wanted the car for myself. After a little haggling we decided on a price of 25,000 rupees and the car was mine. This was in July 2021. Six months and more passed before my mechanic told he had time to take this restoration project full on and the car is now undergoing the same. My mechanic has sent me pics of the project so far and i will share them till the final reveal which i was told is about ten days away, everything willing. So, let's get on with the visuals. My Maruti 800 the day i bought it. i had posted these pics in 'My Local View' thread
column2: @disisfifty there is a difference of exchange rate plus the size of market & the state wise Road Transport Authority Rules. which exist ONLY on papers in Pakistan,. 1969 Toyota Corona can still be seen over motorways. 1972 Bedford ROCKET Trucks are transporting good in the most dangerous terrains up north. @nickatnite has mentioned that law in 2nd paragraph of post #7 perhaps practiced and visible across all states in India.

I don't know if it was plain impulse buying or whatever i decided i wanted the car for myself. After a little haggling we decided on a price of 25,000 rupees and the car was mine. This was in July 2021. Six months and more passed before my mechanic told he had time to take this restoration project full on and the car is now undergoing the same. My mechanic has sent me pics of the project so far and i will share them till the final reveal which i was told is about ten days away, everything willing. So, let's get on with the visuals. My Maruti 800 the day i bought it. i had posted these pics in 'My Local View' thread

column1: Guys kindly advise, what is the best way to repair puncture in tubeless tyre,i meant patch with heating or the process in which they insert something with neddle or, is there any other proper way of repairing puncture @shabro
column2: The repair of tubeless tire from outside surface is called mushroom plug temporary puncture repair. As the name implies it is a temporary fix but can last for many kms. In tire shops in US the tire is taken off and repaired from inside and then the wheel is balanced. However, even in the Gulf countries I have noted that they mostly fix it from the outside.

column1: i have a 2011 corolla driven 132k and after driving in hard rain on motorway the drive belt has started making screeching noise on startup and when ac is turned on for few seconds after startup, it goes away when car is moving and doesn't come back until again startup. does the belt need to be replaced? or driving in rain dried it out, any way to lubricate the belt or would that harm it? thanks
column2: your belt it worn out - replace it and only use a truly good quality genuine part like a continental, pirelli, OE toyota, mitsubishi, gates etc.

column1: i have a 2011 corolla driven 132k and after driving in hard rain on motorway the drive belt has started making screeching noise on startup and when ac is turned on for few seconds after startup, it goes away when car is moving and doesn't come back until again startup. does the belt need to be replaced? or driving in rain dried it out, any way to lubricate the belt or would that harm it? thanks
column2: arzaam.bhatti;4532824: [QUOTE=imrananr;4458181] where is belt lubricator spray available? by the way replaced the belt form dealership but still want to know @Xulfiqar they had two belts one made in japan by bando, and one made by toyota made in indonesia, indonesia one was for 6500Rs and japan one was for 3800rs the service advisor was stressing on indonesia one while the worker changing the belt said use the japanese one its built better, i went for japanese one any way and in budget saved money and used that to make some other repairs that i had in mind for later, what would you say oem belt was a wiser choice or this one, they were authorising both belts Do not ever apply any lubricant to the belt - the belt is a "friction" drive item, Its driving force is dependant on the coefficient of friction between its grooves and the corresponding grooves in the pulley. If your belt is a bit dirty, remove and wash with soap and clean all the pulleys with a strong cleaning agent. btw the original belt that is made in indonesia is pretty stout (the one sold as Toyota OE part). Its made by sumitomo I beleive.

column1: Recommendations for ceramic window film for cars in Lahore? Mainly interested in heat and UV blocking, don't want to tint the windows so looking for film with 70-80% visible light transmission, no color/tint, non-reflective. Protek offers 3M crystalline but its not ceramic and quite expensive. Solar screen offers X series but no idea if its actually ceramic as its their own brand, not some internationally recognized film.
column2: Consider getting Z series metallic tint from Solar Screen for your cars, as it doesn't affect mobile signals and offers significant heat reduction, especially beneficial for smaller vehicles. While initial bubbles may be annoying, they typically disappear with sunlight exposure. The tint is practically invisible, and there have been no reported issues with law enforcement. Prices for installation, like for a Pixis 2018, may vary but are generally reasonable, around 9500 rupees. Solar Screen's Lahore outlet remains operational, offering services like ceramic coating, which has shown a 50% reduction in cabin heat and improved AC performance, albeit with some initial bubbling that clears within a week.

column1: This rare Volkswagen Type 1 'split window' is now under restoration. I have restored many cars in my life time including some rare models, from 2 cyllinder cars to 12 cyllinders. Each car has its own set of challenges and pecularities. Volkswagen cars have an iconic status worldwide. Pakistan is no different. Though I have started work on it and find it much easier and simpler to work on but would still like to have expert opinion of those who have devoted a substantial part of their free time to Volkswagen marque. Keep visiting and leaving your feedback...
column2: my experience of seeing split window beetles in Karachi The one in this post 3 that were destroyed by Shershah junkyard about the same time they cut the Porsche 356 (the beetle were at random car workshops whose owners had abandoned them) - mangled with (light changes etc) 1 fully working car in black bought by some "gora" and shipped out of Pakistan later - this car was in North Nazimabad and was in amazing working order - (old freind of my late uncle). - I believe the only additional thing he had put on was the crank handle starter at the rear.. I believe there is one more in Karachi - its a faded white and its still got the oldschool Karachi plates on it (motorcycle type reg numbers) - I have seen this car once only outside a house behind AO clinic in Nazimabad - not abandoned but in average nick, clean exterior with the little round tail lamps - and largish bumpers

column2: In this region, finding the 'best' mechanic might be elusive, as it often involves trial and error. However, there are numerous competent mechanics available who can get the job done. column2: The 1600cc engines are capable of reaching 200k mileage with ease if properly maintained. I currently own two Toyota engines and one Honda engine, all of which have around 100k mileage, and they are running smoothly without any issues. I change the oil when its color becomes dark and when it starts to lose its viscosity. Generally, synthetic lubricants tend to last longer.

column1: Dear experts, -  - There is a party in Karachi that is selling a Toyota Cami, 1300cc, model 2000. I have seen a few pictures of the car and I am really interested in buying it. The price they are asking is Rs. 1,090,000. I would greatly appreciate your expert opinion on whether I should proceed with the purchase. -  - Thank you.
column2: When considering options for a vehicle purchase, several factors come into play. The Terios Kid, priced between 6.25 to 8 lakh, and the Sportage intercooler manufactured between 2002-2003, priced around 11 to 12 lakh, offer competitive choices. While the Sportage is locally produced and relatively easy to maintain with good resale value, the Terios Kid provides an affordable alternative with its sleek design. Additionally, the Toyota Vitz stands out for its popularity and availability of parts, making it a reliable option. However, personal preferences and budget constraints should ultimately guide your decision.

column1: Hi guys salam This is my first post on this forum, i have recently bought mark 2 1973 and luckily the car is in its original condition. I am planning on upgrading it to muscle car Big engine ( non turbo will be better i gues) upgrading braking upgrading rear differential and shaft ( i think it would need to be changed as heavy engine will probably damage stock differential ) hollow rims with wide tires ( how wide ? ) After all the mechanical works i will move to body works, now i can either stick to the original look and prolly go for front lower lip type bumper or change it to muscle ( dodge look) what do you think ? need some picture. will also upgrade exhaust to get a roar sound out of it. The real question is what engine will be best suitable ( 2zj ?? is it 2zj or 2jz??) , is it reliable ? ( price ?) Has any one successfully completed mark 2 conversion? do you think wide arches will be good or it will spoil the look ? i had so much to type but tried my level best to summarise what i was after, Looking forward to get some valuable information from you guys. Nas
column2: When enhancing a car's performance, it's crucial to consider more than just installing a powerful engine. Ensuring tractable power and controllability is vital, as seen with old American cars like the Ford Galaxie 7 litre. Additionally, when contemplating engine swaps such as a 2JZ in a '73 MKII, it's essential to assess the feasibility and potential challenges, including the need for custom mounts and addressing rear suspension issues. Furthermore, active involvement in the project, especially concerning wiring and other technical aspects, can prevent unforeseen issues and ensure quality workmanship. Remember, projects like these require meticulous planning and oversight to avoid shortcuts and ensure optimal outcomes.

column1: How much tint percentage is allowed for windows in twin cities?
column2: Sure, here's a summary of the article you shared: -  - The article discusses the recent actions taken by the Islamabad Traffic Police (ITP) against vehicles with tinted glass. The ITP has launched a campaign to crack down on cars violating the rules regarding the use of tinted windows. This move comes as part of their effort to enhance security measures in the city. -  - The ITP has set up special teams to inspect vehicles and identify those with excessive tinted glass. Vehicles found to be in violation of the law are being fined. Moreover, their owners are directed to immediately remove the tint from their windows in order to comply with the regulations. -  - The article highlights that the use of tinted glass on vehicles poses a security risk, making it difficult for law enforcement agencies to identify the occupants and their activities. By taking strict action against this violation, the ITP aims to ensure a safer environment for both the residents of Islamabad and the law enforcement officials. -  - Furthermore, the article mentions that the ITP has urged citizens to cooperate and abide by the regulations regarding tinted glass. This would assist in maintaining a secure and transparent environment within the city. -  - Overall, the article sheds light on the proactive measures being taken by the Islamabad Traffic Police to regulate the use of tinted glass in vehicles, with the primary objective of improving security conditions in the capital city.

column1: How much tint percentage is allowed for windows in twin cities?
column2: Please open now. No tinting of car windows, regardless of the percentage, is allowed in Islamabad. Apart from that, even if you have 100% tinting, no police constable will ask you, and they can issue a ticket even for 20% tinting, with no guarantee. Because this is Pakistan.

column1: toyota corolla 5 speed manual purchased 2nd hand in 2002. donot remember what was the odo meter then but immediately the fluids were changed. system fans, water body cooling system and ac was fixed to work on automatic. it was running over stock engine on petrol. all these days since then it was used at home in Karachi as daily rider. after 285000 kms engine started consuming oil 1.5 liters at every 6000 kms. The driver saheb ustad friend wanted to swap the engine suggested 5AFE efi engine for 2 lakhs plus mazdori and electrician charge. i was not in karachi then but suggested take car to irshad at shahrai quadeen as i have read over this forum about them more good less bad. I spoke to guy irshad asked him for compression test and results with his recommendation. I choose rebuild. during eid holidays in Karachi i used the vehicle and it is perfect. fuel economy is 11 / km with ac in city. But like all paid employees do my driver saheb is still complaining saheb gari theek nai hai. since engine was overhauled by irshad at jamil autos in my absence he shared the pictures yesterday so am sharing what is available.

The driver saheb ustad friend wanted to swap the engine suggested 5AFE efi engine for 2 lakhs plus mazdori and electrician charge. i was not in karachi then but suggested take car to irshad at shahrai quadeen as i have read over this forum about them more good less bad. I spoke to guy irshad asked him for compression test and results with his recommendation. I choose rebuild. during eid holidays in Karachi i used the vehicle and it is perfect. fuel economy is 11 / km with ac in city. But like all paid employees do my driver saheb is still complaining saheb gari theek nai hai. since engine was overhauled by irshad at jamil autos in my absence he shared the pictures yesterday so am sharing what is available.
column2: babarhyd: Fuelled by great members of this forum so you got trapped by those members and left a lurcative job. how does your family react when you reach home full of gunk & oil smell the dirty hands, oil stains over clothes.

column1: Dear All, I hope you are well. I have recently purchased a Toyota Hilux Revo V 2020 model and supposedly it's been driven 33k. The exterior and interior is in immaculate condition, no rust anywhere and drive is good also but I don't know why I get the feeling milage is not genuine. Considering there could be a chance the car has been driven more than the meter is showing what can I do to best maintain the diesel engine. Will cleaning the fuel pump and nozzles change the factory settings? I am thinking to get the transmission fluid changed and the condition of this fluid should help make the situation clearer. Anyway I don't want to keep trying to answer my own question and wait for the expert opinions. Many thanks
column2: 33000 kms for a 3 year old pickup truck which city you are from. Sir ! and sir did you purchased it directly from owner or from a dealer / car showroom. ?

Considering there could be a chance the car has been driven more than the meter is showing what can I do to best maintain the diesel engine. Will cleaning the fuel pump and nozzles change the factory settings? I am thinking to get the transmission fluid changed and the condition of this fluid should help make the situation clearer. Anyway I don't want to keep trying to answer my own question and wait for the expert opinions. Many thanks
column2: I purchased a 2019 Toyota Hilux with approximately 40k kilometres on it. Among the first things I did was to change its Mobil oil, filters, including the diesel filter, The vehicle was in immaculate condition and the seller was providing any sort of guarantee that I would be able to take it back if the meter proved to be reversed. Having said that, I was still caught in a dilemma and as a result, I changed the transmission fluid, brake pads and disks, and got a general service done.. My experience with the car so far has been good, and as a regular maintenance guy, I would suggest to get it thoroughly inspected and to enjoy the ride rather than get stuck in a confusion about meter tampering instead.

column1: Instructions for Sygic Full 18.2.0: - 1. Make sure you have an Android device (Car LCD). - 2. You need at least a 1 GB micro SD card. - 3. Download Sygic Full 18.2.0 from the following link:  -     https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Lt4n97mVtk7d-Tz2yR3sjzAmq__09Uuf/view?usp=sharing2.7k - 4. Extract the downloaded file using WinRar on your PC or mobile device. - 5. Copy and paste the extracted files onto the SD card. - 6. Insert the SD card into your Car LCD. - 7. Install the Sygic Full 18.2.0 apk and replace the other folder (overwrite) in the android folder located in the main root of the SD card. - This includes the map of Pakistan. Enjoy and may Pakistan thrive and endure.
column2: I have installed this version and it's much less detailed than the Sygic version 13-14 Sygic 14.x.x version is installed in my car's navigation panel and that's much detailed.

column2: Bro, I've used almost all versions of Sygic for Android since 2013. Maps were more detailed and in-depth in v13-14. Later Sygic didn't update the in-depth maps of Pakistan, only Apk file was updated with some additional features. The area where I live was maped and named in v14 sygic maps. In recent v18 maps, that area is totally absent from the terrain. Moreover some roads and streets are there but those aren't named or if named, named wrongly. So using latest version maps data is of no particular help. I'm still using v14 Sygic.

column1: -- Throttle Body (TB) is the fuel and air intake controller of a petrol engine -- With new sensor and ECU technology this is slightly complex area (for some), yet we clean it very often -- Of many people I interviewed almost everyone has either replaced a sensor or has had serious idling issues If u want to know how it works ... how to save your sensors and how to remove various idling issues ... please read this i will explain with a lot of details and pics so that someone who has never known throttle body may also understand but some portions may be un-necessary which u may skip ( NOTE : TB design varies for different cars i cannot cover all .. just giving a basic concept here ) Location in engine  -- it connected at one end to your air-cleaner assembly and on the other to the in-take housing as shown in the pic below  Parts of TB which need to be understood for maintenance and adjustment There is a diagram of TB below. Following is the list i will discuss in detail just keep refering to this diagram when reading ahead; -- Accelerator Linkage (it has an idle adjustment screw not visible here ).. right most item in diagram -- The air-cleaner side ... marked as 10 -- Hot water pipes ... 40 -- TPS (throttle position sensor) ... 20 -- IACV (Idle air controller valve) other names include ISC (idle servo controller) and Auto-choke .. 70 -- A housing with its seal or gasket .. 57 is the gasket  Parts wise explanation and adjustment  .. Accelerator Linkage it has two main parts which u need to understand -- butterfly ..  [INDENT=2]-- Function : it controls amount of air and when u press accelerator it moves [/INDENT] [INDENT=2]-- Problems : general problems include being stuck and/or not sealing the pipe like housing completely -- Symptoms : Jerky pickups and increased idle RPM -- maintenance : is to completely clean it with petrol and remove carbon sludge   [/INDENT] [INDENT]-- idle adjustment : Just a simple screw to adjust idle BUT this adjustment comes after the basic adjustment of idle from TPS and IACV (explained ahead) .. for minor adjustments use this screw .. generally it has a lock nut as well  [/INDENT] .. Air Cleaner side or housing .. just to give u an orientation of TB location in engine .. Hot water pipes .. these are the source of temperature for auto-choke, early morning start races up ur idle till water attains certain temperature (around 70 degrees centigrade)  .. TPS : The most important item which causes major idling issues, it[INDENT]-- Working : has a linkage (generally a black plastic) which sits in a housing, the housing replicates the movement of butterfly and in turn gives a position identification to ECU (the main computer unit) that what is the position of butterfly at any point in time --Construction : In general it is a simple variable resistance which changes value due to movement of its mechanical linkage .. the voltage coming ang going out of it varies from 1v to 5v which tell ECU the position of butterfly (or accelerator pressed) -- Sub-Parts [/INDENT] [INDENT=2]-- linkage : plastic flat body .. it sometimes sits in a window like shape in TB housing be sure it is vertical or fits the window properly (this is important, the main issues start here, any) -- Adjustable screw and/or spring : TPS gives the primary signal of throttle position if it is wrong, everything else will remain messed up ... there is a process to set it, explained bellow: [/INDENT] [INDENT=3]Adjustment process -- When engine is running .. remove IACV connector (ur idle will reduce ..just normal) -- not adjust the TPS screw or play (as shown in pic below) so that idle is 400-500 rpm (for non-rpm car where engine vibrates and will stall if lowered) .. use the idle screw in the accelerator linkage to achieve this level -- now connect IACV and you'll get perfect idle of 800-850 RPM   WHY : the IACV or auto-choke controls rpm within a certain limit for some reason if u have set to 2500 rpm (from TPS) then either u'll get a eratic idle or a stalling behaviour .. general problem when a mechanic opens, cleans and fits it back not knowing that its play is also an adjustment  [/INDENT] .. IACV : -- Function : It gets reading from TPS and senses water temperature to accelerate the RPM when required, general these include  [INDENT=2]-- turning ON ac -- Cold start -- Other electrical load like power steering turning, operating head-lights, defogger, etc -- Atmospheric requirements like air is thin in hilly areas[/INDENT] [INDENT]-- Construction : It is a stepper motor which works in steps in accordance with voltage applied. Like telescopic rod it pushed butterfly forward to increase the RPM. The step in normal condition are around 10-15 and with AC ON can be up to 100 or 125 (its max limit) -- Checking a Faulty IACV : remove connector when engine is start ur rpm should vary. still not sure, remove IACV from housing put ur finger on sensor tip an just turn ignition key (do not start) and it will expand, the telescope pod will move forward .. turn off key and it will retract with a delay of about 2 seconds, third check is resistance generaly it is around 30-40 ohms in between it pins from centre pins to outwards   Problems : RPM not increasing when required (as given in its functions) and eratic RPM (too high or too low) in noral condition, this involves basic idle setting as explained in TPS above [/INDENT] -- Housing : this is where water accumulates, the only problem u get here is an expanded seal when ur mechanic cleans it with petrol and when fitting back it doesn't sit back properly creating a leakage  WARNINGS : -- never clean sensors with a brush there tips are carbon quoted and either they will give error in reading or will eventually die if this practice is followed. Mechanics put them in a tub of petrol and clean with a brush -- use only prescribed sprays or solutions to clean sensor. My study suggests an elecrtonic circuit cleaner spray only. just spray and then put in the open for half an hour to dry nothing more -- don't mess with idle adjustment of TPS or even its screws if u don't know how to adjust -- Don't check voltages on sensor clips or ur sensor with test lamp it might overload and kill them -- try a reset otr hard reset before doing any of these test/adjustment processes, a reset afterwards is equally recommended Thanks (now i will insert pics .. took me 2 hrs to type this )
column2: This sort of water distribution system is to heat up the whole throttle body, it prevents throttle blade wear in all weather as metal expands and contracts with temperature. e.g. the throttle may sieze in ice weather. This little thing when disturbed is the no.1 cause of those pesky cooling system air locks as it is quite a high point in the system. This is also why the pipes feeding it are rusted like a century old sunken ship. (air+water+heat = bad news)

column1: my mitsubishi mini pajero outsie temp display is not working properly and is displaying "E 0" and not showing anything, i tried resting by removing battery etc but it won't work, i also tried to find the temp sensor or its wire but i can't find it anywhere near the bumper, even took the bumper off for some work and had a good look around, anybody know about this error and how to fix it and wheres the sensor for temp located on this car or is it missing? altimeter and compass work correctly, tomorrow i will post picture of the display
column2: chall3ng3r;5109038: Just to let anyone looking for location of this sensor. In my Pajero Mini 1995, I found it in left (passenger) side bumper cover. The sensor looks like this.  Unfortunately, some local electrician cut the sensor thinking of it something else I guess. So now I am looking for one. To test these wires of are actually of temperature sensor, I checked with voltage meter to see if there's any power on these two wires, there was none. Next I short them, the outside temperature sensor value changed to -30, which confirm connection to sensor. Now I will see if i can find a sensor that works with mine. try an IAT from an old toyota engine.

column1: HI ALL, as the topic says, there was something which was continuously triggering in my head to do something with mehran new model dashboard to control the cooling circulation in the car. during summer days when temperature goes up, the driver side gets not proper cooling because if u tilt the centre vent on both side, the driver side cooling gets obstructed by the steering and dashboard . so i thought why not to install an ac vent on the right side for the driver in the coin box area. after lot of searching on internet and asking ac walas, finally i reached shershah and got my hands on old mehran dashboard which comes with 04 ac vents (02 on left / right and two in centre). so the story goes like this picture wise: ac ducts for both sides and grill
column2: Looking something interesting, for Mehran Users atleast because I had the same question in my mind since the launch of Euro 2 model with 2 front vents for A/c.

column1: My Santro's Power Steering Pump is producing noise. Can it be repaired? Where can I find 2nd hand pump?
column2: Yeah...it depends...are u sure power steering pol pump is making that sound?

column1: My Santro's Power Steering Pump is producing noise. Can it be repaired? Where can I find 2nd hand pump?
column2: yes, new pump is very costly. oil level is not dropping. Also steering is working fine. The heavy sound is just like of faulty bearing. But mechanics says this pumps doesn’t have any bearing. According to mechanic, power pump always give shrill sound and it is strange to produce such noise. Btw for a small interval of time sound disappears.

column1: My Santro's Power Steering Pump is producing noise. Can it be repaired? Where can I find 2nd hand pump?
column2: There is no change in sound when turning the steering. I removed the belt and then started the car. Engine sound was very low without this belt. Also, when I rotated the pmp pully with my hand, I could feel roughness and tick tick sound coming out of it. BTW Steering is very smooth and there is no problem except noise.

column1: My Santro's Power Steering Pump is producing noise. Can it be repaired? Where can I find 2nd hand pump?
column2: Yesterday I visited Mithu tha Ahata in Rawalpindi. I found only two shops having Santro Engines. both did not have power pumps. Although they shown me many other power steering pumps which they said can be installed in my car. Price of the pump was Rs. 2000/-. Anyhow, I am still looking for some original pump. In due course of time, sound is disappearing for long time now but steering little bit heavier. I think pump has stopped working. I want to ask whether is there any harm to steering assembly if I use may car without power pump till the time i find some solution.

column1: My Santro's Power Steering Pump is producing noise. Can it be repaired? Where can I find 2nd hand pump?
column2: Zaheer Ustad from Babar Autos, located behind the Fire Brigade, has successfully repaired the pump for Rs. 2000 (including parts and labor), and it comes with a guarantee. He replaced the bearing and oil seal. Therefore, it can be concluded that power steering pumps can be repaired.

column1: Spare Parts Prices: JDM vs PkDM -  - Preview: Many people are confused about whether to choose JDM (Japanese Domestic Market) or PkDM (Pakistan Domestic Market) cars based on the availability and cost of spare parts. I am creating this thread to help those people make the right decision that suits them. This thread is not meant to discourage the purchase of either JDM or PkDM cars; instead, it is meant to guide people. -  - In this thread, please provide information about the prices of spare parts for imported cars if you have personal experience or know someone who does. Compare these prices with the prices of similar cars in Pakistan, for example, Swift and Vitz, Corolla and Axio, etc. -  - Example: A few months ago, I took my Cultus to a body shop in Peshawar for repairing/painting the bumper. There was a front damaged Corolla Axio in the shop, and some spare parts were lying around. I asked the technician about the prices of these parts and I was shocked by the high prices. The hood (bonnet) was priced at Rs. 60,000, both front fenders were priced at Rs. 30,000, and the complete set of front lights, front bumper, and front frame bars was priced at Rs. 100,000. In comparison, the bumper of a GLI (a locally manufactured Corolla variant) costs Rs. 6,000, according to the person I spoke to (I don't own one). Furthermore, the prices of these parts were even higher in Peshawar compared to Islamabad, where they obtained the parts. In Peshawar, the bonnet price was Rs. 80,000. -  - Member's Input: Please share your experiences regarding spare parts of different vehicles such as Vitz, Mira, Alto, Prius, Axio, Passo, Move, Esse, Every, Probox, Fielder, Insight, CRZ, etc. Thank you. :)
column2: please dont compare junkyard sourced parts with new parts prices, it wont make sense. e.g. I could get an A/C compressor for a corolla in scrap weight if I wanted. It was useless though. A good compressor would have to be bought brand new. But scrap weight compressor would be Rs 200/- max - new compressor would be Rs 20,000/-

column1: What's the best place to have my car's ceremic coating from? Is ceremic is the best choice or are there more options in the market too?
column2: In addition to Ceramic Coating, Paint Protection Film (PPF) is also a good option. It protects your car from scratches and small dings. Some PPFs also have self-healing properties meaning they repair themselves when exposed to sunlight.

column1: What's the best place to have my car's ceremic coating from? Is ceremic is the best choice or are there more options in the market too?
column2: Cermaic Coating will cost you 50k+ while a good quality PPF is closer to 225k-250k.

column2: Demand refers to the desire or need for a particular product, service, or resource. It can also refer to the quantity or level of that desired product or service. In an economic context, demand represents the willingness and ability of consumers to purchase goods or services at a given price and at a specific point in time. Demand is a key factor in determining the price, production, and allocation of goods and services in a market economy.
