column1: Hi all Car gurus, Please give your opinion regarding best battery brand in Pakistan esp for a diesel engine vehicle, I mean durability and quality.
column2: I use AGS X* 100 series with properly made electrolyte, distilled water and sulphuric acid of 1.270 SG. I could start german diesels with it (german diesel starters are not all that fast and require solid amps to turn over)

column1: Hi all Car gurus, Please give your opinion regarding best battery brand in Pakistan esp for a diesel engine vehicle, I mean durability and quality.
column2: whatever battery brand you select it should be prepared with distilled water and sulphuric acid electrolyte, and not the tap water sewage that battery shops have in their drums - and the charging system should be top notch too, the grounds should be of good contact also, the glow plugs in a diesel suck current and need a good solid ground to the cylinder head to heat up properly. Dont fall for brand names - you need to fulfill the basic battery operational requirements first, then comment on quality. If your battery failed in 16 months - you need to look at the root of the problem

column1: Hi all Car gurus, Please give your opinion regarding best battery brand in Pakistan esp for a diesel engine vehicle, I mean durability and quality.
column2: razaksyed;2788698: @xulfiqar, where would you normally source S. acid and distelled water? what make of distelled water Murree Brewery? what is the ideal composition / ratio? from the chemicals supply market and distilled from the medicine wholesale market or lab supplies. and mix 33% acid with 66% water - if you have a hydrometer thats good, then check with that, otherwise use a digital scale and weigh 1 litre of electrolyte 1 litre should weight 1270 grams at room temperature. (basic school physics) anyways to the rest saying that battery life is 1 year, that means that my house cars in Pakistan are either really lucky or there is some voodoo going on. The last batteries installed in them were in 2008, and they still show absolutely no problems, And I dont fiddle with the cars that much. Prior to that, the old batteries were replaced after being 6 years in service. btw the battery brand is AGS and Exide - and I have a secret for their long life.

column1: Hi all Car gurus, Please give your opinion regarding best battery brand in Pakistan esp for a diesel engine vehicle, I mean durability and quality.
column2: autophile;2790665: Xulfiqar bhai. the optimum or peak life is one year, however, batteries can last much longer. I however change when first time battery is unable to rev the self starter and that moment comes once in three years. I know that I can still use the battery by replacing electrolyte or recharging it, but as someone said above a weakening battery puts load on the alternator:) so better have a full strong battery after two or three years. BTW my friend is using stock FB battery in his 2006 Xli. He says that it still revs the self and car starts on two selfs and the horn has become weaker but the battery is still running after five years:) The life of battery also depends on how many start/stops in a day you have. I have tons of starts/stops a day:) my diesel VW in Pakistan had about 10 start stops per day on average, that little engine has a 23:1 compression ratio with a planetary gear starter sucking 400 amps on startup. Still uses the same AGS battery I installed in it. The other jap cars also face similar duty, If your battery was prepared nicely, and you positively know for sure that your whole circuit is good, (meaning no corrossion on grounds etc) and your alternator is good - the battery will live a long life. I see people in Pakistan push start a dead battery car and then expect the alternator to fully charge the battery (for sure the alternator will fail shortly and undercharge/damage the battery and the next battery and the next too). There are some recommendations and procedures for everything in life.

column1: Hi all Car gurus, Please give your opinion regarding best battery brand in Pakistan esp for a diesel engine vehicle, I mean durability and quality.
column2: haris457;3258042: as getting 33% and 66% by weight is difficult option reason being one cant know how much sulphuric acid has already been diluted by the supplier Sorry for the late input measure the SG of neat acid with a set of scales, the SG of pure acid should be 1.840, meaning that 1 litre of sulphuric acid should weigh 1840 grams.

column1: Hi all Car gurus, Please give your opinion regarding best battery brand in Pakistan esp for a diesel engine vehicle, I mean durability and quality.
column2: I have a white mercedes benz OE battery in my car, its a 100AH battery with 900 cold cranking amps, it has a sticker that states it was put in service in 2006. It still starts the 6 cyl diesel engine perfectly. I regularly check the SG of the electrolyte and correct as necessary. The alternator is 120A and always charges a stable 14.1. These batteries are known to last for a decade easily. The batteries in Pakistan are quite good too, the secret to their long life is preparing them with PURE DISTILLED WATER and PURE ACID. Do not expect any sort of life from it if you pour in tap water and gutter ka taizab with stuff floating in it.

column1: Hello Everyone! Rebuilding Nissan Sunny B12 1989-1990 I welcome everyone here for suggestions. The detail of the car is as follows: Nissan Original Engine E13 (rebuilt last year October 2016) The gear was changed to manual 5 speed because it had 4 speed gear and was in pretty bad shape. New Kyb Malysian shockers along with coil springs were installed New Cv joint Outer GSP (Original) with Japanese Inner were installed. Yokohama Tyres ECOS 175/65 R14 were purchased along with rims I am going to get it dented and repainted totally. The body parts which I am changing are: Hood (Taiwanese) New head lights and back lights (Taiwanese) Front fenders (Taiwanese) Front Nose Cut known as radiator support (Used Japanese) Front and Rear bumpers along with their brackets (Used Japanese) Trunk/Diggi (Used Japanese) I will try to keep the thread updated and post pictures of the work done. ENJOY!

column1: Hello Everyone, Can anyone let me know from where can I get the license for Forklift. Is forklift comes under HTV ? Can I get forklift driving license from clifton driving license branch ?
column2: To get a forklift license, you can try contacting your local Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) or a specialized forklift training center in your area. Forklifts are typically considered industrial vehicles rather than Heavy Goods Vehicles (HGVs), so you might not need an HGV license specifically. As for the Clifton driving license branch, I'm not sure about their specific services, but it's worth giving them a call to inquire. Speaking of forklifts, I had an incident where mine broke down, but thankfully I got it repaired at https://anguslifttrucks.co.uk/forklifts-service-in-uk/2.

column1: I have a 1984 Toyota Corolla with an engine swap of 1N diesel (non-turbo). It has been running perfect after 17 years with unbelievable fuel economy. I would like to know about the possibility of installing a turbocharger on it. The 1N-T is the Toyota engine with turbocharger installed as default. Does the 1N engine have the mount to install the turbocharger. My engine does have an extra air cleaner (it is very large) behind the head where the turbocharger is placed on the 1N-T (1N-T does not have extra air cleaner). The extra air cleaner probably does nothing but further restrict the airflow. I would take it off anyway. Question is, can I install a turbocharger on its mount, or if the mount can be improvised? Please help me out so that I go on and look for the CT12 turbocharger.
column2: The IN turbo engine pistons are different - it has cut outs for the piston cooling oil jets and pistons have the cooling slugs in them. The outer bits are that the intake manifold is log type and the exhaust mounts the turbo, the pump has the LDA unit on it. You can do it but it requires careful running if you slap turbo parts on an NA. The engine cannot sustain high stress runs. Otherwise the engine is pretty good for what it is.

column1: Experts here the the car in question is Honda City 2012 with mileage 35000 only, one hand driven only. The problem is the hard clutch pedal. Whenever i stuck in traffic block i literally have pain in my foot by pressing clutch pedal again and again. The clutch pedal is hard to press and i have shown it to different mechanics. Some says its due to bad pressure plate, some says it is due to bad master/slave cylinder and even some says its just fine. I went to mechanic who said that it is due to pressure problem for clutch pressure plate replacement but he did not open it as he was not sure because car is only 35k driven and excellent condition never drive with foot on pedal. Car can have a wheel spin even in 2nd gear too. Now i have a option to go for master/slave cylinder check but there is no symptom of faulty master/slave cylinder. Experts please help me in this regard. Here is information which can help you to advice me. 1) Car can have wheel spin even in 2nd gear, i recently went to Naran and did not face any problem regarding uphill drive or gear changing. 2) One mechanic diagnosed that rubber pipe connecting the line between master and slave cylinder is blocked, he changed it but problem of hard clutch pedal not solved 3) I was also feeling a little problem of hard shift, but after bleeding clutch the problem resolved and also clutch hardness reduced almost 10%. 4) I never ever roasted its clutch by racing/ drag or by keeping foot continuously on clutch pedal. I always used foot rest. 5) There is no leakage, no oil reduction. 6) Working of clutch is fine no any problem except hardness. Please suggest me what should i do??? How to get rid of this problem. One more thing, i have drive my friends same Honda City car but that has so much soft pedal. Even my cultus has so soft pedal. Thread once started cannot be deleted until conditioned, but can be closed. Let us know when ever you like to open it - MOD
column2: When bleeding a clutch or brake, it's essential to measure the oil throw accurately using a clear pipe to prevent backflow. A distance of about 7 inches indicates the oil's travel from the bleed nipple. However, using clear pipes and preventing backflow is crucial for precise measurements. Regarding clutch lifespan, it heavily depends on usage; improper practices like holding the car on an incline with the clutch rather than brakes can rapidly wear out the friction disc. This issue is commonly heard among Honda owners, indicating concerns about clutch durability, especially compared to Toyota models. Some prefer Nissan's cable-type clutch for its perceived reliability. However, the trend in Pakistan leans towards automatic transmissions, with some even considering converting manual Mehrans to automatic. Despite this shift, the availability of technical support for automatic transmissions remains a concern, highlighting the need for trained mechanics specializing in automatic gearbox repair and maintenance.

column1: Greetings to all readers! I’m using Nissan Otti 2008/13 which is almost 1 lac KM driven but fuel average is about 10KM per liter with AC on speed of 90 on motorway. Tuning, throttle body cleaning and plug cleaning done recently. Air filter changed recently but no improvement. What can be possible reason while car is being heated up on speed above 110. Thanks in advance
column2: For low fuel efficiency please also get the injectors cleaned (especially if there is rough idling and misfiring in engine). It can also be related to oxygen sensors malfunction. It will be better to visit a reliable workshop and hook up a good scanner for proper diagnosis of the problem.

column1: Greetings to all readers! I’m using Nissan Otti 2008/13 which is almost 1 lac KM driven but fuel average is about 10KM per liter with AC on speed of 90 on motorway. Tuning, throttle body cleaning and plug cleaning done recently. Air filter changed recently but no improvement. What can be possible reason while car is being heated up on speed above 110. Thanks in advance
column2: If car is heating up you need to check if your cooling system is working fine (radiator, coolant level), Heating can also be caused by blown head gasket. Carefully inspect your car's coolant reservoir for mixing of oil in it.

column1: Now before you think that this is just another Toyota vs Honda brawl you might be disappointed.I have used the search function but the topics came up with replies like Honda is the best, thats why! the purpose of this topic is to find out the differences in between these very similar engines.and why are they so different? now we all know about the TOYOTA {AE111} 4A-GE (blacktop) 20 valves (3 intake valves per cylinder)(a total of 5 valves per cylinder) introduced in 1995 and continued till 1998, 1.6l (1587cc), a sky high Compression ratio of 11:1 , individual throttle bodies , OEM (factory) tubular exhaust manifold(extractors), lightened flywheel,six speed C160 gearbox on later models , this handsome brute manages 165 PS (121 kW 163 hp) at 7800 rpm with 162 N·m (119 ft·lbf) at 5200 rpm of torque. which is very impressive for a naturally aspirated 1.6l engine. but turning our attention towards the Honda engineers, and the truly epic and unimaginable creation the much feared B16B-R. now this engine is based on a simple 16-Valve DOHC design with a displacement of 1595cc (1.6l)(basically a beefed up version of a B16A), a compression ratio of 10.8:1 and the people in charge of the B16B project at Honda managed to extract 136 kW (185 PS; 182 hp) @ 8200 rpm & 16.3 kg·m (160 N·m; 118 ft·lbf) @ 7500 rpm. Now from a 1.6's perspective if this does not seem much mind you a B16B has a higher specific HP output per liter than a Ferrari 360.:o now coming towards my question and the subject of all this information is that why a these seemingly similar for example both are DOHC/twin cam multi valve 1.6 with freakishly alike internal specifications for example look the Bore X Stroke of the two engines: B16B bore X stroke = 81.0x77.4mm AE111 4A-GE bore X stroke = 81.0x77.0mm furthermore...... both employ their versions of variable valve timing control technology. now on paper the 4A-GE looks like a winner with all the factory fitted race spec parts (like tubular extractors and ITB's for a road going car and the 11:1 CR surely looks like something out of a JTCC or Group A racing engine catalog) and the main point Why the 5-valve design what purpose or advantage did the 3 intake and 2 exhaust valves design serve pic 1 from bilzilla.com  now why does the the 4A-GE have a less (20hp +/- 1-2hp) power output than a much simpler 4-valve per cylinder design B16B. thank you.
column2: 2195863: Brother Honda technology is alot better than toyotas when compared to engines. then y is that u see 1000-1600hp supras n 1jz n 2jz in many rwd cars n not honda engines?

column1: Now before you think that this is just another Toyota vs Honda brawl you might be disappointed.I have used the search function but the topics came up with replies like Honda is the best, thats why! the purpose of this topic is to find out the differences in between these very similar engines.and why are they so different? now we all know about the TOYOTA {AE111} 4A-GE (blacktop) 20 valves (3 intake valves per cylinder)(a total of 5 valves per cylinder) introduced in 1995 and continued till 1998, 1.6l (1587cc), a sky high Compression ratio of 11:1 , individual throttle bodies , OEM (factory) tubular exhaust manifold(extractors), lightened flywheel,six speed C160 gearbox on later models , this handsome brute manages 165 PS (121 kW 163 hp) at 7800 rpm with 162 N·m (119 ft·lbf) at 5200 rpm of torque. which is very impressive for a naturally aspirated 1.6l engine. but turning our attention towards the Honda engineers, and the truly epic and unimaginable creation the much feared B16B-R. now this engine is based on a simple 16-Valve DOHC design with a displacement of 1595cc (1.6l)(basically a beefed up version of a B16A), a compression ratio of 10.8:1 and the people in charge of the B16B project at Honda managed to extract 136 kW (185 PS; 182 hp) @ 8200 rpm & 16.3 kg·m (160 N·m; 118 ft·lbf) @ 7500 rpm. Now from a 1.6's perspective if this does not seem much mind you a B16B has a higher specific HP output per liter than a Ferrari 360.:o now coming towards my question and the subject of all this information is that why a these seemingly similar for example both are DOHC/twin cam multi valve 1.6 with freakishly alike internal specifications for example look the Bore X Stroke of the two engines: B16B bore X stroke = 81.0x77.4mm AE111 4A-GE bore X stroke = 81.0x77.0mm furthermore...... both employ their versions of variable valve timing control technology. now on paper the 4A-GE looks like a winner with all the factory fitted race spec parts (like tubular extractors and ITB's for a road going car and the 11:1 CR surely looks like something out of a JTCC or Group A racing engine catalog) and the main point Why the 5-valve design what purpose or advantage did the 3 intake and 2 exhaust valves design serve pic 1 from bilzilla.com  now why does the the 4A-GE have a less (20hp +/- 1-2hp) power output than a much simpler 4-valve per cylinder design B16B. thank you.
column2: sami_voodoo;2227954: It's actually pretty surprising, people here in France do not really know the Black Top. Everyone knows the Honda VTEC engines, but if you tell them about an ITB'd 20 valve Toyota engine, they stare blankly at you. Toyota cars have a reputation of cars for pensioners or grocery getters. So 100 bhp/litre NA engines are quite out of the ordinary. dont talk to them in english they will stare at yr beard,,blankly. . ofcourse with thelil bit torque on 4age, it works well for grocery, turn a corner throttle, slow down, another corner,, throttle , slow down dead stop, red light. another corner ,, yr home. mind you, you all need groceries. skylinedriftmaster uses 4age for grocery even in snow, donest matter if he cant reach home before lunch!,, its fun going sideways.. :D. i use 4age for grocery but instead of stopping at store i drive on .... come back at dinner without food. damm 4age!

column2: "immad100;3241793: ^^^Does the front-wheel drive/rear-wheel drive factor make the 4AGE engine superior to the B16 engine? (No offense, I'm just asking.) I mean, the 4AGE engine produces the same power output in both front-wheel drive and rear-wheel drive configurations. @saadzae Toyota specifically targeted the B18C engine when designing the 2ZZGE engine and it performed well against it. But, yeah, the ""R"" engine has no competition. I'm not offended. I don't want a car that pulls me around, I'd rather have a car that pushes me...:D There is a significant difference."

column1: I made an OIL CATCH CAN using an empty perfume spray aluminium bottle, lpg kit nozzles, copper tubing used in gas kit and steel wool mesh used for washing utensils at home. Works well and keeps my IAC valve and throttle body very clean as new and keeps the oil and dirt grime out of my throttle body and IAC valve. It prevents plug fouling also as the oil doesn't get burnt with the fuel and enginre remains clean of carbon and oily gooey deposits enhancing engine life. I just need to empty the can of the black burnt oil every month just by turn of a stop cock fitted at the bottom of the oil catch can. Costs - less than 250 Rupees.
column2: OIL CATCH CAN EXPLAINED Combustion gases "blow-by" the piston rings during the compression stroke, and enter the crankcase. They dilute the oil and promote corrosion and sludge. Positive Crankcase Ventilation serves to cycle clean air through the crankcase, evacuating the combustion gases, by using intake manifold vacuum as a motive force. The PCV valve vents from the engine block directly to the intake manifold. At idle and low RPMs, vacuum in the IM draws the spring loaded PCV valve open and creates negative pressure in the crankcase. Clean, filtered air from the airbox is tapped off the turbo-charger inlet pipe by a breather hose, and drawn into the crankcase at the valve cover. This clean air sweeps through the crankcase, carrying the blow-by gas and oil-mist out through the PCV valve, where it is fed into the intake ports to be burned. The flow is one way ]] breather hose ]] crankcase ]] PCV valve ]] intake port. Sport car tuners instal oil catch cans at both the PCV hose and the breather hose to keep contaminants out of the engine and intake.

column1: I purchase an Exide "Solar 100" 60Ah (C/20) in October 2021. I got curious about measuring its output, and it ended up at 8.5V after providing just 16.5Ah at a 20W load only a little bit more than a year later. To charge, it absorbs 46Ah towards 14.4V. Clearly, this is ridiculous - I use a great charger, take care of the battery's temperature, float and storage voltage. It was likely prepared with shitty electrolyte and has failed juuust out of warranty. Where can I sell (preferably sell to recycle) this battery? Battery vendors that will take it and give you a credit towards the purchase of a new battery, I suspect, are ripping me off. I'm assuming I can buy a dry, unprepared, flooded lead acid battery from a battery place. Is this correct? Or would they give me some nonsense about the warranty not being valid if they don't prepare it themselves with water from the local river? Where can I buy battery electrolyte? I've heard of companies like Pyrochem, but nobody picks up their listed contact phones. I could prepare some myself, but where can I buy an appropriate concentration of H2SO4 today? And what other tools for measuring SG exist, other than than a (cheap and locally available) bulb hygrometer? Alternatively, does anyone know of a battery place in Karachi that definitely has good battery prep practices and honor their damn warranties?
column2: All batteries are shipped completely dry to the shops. You can buy it as is too. The acid is sold at chemical market near denso hall / napier road in Karachi, distilled water is also available there or adjacent to the medicine market. - only buy acid produced by contact process (sold in dark brown sealed bottles), do not buy the plastic bottle oleum trash, its max purity is 60% compared to 99% of CP stuff. Want to wager what the battery sellers use? For measuring SG, you can use a basic kitchen scales. We know that water is 1.00 sg meaning 100 ml water weighs 100 grams and 1 litre of water weighs 1 kilogram So by that , a litre of 1.27 sg electrolyte should weigh 1270 grams. Simple school stuff, the risk factor here is mixing both water and acid, its an exothermic reaction and boils violently, so extra caution is required and only add the acid drop by drop (smaller quantities is the idea) Then let it cool down to room temp and then fill the battery cells, let it rest for a 10 mins and then boost charge it for a few minutes, it will bubble quite a lot as all air is dispersed from the plate pores.

Schools, collegiates, coaching centers with a chem labs do buy that acid.

column2: "Thank you for the instructions. Therefore, I visited the chemical markets near Denso Hall. I conducted a survey and asked several stores for sulfuric acid. Unfortunately, none of them had opaque glass bottles. Only one store had dirty plastic bottles labeled with an ""S"" written in marker. They were selling it for Rs. 250, but they wouldn't allow me to test the pH or weigh it on a scale. Approximately eight pounds, not eight ounces. Oh, not ounces, kilograms. Weight matters. I decided to leave when I became tired of battery sellers praising their sweet water, claiming to use a specific type of water. One dealer, Defence Battery Traders, seemed reputable and mentioned they use deionized water with a total dissolved solids (TDS) of 300ppm. Deionized water with a TDS of 300ppm. Unfortunately, I haven't had any luck in finding battery acid so far. While searching online, I came across this information:"

column2: asimm76;3515821: I also heard here on Pakwheels that date of tyres DOES matter and it should not be more than 6months old when u r buying it new I dont know whether the person saying that has any basis for that, or he was just portraying our mentality. In car manufacturing industry the shelf life of tyres is considered as 5 to 6 years. They follow first in fiest out method for tyre issuance to production line. As long as the tyre is new there is no problem if the mfg date is even 2 years old. But you can ask dealer to charge the price of 2 years back. All are invited in Party tonight at my Signature space.

column1: I have a Corolla 1974. The drum breaks were replaced with disc breaks. Servo was installed recently. Wheels are getting jammed Is there an expert in lahore.
column2: You know your problem already You have upgraded front brakes without changing the distribution of brakes in front and rear. Replace the proportional valve with the approx and your problem will be solve.

column1: hello, is there a way to remove wiper blade marks from windscreen....my car has lines on the screen which look horrible due to bad wiper blades and there useage...and does removing the scratches leave waves like pattern on the screen ??? if any one know any shop or person in Lahore who is good and professional please let me know.
column2: Buffing will/might reduce or eliminate the swirls but it will also take away a special coating from the surface of the wind screen if the buffing is very abrasive . I am not sure what car you have but it's industry standard that all wind screens and rear screen have an anti glare coating. This is actually applied at the time of manufacturing.. I have seen and came to know from certain people that they have experienced an increased glare after buffing.. this glare issue is also very common with the after market cheap replacement glass.. reason these are not with this glare protection layer.. Expert can throw more light on your screen.. Meanwhile read this thread too. 58https://www.pakwheels.com/forums/news-articles-driver-education-safety/228716-driving-night-danger-responsibilities-safety-measures58 Please share your night time driving experience with other please.

column1: hello, is there a way to remove wiper blade marks from windscreen....my car has lines on the screen which look horrible due to bad wiper blades and there useage...and does removing the scratches leave waves like pattern on the screen ??? if any one know any shop or person in Lahore who is good and professional please let me know.
column2: khjodat;4416544: I have also heard of this problem when the windscreen is being buffed and afterwards you observe balls like glittering on screen when light falls on it from opposite direction. Its true that the windscreens have a coating or it is rather called as Lamination coating and when this lamination coating once removed due to heavy buffing then it becomes unfit. I think it is risky to buff the windscreen and if you have decided to do it then take special care by selecting a good experienced person and ask him to do a very light buffing otherwise your windscreen would be ruined. The scratches normally develop due to using inferior quality wiper blades. Never use wipers to clean the windscreen while it is dry. Once in a while spray silicone spray (which is easily available in market in pressurized tin bottle) on the wiper rubbers to make them soft and supple. you are never supposed to even use the word silicone and glass in the same sentence - you will never be able to remove it from the glass, the wiper blades are rub cleaned with alcohol only

column1: hello, is there a way to remove wiper blade marks from windscreen....my car has lines on the screen which look horrible due to bad wiper blades and there useage...and does removing the scratches leave waves like pattern on the screen ??? if any one know any shop or person in Lahore who is good and professional please let me know.
column2: meth or eth both work, you can even clean it with vodka if you wish. I clean my cars wipers with soap and water then rub clean with such alcohols - I do replace them every year though, no economy in using bad wiper blades.

column1: hello, is there a way to remove wiper blade marks from windscreen....my car has lines on the screen which look horrible due to bad wiper blades and there useage...and does removing the scratches leave waves like pattern on the screen ??? if any one know any shop or person in Lahore who is good and professional please let me know.
column2: visit any lab and read their silicone and glass prohibitions, you will understand, Once silicone gets on glass - its impossible to remove. Secondly wiper blade rubber inserts are only good for 1 year, after that they become useless even if you never switched on the wipers. You are not supposed to lubricate them externally as it would skid on the glass rather than clean it.

column1: hello, is there a way to remove wiper blade marks from windscreen....my car has lines on the screen which look horrible due to bad wiper blades and there useage...and does removing the scratches leave waves like pattern on the screen ??? if any one know any shop or person in Lahore who is good and professional please let me know.
column2: I only buy genuine wiper blade rubber inserts for my cars from their dealers. I clean them every month with a wipey of alcohol and they are good again. Once they start to smear on the first sweep - its change time. I also use rain-x on my MB - its body design is really good - so when it moves the side windows actually clean themselves - the water is sucked upwards as the car moves forwards. For silicone grease/oil on glass - I work in a facility that has tons of labs, they invent high performance poly urethanes, surfactants, pigments, polymers and a whole book worth of other items. Silicone grease is banned in some labs - specially on glass items - upto the point of discarding the item as it can never be cleaned off unless mechanical action is used.

column1: Aoa Members . I hv Mitsubishi ek wagon 2018/2021 model . Here is sign in speedometer which i required your guidance and expert opinion as i dnt know about this sign.
column2: "Yes, you are absolutely correct. For your resetting question, let me take a look at it. There is an error in the Ek Wagon G 2014 Model 2016 Import Mitsubishi. Attached is an image of the error.  -  - Greetings to all brothers. The error keeps appearing on the Ek 2014-16 import G model. Sometimes it shows 7, sometimes 3 or 4, but mostly this error occurs. Now, the problems I am facing are:  -  - 1. The Auto Start and Go (Eco Idling Stop) is not working. The ""A"" sign blinks in yellow all the time.  - - When mechanics reset it with a computer, the ""A"" sign stops blinking, but after 1 or 2 starts, it starts blinking again.  -  - 2. The car is taking a load on the AC excessively, and the AC mostly trips when the car is on."

column1: Aoa Members . I hv Mitsubishi ek wagon 2018/2021 model . Here is sign in speedometer which i required your guidance and expert opinion as i dnt know about this sign.
column2: an spanner in cluster display means you shall connect a scanner and scan the vehicle. Do not reset desi way by removing battery terminals.

column1: Aoa Members . I hv Mitsubishi ek wagon 2018/2021 model . Here is sign in speedometer which i required your guidance and expert opinion as i dnt know about this sign.
column2: If it's the spanner it is a reminder to get oil changed. It's set on a timer, doesn't mean anything. It'll show up even if you have changed the oil. Search how to reset it.

column1: My car's running document is lost. What shall I do now? The car is on lease and on bank's name at the moment. They are going to transfer it to my name in a few days and my brother says they will have to make a new running document anyway so it is not a problem. Is it really so? Bank has the original book and only the document I keep in car is lost.
column2: As long as original book is there i dont think so there will b any issue.

column1: My car's running document is lost. What shall I do now? The car is on lease and on bank's name at the moment. They are going to transfer it to my name in a few days and my brother says they will have to make a new running document anyway so it is not a problem. Is it really so? Bank has the original book and only the document I keep in car is lost.
column2: upto 2003 - 2004 banks normally register the car in their name and keep the original book with them. they just give the customer a authority letter and copy of the registration book to keep it with them in the car. but now bank just want the customers to register car in their name and mark HYPOTICATION "HP" in respective bank's favor. and the original book stays with the customer.

column1: My car's running document is lost. What shall I do now? The car is on lease and on bank's name at the moment. Bank has the original book and only the document I keep in car is lost.
column2: Duplicate copy of running document can not be issued,for this u will have to issue a new registration book and vehicle can be transferred without this missing page.

column1: My car's running document is lost. What shall I do now? The car is on lease and on bank's name at the moment. column2: brother that were original documents, bank dont keep it with them they just transfer vehicle to its name and hand over all to owner. so u lost it original papers, means lowering down ur vehicle value and problem for selling too.. plz do confirm again from ur bank. and also inform me if differs. thanks

column2: Don't worry, I recommend reaching out to your company for assistance. The more people you ask, the more confused you may become. In my opinion, you should consider filing a police report or taking some form of legal action. If the books are in possession of the company, they will eventually return them to you.

column1: Hey guys, I hope you are well. I have started to hear a whistling noise coming from my Revo it only comes when car is driving I accelerated on idle and it was not there but as the car gets hotter the noise increases, please advise what this could be , it's a loud high pitch whistle. Thanks
column2: Can you make a video and share video link? It'd be pretty easy to help you out.

column1: Hey guys, I hope you are well. I have started to hear a whistling noise coming from my Revo it only comes when car is driving I accelerated on idle and it was not there but as the car gets hotter the noise increases, please advise what this could be , it's a loud high pitch whistle. Thanks
column2: Bro it's not from Turbo I just had the break pads and fuel transmission changed turbo and belts checked everything is fine and I was very happy until I hit canal road and it came again, I am starting to think it's something to do with air crossing?

column1: Hello everyone - since we are in lockdown - with lots of free time at hand - we decided to document some of the work we are doing, in this case a cultus's gearbox overhaul / re seal etc... I don't have pics of every step of the way but will try to explain in detail. nonetheless, this is not a tutorial - use this thread at your own risk. thanks so - we start by removing this chamber, you need 10mm/12mm Ts for this operation: which leads you here: moving on, see the labelled picture below - you need a flat faced pin to push the pin lock in (it comes out the opp side) marked YELLOW then you need to undo the hex bolt marked PURPLE, it has a ball inside keep these safe. many more balls to come yet. the light blue marks are circlip locks, which need to be removed to remove this fork with gear and synch assy. Marked in green is a 27mm nut which needs to be undone. I use a impact gun for this job, if you dont have one you can shove a piece of wood between the gears to make the nut loose. once you're done you should see something like this: Also, please note that the assemblies are neat and clean - this is because we didnt actually take pics during disassembly. I'm just using the pics we have to explain. this is it for today. once you have removed the entire 5th gear assy, you should see a needle bearing as shown in the pic below: - mark its top / joint - this will make sure you put it back as it was. if you look closely, you can see the white markers next is to remove those philip head screws 6x and the case plate - there is a bearing shim (marked green ) underneath the plate make sure to keep it safe (it may or may not be re-used, depending on the bearing play) - to end up like this: @margallar specially for your eyes @Xulfiqar will need your input to improve @capsat tusi great ho @babarhyd need tips sir jee! ALSO - SOMEONE PLS FIX THE PICTURES - i tried uploading twice with same results.
column2: Quote - @syncview you need a flat faced pin to push the pin lock in (it comes out the opp side) marked YELLOW then you need to undo the hex bolt marked PURPLE, it has a ball inside keep these safe. many more balls to come yet. the light blue marks are circlip locks, which need to be removed to remove this fork with gear and synch assy. Marked in green is a 27mm nut which needs to be undone

column2: Next up, removing the gear selecting shaft: remove the 3x 10mm bolts: since i don't have a picture of whats inside, here is a snipper from the service manual: once you remove the cover plate, you can then undo the 12mm yoke bolt and pull out the both the bolt and yoke, a magnet helps here. next up, remove the gear select shaft locking 14mm bolt (RED) and 4x 10mm bolts that hold its top cover (PURPLE): once the yoke has been removed and 14mm locking nut undone, you can pull this shaft out with a bit of wiggling (no pic)

column1: "Enjoy the convenience of free navigation and avoid the hefty cost of purchasing a new SD card. Follow the instructions below: -  - For Wince Devices (Car LCD, such as Chinese City Aspire Caska or any other Navigation capable Car LCD): - 1. Make sure you have a minimum 1 GB micro SD card. - 2. Download either Sygic or IGO Primo software from the following links: -    - For IGO Primo: [insert link] -    - For Sygic: [insert link] - 3. Extract the downloaded file using WinRar on your PC or mobile device. - 4. Paste the extracted files onto the SD card. - 5. Insert the SD card into your Car LCD. - 6. If your Car LCD has a default path, name the main folder ""MobileNavigator"" and make sure it contains the .EXE file. - 7. Provide the path as ""MobileNavigator/MobileNavigator.exe"" for IGOPRIMO 9.8. -  - New topics include Navitel Navigation with Pakistan maps and Lost Nav Card Fix for Wince/Android In-Car Entertainment (ICE). -  - For Wince Devices: - 1. Make sure you have a Wince Device (Car LCD, such as Chinese City Aspire Caska or any other Navigation capable Car LCD). - 2. Obtain a minimum 1 GB micro SD card. - 3. Download NaviTel WINCE from the following links: -    - [insert link] -    - [insert alternate link] - 4. Extract the downloaded file using WinRar on your PC or mobile device. - 5. Install the extracted files onto the SD card. -  - For Android Devices (Car LCD): - 1. Make sure you have an Android Device (Car LCD). - 2. Obtain a minimum 1 GB micro SD card. - 3. Download Sygic_Full_18.2.0 from the following link: [insert link] - 4. Extract the downloaded file using WinRar on your PC or mobile device. - 5. Paste the extracted files onto the SD card. - 6. Insert the SD card into your Car LCD. - 7. Install the Sygic_Full_18.2.0 apk and replace the files in the Android folder of the SD card's main root folder. -  - Both options include Pakistan maps. Enjoy the convenience and blessings of this navigation system. Long live Pakistan!"

column1: Assalamulaikum all. I hope you are all doing well. I haven’t posted at Pakwheels for a long time so I’m here with another project. The car in question is a 2002 HA12 Alto. It’s a PKDM variant which originally came with an F10A engine. The engine was a little over 300,000km driven but it was still running strong. I was getting around 14km/l within city (I know it’s unbelievable for this engine but a combination of keeping it well-maintained, different jets in the carburetor and light foot driving helped achieve this.) The idea behind this swap was to improve the fuel average of the vehicle with the insane fuel prices these days and to convert the transmission to auto. If I could get better performance, that would also be a plus. Now I could go the safe route of a K6 auto swap to get better fuel average but that wouldn’t have cut it because of the lack of power. I could use a K6 turbo instead but that wouldn’t help me achieve the fuel average figure that I was after. Therefore, with limited options to achieve what I wanted, I decided to swap in a Honda L-13A IDSi with a CVT transmission into it. Why an L-13A I hear you ask? a) It is known to have good fuel average, even in heavier cars such as the Honda City, Civic and the Honda Jazz/Fit, b) It would have a CVT Transmission, therefore helping achieve the auto transmission bit and c) with 85hp and about 120nm torque, it would offer good power to weight ratio in a car that weighs a little shy of 700kg. I have an ongoing series of Videos for this project on my channel, you may visit the channel at, www.youtube.com/@funcariauto/19 Here are some specifications of the engine. Engine Code: L13A Engine Capacity: 1339cc (Offered in the 1.4 Honda Jazz GG/Fit GE, 1.4 Honda Civic FD) No. of Cylinders: 4 IDSi – Intelligent Dual Sequential Ignition, which means there are Two Plugs per cylinder, sequentially fired for better efficiency. Power: 85hp @5700RPM / 120nm Torque @2800RPM Compression Ratio: 10.8:1 7 Speed CVT-Transmission (SWRA) Most of the work on it is done in-house, which includes mechanical, fabrication, electrical and aesthetic. So let’s begin the process. The car, just before going under the knife. On jack stands and dismantling started. The engine bay before the swap.
column2: Correct Found out that url was blocked at office network Viewing the pics fine on phone One of the top rated threads at pakwheel's at the moment Loving it

column1: Car: Civic 99 VTi Oriel (PK6) - Transmission: Factory AT - Engine: D15B 3-Stage  - ECU: P2J-J61 (originally meant for a CVT/MMT) - Converted (rewired) to OBD2a. -  - Problem 1: The IACV. I can't seem to get it to work. I have tried 7-8 of them. -  - Problem 2: The P2J ECU is causing issues - the car runs like it's towing something behind it, especially with the AC on. The current error codes displayed are 9 and 14. -  - There are currently two solutions presented to me: - (1) Change the ECU to P2J-J62. - (2) Change the ECU to the OBD1 P08 (P08-007, P08-008, P08-009).  -  - I read a post on a Honda forum that suggests the P08 can be made to work with dual VTEC by editing IAB values using Crome. -  - Does option (2) sound like a legitimate solution? What base map will be used in this scenario (P2J or P08)? Are there any other critical elements that I need to consider before going for this setup?
column2: are you sure the wiring shows continuity to the IACV and is not being shorted to anything else. The CKF is just a safety sensor to tell you that the timing belt is in need of attention, the bypass job is easy and quick.

column1: Car: Civic 99 VTi Oriel (PK6) - Transmission: Factory AT - Engine: D15B 3-Stage  - ECU: P2J-J61 (originally meant for a CVT/MMT) - Converted (rewired) to OBD2a. -  - Problem 1: The IACV. I can't seem to get it to work. I have tried 7-8 of them. -  - Problem 2: The P2J ECU is causing issues - the car runs like it's towing something behind it, especially with the AC on. The current error codes displayed are 9 and 14. -  - There are currently two solutions presented to me: - (1) Change the ECU to P2J-J62. - (2) Change the ECU to the OBD1 P08 (P08-007, P08-008, P08-009).  -  - I read a post on a Honda forum that suggests the P08 can be made to work with dual VTEC by editing IAB values using Crome. -  - Does option (2) sound like a legitimate solution? What base map will be used in this scenario (P2J or P08)? Are there any other critical elements that I need to consider before going for this setup?
column2: Car: Civic 99 VTi Oriel (PK6)  - Transmission: factory AT  - Engine: D15B 3-Stage  - ECU: P2J-J61 (originally meant for a CVT/MMT)  - Converted (rewired) to OBD2a.  -  - Problem 1: The IACV doesn't seem to work. I've tried 7-8 of them but still no luck. -  - Problem 2: The P2J ECU is causing issues. The car runs like it's towing another vehicle behind it, especially with the AC on. The current error codes displayed are 9 and 14. -  - There are two solutions that have been suggested to me:  - (1) Change the ECU to P2J-J62. - (2) Change the ECU to the OBD1 P08 (P08-007, P08-008, P08-009).  -  - I read a post on a Honda forum that mentioned the P08 can be made to work with dual VTEC by editing IAB values using Crome. -  - Does option (2) sound like a legitimate solution? What base map should be used in this scenario (P2J or P08)? Are there any other critical elements that I need to consider before going for this setup? The CYP sensor is inside the distributor.  -  - Regarding the IACV, which type are you using? 2-wire or 3-wire? It sounds like your problem might be a wiring issue. -  - Yes, you can use an OBD1 P08 chipped ECU on your D15B dual VTEC. To make it work, you need to do the following things:  - - Buy or make an OBD2-OBD1 conversion harness.  - - Use OBD1 low-ohm 240cc D15B/D16Z6 injectors or a resistor box from a 92-95 model. - - Use an OBD1 distributor.  - - Use an OBD1 VTEC ECU that can be chipped. - - Use a 2-wire IACV or an OBD1 IACV plug.  - - Use an OBD1 alternator or an alternator plug.  - - You need to either bypass the VTPS switch in your new OBD1 ECU or use Crome to eliminate VTPS. -  - Now, for the Crome part: Crome does not have a ROM/code for dual VTEC. If you want your first VTEC to work with IAB activation, you'll need to alter the wiring and create a pinout for the IAB from the ECU (A-17/A-19, depending on the ECU being used) to the first VTEC solenoid (12-valve mode). Alternatively, you can use a P72 ECU that already has the IAB support. However, even with these modifications, you'll only be able to switch between 1st and 2nd VTEC modes. You won't be able to tune your maps for both modes, as both will run on the 16-valve/VTEC maps. This means that even in 12-valve mode (lean burn), your ECU will still provide fuel as per the 16-valve settings. -  - You can either go through the above steps or simply get a P2J ECU and call it a day! Thank you.

column1: I have a Suzuki Jimny with an F6A turbocharged EFI engine. For the longest time, I've been on a goose chase trying to figure out why my engine would stall, after it had warmed up, when pressing the clutch in. It would either stall and die or idle rough at 900rpm, lighting up the oil pressure light. The first time this happened, I had just changed to Valvoline SynPower 5W-30 API SP. "Synthatec gaarha nahi hota, gari purani hay, 20W-50 dalen." I'd rather not kill my turbo, but the oil pressure light was an obvious urgent fix. I switched to Delo Gold Ultra, changed spark plugs, but the issue persisted. I even tested my oil pressure, installed an oil pressure gauge, and am going to back to using 5W-30 or 0W-40 full synthetic oil at the next interval. So it likely wasn't a low oil pressure issue. Eventually, the tiny hoses feeding coolant to the IAC valve in the manifold developed leaks. I bypassed them, and the car idled at 2000-2200rpm, but at least I had oil pressure. Got sick of the ridiculous fuel consumption, got new IAC valve coolant hoses installed back in. New Problem: engine would surge with clutch in and at idle, but only if I gently raised throttle to about 1200rpm. At that point, it would start surging. 2500rpm, 1000rpm, repeat. Obviously, this made driving in stop-and-go traffic very difficult. It happened all the time.The only way to make it stop was to turn on the AC, and even that only slightly calmed it. Turning AC off, or when the compressor disengaged due to the evap coil thermostat, would make the surging come back. Nobody knew what the hell was going on. Until, messing around with vacuum lines, we bypassed this idle control solenoid: Once again, the idle shot up. No surging. Pinch one line off, engine stalls. Aha. The old one seemed to not be working. I found an Afghani replacement, and it solved the problem. Now, I'm trying to figure out what it does and how it's controlled. I notice it doing two things: Adjust idle, bringing it down when high and up when low. I'm confident that it's temperature-dependent. BUT IT ONLY does this (I checked) when: Vehicle completely stopped. Transmission in neutral Clutch not pressed in Dropping idle back down after AC switch is turned off. Once the compressor clutch disengages, engine RPMs rise until "something" happens and they drop back down to 1000rpm. That "something" doesn't happen if this solenoid is disconnected, and surging starts again once engine rises to 1200rpm. So... what is the control scheme for this thing? How does the ECU determine what to tell it? Is it a normally open solenoid like I suspect? Why does it compensate idle only when those three requirements are met??? I'm puzzled. Is this common across other cars from this era? It's an inconvenience if the car fully warms up in traffic, because unless I come to a dead stop, put it in neutral and give it a second, the car won't set the idle at 1000rpm and "remember" it. It'll either do something like 1200rpm or 800rpm, or stall out, unless I do this little dance at a dead stop. The solenoid gets very hot under normal operation, and the Afghan replacement seems to be failing again, behaving inconsistently like the previous one. I want to buy a brand new part, but it's roughly $200. Does anyone have any experience cleaning out and rebuilding these? P.S. Installed an 88°C thermostat, using Glysantin G48 coolant, removed locked-solid clutched fan, installed electric fan with a shroud and temp switch rated for 88°C. Engine still doesn't warm up all the way (water temp needle slightly below halfway) unless it's a hot sunny day with AC on. When warm, it's more likely to stall unless I do the 3-step dance.
column2: The valve is only for idle adjustment, there is never an idle speed condition while moving. You should also check if your throttle body bore is worn out, or adjusted out of spec - that can cause it too. Idle hunting also happens due to the pcv valve causing a vacuum leak.

Engine still doesn't warm up all the way (water temp needle slightly below halfway) unless it's a hot sunny day with AC on. When warm, it's more likely to stall unless I do the 3-step dance.
column2: Firstly make sure the cold start idle up thermostatic unit is working, Remove it and clean it out with vinegar to remove all rust sediment, then test its ports for air passage when hot and when cold. Once its working, then set idle speed on warm engine and retest your situation.

column1: I have a Suzuki Jimny with an F6A turbocharged EFI engine. For the longest time, I've been on a goose chase trying to figure out why my engine would stall, after it had warmed up, when pressing the clutch in. It would either stall and die or idle rough at 900rpm, lighting up the oil pressure light. The first time this happened, I had just changed to Valvoline SynPower 5W-30 API SP. "Synthatec gaarha nahi hota, gari purani hay, 20W-50 dalen." I'd rather not kill my turbo, but the oil pressure light was an obvious urgent fix. I switched to Delo Gold Ultra, changed spark plugs, but the issue persisted. I even tested my oil pressure, installed an oil pressure gauge, and am going to back to using 5W-30 or 0W-40 full synthetic oil at the next interval. So it likely wasn't a low oil pressure issue. Eventually, the tiny hoses feeding coolant to the IAC valve in the manifold developed leaks. I bypassed them, and the car idled at 2000-2200rpm, but at least I had oil pressure. Got sick of the ridiculous fuel consumption, got new IAC valve coolant hoses installed back in. New Problem: engine would surge with clutch in and at idle, but only if I gently raised throttle to about 1200rpm. At that point, it would start surging. 2500rpm, 1000rpm, repeat. Obviously, this made driving in stop-and-go traffic very difficult. It happened all the time.The only way to make it stop was to turn on the AC, and even that only slightly calmed it. Turning AC off, or when the compressor disengaged due to the evap coil thermostat, would make the surging come back. Nobody knew what the hell was going on. Until, messing around with vacuum lines, we bypassed this idle control solenoid: Once again, the idle shot up. No surging. Pinch one line off, engine stalls. Aha. The old one seemed to not be working. I found an Afghani replacement, and it solved the problem. Now, I'm trying to figure out what it does and how it's controlled. I notice it doing two things: Adjust idle, bringing it down when high and up when low. I'm confident that it's temperature-dependent. BUT IT ONLY does this (I checked) when: Vehicle completely stopped. Transmission in neutral Clutch not pressed in Dropping idle back down after AC switch is turned off. Once the compressor clutch disengages, engine RPMs rise until "something" happens and they drop back down to 1000rpm. That "something" doesn't happen if this solenoid is disconnected, and surging starts again once engine rises to 1200rpm. So... what is the control scheme for this thing? How does the ECU determine what to tell it? Is it a normally open solenoid like I suspect? Why does it compensate idle only when those three requirements are met??? I'm puzzled. Is this common across other cars from this era? It's an inconvenience if the car fully warms up in traffic, because unless I come to a dead stop, put it in neutral and give it a second, the car won't set the idle at 1000rpm and "remember" it. It'll either do something like 1200rpm or 800rpm, or stall out, unless I do this little dance at a dead stop. The solenoid gets very hot under normal operation, and the Afghan replacement seems to be failing again, behaving inconsistently like the previous one. I want to buy a brand new part, but it's roughly $200. Does anyone have any experience cleaning out and rebuilding these? P.S. Installed an 88°C thermostat, using Glysantin G48 coolant, removed locked-solid clutched fan, installed electric fan with a shroud and temp switch rated for 88°C. Engine still doesn't warm up all the way (water temp needle slightly below halfway) unless it's a hot sunny day with AC on. When warm, it's more likely to stall unless I do the 3-step dance.
column2: pwuser162557941033: I have a cat temperature warning light permanently on in my dash. I was sent on another goose chase trying to find an O2 sensor for the hollowed-out catalytic converter housing, but there is none. It's a one-wire connector for a "thermal fuse," as Suzuki calls it. This is not a sensor, but a literal "fuse" - its only job is to trip the dash lamp on that is warning a cat converter overheat, (dont park on dry grass or something that can ignite) that part is no longer made and not available from any manufacturer anymore, I have a customer here who imported a toyota century V8 and it had that, - Its unobtanium from Toyota and even Denso warehouses globally, the only source would be a single item sitting on a dusty shelf in some obscure place in the world.

column2: pwuser162557941033: I still don't know whether the VSVs are normally open or normally closed. When the AC clutch disengages at idle, RPMs rise slowly until they quickly come down again, and this seems to be the role of the VSV pictured in my initial post. If there's no crank speed or angle sensor, how does the ECU know when idle is at the set point? My guess is injector or ignition coil duty cycle. Or some kind of lookup table for the MAP sensor? There is always a crank speed sensor (how else would it time the ignition) - even if its just a simple 3 pole reluctor to time the cylinders. VSVs can be both types, NC or NO - it depends on what their purpose is. But - good job on resolving it. It has the same setup like an old corolla, the AC has its own idle up VSV with a bleed adjustment. On the older corollas, the problem I usually faced was removed thermostat, completely jammed IAC (because it would default to high idle due to cold temp) - and the additional wax pellet valve also stuck open. I had to remedy most with a thorough cleanup or replacement - usually the small metal coolant tubes would be clogged full of rust (highest point in system and air loves to trap there causing steam cavitation) - let the engine warm up fully to let the wax pellet open up - then refiddle the idle speed from the "verbotten" stop screw - (the screw that no mechanic in the world would touch, other than a Pakistani ustaad) Finally start the AC and adjust the VSV to correct idle quality - the way it should work is that the idle up would start a few miliseconds before the compressor starts - this way the engine would never lower its idle speed and would smoothly keep running. (make sure your car has its original AC amp in it too - it enables that little delay), Similarly when the compressor disenages, you will feel the engine rpm raise a bit (car wants to nudge forward if in D and foot on brake) - this is all normal.

column1: I had disel running Corolla 86 but that was almost done, so few mmonths ago, i went to Rawalpindi famous 'Mithu ka Ahata' and swapped for a 4EFE. didnt knew about petrol engines much then. So, after a day i got my car back and found out issues like: (1) RPM is not working. (2) Car looses some RPM on Load like headlights and very much on A/C. (3) I have changed my fuel pump thrice but still on petrol it likes engine is turning off on turns. (4) Check light in dashboard is not connected. I have viewing threads for a while and its clear to me that i have to do the wiring and stuff, which i am not scared of, the only problem is that i dont know where to start the thing! What steps should i take and how this problem can be solved cuz i am really annoyed by the Electritians ,they cannot handle stuff the right way, always make 'jugaat' to run it. Needed help from you guys!
column2: make sure the ECU does not have S1, S2 and SL pins, if it does then its an electronic shift Automatic trans ECU and will always show a check light. Get rid of this POS round denso relay, its scrap even when new, you need two relays one main and one circuit opening. The main relay can be any simple Bosch 4 pin SPST relay, 40A type, the circuit opening relay is actually toyotas name for fuel pump relay and works the fuel pump like it should. Its a 5 pin relay with 2 bobbin coils in it. Wiring it up is very simple. Be sure to use a 20A fuse on the feed of the main relay. Otherwise you run the risk of fire.

column2: main relay supplies 12V +ve to the ECU B1 and B+ injectors idle control motor circuit opening relay feed line It is switched on by the ignition key the BATT is direct connection without key but 10A fuse direct to battery for memory of the ECU. in some toyotas the injectors, idle motor and O2 heater are supplied with a direct connection from key switch from the same line that switches on the alternator regulator.

column1: I have minor scratches on screen due to bird poop and car standing outside the house, should I get the windshield buffed/polished for clear vision? Also, has anyone tried services of these online guys, GlassFix_pk in karachi or lahore? they're charging 2000 for my 660cc car. Appreciate the response.
column2: Correct me if I am wrong, there is a hard clear UV coating over the glass which reduces the UV rays entering the care and being harder than the glass, it stops the glass from getting scratched. Buffing will remove this layer, so you might have a clear glass for few days but it will be more prone to scratches. I had my head lights buffed once. They became v hazy with scratches within few months. Next time I got it buffed, I sprayed it with a clear coat usable for plastic and surfaces (bought it from daraz) as shown in a tutorial of Youtube.

column1: I have minor scratches on screen due to bird poop and car standing outside the house, should I get the windshield buffed/polished for clear vision? Also, has anyone tried services of these online guys, GlassFix_pk in karachi or lahore? they're charging 2000 for my 660cc car. Appreciate the response.
column2: Nope actually unlike paint glass has a uv rejection layer packed between the 2 layers of glass in between. The top is just bare glass which can be polished heavily without any fear except cracking windshield. Glass itself is 10x strong than clear coat on body paint. The case with headlight is totally else. Headlights contain a coating above it to save your headlight from environmental damage typically getting it plaed. However you cam buy an headlight coating and apply on headlight after its correction

column1: I have minor scratches on screen due to bird poop and car standing outside the house, should I get the windshield buffed/polished for clear vision? Also, has anyone tried services of these online guys, GlassFix_pk in karachi or lahore? they're charging 2000 for my 660cc car. Appreciate the response.
column2: Actually there's no pre installed coating above the glass. Providing it continous heat of 150°F will damage the plastic layer between both glases as it will start to loose it properties.

column1: I have minor scratches on screen due to bird poop and car standing outside the house, should I get the windshield buffed/polished for clear vision? column2: Hi, so I have done this on multiple cars, Viper marks are visible if the rubbers are not changed regularly. I have seen great results. Recently got My father's 2010 Altis front screen buffed and now he can clearly see at night. got it done In lahore near Mazang Chungi. The guys name is Qasim. Just ask around everyone knows him as he is doing it since long. My cars have never been harmed. Done it on Suzuki Khyber, Toyota Altis and Revo. You can negotiate with him on spot and i think it should be around 1000 for Alto front screen.

column1: I have minor scratches on screen due to bird poop and car standing outside the house, should I get the windshield buffed/polished for clear vision? Also, has anyone tried services of these online guys, GlassFix_pk in karachi or lahore? they're charging 2000 for my 660cc car. Appreciate the response.
column2: Yes an additional layer of protection e.g. glass coat or ceramic coat is preferred for hydrophobic, gliding wiper effect but not necessary. When I buy a car from showroom my cars windshield never gets damaged as i buy fresh rubber every other season for replacement and i cover my car with top cover when parked. As Saad mentioned that its bare glass that a car comes with and the car screen can be buffed a few times before its starts to show signs of irregularity that can distort the view due to uneven buffing. Once or twice is no problem. A good buffer never buff the glass sealant adjacent or closeby areas as the sealant can lose its properties with the heat generated during this process. The sealant is mostly present on the edges of glass or where the rear view mirror is glued to the windscreen in some cars.

column1: Considering the abundance of people that use tap water in their vehicle's cooling systems, this is essential.
column2: No, it is bad. Theoretically is it more bad then soft water. Since is electron hungry, and other then that it absorbs CO2 from air quickly and become slightly Acidic. Better to add coolant with distilled water Or use Soft water.

column1: Considering the abundance of people that use tap water in their vehicle's cooling systems, this is essential.
column2: AC condensate is moisture in the ambient air that condenses on the fins of your AC's evaporator. Theoretically, it would have no solids at all, except that by the time it travels down your evaporator fins, pools at the bottom of the pan, and drips down the drain hose and into a container, it's already accumulated some foreign debris. The point is to not use water alone in your cooling system. Coolant concentrate is diluted with distilled/deionized water to form the final fluid that goes into your engine's cooling system. Coolant lubricates the water pump, raises the boiling point beyond 100°C, lowers the freezing point below 0°C, prevents corrosion, and prevents damage from cavitation. There really is no reason not to use it. Nobody seems to have read the contents of the image. Only certain regions in the United States have tap water that is suitable (although not ideal) to use in an automotive cooling system, with a solids content of less than 120ppm. You do not want solids (or gases, for that matter) in your car's cooling system.

column2: your car was built with R12 heat exchangers, you can run R134 in it with very good performance if you fit a parallel flow condenser in it and make sure you have very strong cooling fans. The dryer is a standard liquid line dryer but only install a genuine part of denso etc. make sure you use the correct oil in the compressor - do not use universal A/C oil that shops use, R12 and R134 require different oils.

Also EricTheCarGuy says that if drier are not under pressure they absorb Moisture and get saturated so i guess all original ones at Bilal Gang should be doomed. Ill have to Buy new ones. OR Refill R12 which is standard design for my car. Not sure compressor can handle it or not. When speaking of figures Condenser will cost me something like 7000 Drier 2000 Refil and Gas charges 2000 its heavy investment or i pay someone to fill R12 the drier is shipped with a vacuum seal or even some refrigerant to keep it good. As soon as you open the plastic stoppers the dessicant is exposed - you have now time window of about 1~10 minutes to install it if you are in humid weather. when reusing old A/C hard parts like lines etc. I wash them with acetone and use nylog on O rings. The oil to be used is mentioned on the compressor itself, dont dump all of it in the compressor - put a few ml here and there around the system like the evaporator, dryer etc. Once done pull a vacuum and inspect.

column2: saadkhangul;4384386: There is not much issue of gas here. Older system designed for r12 gas can run on r134. But the newer ones designed for r134 cannot run on r12. For running r134 in r12 system, you need to change the compressor oil to a r134 based one and a dryer designed for r134 and the high and low lines if they are of r12. There is a huge issue of gas here - when you fill R134 in an R12 system you need approximately 80% weight only and even then the performance is not anywhere equal to the original system. The only way you get good performance is to replace the condenser with a very good parallel flow unit - R134 is a very stubborn refrigerant and does not take change in temperature as easily as R12 does.

column2: the original fill capacity of gas was 790~800 grams, the oil was approximately 120 ml (dry fill) - this was spread across the whole system, meaning some in the compressor, some in the condenser and some in the dryer etc. To flush the hard parts - firstly if your system has baffles in the suction line, that cannot be flushed, you need to replace the line, Use Acetone to flush A/C lines and use compressed air clean the acetone and finally purge with nitrogen if you can. Replace the expansion valve with a new and genuine part, use a single capillary valve. The twin one is obsolete and no longer available. It basically has a bypass built into it. make 1000% sure the condenser is good and the O rings are installed with nylog (A/C supply shops sell it). Do not let your technician charge the system by inverting the cans - liquid can damage the valve plates in the compressor. Let the system suck on it own power, to get the last bit of gas out of the can get a pan of hot water and dunk the refrigerant can in it as it is charging.

column1: Where can I find genuine Liqui Moly 5w30 fully synthetic oil? I am currently using 5w30 synthetic oil but I am unable to find the fully synthetic version in 5w30. I asked at the Liqui Moly outlet in I8 Markaz, but they do not have it. Does anyone know where I can find it in Islamabad or Rawalpindi? Click here for SOLUTION126.
column2: I think the 0w-20 or any 0w-xx grades are not suitable for hybrid vehicles. Such thin oil viscosity can potentially cause damage to non-hybrid engines. The oil sumps in these vehicles are generally small, which makes heat dissipation more difficult with a smaller oil sump. Based on my limited knowledge, the ideal and best engine oil grade for most 660-1000 cc non-hybrid vehicles throughout the year is 5w-30. Perhaps 5w-20 may be suitable for city traffic in winters, but not for highways or extreme summer heat. In any case, 0w-xx is not recommended.

column1: Where can I find genuine Liqui Moly 5w30 fully synthetic oil? I am currently using 5w30 synthetic oil but I am unable to find the fully synthetic version in 5w30. I asked at the Liqui Moly outlet in I8 Markaz, but they do not have it. Does anyone know where I can find it in Islamabad or Rawalpindi? Click here for SOLUTION126.
column2: Brother, I recommend using a fully synthetic engine oil with a grade of 5W-30, an API rating of SN, and that is 100% genuine and original. Personally, I have had an excellent experience with ENEOS SUSTINA 5W30 SN/RC. You can find it at http://www.eneos.pk/sustina-5w30-snrc/76. It costs Rs. 4500 for a 4L pack and can easily last for 8000 kms with city traffic, extreme rush hours, and highway driving. -  - Alternatively, you can also consider using QUARTZ 9000 FUTURE GF5 5W30. The 1L pack is priced at around Rs. 835, and the 4L pack is approximately Rs. 3128. You can find more information about the prices at http://totalparco.com.pk/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/Price-list-of-AO-01-March-2018.pdf. -  - I advise against using ZIC oil. Please note that as of 22-05-2018, Shell, Mobil, Liqui Moly, and Caltex Chevron do not offer 5W-30 fully synthetic oil, so they can be eliminated from consideration.

column1: Where can I find genuine Liqui Moly 5w30 fully synthetic oil? I am currently using 5w30 synthetic oil but I am unable to find the fully synthetic version in 5w30. I asked at the Liqui Moly outlet in I8 Markaz, but they do not have it. Does anyone know where I can find it in Islamabad or Rawalpindi? Click here for SOLUTION126.
column2: Brother, using 5w-40 oil can be too heavy for the engine. Last week, I couldn't find Eneos Sustina 5w-30 fully synthetic oil. At that time, there were no other well-known brands offering 5w-30 fully synthetic oil. So, I ended up using Havoline ProDS Fully Synthetic LE SAE 5W-40 oil, thinking that it is close enough to 5w-30. It was my first experience, and I regretted it. Since then, my car's engine has almost failed. It struggles to reach speeds of 0-20 km/hr within 8-10 seconds, and the fuel efficiency has also decreased. Previously, the eco light used to turn off, but now it doesn't even turn on. (I own a Passo 2013 with a genuine odometer reading of around 38000 kms). So, my sincere advice is to not even consider using 5w-40 oil in your vehicle.

You personally have had a positive experience with it. -  - However, you are curious about other options like 5w-20, 0w-20, or even 0w-30 for your vehicle. You travel about 70 kilometers daily on the Islamabad Expressway and occasionally take the motorway twice within a span of three months. -  - You have tried using 5w-40 in the past but do not want to continue with it. Apart from 5w-30 and your brief experience with 5w-40, you have no knowledge or experience regarding 5w-20, 0w-20, or 0w-30 for a Toyota Passo. column1: My question is regarding the diesel engines of BMW. I heard they have been a failure in Pakistan due to the low quality diesel in Pakistan. Is this true or this just a myth? Would be grateful if anyone can answer this. THANKYOU
column2: Sounds like someone needed a payday. All of these DI diesels use taper wedge compression rings which means that they will show low compression on cranking test. From my own experience of dewan bmw, they dont have even a single bmw trained mechanic, the only person holding a cert is the SM who sits in an ac office all day long. Dewan also have a habit of hiring morons in their corporate office side too. But anyway, the old wives tale of “diesel ki kwaltee” in Pakistan is nothing more than hearsay. The mechanics tearing down engines for overhaul because “diesel ki kwaltee, bohot carbon etc” are basically milking the client for all his worth as the labour cost will make a very nice payout. A very simple acid test of these mechanics by asking to exhaustively and visually prove the failure will quickly filter out the crooks, in dewanay case would be 100% of the staff including corporate officers.

column2: LNG & LPG are 2 different fuels. Natural Gas is Liquified for bulk transportation, at destination it is converted to gaseous form and pumped into natural gas lines. Thats why LNG / CNG / Natural gas is used by domestic users through lines. where as LPG is - Butane / Propane obtained from oil refineries, both are combustible and does not need compression over 40 psi for the cylinder for transportation or domestic usage.

column2: natural gas in pipe lines is story from past now, in many areas across Karachi it is almost non-existent. In some areas it is like electricity load shedding aka timed availability. Since Oct 25th to date approximately Rs. 19000 worth LPG has been used in kitchen. Forget about geysers warm water in taps. In Pakistan we destroyed our natural gas reserves (resources) by making it cheap fuel for transport industry. Every time i saw a CNG vehicle filling 9 kgs of gas at Rs. 125 / kg, the amount was equivalent to my WINTER' gas bill. So imagine my 30 days of gas was consumed by a taxi just for 250 km run, and after that he burn again my monthly gas consumption. Figure out what speed we have F&%!ED our gas reserves. Now looking around to buy from abroad, by paying foreign exchange which again is slowly vanishing. LPG or CNG as transportation fuel will also become premium product for us soon,

column1: Aoa, my friend has 2010 model Toyota Vitz with 1KR-FE engine and he is getting p67-y this code on his speed o meter sharing picture of the speed o meter. I searched on many forums on google but didn't found anything about it. Please help if anyone knows something about it.
column2: pwuser161228146379: p67-y apparently it is child seat indicator, locate an extra seat belt clamp over rear seats i located this answer at PW using magnifying glass on right top. it has been asked number of times. ANY YELLOW CEL (ERROR) Light means vehicle need scanning.

column1: Assalam o alaikum dear Pak Wheelers, I am a silent reader of this forum for quite a time and I found it very interesting. I have an JDM Nissan AD 2006 regd 2012, 1300 cc having QG13DE engine with A/T. The car has completed 215,000 kms on the ODO and till last month it was running on original engine (without any rebuild). For the last 3 / 4 months, I observed that car losses its power gradually by the time and vibration in engine at idle or low rpm. The car moves to & fro (jerks) when stopped on signals/traffic while in D position. The jerking is quite high and I have to bring the gear lever to N while the car is stop. The car has no cold/hot starting issues and always start in one self. no overheating history, thermostat valve is in place and fans are auto. In Pakistan, the car is mostly driven on CNG (almost 100k kms). IMO Overall engine is in good condition having no engine oil loss, blue smoke, carbon deposits at silencer end, smooth engine sound etc. Last month, due to missing, vibration and lack of power, my mechanic advised me to rebuild its engine head with new valves, valve seats and machining etc. I followed his advice and rebuild engine head with new taiwan valves set and related stuff, the machining was done at Al-Madinah Engineering at water pump. After dis-assembling, we have found one exhaust valve seat burnt and that particular cylinder was misfiring. After rebuild, i observed that the engine missing/vibration has gone and power is restored to an extent (but not completely) I notify the matter to mechanic but as they all said, it will be better with time (and it doesn't). Now the condition is, the car performs well for 6k kms after the rebuild and during the last week I started observing slight vibrations in engine, car also vibrates/jerks minutely when stop in D position. The missing can be heard at exhaust tip also. The mechanic is so dumb he cannot feel the vibration and missing and advice me to either increase engine RPM through software or ignore it, its all normal. (well IMO its not). I think valve seat(s) is/are damaged again and we have a loss of compression in cylinders. My car mostly driven on National Highway within speed of 80km/h to 120km/h. I use Havoline Formula 10W30 for this engine with guard oil filter. Kindly advice guys, i am so fed up with these mechanics. Should I have to rebuild head again, or make adjustments in valve shims by grinding them a little. I am also thinking of replacing complete kabli head from shershah, they are asking 22k for it. Kindly also advice, do we have some special valves and valve seats for use in CNG vehicles, as i heard form many that CNG produces high temperature in combustion chamber hence burn valve seats. I will be very thankful to you guys for your concern. @xulfiqar bhai, @spectra, @capsat (your advises are critically required).
column2: immediately change the transmission fluid am not sure which city you are located, Obama car care Tipu Block, Lahore can do the job nicely.

column2: There is no need to change the ATF if it is 15,000 km old. The ATF life is over 65,000 km. A new CVT transmission oil change is recommended at 75,000+ km. The Guard oil filter is not suitable for JDM engines. Please get a Leppon or VIC oil filter and use Aisin or Shell Helix engine oil. If you are in Karachi, go to Jamil Autos at Shahrea Quaideen Society office. You can contact them at +92 300 9232821 / PTCL 34761699. They are open from 10 am to 7 pm on weekdays only. First_blood;5225051: Thanks Capsat for your advice. The ATF was replaced around 15,000 km back with ZIC ATF III. However, I will replace it this coming Sunday. I usually replace ATF at intervals of 15-18 K kms. The current condition of the ATF is not blackish and looks reasonably clean.

To ascertain what exactly need to be done do not attempt shim cut without dry & wet readings. Get it done for free again, or it may be that you were simply trying to have an upper hand of knowledge n holding the leash and they got scared.
