column2: first_blood;5225612: No codes were checked till yet, so is the RPM values, AD van does not have an RPM meter in its cluster.However check engine light went ON when I drive the car on CNG and went OFF when I used it on petrol for few days. Currently, from the last one week I am running car on petrol and check light is OFF. I think if any sensor malfunctions the check light should not went OFF. One more thing, the exhaust sound at exhaust tip is not continuous, it has the sound of that misfiring (Phak Phak sound). Last time when engine head was rebuild the same sound was there which vanishes after rebuild work. I am willing to go to Jamil autos tomorrow in-sha Allah, ask him to connect the scan tool and pop out codes if any, lets see what it shows. This proves that engine is misfiring.

column1: What is the difference between NGK 9807B-5617W and 9807B-561BW? 9807B-561BW is for civic 1.8L. 9807B-5617W is for accord/crv/element 2.4L and 2.0L civic. I own an eighth generation civic otherwise known as reborn, it comes with an R18A engine. Now the issue I am facing is that I can not find the spark plugs for civic in the market (did not check the honda dealership), other people sell NGK 6774 IZFR6K-13 for civic in Islamabad/Rawalpindi, where they are meant for Honda Fit. So basically the closest I could find to NGK 9807B-561BW is NGK 9807B-5617W. Now my question is would these plugs cause any issue to the performance/efficiency of my car or is it ok to use them? Also, if anybody could guide what these numbers and alphabets mean, that would be a great help because I couldn’t find the right answer on google. Thanks!
column2: The Honda part number is 9807B-561BW and the NGK part number is IZFR6K-11S.

column2: For the Civic, it is recommended to use IZFR6K11 spark plugs. I happen to have 100% genuine IZFR6K11 spark plugs with me. If you're interested, please let me know.

column1: Salam, This project was basically a sort of restoration of a toy car. This toy car was my first birthday gift way back in 1984. Pictures below, Allah has blessed us a son and he is going to celebrate his first birthday. I was thinking of presenting him something different if not special. I decided to DIY of restoring this car. By now you have seen the damages to the car, front bumper, front lights, backlights, rooftop light are missing, stickers, sides broken (near bumpers), windscreen and one window glass is missing or broken. I kicked off the proceedings with front bumper. For this I used milk can and a wall clock plastic base. Used Soldering iron and knife for plastic welding and cutting, heating for giving desired shapes. After this I used sanding and coloring with shinny black spray. Next I picked was front lights, initially I used bike indicators. It was unsuccessful in the end, due to heating process glass became faded and due to low quality plastic, buffing didn't work. Then I used bike helmet visor, it didn't get faded. I am aiming in future phase, to use JDMs broken lights, better quality plastic, buffing would be possible. Beside glass work I also added background chrome, using aluminum foil. For backlights I used bike reflectors, shaped them as per area by heating. For rooftop light, I used a light part from a donor car. For body damages I used filler, sourced from dent/paint shop. Used plastic, mold them as per need, glued them to the broken areas to fill that area. Applied filler for final finish. LEDs were used for illumination, unfortunately I didn't work quiet well in the end. I didn't have much time so I decided to improve it in the next phase. For now I captured the effects in dark. Pictures to follow, For windscreen and window, I also used helmet visor, crafted them, molded them, colored them. For side emblems I took help from plotter (service available at any number plates shop). Result can be seen later in this write-up in final outcome pictures. After completing all the repair work, I proceeded with color process. Used matt black for the lower base, shinny black for glass, side mirrors, bumpers, tyres. Shinny red for the body color and hardener in the end. Now the final outcome: That's all I hope you will like my effort. Thank you for your time. Abdul Rehman
column2: Not a toy anymore, but a live memory for one. @abdulrehmanrauf: Beautiful share, May God keep the kid inside-us all "alive" to respect the moments we spent with our parents and loved ones.

column1: AOA , I bought second hand 2007 Model Honda City VARIO , I don't know which oil was used in engine before but I started it with Caltex Synthetic Oil 5W-40 , immediately after that change of oil I heard click click and tik tik sound from engine. I ignored it and kept using it , there was no engine noise on high speeds , I drove it to 140km speed. For my satisfaction l I thought why not try the best one MOBIL 1 5W-50. Even after that the engine noise on idle not removed. I went to Honda 3S and they advised tappets adjustment. After that service ,Noise issue slightly recovered but not fully recovered. I kept using engine in that state for about 2 months but engine noise not resolved. I took advise from some senior technician and he said Engine needs overhauling. That made me depressed and worried as well . because I used best engine oils so why should it happened. Surprisingly there is no issue in driving performance. Engine performance is perfect other than annoying sound click click , tik tik or idle state. On a advice I further tried normal 10W40 Mobil XHP and Mobil imported 20W-50 Super but noise not gone. Finally HONDA 3S also advise Overhauling. Need help or advise if ENGINE OVERHAULING is the last option for me as no issue in pick or performance ? Any competent ADVISE ?
column2: please dont overhaul the engine if its not giving smoke or reducing oil in big amount try to ignore the tik tik sound and keep driving(my car has the same sound to b.t.w )

column1: AOA , I bought second hand 2007 Model Honda City VARIO , I don't know which oil was used in engine before but I started it with Caltex Synthetic Oil 5W-40 , immediately after that change of oil I heard click click and tik tik sound from engine. I ignored it and kept using it , there was no engine noise on high speeds , I drove it to 140km speed. For my satisfaction l I thought why not try the best one MOBIL 1 5W-50. Even after that the engine noise on idle not removed. I went to Honda 3S and they advised tappets adjustment. After that service ,Noise issue slightly recovered but not fully recovered. I kept using engine in that state for about 2 months but engine noise not resolved. I took advise from some senior technician and he said Engine needs overhauling. That made me depressed and worried as well . because I used best engine oils so why should it happened. Surprisingly there is no issue in driving performance. Engine performance is perfect other than annoying sound click click , tik tik or idle state. On a advice I further tried normal 10W40 Mobil XHP and Mobil imported 20W-50 Super but noise not gone. Finally HONDA 3S also advise Overhauling. Need help or advise if ENGINE OVERHAULING is the last option for me as no issue in pick or performance ? Any competent ADVISE ?

column2: talhawaleed;4331970: Possible Reasons: [LIST=1] [*]Buildup of sludge which may prevent oil from circulating freely, you should have flushed the oil first using liquimorly engine oil flush and later filled it with new oil. [*] Bad ignition coils, maybe one or more coils are not working. [*]Maybe one of the injectors are so much clogged that its close to not delivering the fuel in one of the cylinders. [*]Vacuum leak from somewhere and maybe clogged PCV valve. [/LIST] Recently I did following with my vehicle. [LIST=1] [*]Replaced the engine mounts which resulted in lesser vibrations from engine. [*]Replaced the advancer/emulator whereas original wirings were short and problem with rough idling was solved and poor accelerations was solved. [*] Bad starting issue was solved by changing from 20w-50 to 5w-30 oil. [*]Stuck gears issue was resolved by filling the gear box with kerosene and let idle for 10-15 minutes on it and later filling it with Honda genuine gear oil which is compulsory for city. [*]Plugs Changed, Throttle body wash, intake manifold cleaning, Injectors cleaning as this was difficult and surprisingly all of them were badly clogged and result was enhanced fuel economy. [*]Leakage in lower engine oil pan and timing chain cover leakage was fixed, surprisingly engine did not lose the oil since then. [*]Brake oil flush using suction machine, braking improved even on old tires. [/LIST] Lost glory was restored after this. From where you got this work done on your car? Honda 3s?

column1: As the title suggests, I along with my friends overhauled engine of my car. A little history, this car is with us since last 10 years and has been overhauled before by a jugaaru mechanic. It had CNG installed in it and was in use by the previous owner. The issues which led to this overhaul were: 1- Excessive oil burning and leakage. 2- Knocking/pinging noise (carbon build up on the pistons) 3- Running on wrong oil grade i.e. 20w50 4- Low compression. Values were 105 95 100 104 psi The car previously overheated too and blew a head gasket (which was fixed by that jugaaru mechanic). All of these seem perfect recipe for a disaster. Before taking up the overhaul, we searched junkyards to find a good clean engine which can be swapped in and save the effort and time of overhaul. But all in vain, junkyard engines were, you guessed it right, junk. Not a single clean 2e, 4e, 4efe, 4afe, 5afe, 7afe (even checked 4ages) was available. It didnt seem wise to get such engine and rebuild it all over again. Hence the decision was made to rebuild the existing 2e engines. After which, list of parts was made and procured (toyota genuine parts were used when available). Machinist was decided, service manual was arranged and gone through, all bolt torque, clearance etc values were gathered. I had to take leaves from the job to carry this out. First step was multiple runs of real concentrated solution of citric acid in the cooling system (it ran on water and had rust deposits) and then the disassembly started. I will attach pictures and steps in following posts.
column2: There is still a lot of rust in the engine, needs a second dose of acid wash. Btw Good job!!!

column2: This is a very good and sure process to clean out rust from an iron engine, its done quite commonly in other countries. In proper machine shops they usually have a fire oven where they bake this block while its rotating, it will literally burn off everything from the metal and make it ready prepared for machining. There is another way to degrease such a block on the cheap! you have to find a drum, fill it with some water and a strong soap (industrial soap) and then put a low flame under it and drop the block in and let the "paaye" cook. It will come out looking like fresh cast iron. (literal light shiny gray) - When I was a lad in Pakistan, I did that on a toyota 2K engine which I can bet was cooled with river mud instead of tap water.

column1: Can some 1 share his knowledge of engine life (how many kilometers a car can do with a good driver without getting engine overhauled ) of 1- Suzuki Max (100,000) KM 2- toyota Max (300,000) KM 3- honda Max (500,000) KM i might be wrong but please share the knowledge
column2: The lifespan of an engine is influenced by various factors like the operating conditions (load, atmosphere, humidity, etc.) and the maintenance it receives. In an ideal environment, even a Suzuki Alto could run for 500,000 miles before requiring an overhaul. On the other hand, a Mercedes V6 engine could fail after just 5,000 miles if it is abused and not maintained properly. Therefore, It is not fair to make generalizations solely based on the brand of the car.

column1: Can some 1 share his knowledge of engine life (how many kilometers a car can do with a good driver without getting engine overhauled ) of 1- Suzuki Max (100,000) KM 2- toyota Max (300,000) KM 3- honda Max (500,000) KM i might be wrong but please share the knowledge
column2: 6037550;2478037: toyota has longest engine thatts why its called more reliable. you can see the originla rollas of 80s or 90s running fine on road with about 4lakhs kms.honda has not so good life but old civics can done 2lakhs kms but new civic vtec cant bear so much maar. generally speaking toyotas run lower compression engines. take for example teh 5VZ in my surf. it is an "overbuilt" engine as it is designed to be a workhorse in light truck applications. however if abused and incorreclty maintained it WILL die after only 100,000kms. yet at the same time if maintained correctly it's possible the enigne lasts as long as the car. hondas tend to be driven hard in thehands of young people and if you add to that the higher compression engines, higher operating temperatures and the need for better octane fuel you'll see why these engines tend to fail. as the expression goes "guns don't kill people, people kill people". same applies to the operators of cars. they are the main reason engines fail, not the engines themselves.

column1: Can some 1 share his knowledge of engine life (how many kilometers a car can do with a good driver without getting engine overhauled ) of 1- Suzuki Max (100,000) KM 2- toyota Max (300,000) KM 3- honda Max (500,000) KM i might be wrong but please share the knowledge
column2: A well-designed engine, such as the Toyota 4A, 2NZ, 1NZ, 2ZZ, and 1ZZ series, and the Honda D range, as well as the Suzuki Billi range (including the Suzuki 660cc), will perform optimally if properly maintained. Proper maintenance involves allowing the engine to warm up before subjecting it to heavy loads, avoiding exposing it to water (such as through a high-pressure wash at a service center on a hot engine), and regularly changing the oil using high-quality oils instead of opting for cheaper alternatives. These are some of the steps required for ensuring the engine's longevity and optimal performance.

column2: this is a nice pictoral, now all you who have graduated SSC with science usually had access to the physics lab can relate to what I write. there is a phenomenon which happens in liquids which is called cavitation, its an imploding bubble which has enough energy to physically erode metal. Engine coolants have additives in it to prevent this very exact thing, If you take out your water pump and have a look you may find little round craters in the backplate - this is caused by cavitation. You might consider "mehhh - 1500 rupay ka to hay sirf". This statement can be ok if you own a POS mehran which was design and built by lazy stoned overworked labour, But if you have an engine like saad mentions backing a factory run - cavitation in that engine usually costs about Rs ten million and above, if the cylinder liners also give in. It can in a diesel engine - specially near the cylinder head/block junction. If you ever wonder why your mehran engine block coolant holes are corroded to hell and widened up - it was cavitation foaming at work. coolants are of many types, e.g. GM use the dexcool coolant (like caltex kinoo coolant) which actually does a darn good job of scrubbing out rust and depositing it neatly in the expansion tank. Nice for systems which are 100% liquid. take MB, BMW, etc. they are EU cars and EU has water so damn hard that you need to chew it before drinking, soap forgets how to soap too. They use BASF glysantin for their applications. It is a very good HOAT coolant that does a very good job against cavitation protection, lubrication of pump bearings (its actually slick) and keeping off rust - It cannot remove rust though, for that you need to acid wash the system. It also contains some silicates (needed in diesels) that is why those manufacturers have a packet of some fumed silica in their built in surge tanks to keep adding the required dose. Your average andaa omellete japanese car uses HOAT coolants with phosphated salts - they are quite picky on this - mostly it has to do with the plastics and metals in the unit. SO - please everyone who lives in Pakistan and reads this - do not run your car on plain water cooling system, if you do then dont complain that you are paying heavy for maintenance etc. You yourself are inflicting this pain. Use 50% coolant conc. mixed with distilled water only. Make sure the system is top notch. If your mechanic is so poor he cannot afford a drain tub and a gallon bottle, get your own drain tub and bottle, if he has to drain coolant - make sure he puts it back in the engine, Not let it trickle out onto the ground then proceed to fill with sea water.

Seen quite a few standby gennies in the US that are insanely big, Good Lord they scream into life to pass the 10 second test. oil is preheated and force injected first to prelube it then the petrol V8 engine starts to crank it. btw the coolant is preheated too, so technically the engine is at full operating temperature even switched off. a little example for everyone. Not the same engine but just a teaser. //youtu.be/6YGsHc2pA6Q no - it does not have or need VTEC, VVTi or any jazz - its raw brute power.

column2: nfssaad;3874395: OOOOOh so thats why theres a coolant preheater in the system.... i couldnt figure out the reason for it when studying the process and instrumentation diagrams. If you study some F1 engine specs or witness how its started up - it also requires preheated coolant. technically when cold an F1 engine is siezed - the clearances open up only when warm coolant is pumped through it - then hot oil is pressurefed in the ports and finally the engine started. The tolerances are insanely tight. anyway - on these big ladies you need to spend the MONIES to keep them happy, they are very picky on what they get. Consider yourself lucky you are not experiencing a detroit diesel 2 stroke, They leak so much oil all the time that if at any time its not leaking oil the first engineer hits the kill switch - because the engine has ACTUALLY RUN OUT OF OIL.

column2: people in Pakistan also forget that coolant also needs to be replaced following the manufacturer recommendation. e.g. toyota pink first change is about 200,000 kms - and then 100,000 kms thereon. same for suzuki long life etc. etc. - furthermore, most people buy the cheapest and low cost whatever coolant they can get their hands on, e.g. some people buy a 40% premix bottle because its 60% cost of the concentrate bottle - forgetting that they paid more for the premix.

column1: Hello, I was just going thru internet and came across car voltage stabilizer, it claims stable voltage for lights and all electrical utilities in a stock car and also claim to save fuel. how is it used and what exactly does it do?  i have a super fabulous alto 1000cc alhamdulilah, would want to know as i dont want high rpm's on idle mode so the brightness of lights accordingly fluctuate a little when accelerated on idle. is this the stabilizer usually solution for that?
column2: hash4u;4953833: Voltage Stabilizer And Grounding Cable Effect - Myth And Fact That is the most lol piece I have come across, what the reviewer forgot is ampacity of the battery and the charging system too. e.g. if your car is equipped with a piddly 30A alternator and you think that installing 8 halogen lamps in the front of your car is "business look" - then nothing (not even hazrat voltage stabilizer RA) can save you. If you want to solve your charging issues then look into investing money to upgrade the charging system and battery of your car. (for learning it - go look at some high end cars)

column1: Aoa, i have recently bought a 1990 Toyota Corona which has a 5a fe toyota 16 valve engine with automatic transmission(most probably its original),The car is very smooth and fun to drive but it is a gas guzzler and it returns 4-5km/liter only. i have got it inspected from 2 workshops and they have diagnosed that the car has 5a fe engine the ecu is of 4a fe and the Map sensor is of 7afe ,the mechanic has suggested me to install 4afe map sensor and replace injectors with 660cc or 1000cc injectors :Now i am really confused because all of this does not makes any sense.please suggest that what should i do now?
column2: If you have a 4AFE ECU driving a 5AFE engine - I dont quite beleive it because the 4AFE ECU actually requires a cam sensor to synchronize the injectors and firing pulses. If the G- signal (cam sensor) is missing the ECU makes the engine work as "batch fire" meaning all injectors fire at the same time. Please take a picture of your distributor and post it here, the 5AFE distributor should have 2 wiring plugs, one with 2 wires (coil) and one with 4 wires - 2 are for the crank sensor inside the distributor and 2 are for the ignitor inside it. the 4AFE distributor should have a 2 wire plug for the coil and a 6 wire plug into the distributor. Also please indicate if the check lamp is connected and works. your mechanic is a bit ill informed on his diagnosis, the MAP sensor on the 4,5 and 7AFE are the same output - even mazda and suzuki map sensors will work. The injectors need not be changed as the problem is elsewhere - first get the original stuff corrected - then we can go into other tuning like fuel trim testing.

column2: The orange sticker ecu for AT will work on manual box. But the black sticker ecu is ECT and drives the transmission solenoids, if you install that in a manual car, it will be stuck in limp mode and suck petrol lile crazy.

column1: Dear Friends, I own Honda Vezel and Alhamdullilah it has done 40,000 km. I want to change my transmission oil so i contact honda dealer ship in ISB I-10 Honda Classic and LHR Honda Point. Both dealer ship very confidently mentioned that the replacement oil is "Honda CVTF, white bottle" and its available with them. For some reason i was not convinced so i decided to contact honda japan and below was their response (thank god i did not believe the local dealer ship other wise i would have possibly destroyed my tranny). Any forum member can guide where to get this ?Honda genuine ULTRA ATF-DW1? since its not available with honda dealership in pakistan and most people have not heard of it. > On 01-Mar-2016, at 4:05 PM, [Honda] Customer Relations Automobile <customersvc4@spirit.honda.co.jp> wrote: > > Japan, March 1, 2016 > > Dear Mr. Haseeb Ali > > Thank you for contacting Honda Motor Co., Ltd. > > Referring to the recommended transmission fluid for Vezel Hybrid, we always recommend to use ?Honda genuine ULTRA ATF-DW1?. We confirmed that the attached picture is CVT fluid which is not suitable for Vezel Hybrid. Vezel Hybrid is sold only for Japanese market and 7-speed dual clutch transmission (DCT) is mounted, which is different from continuously variable transmission (CVT). For this reason, we can assume that the local dealership may not recognized that CVT fluid should not be used for DCT model. > > As this is imported model, we cannot advise where to get the fluid or how. > Hopefully you would understand. > > Thank you. > > Sincerely > > Customer Service > Honda Motor Co., Ltd.
column2: Docjunaid;5032299: Thank God [emoji1303][emoji56] instead of throwing around pet names for parts to customer service, just ask the manufacturer for the "part number" or "material number" for the item you need. Its classified under service parts. This makes it very easy to identify replacements.

column2: highroller;5081602: Is there any transmission coolant? How to check heat heat exchanger? Local ustaad having couple of vezels parked for repairs gave his verdict to replace tran, period ! Sent from my iPhone using Tapatalk every automatic transmission has a heat exchanger, in small econo production cars like your vezel its built into the return tank of the radiator or there is a cooler sandwich on the transmission, both serve same purpose. If your trans is suffering consistent overheat then it maybe a mechanical problem inside and the only solution is to "replace" it as Honda do not sell its internal parts as spares.

column2: deltree;5081635: It's a transmission that I feel is probably even one step better than CVT's, the age of his car is considerably new and I don't think the tranny is going to give up that soon. Maybe all he needs is a oil change and he can get back to us with the results. The biggest problem for him will have to be flushing and topping it up at the right quantity! Dont assume everything is hunky dory in a brand new car, I have had Nissan USA change my 6 month old 10,000 miles driven CVT unit because it was misbehaving. Some new 8 and 9 speed units in chryslers etc. are reported to be bad from the start, they are changed out under warranty, they are so finicky that they wont even select Park unless you program its brain (TCU) which is inside the gearbox itself. deltree;5081638: Local ustaad chutu hai, took me 180k km and a 10 year old car full throttle racing run back to lahore from islamabad in my cvt to break it's belt. Itni nazuk nai transmission k shehar mein kharab hojayay. The heat in lahore is bad agreed but not this bad. I suggest you meet with syncview and troubleshoot this problem he doesn't just look at the error codes he also looks at all the other stuff that can be tested with a tranny. Mitsubishi make a reasonable CVT unit and it works pretty much the same as a JATCO unit, The Honda DCT is pretty but it is sometimes quite goofy and can cause rapid mechanical failure. My local Honda dealer (showroom) has changed about 20 units but they never tear it down, they are shipped in crates back to Honda headquarters for analysis.

column1: Aoa, I know a thing or two about mobile phones and I am planning to buy a new car. Also I am against insurance (religious reasons).. so one of the ways to secure my car is through car tracking... Now normal trackers are expensive.. (Any cheap or used ones available? pls tell) I was thinking, if I can hide a mobile phone with built in GPS (e.g. nokia n82 etc etc which comes for around 12k max (used)) in car (need good ideas for hiding place), and connect it to mobile car charger and car battery (mobiles battery will serve as backup), i can practically make it a tracking device.. i know of software that can msg me back the exact gps location, or if i subsribe to internet trhough sim,it can update its location live... so i can track it in real time using the internet (e.g. google maps, latitute etc).. I can get all the necessary software (garmin etc etc).. Has anyone tried this before? The problems that I can face are: a) How to connect car battery to mobile phone (probably a work for the electrician). b) Good and safe hiding place for mobile phone c) if the theif or whoever takes battery out.. mobile battery will only last for 3 hours max with GPS on.. after tht it will switch off. How can I switch it back on without touching it physically? d) How can I remotely control the car? lock it etc.. I can install the cheap china remote controls.. but how can i conect it to mobile phone? Suggestions, practical advice etc etc required.. thanks
column2: built in GPS antenna in cell phones wont work if the cell phone is not exposed to the satellites. you would need to do some thing after taking out its GPS antenna and that would be risky. any way wish you all the best and looking forward to see some thing from your side. waise I am /electrical/electronics engineer and have worked on many these kind of projects

column1: Hello Guys, It All started when i bought my New car Toyota Corolla GLI 2013 Bluish silver and went to Toyata motors for my first regular maintenance. At the Parts shop i saw many car waxes which were really very expensive and the Brand was mothers. I had only seen formula one and cosmic polish and i always thought the world of polish ended here lol. So my first good wax that i purchased was -Mothers Reflections wax and top coat -Mothers wash and wax -Mothers Glass cleaner -Sonax vanilla (Still miss and recommend that). -Mothers Glass cleaner   I kept on using the wax on my car until the bottles were empty. column2: AusI;4982464: Try some swisswax onyx I have SV, its just not the onyx. Something a little up the order. BUT, comparing the prices, the Souveran has to be the smoothest wax in the $50-$100 range. Waisay if maybe you could carry a small wax pot when you visit Pakistan, I have one on my wish list which I would love to own. makhdoom123;4982636: Yes Mustafa Bhai , i just noticed it yesterday but didn't had the energy to edit the post that time in shaa Allah will use the wax soon and share the result its nice to know you are a detailing enthusiast too ! Haha, I wash my car in the rain. That should tell you a whole lot about my obsession. What you need now is a sealant. So before you get anything else, save up for that. A sealant and wax combo will do more wonders than what a wax can do alone. Also note, I've used a ton of wax's and like I said, I love the souveran. However, note that its not a durable wax. Its more of a show wax. So expect a maximum of 2 weeks of durability for a daily runner and 3-4 for a garaged weekend car. A sealant will do wonders so keep that in mind when you make your next detailing purchase. There a few that work better than others so don't get whats readily available on PW. There are those who have the good stuff with them but you need to poke em to sell em to you

column2: makhdoom123;4982868: haha thanks for the info Yes i thought of purchasing a sealant and yes this is a show car wax thats why i will top the car with 2 - 3 wax coats for maximum durability and as it is really easy to apply so applying after a week won't be a big problem actually i have thought of having the new car ceramic coated , so will i be needing a sealant then also ? after the ceramic coating ? i thought i would not need a sealant after ceramic coating thats why i did not opted for one. if you guide me through it then i will definately make better purchase choice next time the next purchases on my list will be black fire black ice wax(edited) for black car but its way too expensive but i will try it too In that case, I would thing the sealant would indeed hinder the capabilities of the c-coating. But I could be wrong though. I've bought the Blackfire crystal coating myself. They say the 15ml bottle covers three cars. I doubt that. I'm actually waiting for the current BF Wet Ice over Fire protection combo to diminish on the benz. Until then, I'll put up a thread on DW and AG and ask about the combos I can use over the CC. But since most people use a wax over a CC, I would assume a sealant may also work. I need to do some research myself. However, you can still use a sealant in the engine bay, headlights, glasses and tailights.

column2: Automotorsport_Lover;4983951: Hehe bro something went wrong here! You should not be waxing a coated car! Waxing it wont do much good... for a coated car what you should do is, clay it. And then maintain with a synthetic spray on sealant i.e. water based. Usually good coating have their own company recommended maintenance spray.. to be used after washing the car(Ideally after claying) as a top up for the coating. I would have recommended something like Carpro Hydro shampoo and its sealant. Coated cars dont need waxing, waxing reduces their water beading and self cleansing effect... any abrasives in the wax will also not be friendly for the coating. Coated cars need periodic Claying to remove any stuck contamination which is reducing water beading and self cleaning effect... Plus a topup for the coating The car hasn't been coated yet. Its something he plans on doing.

column2: Automotorsport_Lover;4986177: I know but he has invested in an expensive wax already! If he likes waxing.. he can give up the idea of coating. If he wants it coated, he can sell the wax(Must sell easy) and buy some purely synthetic stuff! Waxing a coated car would be somewhat similar to topping up with a 20w-50 Havoline oil, over a Mobil's 0w-30 fully synthetic engine oil! Lol.. The only problem is, I've seen a couple dozen people who wax their coated cars on detailing forum's. I don't remember if the wax's used were synthetic or carnauba. However, they there were mention's not to use sealants on top of coatings. I'm still trying to figure out whats best for a coated car but the claying suggestion is pretty much to the point. Claying + DS is what I think should keep the coating nice and clean. As for the wax, I'll buy that off OP if he decides to sell it

column1: I was driving around Murree and Nathiagali and observed the coolant temperature to be between 94 and 96C. I am using bluetooth OBDII transmitter to check temperatures. The app I was using shows the red (engine hot) arc around the range of 110 and 120C. I stopped the car since I couldn't hear the radiator fan running and checked. And in fact the radiator fan wasn't running. Is this normal? Are you aware of the temperature when the fan should start? In urban Lahore, I remains between 84 and 86C. Engine 1Kr Vitz 2016 model (KSP130)
column2: If temp is NOT rising further then its normal, all engines run hotter when driving uphill. My civic's fan turns on at 95C

column2: Radiator Fan of Vitz should turn on at 97C to 98C. Temperature upto 101C is normal in Vitz and specially when you are driving around hilly area as you said so.

column2: Yes it is normal, normally engine operating temp designed for hot zone is thermostat value open temp is 82C, fan trigger on at 93C according to service manual, but car imported from japan vits ,platz fan turn on temp is 97C may be it must be designed for colder areas, i have also verified from official yaris/vitz forum.I have platz with 1sz-fe engine. you can not modify easily ECU to fan trigger at 93C which is recommended for hot zone. One perfect solution i have done by program a micro controller chip , reading temp data from sensor, and trigger at 93c, and with AC fan on always. you should also for such solution if you located at hotter zone.

column2: ahsan1702;2216217: There is something in the guide I find misleading. The API rating comments are like "It is for 2004 and older automotive engines." "It is for 1996 and older automotive engine." Sorry but exactly whats the logic behind this ? Whereas these rating are all API revised and indicate the quality of the oil rather than the engine its meant for (Manufacturer usually advise the oil, usually a certain viscosity rating) ... but in no way can u say This rating is for older/newer engines. The guide seems to be suggesting that I shouldnt use a high rated SM/SL oil in my 87 GTti or Integra ... instead use 1996 and older ... obsolete oil ? i hope the people at ZIC don't mind me stepping in here... as engine designs change the requirements of the oils change, over time engines have started producing more power from smaller capacities, and they require different properties fromt the oils. the reason the API ratings change are so that the standards are raised/imporved over time. here is a current chart explainting the ratings:

column2: SKZIC;2247177: REMEMBER ONE THINK MAIN OIL'S PROPERTY ALONG WITH OTHER IS VISCOSITY INDEX THE HIGHER VISCOSITY INDEX THE BETTER THE OIL AND LOW VICOSITY INDEX MEAN LOW OIL QULAITY Not necessarily. A wide Viscosity Index means the use of VI improvers added to the base oil. These will degrade more quickly, leading to shearing down and change of the properties of the oil, some formulations more than others. More VI improvers do NOT mean it is a better oil just by themselves. It means just that: that the oil has a wide VI when new. Some of best oils have narrow VIs by design. The choice of the oil should be based on the base oil and the additive pack, and these have many more factors than just VI. One should choose the proper viscosity range based on the operating temperatures, the environment, and the use of the engine. However, having said that, what you are saying may be CORRECT for the oils that are available in Pakistan, so please ignore my comments and accept my apologies if they do not apply there.

column1: Hello! On Tuesday morning, when the driver started the car, it had been left on CNG overnight. As a result, it took a long time to start, and the starter was strained, as if the engine was running on the starter. Afterwards, the car got stuck or the battery's amperage went down. However, there was no way to start it on CNG. Eventually, it was push-started on petrol, and after running for about 1.5 km, it was switched to CNG and everything was fine. This incident occurred in Karachi, where the current temperature is reported to be 8-11 degrees Celsius. I'm wondering what could have happened to the CNG. Did it freeze in the cylinder or the lines? Or did something get jammed? Any ideas? It seems like the engine was trying to suck in the fuel, but there was nothing in the lines to start the engine. Maybe it froze. Any ideas? Thank you.
column2: I start my car after office 6 in the morning in isb. Its Minus temp at that time.My car is EFI, starts on petrol and switches on cng when i press on the gas peddle.The best milage i get from CNG is when i get it filled 6 in the morning.The gas is cooler/full pressure, no cues at filling station.

column1: I installed aftermarket Chrome Door Handle Covers about 3years back on my car with the help of 3M tape. Now those covers are worn out and become pale & their chrome color faded. Kindly share how to remove them at home. I have watched youtube videos, they used heat gun, i don't have heat gun. Share some trick and tips to remove them easily. Thanks.
column2: Best to borrow a hair dryer from the lady of the house when she needs it. More exciting!

column1: I installed aftermarket Chrome Door Handle Covers about 3years back on my car with the help of 3M tape. Now those covers are worn out and become pale & their chrome color faded. Kindly share how to remove them at home. I have watched youtube videos, they used heat gun, i don't have heat gun. Share some trick and tips to remove them easily. Thanks.
column2: Get a hair dryer, use it on low heat (1) and go over the handle. Make sure you don't hold it in one spot for too long. Get some dental floss and slowly cut across the tape by going up/down. Cut a long piece so you can wrap it around your fingers to get a good grip Once the cover is off, just got some ipa and gently wipe away the tape residue

column1: I installed aftermarket Chrome Door Handle Covers about 3years back on my car with the help of 3M tape. Now those covers are worn out and become pale & their chrome color faded. Kindly share how to remove them at home. I have watched youtube videos, they used heat gun, i don't have heat gun. Share some trick and tips to remove them easily. Thanks.
column2: Never a good idea to remove it by force. These flimsy chrome parts crack when you bend them. Doing so will probably result in scratching the paint surface under with those jagged edges. You'll end up with more to worry about than when you started

column1: I installed aftermarket Chrome Door Handle Covers about 3years back on my car with the help of 3M tape. Now those covers are worn out and become pale & their chrome color faded. column2: You forcefully pull on that chrome, you're gonna break it if its become brittle and that tape under it has hardened. That sharp edge will push into the paint while you lift up on the other end, scratching it. Its not about throwing the chrome strip away, it's about removing it the right way I'm sure the topic of removing emblems and chrome parts has been covered hundreds of times on the Detailing forums here. You are an active member on there so suggesting someone to remove it by force isn't great advice Slow and steady wins the race when it comes to detailing

column1: Assalam-o-Alaikum everyone, My car had an accident last week and there was some damage done. Thanks to Almighty Allah no one was hurt. After the accident I was in the mood of selling it but my denter assured me that the damage is not much and can be easily repaired so now its being repaired. It is not a big project or restoration. The main purpose of starting this thread is to get guidance from those people who have kept this car or have done some work on it. I will try to update this thread on a regular basis. Your guidance will be highly appreciated.
column2: before anything goes on the car, paint the front exposed crossmember gallery with thick black enamel paint - it will prevent rusting internally. Then get welder bhai to weld the sheet over it. Secondly paint the headlamp surrounds and lock support bracket matte black. Buy a can of underbody butyl based paint and spray over the repaired areas in the wheel well. It would be a job far better than Pakistan suzuki tried. It would be a very nice time to plate the bolts and nuts that you removed, They would look very pretty. Get a can of turtle presoak and wash up the whole engine/tranny

If one doesn't expect to face an accident at all, then he should drive in his drawing room. The damage on your car isn't much and it would be back in shape. Best of luck for the project.

column1: which is the best injector cleaner available inthe market to add in the petrol tank to clean the injectors ?
column2: To effectively clean built-up sludge in fuel injectors, it's essential to use methods like sonic cleaning rather than relying solely on carburetor cleaner, especially for finer sludge embedded in the injector pintle. Liqui Moly's injector cleaner is recommended for maintenance. For services in Karachi, Welcome Autos in Soldier Bazar and mechanics near the Touchme roundabout in the Sharfabad area are suggested. Regular injector servicing, approximately every 25,000 km, is advised due to the low-grade petrol commonly found in Pakistan, as injector cleaner may not suffice to address the issue entirely.

column1: Hello everyone. If any one can suggest me from where to source engine and body parts for Nissan Cedric 1988 in Karachi Reference picture of car attached
column2: For troubleshooting a VG (V-6) engine, it's crucial to seek expertise from reliable specialists like Jameel Autos for compression tests and adherence to oil viscosity standards. Climate control and electrical issues can be addressed by experienced electricians familiar with older vehicle models. Regarding bodywork, Alfa Motors next to the bridge after Landi-Kotal, operated by Mehboob or his son Masood, offers purpose-built facilities for thorough inspections and negotiations on pricing and timelines. Afzaal, mentioned previously, is recommended for suspension and steering repairs despite potential distance constraints. Special thanks to @hanifbhatti for assistance, emphasizing deep cleansing of the engine bay with a lemon Max solution and methodical restoration guided by the vehicle's service manual. Notably, the engine in the shared pictures appears to be a VG30S, and for personalized assistance, initiating a new thread with detailed vehicle history, pictures, and location is advised. Additionally, a Cedric with a modified front grille was spotted in the Lines Area close to Afzaal Suspension workshop at 4 pm.

column1: Hi all, i have this problem for last many days with my Cultus (02) Its engine stops while i come to low speed like 30/mph. As i approach a speed breaker and apply brake and after crossing the speed breaker when i push the race paddle, i found the engine is off. And sometimes it also do knocking while on low speed. Any solution to solve this problem plz ?
column2: For troubleshooting engine issues, several suggestions have been offered. @tiptop was advised to check vacuum tubes connected to the distributor or visit Obama Car Care Centre in Tipu Block, Garden Town, Lahore, for diagnostics. If the car is carburetor-equipped, the fuel cut solenoid might be a potential culprit. Proper tuning, along with checking plugs, plug wires, and filters (air and fuel), was recommended, with guidance on workshops contingent on location. Additionally, checking the car's alternator/generator was advised. Despite changing plugs and the fuel filter, and cleaning the carburetor with a spray can, one user reported no improvement in their car's performance. Notably, the vehicle runs on petrol and is a 2002 model. A user found resolution at Mini Motor Workshop in Gulberg, where during tuning, a mechanic discovered a damaged electric wire under the carburetor, which, when repaired by an electrician, resolved the issue for a minimal cost of Rs. 75. Tuning charges of Rs. 600 plus 16% government tax were also incurred. Appreciation was extended to all for their suggestions.

column1: Which is better for Baleno power steering: Zic Dexron 3 ATF or Kixx Dexron 3 ATF?
column2: Dexron II, III, and VI are all acceptable for power steering systems, irrespective of brand, with some cases even seeing the use of aviation oils. Dexron III and 3H, although different formulations, became obsolete in the mid-2000s when General Motors phased them out in favor of Dexron VI, now the standard. Dexron 3 may still be available with variations in production quality, whereas Dexron VI has become the norm, and in markets like the USA, Dexron 3 is no longer sold, prompting alternatives like Dex/Merc. Despite differences, Dexron 3, 3H, and 6 remain compatible choices for power steering systems. As long as the product label indicates suitability for power steering use, it should be safe to use, with Dexron 3H being a viable option if Dexron 3 is recommended in the vehicle manual.

column1: Anyone know from where I can buy CASKA navigation system for NEW CIVIC, other then from company, as they charge a lot.. Thanks alot
column2: The issues with the current navigation system seem to be escalating, prompting suggestions to switch to an aftermarket unit, possibly by selling the current one through various channels. While aftermarket units can integrate with steering controls and offer trip data, the integration with car controls and ECU, along with concerns about offline navigation availability, remain challenges. Several popular aftermarket units can be paired with steering controls using a steering wheel module. However, complaints about performance issues persist, including poor touch response, delayed booting, GPS failures, speaker humming, and CD ejection problems. Users have reported dissatisfaction despite multiple replacements, citing issues such as delayed parking camera activation, poor camera resolution, and lack of clear parking indicators. Tracking World has introduced an upgraded iGO3 system to address some complaints, but users still face challenges with video feed quality and system reliability. While warranty claims for upgrades are possible, significant improvements may not be guaranteed. The potential for tablet-based systems as future alternatives is mentioned, although concerns about product quality and customer satisfaction persist. Some users have experienced intermittent loss of multimedia control through steering buttons, further adding to frustrations. One user seeks assistance with restoring default settings on their Honda Civic 2015 iGO3 navigation system, highlighting password retrieval challenges.

column1: Why some cars of older models shake left n right from front i mean feeling like swing left n right from its hood Mod: Please create one thread if you have a query .
column2: Various factors can contribute to a car shaking while driving, including poor aerodynamics, unbalanced tires, suspension issues, worn-out tires, and uneven brake rotors. Brake rotors, also known as brake discs, can cause shaking if worn, but diagnosis without a mechanic can be challenging. Signs of worn rotors include pulsating brakes or noise when braking. Repair or replacement costs vary depending on the extent of damage and the car model. Suspension bushes, tie rod ends, shock struts, and braces can also affect stability and should be checked for wear. "Wander," or side-to-side drifting while driving straight, may indicate issues with these components or low tire pressure. It's essential to address these issues promptly to ensure safe driving conditions.

column1: I'm looking for engine oil dye products online but couldn't find a single local website offering any. Basically, an engine oil dye is a liquid that you can add to your engine and then use a UV light to detect leakage points. It's a simple DIY method for tracing any seepages. It's insane we're so backward that these products aren't even available here and mechanics resort to removing your entire friggin' engine just to detect one minor seepage. Does anyone have any info about finding products like these anywhere in this god forsaken country? Would really appreciate any leads. Thanks!
column2: Tracing coolant leaks can be challenging, but various methods exist for detection. Genuine coolants from Toyota, Honda, and Suzuki create distinct traces resembling colorful rock formations, while Havoline coolant may leave black oil stains that wash away with water. Talcum powder, a cost-effective solution, can help detect oil leaks when applied and inspected under strong light. In the USA, dye kits are available for identifying AC and hydraulic leaks. While visual inspection, experience, and common sense are invaluable, it's essential to remain vigilant, considering that seals may degrade over time, potentially leading to leaks. In the used car business, honesty is paramount; deceptive practices may yield short-term gains but compromise long-term success. Establishing trust by providing accurate car assessments, transparent documentation, and reliable repair estimates can attract potential buyers. Consider leveraging workshops for estimates and fostering credibility through platforms like YouTube, where documenting refurbishment processes can garner interest and build a loyal audience.

column1: Hello everyone, My tension is increasing day by day with Santro. I have a black Santro 2007. Two days ago I realise the engine oil level decreasing. Further black smoke is present in the exhaust. Long story in short I changed the top sensor ( that connected with the throttle body) the fuel average is now pretty good in the city ( 10/L ) as compare to the previous ( 6/L). But light black smoke is still present and I believe the average should be better after fixing the black smoke problem. One mechanic said to change the map sensor but the engine check was not present then why? The second issue is burning engine oil but no blue smoke is present at all. The mechanic said to change the ring, valve, seals. gas kit that will cost me 20k with labor. Please suggest to me how to fix that problem. I am new to the automotive industry. Evey help will be appreciated. Thanks
column2: when there's black smoke and engine's burning oil .. it means the old fella needs a break : ( valve seals are leaking causing the oil to leak in combustion chamber and burn in engine and emitting black smoke ... so i am afraid the mechanic is right.. time to spend money : (

column1: On June 11 2021 I purchased MG ZS from MG Motors Pakistan (78-D/1,8th Floor, Aashiyana Shopping Centre, Main Blvd Gulberg, Town, Lahore, 54000) After taking my car home, I took it for a drive at night. It was at that moment I noticed scratches on my front Windshield mirror, I thought they were just normal marks on the glass and I needed to clean it. After a few days, I realized that these were permanent scratches on my front windshield only. To this day I have visited MG Motors Pakistan multiple times, both branches here in Lahore but they have failed to provide a solution for this major issue. Kindly check all parts of the car before purchasing, especially cars from manufacturers like MG, etc.
column2: The car was probably struck on port for long time and got covered with lime/cement dust and non professional buffing resulted in this.

column1: Salam everyone! I hope everyone's doing well, my Mazda RX8 is finally home & now? It was finally time for myself to get another car to play with, after throwing in money for those huge bills on the RX8, I was looking to get an affordable, yet a different project, I honestly was thinking of getting a Suzuki Swift MK1 (2 door) for myself but as I was going through my routine pakwheels surfing, I came across an ad that blew my mind & I actually made a blind deal, here she is! The Honda Accord 3G itself, this is my new toy that I'll be playing with & since people are not really into reading threads here now, I'll be posting updates on my YouTube channel as well, to which you all can subscribe & stay updated to the project there, as well as here. Avoid the lousy picture quality, these were shot at 6am on my iPhone. This car is a treat for me for the price that I've got it for, I'll be following the rule of one project at a time especially after my RX8 because projects are a pain in the ass & a drill to your pockets, but I'll be starting this car from scratch as well so it will definitely require time but it'll be worth the wait, I promise! SUBSCRIBE TO THE CHANNEL HERE! www.youtube.com/abdulmunimqadri31 SPECS Honda D17A motor linked to the original PROSMATEC tranny . Power Windows (Mentioning because they weren't standard) . A decent set of 15" rims with a decent amount of tread left on the tyres . Sunroof AND IT WORKS TOO Links to my previous projects Bringing my RX back to life - Mazda RX8 1JZ VVTi Mazda Asalam o alaikum everyone. Months ago, I got my hands on a Mazda RX8 2005. The car was swapped with a 2JZGTE by the previous owner but I bought the car without any engine under the hood. It was parked in a plot for months and the owner wasn't willing to sell it but after 2 months of procrastination, I finally got my hands on it. The car was and still is in a pretty bad condition, the last owner had the car showered in matte blue, then matte pink and currently the car is showered in matte yellow …  The Budget Modification - Honda Civic EK Honda Asalam o alaikum Pakwheelers, back in 2013 I bought a Honda Civic EK 2000 for a project but since I had no idea about how expensive and time consuming a project car could get, I could never save up the proper amount to modify it as per my needs. I was a broke college student back then so all I could modify in it were the headlights, license plates and I got it converted to 5 studs from 4 because I wanted to get a specific set of rims on it and sadly, they weren't available in 4 studs ever. My RX…  abdulmunimqadri: Remember her? We got her a set of new shoes today. 13" [image]
column2: It seems that your car's rear struts may not be original, potentially leading to rust issues, particularly around the tail light mountings, which could benefit from sealing with butyl ribbon for a durable watertight seal. The absence of sunroof drain spouts and potential clogging can result in water ingress, causing various problems like bad smells, carpet damage, and rusting of floors and side panels, with accessing the sunroof drain tube potentially requiring dashboard removal. Ensuring thorough rust removal and applying cavity wax is crucial, especially around the lower pinch weld area, to prevent water intrusion. Consider sourcing replacement tail lamps carefully, as USDM lamps may offer a different aesthetic compared to the original double-glazed ones. Additionally, investing in cavity wax and learning its application, such as a homemade mixture of turpentine or odorless spirits, beeswax or paraffin wax, and oil, could protect against future rust. Accessing trapped cavities for wax application typically involves removing rubber bungs from various parts of the car, while other users may have alternative recipes for cavity wax.

column1: Hi all, After my brief first play with an Android Auto based ICE unit (more on that later), I decided to upgrade my car to the experience as well. Here is the stereo from my wife's VW Polo, which has been my inspiration to upgrade my own head unit. The Inspiration: VW RCD-510 . Switched Off .  . Waiting for Mobile Connection .  . Android Auto Home Screen .  . The Very Familiar Google Maps .  . Phone (contacts also get transfered) .  . Night Time driving with Google Maps . I will be sharing my experiences of my own head unit in particular and Android Auto in this thread.
column2: bym007: My car in particular had a lot of electronic integrations with the factory Navigation unit/screen, which was confusing to a lot of installers. I couldn't find a single post online of people who had done it successfully on this particular car. Despite, all of these difficulties, the first improvement on my new car was going to improve on that hideous looking outdated navigation system. .  . I have used the infotainment system on the little VW Polo that my wife drives. It does beautiful Android Auto and Apple Car Play, which offer far superior navigation experience in my opinion. So I started looking into the current options. I needed a head unit which would replace the factory stereo, features Android Auto for me and hopefully improve sound stage as well the car interior. So after much deliberations, I settled on a Kenwood Double DIN unit. The Kenwood DDX9017DABS  . The unit itself is a 7 inch touch screen, which does digital radio, simultaneous Bluetooth connectivity with 2 devices, 2 video camera inputs (front and rear), 5 channel gold plated output ports, 2 USB ports (can be used for USB memory sticks, connecting and charging phones), out of box steering wheels connectivity for most of the Japanese + Koreans cars. Plus Kenwood is getting a lot of recommendations from the installers as well, due to ease of install, cost vs features etc.

column1: Hi guys, I am looking to make my own car but I need help with fabricating the fiberglass body for my car. Does anyone know of a good mechanic/fabricator of fiberglass bodies in ISB. I did check with one person and he quoted 200,000 to 250,000 rupees which I think might be TOOO much. so I just want to check with other known fabricators in ISB. Please advice guys.
column2: If you intrested in diy then use this instruction. other wise use this information for cast your project enjoy;) Things You'll Need: Step 1 Sketch your design. Without getting your layout on paper first, your body kit is almost guaranteed to look terrible. This is the place to let your artistic side run wild. Get an idea of what you want by looking at existing body kits, and put your favorite aspects of each one into your design. li value=0" Step 2 After removing the existing bumpers and trim on your car, cut lengths of high-density foam into the approximate sizes of each part. Using blocks of scrap foam, raise each part until it is resting where it will eventually be located. For the time being, you can secure it in place using some duct tape, if you wish. /li li value=0" Step 3 Following your drawings precisely, use a heavy marker to draw out the details directly onto the foam. Make note of the depth each indentation or cutout should be carved to. Draw half of each body panel first, then carefully measure and copy each design detail to the opposite side to ensure perfect symmetry. All it takes is one mistake to completely ruin the project, so triple check your measurements before work begins. /li li value=0" Step 4 Begin carving your design into the foam, being careful not to damage the parts during this process. When you lay the fiberglass on top of the foam, remember that each of the parts will be slightly thicker, so compensate for that during your cutting. Make sure every single cut lines up with the marks you drew in the previous step. If you make a mistake, you don't have to scrap the entire piece, just cut out the ruined section, glue another block of foam in its place, and resume work. /li li value=0" Step 5 Remove the finished foam pieces, and cover them tightly in aluminum foil to prevent the resin from sticking. You may want to use an adhesive spray to hold the aluminum into place on the foam. Next, spray the outside of the foil with a non-stick cooking spray, which will act as a mold release when you remove the fiberglass. The parts are now fully prepped. /li li value=0" Step 6 Begin laying your fiberglass. Start off with just one sheet soaked in resin, and lay it across the outside of the mold. Use a roller to push out any air bubbles, and tuck the fiberglass sheet around the edges and contours of your body kit. Allow the single sheet of fiberglass to completely dry, then gently pull it off of the foam mold. Be careful, as the single fiberglass sheet will be very fragile. /li li value=0" Step 7 Reinforce the inside of the parts using multiple layers of thick fiberglass matting. Smooth out the air bubbles on each layer, and allow adequate dry time before moving on to the next layer of glass. By placing this matting on the inside of the parts, you can add as much thickness as desired without changing the outside shape of the finished product. /li li value=0" Step 8 Sand the outside of the parts using a rough grit sandpaper, to smooth out any bumpy areas or lumps. A metal file can be used around the openings to ensure clean edges. Use a proper breathing respirator, thick gloves, and long sleeves to protect yourself. Once the finished look is achieved, blast the parts with an air comperassor to remove sanding dust, then wipe the entire surface down to remove the last bits. Now is a great time to do a test fit to make sure the parts line up to your satisfaction. /li li value=0" Step 9 Cover the entire outside surface with Bondo to create a smooth, finished texture much like a worked piece of auto body sheet metal. Multiple layers may be necessary to thoroughly cover the surface. After letting it cure, sand the Bondo to a flat surface, but don't leave it perfectly smooth. You want to finish with a somewhat rough sandpaper to make sure the paint sticks. Wipe the finished product with isopropyl alcohol to prep it for the next step. /li li value=0" Step 10 Prime the parts for paint. Any commercial automotive primer in a spray can will work fine. Use long, sweeping motions to cover the entire surface. Start spraying the can before it hits the surface, and do not stop spraying until you have completed the sweep, and have cleared the surface on the other side. This ensures uninterrupted coverage. Two coats of primer is plenty, and it only needs to dry 5 to 10 minutes between coats. Let the final coat cure for a couple of hours before moving on to paint. /li li value=0" Step 11 Paint your body kit. Use the same, long sweeping motions to completely cover the surface. Use multiple coats of very light paint, as opposed to thicker coats. Same with the primer, let it cure for 5 to 10 minutes between coats, then move on to the next one. It may take 10 or more coats to thoroughly cover the surface. When done, top it off with 2 coats of clear coat to protect the finish. /li li value=0" Step 12 Mount the body kit to your car. You can use the same mounting system that the original bumpers and trim pieces used, though depending on your car, you may have to craft some custom brackets to do so. Double-check clearances to make sure the panels are tight and everything looks like a good fit. /li

column1: From where i can purchase a true distilled water as locally available distilled water is not actually a distilled!! Is there a way from where one can make true distilled water at home? some people says AC condensed water is a good alternate for a battery water, is it true?
column2: SG is simple school physics, its the weight of the liquid of same volume compared to a standard which is water meaning 1 litre of water = 1000 grams (metric standard) means SG = 1.000 battery electrolyte of 1.270 SG means that 1 litre volume of it should weigh 1270 grams. When I made electrolyte for batteries I checked with my cheapa$$ hydrometer first then a digital scales too - you can ask your freindly parchoon ki dukaan for this or buy a small sized digital scale.

column1: HI i recently sold my margalla and purchased a 88 anda charade which has 1.0 diesel turbo engine, which i am planing to change in next couple of days.i am a bit confused in two diffrent engine.one is 4EFE and other is 1NZFE. the scene is that i am getting both the engines in RWP/ISB. 4EFE is very commonly been swaped in charade and other cars so the prices are a bit higher for 4EFE secondly its a bit difficult to find a clean and a rarely used engine because of thier discontinuation in 2000 where as i am getting a very good deal on 1nzfe.i am getting 1NZFE in low price then 4EFE and also got around 15 engines to chose from.also its not the local 1nzfe. its a japenese imported engine .its a 1500 cc VVTI DOHC EFi.(the one which comes in COROLLA X AND 2009 COROLLA) now what i am confused about is that weather 1NZFE would fit in charade 88 anda.i dont mind minor alteration.and has any one tried it. personally i want to go for 1NZFE bz i am getting a 1600 cc dohc VVTI engine for a chaper price then a 1300 cc dohc engine so plz guys help me out.its urgent thanx
column2: @azicoll bro its all yr call...4efe comes in 1300cc catagory and 1nzfe in 1500cc its only 10hp diffference between them.... u r getting very low price engine....go for it..in markit u wont get it less then 50k 1nzfe is new engine with tech ..so will recomand u this if willing to keep it NA BTW what else engine yr friend got in that container any 4efte

column2: Well Well Well...! 1NZ-Fe And 4EFE....!! I Would Say..Ummmm......1NZ For Sure....!! New Tech...VVT-i...More Power....Same Weight As 4EFE Due To Aluminum Designed ....!! Just Need More Space But Still Manage To Come In ANDA...! All You Need To Work Out Is On Electronics Of 1NZ...If You Can Get Its Wiring Gone....Just Go For It...Its One Awesome Machine....!! Other Than That...4EFE Is Also Very Good But Since Its Getting Swapped In So Many Cars Likely In Corolla's /Starlet Due To Its Bolt-on Ability..Its Hot Item In Market.....Other Than That... 5AFE Can Also Be One To Be Swapped.....But 1NZ Is Surely A New Gen Engine And Is One Step Ahead Of Both Of Them....Just Make Sure You Manage To Run It All Correct...!! Regards

column2: Well The Basics Of EFi Engines Is All Same....! It Got Almost Same Sensors As 4EFE Gets There Are Major Difference In Actual Design And Tech Of Both 4EFE Is Having MEchanical Distributor Type IGN Whereas 1NZ All Runs On DLI's(Coil Packs) Thats The Major Difference.... 4EFE Does'nt Have Anything Regarding Cam profile....1NZ Got VVT-i Which Is Another Major Difference..... It Just Need Lil More Space Than 4EFE...Other Than That....Its One Amazing Thing....!!Thats To Be Sure That Engine Spares Are Somehow Expensive Compared To 4EFE But Regular Maintaince Things Does'nt Need Much Of It...!! Just Take Care Of Them And They Run Like CHAMPs....!

column1: HI i recently sold my margalla and purchased a 88 anda charade which has 1.0 diesel turbo engine, which i am planing to change in next couple of days.i am a bit confused in two diffrent engine.one is 4EFE and other is 1NZFE. the scene is that i am getting both the engines in RWP/ISB. 4EFE is very commonly been swaped in charade and other cars so the prices are a bit higher for 4EFE secondly its a bit difficult to find a clean and a rarely used engine because of thier discontinuation in 2000 where as i am getting a very good deal on 1nzfe.i am getting 1NZFE in low price then 4EFE and also got around 15 engines to chose from.also its not the local 1nzfe. its a japenese imported engine .its a 1500 cc VVTI DOHC EFi.(the one which comes in COROLLA X AND 2009 COROLLA) now what i am confused about is that weather 1NZFE would fit in charade 88 anda.i dont mind minor alteration.and has any one tried it. personally i want to go for 1NZFE bz i am getting a 1600 cc dohc VVTI engine for a chaper price then a 1300 cc dohc engine so plz guys help me out.its urgent thanx
column2: Precautions....!! Well There Are Some Letme Mention!! When Old Engine Is Out And BAY Is Clean......Just Look For Things Inside BAY 1st Which Need Replacement As Its Most Easy Job To Do At A Time.. Letme Mention Steering Rack....Brake Booster...... Engine Bay PAINT(If Its Rusted And BADly need Paint) 1.Check For Steering Rack...If Power Check For Leaks And Worned Boots And Shaft.....Brake Booster...If You Fell Your Old Booster Is Not Good Enough....Just Replace It Now..As Its 15min Job Now To Fit.....!! After Engine Is Inn Once...Its Hardest Part To Change Them..Minutes Converts Into Hours...Due To lack Of Working Place ...Keep That In Mind...Its My Personal EXperience... 2.Get Mounts Done From Proper Place....Who's Master In Doing..And Well Known....All Can Make Mounts But Expert Knows The Proper Way To Align Engines.....If Mounts Are Not Done Welll...Axles Issues Can Exist Later Or Vibration Issues In Car....So Look Also For This....!! 3.Same Goes With Wiring....Choose Best Among Town And Also Try Guessing That He's Well Known Enough For JOB's......!! NITTO ELECTRICIANS Are Just Not Enough For This Job...Ur ECM Is Always On Risk In Their Hands....!! So Be Careful....!! 4.Check For Wheel Bearings And Brake Dics(Front) Drums (Rear) And Replace Them Now...While Opening Hubs..Check For Wheel Bearings Too And If Sounding....Also Replace Wheel Bearings....Put New PADS And If Possible Use Some Bigger Discs Available A/c To Spec Of Car Since You Are Going To Put Heavy And More Fast Thing..So Brakes Must Be Perfect....!! 5.A/c To Engine Weight You Need Heavy Front Shocks Too....Diesel Model Shocks Can Do Job As They Are Heavy Enough For Weighty Engines.....If Bought Any Shock From 2nd Hand Market..Just Don't Put Them As They Came.....Remove Springs And Check Either Shock Is In working Condition ..Not Leaking..Or Weak Enough.....!! Checking Will Save Opening Shocks Again And Again In Future....!! 6.Radiator Must Be Big Enough To Cool Down The Engine....Dual Barrel Radiator Is Recommended...!! Do It Once...Swap Dual Barrel Radiator From Any TOYOTA Which Can Fit Or Diesel Models Once...!! 7.Properly Grease Axles And Confirm Axles Are Not Worned....Use Axle GREASE Instead Of Local Or CRAP Grease....It Comes In Tube...Specially For Axles ..One Tube Fills Once...Its JApanese I Think Use It..!! 8..Watever You Swap....Check For Its Service Manual On WEB And Get Oil Specification Of Gearbox Oil And Engine Oil From There...... Using Wrong Oils In Gearbox Can Cause Damage To Synchronizers...So Confirm And Use Correct One....!! 9...Swapping Fuel Pump Inside Fuel Tank Needs Opening Of Tank And Soo....Remember To Get A Bowl Type Square Box Built 1st And Place It Inside Fuel Tank 1st And Swap Pump Base In That Bowl....!! If You Don't...You Will Face Fuel Starvation Issue Later....And Always Use Intank Fuel Pump....Don't Go For Inline (External) Fuel Pumps As They Just Are Easy To Install But Quiet dangerous And Risky As They Get leak......So Make Complete Intank Fuel Pump Setup along With Return Line....!! 10...Swapping Bigger Engines 1NZ-FE/4A-5A-7AFE/4EFE Would Need Bigger Diameter Exhaust Pipe Since A/c To Power Need.....Get Atleast (1 3/4") (45mm) Piping Done From Manifold Till Tail In Order To Make Engine Release Exhaust Easily...!! Well Thats All I Remember Now And Its Enough For A Successful Swap.....!! Any Thing You Don't Understand...Do Ask For it.. Regards Farrukh(SER_GTR)

Petroleum Jelly ?

column2: NiGhTShAdE;4483778: I think you are refering to Conductive Grease....it is used on electric terminals, connectors and joints to prevent corrosion.... Di-electric material is an insulator...even a tiny film of it between connectors would hinder the electric flow...both conductive and di-electric greases are silicone based though highly different in properties....... Sent from LG Optimus LTE LU-6200 using PW forums mobile app silicone di electric is specified for ignition components so the HV dump it does not arc to ground where we dont want it, we we want the HV to dump to ground in the spark plug electrode. We also apply it to electric low voltage connections so we dont get arching from moisture - it also is non miscible to water making it all the better.

column1: Since last few months, me and my friend are trying to provide oxygen pipe to a B13, and every now and then, it comes up that the oxygen pipe is not enough for it :P. So, we have ultimately decided to do a surgery on it and here we are. It will be an interesting and long surgery, as car needs denting, painting as well as engine replacement. QG18DE. QG15DE. GA15DE. Restoring E15. AC system also needs to be placed as well as seats will be either replaced or poshish will be done, which ever suits better. Here are some pictures of "before"    Upgrades so far: QG18DE Multiflow Condensor from B14 Dual barrel radiator from B14 for Auto Front fenders replaced with Super Saloon Doors replaced with Super Saloon ones with Power Windows Retract Mirrors OEM wiring replaced AC Panel upgraded to push-type Suspension overhaul Rear bumper changed with Super Salooon one New Headlights Front New Parking Lights Front New Back Lights Trunk replaced with Super Saloon one Meter replaced with RPM one for automatic Shock absorbers replaced Motorized Heater Box Motorized Cooling Box Motorized Air flow vent control Paint OEM Mud flaps OEM Fender Shields OEM Front Grill OEM Fuel Tank Cover Planned Upgrades: 1. Sound System 2. Upgrade to 15" Rims and Tyres 3. GT Bumper with fog lights 4. Nismo Exhaust 5. Rear Lip for B13 6. Super Saloon Console with Armrest
column2: star2;4127577: unfortunately due to busy schedule could not go to the workshop today, but talked with my mechanic over the phone, he said your brake pipes are all over the engine bay and those are because of the brake T to which the pipes are coming and then going forward to tank. He said the T needs to be changed as it is not the original T. Rest, he has removed all the parts from the engine bay and inspected suspension parts. Now tomorrow, denter will take a final look at the engine bay and it will go for paint. Will go to workshop tomorrow. Get those pipes galvanized. They look real sharp - almost give a new car look.

Restoring E15. AC system also needs to be placed as well as seats will be either replaced or poshish will be done, which ever suits better. Here are some pictures of "before"    Upgrades so far: QG18DE Multiflow Condensor from B14 Dual barrel radiator from B14 for Auto Front fenders replaced with Super Saloon Doors replaced with Super Saloon ones with Power Windows Retract Mirrors OEM wiring replaced AC Panel upgraded to push-type Suspension overhaul Rear bumper changed with Super Salooon one New Headlights Front New Parking Lights Front New Back Lights Trunk replaced with Super Saloon one Meter replaced with RPM one for automatic Shock absorbers replaced Motorized Heater Box Motorized Cooling Box Motorized Air flow vent control Paint OEM Mud flaps OEM Fender Shields OEM Front Grill OEM Fuel Tank Cover Planned Upgrades: 1. Sound System 2. Upgrade to 15" Rims and Tyres 3. GT Bumper with fog lights 4. Nismo Exhaust 5. Rear Lip for B13 6. Super Saloon Console with Armrest
column2: star2;4124611: Brake pads are new and OEM replacement from Nissan authorized dealer, as well as rotors as I told you before. Two front brake pipes were replaced recently, one was leak, one had cracks but not leaked so both changed and they are good. Rear brake pads changed as well, about cylinders, not sure, if they needed to be replaced, will replace them if I find them new. Regarding shocks, original oil filled shocks of B13 were recently placed along with original springs. Will see if they do justice, they are new practically, so hoping they do the trick else another 8-10k was the brake fluid flushed out or simply bled and topped up, old watered brake fluid is useless for any sort of braking.

column2: you can easily replace all these pipes - for that you need to get some pieces of wire (ask a denter to give you some welding wire) use that to make shapes of how the original pipes are supposed to be routed. You might need another good car to compare or use a photograph. Get a pipe bending tool - proper CNG installers had it, its basically a pipe with a another pipe welded to it at a right angle and a sort of lip to grab the pipe, They usually had it in 3 sizes. Home/commercial A/C technicians also use it - Not the cheap idiots who dont know jack, but proper ones. Get a flaring tool to make flares on the new pipe and use the original nuts on your pipe bend the pipes as required and before installing them get them hot dipped or galvanized so they dont rust. For the plastic clips, I knew one shop in Karachi that sold them (they were local made items that were 2 piece and had a hole to use a bolt or screw to mount them on the body) btw - why are they mangled up?

By the way, the new pipes I will be getting, will those be available in straight lengths ? and they are mangled up because there are multiple booster changes (suspected) and the Brake T currently installed is also not of B13 (very bad to know). That's why experimentation has caused them to be in the present shape. Wohi, our local craftsmanship wonders..... yes you can buy them in straight lengths. column2: nice going man. you are really going to enjoy a refurbed car - rebuild the entire rear suspension too for that classic Nissan sunny smoothness. btw go to the yard again and try to locate the original fender plastic liners for this car, originally they are very high quality and very nicely finished too, I noticed a lot of mud and dust on the pictures with removed front fenders which means your car had them missing. btw get some cosmoline or body cavity wax or make some yourself - to protect your investments

column1: I have the original plate AJX-279 on my lancer put in the back windshield of the car, and it displays, and i have another plate with Mafia written on it at the original plate location, will police stop me for doing this? And isnt the law that original plate must be displaying in the car.
column2: You can do whatever you want if your abba, chacha , mama aur taya is having some good influence or is any govt official Sorry to say but Pakistan is NO MANS LAND.

column1: I've bought a Diahatsu move. Old owner has installed Amp + Subwoofer. I want to remove that because subwoofer has taken half of boot space. Without that door speakers are giving very flat sound. Old owner said that I can't get good sound with door speakers because doors do no have enough space for big magnets. I'm not sure if thats true. Because nowdays even small bluetooth speakers can generate rich and loud sound. Are there any good speakers for doors that can produce good crisp sound with reasonable bass? P.S. The car has touch panel with equalizer feature.
column2: In order to get better midbass response, you need to do some sound deadening in your doors. Aftermarket speakers can usually be installed with plastic rings to adjust the mounting depth. Leave the amplifier even if you want to remove the sub. Aftermarket speakers will run better off with an external amplifier than the headunits built in amplifier. If you space for speakers in the the rear doors, install some Aftermarket coaxils there too. Run all four speakers from the amp. Remember, your speakers won't produce the same low end tones that a sub can. However, with some good after market coaxials, an amp and some decent sound deadening, you won't lack a punch
