column2: Keep stock speakers as it is.. install tweeters on dash with after market cross overs easily available at home audio shops to separate mid and treble and for woofer part buy an under seated woofer which has built in amplifier.. go to this link they have many used branded under seat woofers.. in range of 6-10k.. thats it.. i did same and its perfect

column1: Hi all, I am again in need of a little help from PW. Now the situation is that i am going to buy a Toyota Corolla 1980 KE70 & i am going to keep it in stock looks interior & exterior both but the changes that i am going to do are these i will have it re painted with best paint quality possible but keeping it in original shade will not change the color at all (if i get a red or white i will be happy), I will make a little changes to suspension will lower down the ride but with coil-overs i don't know if i will be able to find original coil-overs or i will have to get it custom built, Now the main thing is motor(engine) i was planing to go with 4A-GE but if you guys can suggest something better please let me know but do keep one thing in mind that i am not going for something fast & furious i am not a racer type guy i don't want something over or under power just want something perfect with the weight of the car... The help that seek from fellow members is about suspension & engine where can i get suspension parts & what are the parts that i will need & in regards to motor do you guys think that 4A-GE is a good choice if not then what other options do i have & what about transmission, LSD. Looking for some good feedback's with tons of ideas. Note: I am looking for 1980 KE70 in Lahore if you guys can tell me about a good KE70 for sale. Bought It
column2: for decent power the 1.6 2T engine is also a champ, As these cars are now very senior citizens they need a major overhauling to be considered road worthy - which in my head means taking the entire car to bits and building it back up, repairing or correcting any failures with NEW GENUINE PARTS. not chinese, ustaad, hathora, jugaar etc.

column2: DANY_KHANN;3817554: @zulfiqar.... well if 1.6 2T then why not restoring it original specs to avoid all the hassles of alterations & after marker parts?? *T fits on the same mounts as the *K engines - no modifications required. If I were you, I would make some very tall stands for the car and unbolt everything from it specially under it, replace all rubber bits and repair metal parts - coat new metal parts like brake lines, fuel lines etc and install back with all clamps in place. It will give you a very good "base control" to compare to. If you are going to blindly trust the mechanic/denter/electrician/ustaad - then you are signing up for a bull fighting match. Unless you have infinite pockets of money its best to at least do it 50% DIY - that way you know how to measure what those guys are upto. e.g. simple procedure of packing front wheel bearings becomes a nightmare because ustaad ki grease dibbi is actually chit, ustaad refuses to buy high temp lith complex grease for disc brakes because it costs Rs 1000/kg. The nukkar ki dukaan does not store it as no ustaad buys it Who suffers ....................... YOU the car operator.

Ensure the engine is not sludged up or worn down as the guy is not running an air filter and the breather vent is open.

column1: Does anyone know of an exhaust shop in Karachi that does decent welding and has good quality exhaust/muffler systems in stock?
column2: There is one in garden, on the back side of zoo. Opposite meezan bank. Have heard he does very good welding but charges almost double the normal price. I took the complete Exhaust system and he asked for 4k to do 7 or 8 Welds (500/weld). My father in law gets Exhaust work done from this guy (don't know his name, but he has long beard) . I bought the system from bukhari silencer on thr back side of Japan plaza

column1: "June 2012 Updates on Page 20! - Tasks Completed: -  - Body & Paint: - 1. Replaced old rusted floors with locally fabricated ones as per stock design. - 2. Replaced engine bay floor with stock. - 3. Repaired rust patches on rear right door, boot door, and left front fender. - 4. Re-built side door panels on both sides as per stock specs. - 5. Applied rust protective coat under the car, under the fenders, and on the floor. - 6. Completed paint job on the entire car, including the inside of the doors, boot, under the roof, and outside body. - 7. Painted differential and fuel tank. - 8. Detailed paint job on starter motor, coil, wiper motor base, fuel pump, pedals, steering assembly, etc. - 9. Applied new paintjob on the complete engine (British Green). - 10. Backed paint on the rims (old English white). - 11. Serviced door window motors and all locks. - 12. Installed new front screen. - 13. Installed and buffed front and rear bumpers, and bumper horns. -  - Mechanical: - 1. Re-built complete engine to deliver compression as per stock specifications (replaced pistons, rings, valves, crankshaft, timing chain, biggens, gaskets, and seals). - 2. Re-built gearbox and changed synchronizers. - 3. Replaced clutch plate and pressure plates. - 4. Re-built carburetor using a complete kit with jets. - 5. Replaced differential seals and cleaned from the inside. - 6. Installed original brake cylinder with new brakehead kit, replaced brake lines, and replaced all wheel brake cylinders. - 7. Installed hand brake cable. - 8. Installed speedometer cable. - 9. Replaced left rear wheel hub. - 10. Re-built rear suspension, installed new leaf springs, and installed original shocks. - 11. Installed complete rubber kit for front suspension. - 12. Cleaned and greased steering system, and installed new boots. - 13. Serviced and fixed leakages in the stock radiator. -  - Electrical: - 1. Re-built fuel pump using original kit. - 2. Replaced fuel gauge. - 3. Serviced wiper motor, cleaned old grease, and applied fresh grease. - 4. Re-built starter motor. - 5. Installed stock new ignition switch. - 6. Installed stock new indicator assembly. - 7. Installed stock electric and wiper switches. - 8. Installed heating system and stock screen air vents under the dash. - 9. Installed speedometer from deluxe model, connected hidden switch for meter lights. - 10. Installed warning light for engine oil and engine oil filter change due. - 11. Installed stock fuse boxes. - 12. Installed coil (not stock). - 13. Installed complete new wiring as per stock design. -  - Detailing: - 1. Replaced front windscreen rubber. - 2. Replaced rear screen rubber. - 3. Replaced quarter glass rubbers. - 4. Applied white walls on tires with stock 5-20-14 tires. - 5. Installed Morris Minor original badges. - 6. Installed stock new wiper push button manual pump. - 7. Installed stock new wiper bottle ""TUDOR"". - 8. Installed Lucas new headlights along with original chrome rings. - 9. Installed Lucas new front indicator complete lights. - 10. Installed Lucas new rear brake-lights. - 11. Installed Lucas rear number plate lights. - 12. Installed stock cabin light and connected with front 2 doors stock mechanism. - 13. Installed stock stickers on engine and batteries. - 14. Installed stock rear view mirrors on the fenders. - 15. Installed stock steering assembly (replaced from a Corolla). -  - Interior: - 1. Installed new seats upholstery as per stock design. - 2. Upholstered doors using stock material and painted them to match the seat colors, also installed plastic protection coat. - 3. Applied sound and heat proofing on the floor and under the dash. - 4. Installed new carpet as per stock design, along with mats. - 5. Installed new upholstery under the roof as per stock. - 6. Re-built sun shades to match the roof. -  - To view images, please follow the link: [insert link]"
column2: sadly it is a forgotten classic in PK. peoplelook at them like they do at beetles,.. they don't realize the history behind these cars. all they care about is "will it run on CNG", "does it have a b16", or "does it have VVTi".... i'm a particular fan of the early models which had the headlights in the grille,... serious history, and VERY collectable.

column1: Hey guys i was considering to dampen my jeep to improve both sound and ride quality. Just wanted to know what options i have available here. Currently i have the desi "namda" or wool insulation and im not happy with it at all!! any idea what the cost of products like dynamat is here in the isb/rwp area? and how well will it perform if used to insulate the floor and firewall. Another one i thought of was peel and seel, is that stuff any good or a waste of money? So if u guys know of any other options available i'd like to hear em doesnt matter if they're "desi" methods as long as they get the job done and do it well. I'm looking to get the cabin as quiet as possible and areas that will be sealed are; the complete floor area + area behind dashboard, doors, wheel arches, boot space, roof and under the bonnet. oh and let me know if there's any other areas that should be insulated as well. Thanks in advance Durrani
column2: Lambo sheets are available in limited quantity. For optimal performance, it is recommended to use MLV (Mass Loaded Vinyl) or rubber sheets over the lambo sheets.

column2: imranuh;4263974: Its the one you lat under carpet in rooms. I got it for 10 rs / sq. foot and this was the lowest price I was able to get so expect it for around 20/sq ft from anywhere... thats not lambo sheet, that is called underlay. jumbolon is a local product name used for heat proofing of roofs.

column1: Hey guys i was considering to dampen my jeep to improve both sound and ride quality. Just wanted to know what options i have available here. Currently i have the desi "namda" or wool insulation and im not happy with it at all!! any idea what the cost of products like dynamat is here in the isb/rwp area? and how well will it perform if used to insulate the floor and firewall. Another one i thought of was peel and seel, is that stuff any good or a waste of money? So if u guys know of any other options available i'd like to hear em doesnt matter if they're "desi" methods as long as they get the job done and do it well. I'm looking to get the cabin as quiet as possible and areas that will be sealed are; the complete floor area + area behind dashboard, doors, wheel arches, boot space, roof and under the bonnet. oh and let me know if there's any other areas that should be insulated as well. Thanks in advance Durrani
column2: omarss;4259542: You cheapest solution is that. But considering OP already has namda installed and not happy with that, i would assume he is looking for a higher level of sound insulation. I would say 75% vibration damping and 100% sound insulation using good materials. Lanbo is a good cheap alternative but peel n seal is a different thing altogether. its meant for sealing broken roofs. It may work ok for the floor but not so sure about vertical installations as the black part of the peel n seal is not very heat resistant and would become soft when the temperature rises. Correct me if I am wrong. I havent used peel n seal. Peel and Seal does not become soft under heat and stays attached like a bond, just like Dynamat, STP Sound Deadner, Stinger Roadkill or Damp pro, however yes it has a complete different application however its heavy and used Butyl rubber with adhesive on one end and foil type material on the other end. Its the cheapest solution out there. Jumbolon is a different type and one its application is sound deadening, which can be called, a 'Jugaar'. Recommended dampening is Jumbolon for floor and all other areas, Dynamat equivalent brands which include STP, Roadkill etc for the outer frame of the door. The inner side can be applied with Lambo sheets. Peel and Seal is not available here so won't consider it.

column2: Ally1;4258716: I installed a jambo (presumably an aftermarket modification) in my Civic, and it works great. This modification is suitable for a petrol-driven car. However, it won't provide any benefits for a diesel SUV. For a diesel SUV, the cheapest solutions would be using Peel&Seal, Lambo sheets, or Namda.

I havent used peel n seal. i hope yawar's reply has been usefull. however peel&seal does tend to peel of if applied onto the inner skin of the roof. direct sunlight can do the damage. as for using it on the doors, well yes i have read it on alot of forums that it tends to peel off even from doors. however the same number of people say it works absolutely fine. even the members on pw who are using it on their doors havnt had complaints. So yeah, i think it shoudnt be a problem on doors, fender arches and the floor. about the roof, id say go for lambo or the more expensive stuff. yawar has also explained why P&S does the job so well too. about where to find it. well its cheap and alot of sites have them so id say importing them isnt hard or expensive. there is a 70% on a brand that makes deadening sheets and mats, i saw it somewhere. will check it out post the link here.

column2: Hmm Whoever says it costs more to fix a car on cng than saving well they should attend math classes again. I save 7000Rs every month in my CNG Car. Its been over a year i am driving it. column2: mileage of cng fitted reborn prosmatec in lahore. 60kg cylinder. 100-120km within city and around 120-140km out of city with/without ac. petrol average is 8km/l within city and 12km/l on highways. MANUAL reborns perform better than the above mentioned values. You can get any simple CNG kit in your car. No lambda kit is needed for reborn. Nothing happens to the engine if you dont abuse it. Gear technology is simple and its absolutely fine to run on CNG. BUT, if you want it to be on its toes every time you floor it, then dont go for CNG. You will have to compromise a little on that case. Apart from that, all is well. emulator and advancer increase car's pic and response on CNG. use them. Prices can be checked from KHI market. Landirenzo is the best. Get it from any famous CNG fitter in KHI. Plugs must be used as per civic's manual. Honda also has its own engine oil. You can use that also. Earlier it was the same as Caltex Havoline (Black can) as both were being made by Chevron Limited. Now Honda has given the contract to some other company. I however still use Havoline in 2007 reborn and change every 3000km. CNG installation should not make any difference on power steering. Hope it helps.

column1: Time to Edit This Post Again. A while ago, I'd taken delivery of these two cars, almost side by side. The first was a '67 Impala, which made its way over to the workshop almost straight away for some major refit and refurbishment. A lot of hard work went into this machine; in virtually all areas possible. The body, the interior, engine, suspension, ergonomics, cosmetics. And now, by Allah's grace, it's complete. It boasts a good body, a 350 cubic inch (5700 cc) engine, and a three speed automatic transmission. The vehicle rides on 20 inch wheels clad with 295/40 tyres. My son, Shayaan, was very closely involved with the rebuild of this creature. It was at his insistence that we opted for it to be returned to as close to stock, as was possible. It was at his urging, that we adopted some non-stock touches to embellish and beautify the car, at the same time. Yeh uss ki zidd thi, ke hum iss ko "Supernatural" wali Impala banayen. This is very much HIS car. I hope that when he grows up a little more (he's currently just short of 17 years of age, and will not be getting the car until he's 18), he learns to appreciate this machine and all others like it. I sincerely hope he also learns how to have fun with these lightning-strike monsters; but does so responsibly, and sensibly.   The other car, is MY car. This one is a '65 which I bought a while ago. It had been recently rebuilt with a 3000 cc 6 cylinder engine, with a 3 speed automatic transmission, and sported 16 inch rims clad with 195/60 tyres. The car underwent some "cosmetic surgery" in the form of a flame-paint job, and also had its interior completely refinished in crimson and black. For the engine, we chucked out the 6 potter and bunged in a 4000 cc 1UZ-FE VVTi, V8, with a 5 speed Tiptronic gearbox. The suspension underwent a complete overhaul, as did the exhaust. The vehicle retains its 'old' rims, but now wears 225/60 tyres. This car is still 'incomplete' in the sense that it's going to get a cosmetic makeover in the near future. Perhaps some much-needed body work, along with some charcoal-coloured matte wrap, and some re-chroming. Maybe some blacked-out wheels. Until then, it continues to breathe fire on the roads, and be an absolute pleasure to drive and own.   Although, hum baap beta aapas mein, apni apni car ki siftein parhtey rehte hain...we're both grateful to Allah Almighty, who's given us the wherewithal and the opportunity to own these great rides!
column2: Saw these Impala's along with Fouad My vote is to rebuild them one by one Fouad if u need any kind of help in procuring parts then do let me know

column1: salam to all... Yesterday got time and did my Big 3 wire upgrade on my cultus , it was tough as per me as i am not much that of a hardworker ,and not use to this kind of work:P .The Diy was done by myself(2 hands) and took 1.5 hours to complete and was a success .Things used 8 thimbals big ones  .1 60A fuse to in line with alternator to battery positive wire  .approx 3 meter , 2 gauge wire  .nuts and bolts as required  .thats all :)with other household tools used Procedure. this is efficient yet cheap upgrade to improve overall car's electrical performance ..we change three wires accordingly 1st Alternator to battery positive wire  2nd Negative to chassis ground wire  3rd engine block ground to battery negative wire does Big 3 help in real yes it did for me there is notice able increase in cabin light, headlights bright, lights fluctuate less when blower stars ... engine starts early than before... .. btw was really tired :(but really statisfied after a diy:P:P  60A FUSE   PAINT SCRAPPED OFF FOR GROUND CONNECTION      MY HANDS ALL MESSED UP TOOK AN EFFORT TO TAKE GREASE OFF:P      :D:D:D COMMENTS ARE WELCOME

column1: salam to all... Yesterday got time and did my Big 3 wire upgrade on my cultus , it was tough as per me as i am not much that of a hardworker ,and not use to this kind of work:P .The Diy was done by myself(2 hands) and took 1.5 hours to complete and was a success .Things used 8 thimbals big ones  .1 60A fuse to in line with alternator to battery positive wire  .approx 3 meter , 2 gauge wire  .nuts and bolts as required  .thats all :)with other household tools used Procedure. this is efficient yet cheap upgrade to improve overall car's electrical performance ..we change three wires accordingly 1st Alternator to battery positive wire  2nd Negative to chassis ground wire  3rd engine block ground to battery negative wire does Big 3 help in real yes it did for me there is notice able increase in cabin light, headlights bright, lights fluctuate less when blower stars ... engine starts early than before... .. btw was really tired :(but really statisfied after a diy:P:P  60A FUSE   PAINT SCRAPPED OFF FOR GROUND CONNECTION      MY HANDS ALL MESSED UP TOOK AN EFFORT TO TAKE GREASE OFF:P      :D:D:D COMMENTS ARE WELCOME

column1: Although i need to learn a lot about project management and time management but still this will be my next project car Inshallah immediately after liteace comes to and end is sent to Faisalabad. This is my Taya's 74 corolla. He bought it himself and drove it as a daily runner. Sadly he died in 1976 at the age of 43. My father kept quiet about custody of the car so far waiting for the things to get favourable. now we can get it as per free will of the curent users in the family. This project again will be a very touching and full of affiliations, especially for my father. I was born in 1976 and i can only feel what he has for this car. I will be putting in my heart and soul into it and need the usual support from the fellow pakwheelers.     we also have service booklet of the same car with my Taya's name on it.    The best part about is the fact that we will be using it ourselves after restoration. Wish me luck people
column2: you were born in 1976?. i was already pushing corolla75 in garage in 1976,, because i was still too short to pop clutch.

column2: brotherly advice. get at least 3 cans of body cavity wax and apply generously to the car, the areas that rusted on the rear wheel arches rust to due water entrapment and condensation, the wax prevents this water from pooling.

column2: the wax is applied last - if you look in the wheel well - you will find a few holes with rubber covers on them, those holes were specifically drilled to apply the wax coating. The largest one near the front edge opens into the "footboard' aka sill aka rocker panel. wax is applied liberally there too. Dont confuse undercoating with wax, btw the undercoating extends out all the way till the lower edge of the footboard or sill panel to protect against rusting. When installing the tail lamps back - make sure that the foam rubber gasket is good - if its not then water gets into the boot and creates a nasty muggy atmosphere which also stinks and causes fungus and bacteria growth.

column2: I think you may have gone overboard with damping the floor. it does get wet if the car goes through deep water, and then moisture may become hard to remove.

column2: Source: Pioneer AVH-2550NEX https://www.pioneerelectronics.ca/POCEN/Car/DVD-Receivers/AVH-2550NEX2 First things first, lets get the brains of this build set up. So the stock head-unit that Toyota provided in these cars wasn't at any level even near what a true audiohead would want in their car. The audio quality was FAIR at best and considering these are locally produced, that's pretty obvious The AVH-2550NEX is a great headunit featuring a 6.8" display, Amazon Alexa, Apple Carplay, Android Auto, SirusXM, Weblink, Spotify, Pandora, Dual camera inputs, selectable guidelines etc. More importantly, it features a 13 band EQ, built in DSP with auto/manual TA, HPF/BP/LPF Crossover Network, Full active Network mode, 24 Bit DA Converter and Auto EQ. All of this comes at a reasonable $550-$600 price tag depending on where you source the headunit from but it's a worthwhile investment if you are not a fan of those larger panels and want to maintain the OE look of the dash.

column2: Sound Dampening Stage 1: Sound Deadening Sheets Stage 2: Closed Cell Foam Stage 1 Includes deadening the entirety of the Cabin, the Hood, Trunk & Boot area of the car with Sound Deadening sheets (To eliminate metal resonance inside the cabin itself). Once these area's are covered, we'll move onto the CCF for the Cabin panels, roof and floor (which acts as a sound barrier). Combining these two layers greatly decreases the Db's inside the cabin making it a great place to listen to your music Hood / Trunk / Boot

column2: Passenger Cabin Moving to the cabin and prepping to isolate it as much as possible. First up is the Roof. The reason I decided on using the sound deadening sheets on the roof (~60-70% application area) was because its hella annoying to hear the rain slapping against the metal sheet above your head while youre listening to music. I had to experience this with my 2019 PKDM Alto ( Was worse than this ) and the deadening sheets made a hell of a difference completely eliminating the sounds of rain against the roof. You will instantly realize its the rain hitting the windscrean now that will bother you but hay, that still isnt as bad as the roof We can then move onto the Doors, the rear parcel shelf area and the Rear wheel arches Finally, we move to the smaller regions, the A,B,C Pillars Despite the fact that these are all strong points when it comes to metal sturdiness (due to the welding points and double metal sheets at the corners), I wanted to cover these up for my peace of mind

column2: Stage 2: Accoustic Closed Cell Foam Application Moving onto the Closed Cell Foam application to the plastic trim. First up, a look at the 2 different type of CCF Sheets being used in the build. Let's start with the door cards. Pictures show the driver and right rear passenger door panels. The process repeats for the other two doors. Each was cleaned with a solution of Isopropanol and wiped dry. The different sections of these door cards are held with small metal screws. Since these are screwed into plastic, these tend to loosen with time. I simply grabbed some red thread locker, put a small dab and retightened all of them Once the screws were tightened on all 4 door cards, I applied the same sound deadening material on them. Just like in the case of metal, these help the plastics from flexing by adding weight to the panel itself Next we can move onto the CCF application. Each Sheet is 100x50x2.5 cm in total.

column2: CCF Application: Kick Panels, Front Inner Fender, ABC Pillars & Rear Wheel Wells Moving onto the other plastic panels inside the cabin. Heres a look at the footwell kick panels first I also went ahead and took out the front inner fender shields. These were cleaned out with some APC and Isopropanol before applying the CCF. This was done to block as much of the road noise from the tires at the front of the cabin. The rear wheel Wells were also treated Same application was done to the A,B,C pillars Lastly, the rear wheel arches got treated

The thread will be updated as more parts arrive in Pakistan for the build: -  - Master Source: - - Pioneer AVH-2550NEX -  - Processor: - - Mosconi Gladen 4 to 6 DSP -  - Front Stage: - - Helix Precision P62C - - Helix Precision P3M -  - Sub Stage: - - Helix Precision P12 -  - Amplifiers: - - Helix Precision H400X - - Mosconi Gladen AS100.2 -  - Capacitor: - - Helix Precision DPC1000 PowerCap -  - Power Wire: - - AudioSystem Z-PCS35 2 Gauge 100% OFC Pwr/Gnd Wire -  - RCA Interconnects: - - 2 x Focal ER5 OFC triple shielded Interconnects - - 3 x Stinger 6000 SI623 Interconnects -  - Speaker Cables: - - Oehlbach SP25-3000 OFC 2x2.5mm2 30M speaker wire -  - Subwoofer Cable: - - Focal Elite ES4 OFC -  - Damping: - - Infinity & Caliber Deadening sheets - - 25mm/15mm Closed Cell Foam Sheets -  - Distribution Blocks: - - Stinger SHD-821 4 Position Fused Power Distribution Block - - Connection BDB-51 4 Position Ground Distribution Block -  - Inline Fuse Holders: - - Connection BFH11 Inline Fuse Holder - - Gladen Fh20 Inline Fuse Holder -  - Fuses: - - 2 x Connection SFA150 Sonus AFS Fuses -  - BIG4 Upgrade: - - NVX EnvyFlex 1/0 Gauge Tinned OFC Wire -  - Power Wire: - - Audison Connection MainPower 1/0 Tinned OFC Wire -  - Battery Terminals: - - T-Spec VBTPN 1/0-10 Awg 8 Position Positive Terminal - - T-Spec VBTPN 1/0-10 Awg 8 Position Negative Terminal -  - Fast Rings: - - Stinger Fastrings - - 3M Fastrings -  - Accessories: - - Audison Connection Sonus SRT 2 - - StreetWires Power Rings PRS0 - - Alextech Expandable Braided Sleeving (25ft 1/2"" - 25ft 3/4"") - - Tesa 51617 PET Fleece Tape -  - A special thank you goes out to Shehryar from Sound Valley for helping me choose the equipment, Yawar for all the assistance, and Moj who is one of the coolest people I've dealt with."
column2: Stage 1 & 2: Cabin Floor Started out by taking the interior out including the carpet in its entirety. Took me less than an hour to completely strip the interior. Once that was done, I went ahead and cleaned the floor with some IPA. Because of time constraints and me wanting this done ASAP, got a little help to put down the Caliber Deadening sheets Time to pull that Driver seat out again and put down the acoustic CCF followed by the carpet. Almost there, ALMOST THERE, ALMOST.........

column1: One of the tires on our 10 year old car keeps losing air rather fast (2 psi/week). Got it checked from multiple shops but they didn't find any punctures and valve is fine as well. Researched online and found that it might be related to bead leakage because of corrosion inside alloy wheel. Recommended method is to take off tire, sand/scrub the wheel bead area thoroughly and remount the tire. Is there any decent shop in lahore experienced in this?
column2: 3 months, Michelin XM2+. But its just one tire that loses pressure. Previous tires were also Michelin XM2, back then one tire was losing pressure quickly as well. So definitely not tire issue or valve issue.

column1: One of the tires on our 10 year old car keeps losing air rather fast (2 psi/week). Got it checked from multiple shops but they didn't find any punctures and valve is fine as well. column2: There is a tire market in moon market Faisal town or any big tyre rim market shop can help. there are people who are selling rims also repairs them or get them repaired. The actual repair markets are way inside the city where a car cannot reach somewhere in kotha pind area. I have once gotten my rims diamond cut and polished from near faisal town moon market. don't remember the exact area now as it was 8-9 years ago but market is still there. Also neela gumbad is the biggest and oldest tire market and sure here are people who repair rips if you go and ask around. Hope this helps.

column1: I have a Toyota Tamaraw (South East Asia model only) powered by a 2C diesel engine and my tachometer have been acting up lately. It would work every cold start upto about 8-15 minutes then it will suddenly drop dead. I have checked the tach circuit itself but didn't find anything wrong or busted or any crossed wires. Screws are fairly tightened (not too tight) and contacts are clean. I also checked the terminals and all are in good condition and I think I've probably eliminated the basic possibilities. What could be issue? Thanks.
column2: check the rpm sensor at the pump, its a 2 wire sensor that reads the governer teeth.

column1: I like to keep my car Honda city 2014 clean inside out. And for that matter i have to get my car washed every 15 days. Most of the time i visit service stations in Lahore. They charge from 600-1000 per service and even after that i am not much satisfied from it.Except from one place which charge around 1000 ruppees per wash and is almost 8km from my place. So i have to spare 3-4 hrs for it. Sometimes i wash the car myself.I have Shampoo,APC,microfiber cloth,Interior Dress,Soft 99 kiwami wax. But i dont have Pressurewasher or vaccum cleaner which makes it more time consuming and tiring. So i was thinking of buying a pressure washer and Vaccum cleaner for this purpose. Now the Question is that is it worth it to buy these Equipment? Is it more easy to wash the car with these equipment or its just a "Kera"? Will it save any time?
column2: I tried and tested lots of pressure washers in the past but find Coofix pressure washer best amoung all, its parts are easily available in the market. 2nd is Hyundai Pressure Washer which is also very relible and after market service is also very good. https://www.daraz.pk/products/coofix-1400w-high-pressure-washer-pure-copper-water-from-bucket-and-tap-both-function-i139578707.html24 https://hyundaipower.com.pk/product/hyundai-pressure-washer-110-bar-hpw-110im/19

column1: I like to keep my car Honda city 2014 clean inside out. And for that matter i have to get my car washed every 15 days. Most of the time i visit service stations in Lahore. They charge from 600-1000 per service and even after that i am not much satisfied from it.Except from one place which charge around 1000 ruppees per wash and is almost 8km from my place. So i have to spare 3-4 hrs for it. Sometimes i wash the car myself.I have Shampoo,APC,microfiber cloth,Interior Dress,Soft 99 kiwami wax. But i dont have Pressurewasher or vaccum cleaner which makes it more time consuming and tiring. So i was thinking of buying a pressure washer and Vaccum cleaner for this purpose. Now the Question is that is it worth it to buy these Equipment? Is it more easy to wash the car with these equipment or its just a "Kera"? Will it save any time?
column2: Its always better to clean or wash ownself. If you love cars. Because you will do this job with care detailing and also know your car better. Sometimes you will get to know any demage or new dent or any thing happen to your car which you are not aware of. Service station guys dont care about cloth using on the car and leave with beautiful swril marks on your car. Get any pressure washer with less power. To my understanding cleaning car with high pressure is not suitable. If you have good pressure in tap, you can simply get a good garden hose gun and it will done your work perfectly. Using water less spray washer or quick detailers are just fancy things and spending extra money to my point of view. Avoid dry dusting your car. Micro fibre clothes are useful. For interior cleaning you can get any wet n dry vaccum cleaner. It will do your house work as well. Using blower to clean interior is not really useful to my view because it blows dust to others area of the car. Vaccum cleaner is better than blower. Btw, after long time once i washed car with regular hose pipe and found it way better than these pressure washers. Idk why. Washing car from bneath is important also. And lubricant car suspension is also important. Dont wash engine bay ever. Get a simple spray bottle and clean with it. I am keeping extra tooth brush for engine bay detailing because its impossible to clean some area with cloth.

column1: Assalamualaikum. I restored a Honda Accord 1985 - 1600CC car back in January 2022. It cost me almost 100k-120k to bring it back to its current condition from being completely non-functional. However, as a student, I couldn't afford to invest another 100k for further repairs such as mechanical issues. As a result, the car has been idle for almost 1.5 years. As someone who is passionate about cars, it breaks my heart to see my favorite car, my project car, in such a condition. I feel even worse because I have an emotional attachment to this car. I need some help and suggestions to revive this beauty and get it back on the road. Those who own or appreciate this particular model will understand its value and how comfortable the ride is. Thank you in advance for any suggestions and help regarding parts and repairs. Please share this post so that it reaches Mr. Suneel Munj, as I really don't want to sell this car. I love her and I want to restore her so that I can use her as my daily driver again.
column2: Where is the picture? How can we find out what work has been done?

column1: I bought an android panel a few months ago (4-5months) and it used to work fine, turned on within few seconds after ignition, And Even played/remembered music from the same time, now it has started to cause an issue. Whenever ignition is turned on after few hours it will start from the Boot Up, and take usual 1-2 minutes to load No longer remember music track time and volume settings I tried factory reset twice and deleting all apps etc, I came to find out its internal battery (that helps it remember its last state) has gone kaput - I mean within few months already? What is the remedy ?! 5
column2: Maybe corrupted software , Maybe overheating , Maybe Bad apps or Maybe your functions exceeds it's Ram.

column1: Yesterday Iqrar-ul-Hassan of Ary News showed in his program that fake engine oils, brake oils and gear oils of every brand are manufactured in Hyderabad and may be in other cities nation wide. These oils totally resemble to the originals in packing. Beware if these fake oils. What should be done to avoid and locate these fake oils?
column2: I always made sure I bought lube oils from a high volume outlet - and I had it pumped from the 210 litre drum, or just bought the drum. It was always genuine and fresh product. As Romano also put it destroy the plastic container and bin it. That way its a bit more expensive for the fraudsters who may eventually have to look for something else to do.

column2: best go to a truck stand and buy it from the drum - cheaper and fresh. Truckies will probably shoot the shops if their engines died due to poor oil. Mohmand Oil Agency was a big caltex jobber.

column1: Yesterday Iqrar-ul-Hassan of Ary News showed in his program that fake engine oils, brake oils and gear oils of every brand are manufactured in Hyderabad and may be in other cities nation wide. These oils totally resemble to the originals in packing. Beware if these fake oils. What should be done to avoid and locate these fake oils?
column2: Mohmand Oil Agency is located right next to Shahrah-e-Faisal, opposite the Federal Tax Ombudsman's office. They offer a variety of oils in drums, gallon containers, and 1-liter containers, along with filters, and more. Previously, they used to charge Rs 20/- as labor fees for an oil change, which could be done in 10 minutes. By the way, STP Power Steering fluid is essentially the same as regular untinted ATF Type A fluid. In fact, most power steering fluids are of the same type.

column1: Salam to all pakwheelers, Guys iam starting my car restoration and modification its suzuki khyber model 1993, the car is in pretty bad shape right now its need restoration first engine, suspention and brakes is in good condition these are recently done. Basically my project will be completed in two stages Stage 1: 1. denting and painting work 2. interior remake 3. install car deck 4. dashboard repairing 5. electrical wiring 6. power windows 7. central locking Stage 2: 1. modify the body kit 2. hood modification 3. install spoiler 4. light weight alloy rims 5. hks imported exhaust 6. vinyling 7. modify speedometer 8. install RPM meter  I have also planned to swap the engine with suzuki G13B but it will depend on the time and conditions after basic restoration any suggestions will be appreciated History of the car in Pakwheels 92https://www.pakwheels.com/forums/members-member-rides/160207-just-bought-khyber-1993-a92 32https://www.pakwheels.com/forums/body-lights-appearance-parts/167410-recaro-bucket-seats-sale32 20https://www.pakwheels.com/forums/vehicles-bikes/174799-wts-suzuki-khyber-model-93-a20 Previously restored car 53https://www.pakwheels.com/forums/d-i-y-projects/180920-1982-nissan-pulsar-restoration53 UPDATE 18-1-12 Dashboard is repaired on page 11  UPDATE 01-2-2012 Car is painted on page 16  UPDATE 16-3-2012 Basic restoration completed from page 22
column2: Do you live near the sea? this is incredible amount of rust and corrosion, you should also be looking into bracing the floorpan and front end too, I bet the floorpans are gone to hell. Best would be to take out everything from the car, engine/tranny, complete suspension steering, interior and dash, and look for all traces of rust. Or you would be fixing all this again in 1 year.

Basically my project will be completed in two stages Stage 1: 1. denting and painting work 2. interior remake 3. install car deck 4. dashboard repairing 5. electrical wiring 6. power windows 7. central locking Stage 2: 1. modify the body kit 2. hood modification 3. install spoiler 4. light weight alloy rims 5. hks imported exhaust 6. vinyling 7. modify speedometer 8. install RPM meter  I have also planned to swap the engine with suzuki G13B but it will depend on the time and conditions after basic restoration any suggestions will be appreciated History of the car in Pakwheels 92https://www.pakwheels.com/forums/members-member-rides/160207-just-bought-khyber-1993-a92 32https://www.pakwheels.com/forums/body-lights-appearance-parts/167410-recaro-bucket-seats-sale32 20https://www.pakwheels.com/forums/vehicles-bikes/174799-wts-suzuki-khyber-model-93-a20 Previously restored car 53https://www.pakwheels.com/forums/d-i-y-projects/180920-1982-nissan-pulsar-restoration53 UPDATE 18-1-12 Dashboard is repaired on page 11  UPDATE 01-2-2012 Car is painted on page 16  UPDATE 16-3-2012 Basic restoration completed from page 22

column1: its been 2 months since I bought Civic VTI MT. it has Bridgestone Sneaker SNK2/SNK2AZ 195/65R15 91S.  The problem is, in these 2 months, i have had like 80 punctures altogether on all 4 tyres on different occasions. I am not a rash drive. Although i tend to drive at fast speed in 1 out of 5 drives. The car is driven around 1700KM in 2 months and all inside city. I live in DHA so you can have an idea about the roads. But have driven outside DHA as well. I have spent like 4-5000rs only on punctures in these 2 months. Just today I had 14 punctures on one tyre. A month ago, in first week of january, I got the tyres checked from the tyre/puncture shop and 1 tyre had 6, 1 had 9 and 1 had 11 punctures at that time. Its been going on from first week. After every 5 to 7 days I go to the tyre shop to get the air pressure checked and turns out that one of the tyres is puncture and when they check the puncture, turns out it has like 7-10 of it on 1 tyre. Please help me what is wrong here? is it the design of the tyres or what?   Click here to go to the SOLUTION5
column2: you can buy the needle and thread type repair kit in pakistan for about Rs 200/- plug and patch repair requires dismounting of the tire.

Dunlop sneakers, That too made in China, These are definetly not the tires sold in Pakistan, Dunlops are usually made in Japan/Indonesia, These seem scrap tires, The guy who sold you the car either replaced tires to make it look good, or removed good condition tires. Filhal the best option would be to opt for new tires, Or atleast try changing the punture shop you goto.

column1: Hello everyone, As the title suggests, I will start with the details. Like any other car enthusiast, it has always been my dream to restore an eg8 that closely resembles a Ferio. I purchased this 1994 Civic back in 2012 with the intention of restoring it, and I have owned this car for over a year now. The car has been good to me, with no engine problems or starting issues. The car runs perfectly fine, as the previous owner had replaced the engine with a D15B 3-stage VTEC. It also has 17-inch rims and a modified body kit. The car was in excellent condition both inside and out, with no major accidents involved. -  - Initial plans: I wanted to remove the body kit, strip the car down to bare metal to get rid of any rust, and then work on the body by redefining the lines and ensuring high-quality paintwork. I also planned to remove the carpet to check for any rust and found that the floor was in good condition. The tires needed to be replaced. -  - Shopping list:  - 1. Front/back bumpers (Taiwan) - 2. Genuine panels - 3. Mudflaps (best possible quality) - 4. Front left side mudguard - 5. Mudguard shields (best possible quality) - 6. Windscreen (best possible quality) - the old one started to wear off - 7. Door rubbers (all four doors from Bilal Ganj) - 8. Ferio samosa (bought it from Bilal Ganj) - 9. Window gola (Bilal Ganj) - 10. Door moldings (Bilal Ganj) - 11. Chrome window trims (Bilal Ganj) - 12. Genuine trunk lock (Bilal Ganj) - 13. Windshield washer nozzles (Bilal Ganj) - 14. Wiper shield - 15. Honda emblems (removed from trunk) - 16. Ferio & LEV emblems - 17. Roof golas - 18. Side mirror frames - 19. Door handles -  - Appearance: JDM ducktail or flush/lip spoiler Ferio (bought it from Pakwheels), genuine Stanley tail lights (Bilal Ganj), Advan RGii racing wheels replica with 205/15/55 OEM EG9, smoke black crystal headlamp, front bumper lip (Mugen style, bought it from Pakwheels), JDM tow hook (bought it from Pakwheels). -  - Built Not Bought/VTEC decals. -  - Mechanical:  - 1. Generator - 2. Self-starter (removed from fresh import) -  - Paint job: DuPont Granada Black Metallic (with golden flakes) NH-503P -  - Pending tasks: engine detailing, headers, Matin coilovers, lowering springs, floor carpet installation, doors, interior. -  - Suspension was taken care of a few months back. -  - I believe I have written enough for now, and it's time to let the pictures tell the rest of the story. Please note that this is my first project, so I may have made a few mistakes or missed mentioning a few things. Feel free to share your feedback and suggestions for future reference. I would like to thank everyone who helped me throughout the project by sourcing parts and providing advice. Thank you to Shabbir.1, Badpigs, and Ominous.  -  - Previous condition: - Current condition:

column1: Dear All. I am purchasing KIA Picanto A/T in Mercury Blue color. Minor scratches are more visible in dark color vehicles so i am a bit worried about it. After my research i have identified two possible solutions, Paint Protection Film (PPF) or Ceramic Coating. Which one is better?
column2: When considering paint protection options like Paint Protection Film (PPF) versus Ceramic Coating, it's important to understand their differences. PPF provides a durable shield against dings, scratches, and stone chips, making it ideal for protecting your car's paint. On the other hand, Ceramic Coating offers a slick, hydrophobic finish that enhances shine but may not offer the same level of protection against physical damage. Some view Ceramic Coating as akin to a lacquer coat, albeit less durable, lasting only a year or two if properly maintained. PPF, being a thermoplastic urethane film, offers more permanent protection against abrasions and minor damage. However, if PPF is damaged in a specific area, the entire panel may need replacement. Ultimately, the choice between PPF and Ceramic Coating depends on your priorities and budget, with PPF being a more robust but expensive option compared to Ceramic Coating, which requires multiple layers for effective protection.

column1: Lately I purchased a car which had serious acceleration issues ..A lot of things were checked and maintenance / replacement done .. Sharing my knowledge on it ..ur comments and suggestions will be highly appreciated Basic Tuning . Throttle body service : A common step these days, technically its not to be done unless there is a serious issue but since every one is doing it so i do it as well .. just spray some carburetor cleaner in throttle body . Plugs : check gap .. new plugs come with 1.0 or 1.1 gap .. older can be set upto 1.3 gap .. for cng vehicles set gap to 0.8 .. clean plugs .. plugs used more than 40k (iridium) may be replaced and normal plugs after 25k km. always use OEM recommended genuine plugs .. those cheap rs 160/- plugs have irregular currents and can cause damage to coils etc . Air filter : Genuine filter only .. exception for cng vehicles as there filter is changed more frequently . Oil : OEM recommended .. Thinner oil like 0w20 or 5w20 may be replaced with 5w30 for hotter climate areas .. do not shift from fully synthetic to semi and back .. use a type for once .. its better to use fully synth for first 75k km or 100k km then shift to semi synth like 10w40 .. but if compression is good keep using fully synthetic .. thicker oil chokes internals and causes all kinds of problems .. so stick to OEM PCV : choked PCV builds up excessive pressure in crank case, causing smoke in exhaust and may also cause reduced performance of car Max Speed Not being Attained . CAT ; if clogged will restrict exhaust gases and maximum speed .. Clean CAT but never remove or damage its mesh .. U will end in disturbed air fuel ratios, high fuel consumption, poor idle and loud engine sound .. replace CAT if required . Fuel pressure ; Use of substandard fuel causes strainer to choke or pump to decrease efficiency causing poor pick up and /or high speed .. the best way to check is to attach a pressure guage near the fuel injector rail .. if the presure is 40psi or more then things r ok . Injectors : same problems as above .. individual injectors can be checked by removing wire clip while car is in idle .. clogged injectors r cleaned on ultrasonic machine and treatment with injector cleaniners also helps but frequent use can damage rubber parts .. though injector cleaners r not very efficient Poor Acceleration . EGR : this was one culprit which caused my car acceleration problem .. clean it and make sure to clean its passages as well . VVT timing : cam shaft in vvti engines has cam phaser (timing advance / retard mechanism) which gets stuck when thicker oil is used and sludge is formed .. solution may be in flushing engine and giving a slight movement to cam phaser .. in severe cases cam phaser has to opened and cleaned . OCV : oil control valve operated cam phaser so this has to be clean alongwith its filter . Coils : weak coils can also cause acceleration issue .. always use quality plugs or ur coils will die early . CVT : cvt oil and cvt performance can also cause accleration issue .. oil can be physically checked but cvt can only be checked on a obd scan tool Poor Economy . General tuning : do a general tuning, as explained above . Fuel Trims : buy a mini diagnostic tool (ELM -327, approx price rs 1000/-) works on most cars, runs on android application "torque" .. check fuel trims .. meaning fuel adjustment before and after engine .. a lean or rich mixture indicates the problem area .. like O2 sensor issue, MAF sensor problem .. temperature readings tell how CAT is working . Sensors : ur air fuel ratio is disturbed so clean MAF(or MAP) and O2 sensors first. In further investigation, u may check functionality of sensors and wiring / signals from ECU . CAT . Plugs / Coils . Fuel Injectors This is all for now .. these r general items a more complex fault may also lead to speed issue do point out mistakes, missed items do share experience Thanks
column2: Once the vvt phaser starts getting stuck or its lockpin starts to rattle then its time for a new cam phaser, Its installation is quite intricate and requires a torque wrench.

EGR : this was one culprit which caused my car acceleration problem .. clean it and make sure to clean its passages as well . VVT timing : cam shaft in vvti engines has cam phaser (timing advance / retard mechanism) which gets stuck when thicker oil is used and sludge is formed .. solution may be in flushing engine and giving a slight movement to cam phaser .. in severe cases cam phaser has to opened and cleaned . OCV : oil control valve operated cam phaser so this has to be clean alongwith its filter . Coils : weak coils can also cause acceleration issue .. always use quality plugs or ur coils will die early . CVT : cvt oil and cvt performance can also cause accleration issue .. oil can be physically checked but cvt can only be checked on a obd scan tool Poor Economy . General tuning : do a general tuning, as explained above . Fuel Trims : buy a mini diagnostic tool (ELM -327, approx price rs 1000/-) works on most cars, runs on android application "torque" .. check fuel trims .. meaning fuel adjustment before and after engine .. a lean or rich mixture indicates the problem area .. like O2 sensor issue, MAF sensor problem .. temperature readings tell how CAT is working . Sensors : ur air fuel ratio is disturbed so clean MAF(or MAP) and O2 sensors first. In further investigation, u may check functionality of sensors and wiring / signals from ECU . CAT . Plugs / Coils . Fuel Injectors This is all for now .. these r general items a more complex fault may also lead to speed issue do point out mistakes, missed items do share experience Thanks
column2: Naweed: This is all for now .. these r general items a more complex fault may also lead to speed issue do point out mistakes, missed itemsdo share experience Thanks The first thing to do is to check the actual fuel consumption: fill the tank, drive and note the odometer readings, then fill up again to calculate. The second thing to do would be to use a scan tool (if OBD2 compliant) to check out the sensors, fuel trims and codes, if any.

column1: Lately I purchased a car which had serious acceleration issues ..A lot of things were checked and maintenance / replacement done .. Sharing my knowledge on it ..ur comments and suggestions will be highly appreciated Basic Tuning . Throttle body service : A common step these days, technically its not to be done unless there is a serious issue but since every one is doing it so i do it as well .. just spray some carburetor cleaner in throttle body . Plugs : check gap .. new plugs come with 1.0 or 1.1 gap .. older can be set upto 1.3 gap .. for cng vehicles set gap to 0.8 .. clean plugs .. plugs used more than 40k (iridium) may be replaced and normal plugs after 25k km. always use OEM recommended genuine plugs .. those cheap rs 160/- plugs have irregular currents and can cause damage to coils etc . Air filter : Genuine filter only .. exception for cng vehicles as there filter is changed more frequently . Oil : OEM recommended .. Thinner oil like 0w20 or 5w20 may be replaced with 5w30 for hotter climate areas .. do not shift from fully synthetic to semi and back .. use a type for once .. its better to use fully synth for first 75k km or 100k km then shift to semi synth like 10w40 .. but if compression is good keep using fully synthetic .. thicker oil chokes internals and causes all kinds of problems .. so stick to OEM PCV : choked PCV builds up excessive pressure in crank case, causing smoke in exhaust and may also cause reduced performance of car Max Speed Not being Attained . CAT ; if clogged will restrict exhaust gases and maximum speed .. Clean CAT but never remove or damage its mesh .. U will end in disturbed air fuel ratios, high fuel consumption, poor idle and loud engine sound .. replace CAT if required . Fuel pressure ; Use of substandard fuel causes strainer to choke or pump to decrease efficiency causing poor pick up and /or high speed .. the best way to check is to attach a pressure guage near the fuel injector rail .. if the presure is 40psi or more then things r ok . Injectors : same problems as above .. individual injectors can be checked by removing wire clip while car is in idle .. clogged injectors r cleaned on ultrasonic machine and treatment with injector cleaniners also helps but frequent use can damage rubber parts .. though injector cleaners r not very efficient Poor Acceleration . EGR : this was one culprit which caused my car acceleration problem .. clean it and make sure to clean its passages as well . VVT timing : cam shaft in vvti engines has cam phaser (timing advance / retard mechanism) which gets stuck when thicker oil is used and sludge is formed .. solution may be in flushing engine and giving a slight movement to cam phaser .. in severe cases cam phaser has to opened and cleaned . OCV : oil control valve operated cam phaser so this has to be clean alongwith its filter . Coils : weak coils can also cause acceleration issue .. always use quality plugs or ur coils will die early . CVT : cvt oil and cvt performance can also cause accleration issue .. oil can be physically checked but cvt can only be checked on a obd scan tool Poor Economy . General tuning : do a general tuning, as explained above . Fuel Trims : buy a mini diagnostic tool (ELM -327, approx price rs 1000/-) works on most cars, runs on android application "torque" .. check fuel trims .. meaning fuel adjustment before and after engine .. a lean or rich mixture indicates the problem area .. like O2 sensor issue, MAF sensor problem .. temperature readings tell how CAT is working . Sensors : ur air fuel ratio is disturbed so clean MAF(or MAP) and O2 sensors first. In further investigation, u may check functionality of sensors and wiring / signals from ECU . CAT . Plugs / Coils . Fuel Injectors This is all for now .. these r general items a more complex fault may also lead to speed issue do point out mistakes, missed items do share experience Thanks

column1: Car starts during daytime when temperature is around 21 22C but doesn't start and gives a weak self sound like when the battery is dead, during the night and early morning when it's super cold outside, is it time to replace the battery? This situation is after 12 13 days parked car
column2: If your car battery is draining over a week or so, despite being only a year old, it's essential to diagnose the issue. Start by checking the battery cells and ensuring they are functioning correctly. Lubricating the terminals with grease or petroleum jelly can prevent powder deposits. Next, examine the starter, alternator, and battery using a voltmeter. A healthy battery should read around 12.6 volts or higher. If it reads significantly lower, there may be a discharge issue or a failing battery. In the case of a Baleno 2005 experiencing cold start issues only after the car has been sitting for a week or more, despite having a working alternator and starter, consider other factors such as additional electrical components like amplifiers or potential parasitic drains.

column1: Hi, I have nissan march 1997. Few weeks back, I changed its radiator and ac condenser due to leakage. It was in winters. Now, in summers, its ac does not work very well. The guy from shershah gave me the radiator and condenser of 1000c imported wagon r for fitting. Its condenser size is half of what nissan's used to be. So, will changing the condenser to a bigger or original size fix the cooling problem in summers? Thanks
column2: Go find the original parts and install them, the condenser and evaporator are a matched set, in your case you have very little liquid volume compared to vapour volume. Nothing else will help, and also find a good ac tech fhat owns a real vacuum pump and scales. Dont let them guess the charge or try to adjust the charge just by looking at pressure

column1: Hi, I have nissan march 1997. Few weeks back, I changed its radiator and ac condenser due to leakage. It was in winters. Now, in summers, its ac does not work very well. The guy from shershah gave me the radiator and condenser of 1000c imported wagon r for fitting. Its condenser size is half of what nissan's used to be. So, will changing the condenser to a bigger or original size fix the cooling problem in summers? Thanks
column2: ae92 came equipped with serpentine evaporator only. If you change condenser to multiflow type then make sure its about the same size as the old one and it has manifold tanks too. This will keep the system balanced. Also make sure the AC mechanic knows how to install a T shape expansion valve correctly and also how to insulate it correctly. The performance of it is highly dependant on its installation - the sensing bulb has a certain orientation/clocking of it relative to the suction line to sense the correct temperature of the discharging refrigerant from the evaporator. Placing it too low or too high is bad.

column1: Hi, I have nissan march 1997. Few weeks back, I changed its radiator and ac condenser due to leakage. It was in winters. Now, in summers, its ac does not work very well. The guy from shershah gave me the radiator and condenser of 1000c imported wagon r for fitting. Its condenser size is half of what nissan's used to be. So, will changing the condenser to a bigger or original size fix the cooling problem in summers? Thanks
column2: I think this task is beyond your scope. Study it a bit then make your decision on how to make it work or get it worked on (meaning be informed so you can measure the workmanship being recieved) The expansion valve is T shaped in your car rather than the H shaped one used on modern corollas. Installing the H shape requires no skill, T shape requires brains and skill, make sure mechanic understands such. Forgetting to insulate the T shaped valve will result in bad working, same with installing its sensing bulb wrong.

column1: I simply dont understand that how can someone just out of his behind determine that the diesel engine is dead because of back blow... Did they check compression? (They wont even have a diesel tester) Was a proper vent check done? Maybe its restricted Did they check the valve clearances? Can cause noisy intake and blow like crazy (cylinders not filling with full air and hence no compression load on the rings) Did they actually check the timing..(forces the rings to expand on the power stroke sealing it at TDC) Diesel engines will last for at least 400,000 kms easily without breaking a sweat.. I simply cant fathom the fact - even dealerships in Pakistan lack the diesel compression tester - and just rely on the musings of an old **** of a diesel mechanic that the engine is dead.. And customers fall for it. - I wouldve made them sweat for their money before they hand me some crap like that
column2: When inspecting for back blow in a diesel engine, particularly when hot and at normal idle speed, a method involves opening the oil cap and using a piece of paper above the filler opening. The paper should flutter or be pushed up slightly, indicating proper sealing. Revving the engine should cause the paper to go dead or be sucked in, signifying potential issues like blowby. Checking for compression, timing, and valve clearances is essential. If air is observed being pushed out of the intake manifold, further examination of the timing belt, valve clearances, and injection pump pressure is warranted. Deviations in nozzle breaking pressure can affect engine performance, leading to symptoms like black or white smoke. For a Toyota 2C engine, the nozzle breaking pressure should be within specified ranges, and internal pump pressure at idle speed should be checked. Diesel Power Systems on Sh Faisal in Karachi is recommended for diesel pump services, although finding a shop knowledgeable about pump advance and internal pressure is crucial. Be cautious of the pump cold start device, which can impact timing when stuck or malfunctioning.

column1: AoA I am planning to introduce a vehicle tracking system in Pakistan, and this is just a primarily survey to see if people would be interested in such kind of systems or not. The system can: Show the location of your vehicle on PC / Mobile Send mileage / maintenance notifications over mobile and through email Send over speeding notification over mobile and through email Send notifications over mobile and through email if the vehicle goes out of a predefined area The approximate cost for installation would be around Rs. 10,000-15,000 with a monthly service charges of approximately Rs. 1500-3000 depending on the services activated. I am planning to move back to Pakistan this December I have already tested a prototype in Pakistan and now I am really looking forward to set up this system. But now I need feeback from the market which is you guys :). I am open to all kinds of comments / suggestion / feedback
column2: If someone is selling the system in Pakistan then I think it’s a good idea and you will gain many customers at the end of the day. Average cost of the device would not cost more than Rs 15000 as I have imported two average trackers in past from china for Rs 7000 each including shipment charges and Rs 13000 a good quality tracker. Be very clear, you don’t need to bring third party companies in between in order to watch your vehicle. GPS signals is free for entire world so no monthly cost is involved. Only cost involved is the charges which cell phone companies charges from you once you send an SMS to a friend. Because commands are sent through SMS and car replies through SMS. Once I top up 100 Rs balance in my cars device then it lasts for more then 4 months. Trackers are only toys as companies which sells tracker for USD 100 also sells jammers for USD 20. But in between it will give you a peace of mind once your family is out for shopping and you would know where they are. How fast your driver is driving the car and where he actually is once you need the car at home.

column1: hello guys hope u all will be fine ! i will be installing complete a.c unit in my car on Monday ! the question i want to ask is that which compressor should i go for ? denso or sanden ? the mechanic told me to go for sanden because it has less load on engine has better cooling and has steel piston ! and told me that denso has load on engine has has aluminium alloy piston ! i dont know heck about refrigeration and compressor until now but would be grate full if u guys help me in choosing
column2: the original one that comes on a 5AFE is very good - its a 10 cylinder denso unit, (aka 5 piston in Pakistan) - If you correctly install the A/C and have proper functioning TXV and a good condenser it will work very very nice.

column1: hello guys hope u all will be fine ! i will be installing complete a.c unit in my car on Monday ! the question i want to ask is that which compressor should i go for ? denso or sanden ? the mechanic told me to go for sanden because it has less load on engine has better cooling and has steel piston ! and told me that denso has load on engine has has aluminium alloy piston ! i dont know heck about refrigeration and compressor until now but would be grate full if u guys help me in choosing
column2: Vaqas1;2785119: I am also using original Denso compressor (134) on my 5AFE with Corolla 98 Evaporator and Multi flow big condensor. Cooling is good when car is moving chilling but as you stop it loses the cooling in the day time. But if you can maintain around 2000 or 1500 RPM hmm it cools again even at idle. My experiance unless you have a guy who knows what he is doing it will be hard to get very good cooling out of Denso compressor though i have seen Sanden cooling better especially on low RPM. Load well load is there with a/c on cng hmm around 15 to 20% decreased performance. That little sentence literally says it all, If you are using a shop that does not know what refrigeration is - you are wasting money

column1: hello guys hope u all will be fine ! i will be installing complete a.c unit in my car on Monday ! the question i want to ask is that which compressor should i go for ? denso or sanden ? the mechanic told me to go for sanden because it has less load on engine has better cooling and has steel piston ! and told me that denso has load on engine has has aluminium alloy piston ! i dont know heck about refrigeration and compressor until now but would be grate full if u guys help me in choosing
column2: over my head I dont recall - but its the same unit that comes attached to 4AFE too. raw.. The measures to take are ensure the high pressure switch is actually functioning and be positively sure that your expansion valve is in perfect working order, The newer corollas require removal of the entire dashboard to service the A/C (the TXV valves installed by Indus motors are not good) - most shops would not take such a job as it takes one whole day to service and put back. a malfucntioning H block TXV will block gas flow and literally blow apart the compressor if the high pressure cut off switch is not working - (most A/C shops in Pakistan cut that first - because the snooty and snobby car owners want their 2D A/C to perform like a VW Phaeton A/C regardless of temperature) Secondly when the A/C shops discharge the gas - oil is lost too, and they do not put in the required and recommended oil for 134 as it is very very expensive, Rs 12,000 for a 4 litre bottle. Ive seen some shops put in ester oil (of R12) in R134 units. I wanted to cry/laugh at the same time. A collection of the above causes failures left and right. Ever wonder why people in other countries are not changing A/C compressors every year. I used to own a 1997 Camry 3.0 here in the US - I recently sold it with 200,000 miles (320,000 kms) it was using the original 10 cylinder denso compressor that the toyota factory put in (same corolla compressor). I did however have service records that the TXV and drier were replaced in 2005. Measure for yourself now.

column2: If you choose the secondhand one, I would recommend Sanden. I recently installed a Sanden compressor in my Nissan and I am very satisfied with the results and cooling it provides. Denso is also fine, but the best thing about Sanden is that you can overhaul it multiple times. Rotaries are good compressors, but they are nearly impossible to repair. Personally, I used the Sanden SD-507 and I am happy with it.

column1: HI Guys, I am starting this thread to specifically focus on the types of protections available for the body paint. Main points to consider would be : 1 - Protection against minor scratches and stone chips 2 - body colour preservation 3 - Hydrophobic qualities 4 - level of gloss Pros please comment on this !
column2: To protect your car's paint from potential damage in hot weather, it's essential to follow some maintenance tips. Firstly, regular washing with a mild car shampoo using soft tools like a sponge or microfiber cloth helps remove dust and pollutants without scratching the paint. Applying a protective wax or sealant provides an extra layer of defense against UV rays and heat, extending the paint's lifespan. Parking in shaded areas and using a breathable car cover further minimizes exposure to direct sunlight, preventing paint fading or cracking. Avoiding abrasive materials during cleaning and maintaining regular waxing and polishing routines also contribute to preserving the paint's appearance. While these measures can help, it's important to note that they may not entirely prevent issues like Florida paint cancer or swirl marks caused by improper washing techniques. Additionally, understanding different paint protection products like wax, sealants, ceramic coatings, paint protection film (PPF), and vinyl wrap can guide you in choosing the right option based on your car's needs and budget. Sealants, for instance, are suitable for daily-driven cars, offering good durability without the expense of ceramic coatings, while products like Menzerna Power Lock and Sonax PNS are recommended for their proven effectiveness. Ultimately, maintaining your car's paint not only enhances its appearance but also preserves its resale value over time.

column1: Hi every body, i want knowledge regarding pros and cons of automatic and manual gear shifting system plz give your opinion thanx
column2: Opting for a manual transmission is preferred due to its easy maintenance and cost-effectiveness, especially considering the affordability of replacing a worn clutch plate compared to the expensive automatic gearbox kit. While newer car models may offer improved technology, manual control is valued, particularly in situations like getting stuck in mud, where gear shifting aids in control. Personal experience, such as handling a Corolla with brake failure by shifting gears, reinforces the reliability of manual transmission, especially in remote areas with limited access to workshops and mechanics. Additionally, anecdotes like a lancer's automatic gear failure within six months of use in a village context underscore concerns about automatic transmission durability. However, opinions may vary, with some viewing automatic cars as a luxury, appreciating models like the 2002 Oriel PT. Nonetheless, considerations of fuel efficiency, maintenance costs, and performance characteristics between automatic and manual transmissions highlight the multifaceted nature of the debate. For instance, automatic transmissions tend to be thirstier on fuel, require costly servicing, and may deteriorate if maintenance is overlooked, with fewer pre-owned autos observed to be in good condition. Technical differences, such as torque converter operation relying on oil pressure and its implications for power transmission and towing capacity, further delineate the differences between automatic and manual transmissions. Finally, in instances of car battery failure, manual transmission cars may be push-started, while automatics necessitate alternative solutions like jump-starting or seeking assistance from another vehicle.

column1: From past year the Ac hasn't been performing well when the car is stopped. Took it to a local workshop the guy said gas is less than half and that I should just top up. Do they take off entire dashboard and remove evaporator coil to clean it? Is it necessary if our car has cabin filter that was cleaned/replaced regularly? I'd rather not have a mechanic take off entire dashboard and end up with more problems in the future. What are reasonable charges for just topping up gas, vs gas top up + service?
column2: Duplicate thread. AC service from Honda 3S worth it? Honda From past year the Ac hasn't been performing well in our 9th gen civic. Called two different Honda 3S dealers in lahore, and both provided wildly different quotes for topping up gas 4400 vs 8000. Has anyone gotten their Ac gas topped up from 3S dealer, how much did you pay? What about getting AC serviced from them, do they take off entire dashboard? how much did you pay for ac service?

column1: Assalamualaikum! A person works hard and saves money to buy a car with enthusiasm, only to have it vandalized by a sadistic individual. I guess this is my way of celebrating Eid. This is my first car and I am not knowledgeable about cars at all. I am aware that there are tutorials available online on how to remove these scratches, but I am not confident in doing it myself. I would appreciate any suggestions on where I can get these scratches fixed in Islamabad. Thank you and Eid Mubarak!
column2: The scratch looks like upto the clear coat. This will be easily removed with compound.

column2: Simple way to check clear coat scratch is to do a water test. If applying water to the scratch hide the scratch until water is applied then it is a scratch on the clear coat. You should also buy scratch remover, it really helps in minimizing scratch visibility. I bought it almost 8 years ago, still working

column1: Assalamualaikum! A person works hard and saves money to buy a car with enthusiasm, only to have it vandalized by a sadistic individual. I guess this is my way of celebrating Eid. This is my first car and I am not knowledgeable about cars at all. I am aware that there are tutorials available online on how to remove these scratches, but I am not confident in doing it myself. I would appreciate any suggestions on where I can get these scratches fixed in Islamabad. Thank you and Eid Mubarak!
column2: AOA, the paint comprises of multiple layers. Correction depends on how deep is the scratch or in other words how many layers deep the scratch has gone. The topmost layer is lacquer or clear coat. Scratches that do no go deeper than the clear coat are easily removed and if done properly will not be visible standing a few feet from the car. The next layer after the clear coat is the actual paint or base coat. Here is where it gets tricky. If the scratch has just slightly disturbed this layer it "may" be able to buff out. The next layer below the base coat is the primer. If the scratch has gone into the primer, I am afraid it will not buff out. See pic below:

column2: Hello, don't get disheartened. This is not a big deal, it's actually nothing. Don't let your heart shrink over such small matters. Eid Mubarak!

column1: Recently someone has imported a lot of Amsoil products in Pakistan. It is being sold all over the country with absurd claims such as 20km/L fuel average Stops Oil burning Reduces Engine noise Good for 20,000km Increases Performance It is mostly being sold at posh oil change shops and "racing" workshops. THESE ARE ALL LIES recently a guy visited a friend's workshop with 8k worth of Amsoil which he wanted to use for 20k km and then he was asking for liqui moly flush. He was previously using Shell 0w20 (which is one of the best oils in the market) and now someone had sold him onto these lies. Companies like Shell, Chevron and Total are already selling competitively priced and excellent quality oils. Amsoil or totachi are not going to replace worn out metal on the bearings or the cylinders. Please stop wasting your hard earned money on such scams. It is much better to use an oil from the three mainstream locally available brands and use the same money to buy a good quality oil filter (like vic or the OEM). Using these Oils for 20K will definitely hurt your car's engine, and since the company is not even officially in Pakistan, who are you going to turn to, to claim damages? the khaipya? @vcheng @xulfiqar @capsat @babarhyd
column2: Let's assume that a milkman, who is 50 years old, is carrying 4 bottles and using Amsoil branded engine oil. Will the engine oil survive for 45,000 kilometers without needing to be changed?

column2: "I find it quite amusing when I come across owners of ""janoo german"" Mercedes Benz and BMW cars. They believe that these cars are filled with oil imported from Germany, as it is written on the packaging, and even assume that there are radishes inside the engine. However, I inform them that Benz actually uses Mobil and Shell as their factory fill, while BMW uses BP (Castrol) and Shell. It's really entertaining to witness their surprised expressions. The same reaction occurs when they are busy searching for ""jenyann janoo jurmann"" brake oil, and I show them an inexpensive US DOT 4 rated brake fluid from a store, and then direct their attention to the US DOT regulations white paper."

There is one point u have to know that 1kg of LPG = 2 ltrs. of LPG. LPG Price = 65 per ltr. Petrol price = 102 per ltr. The point is LPG and Petrol have almost same milage.... column1: Salam. Yesterday I drove my car normally on a usual 30kms route. Just outside my house, Eng temperature red light started blinking. I turned off engine immediately. Radiator was filled with steam. I topped up and next day in morning I replaced the cap as it is the easiest step to do first. I filled up the radiator with coolant. Drove the car again whole day without any fault but I experience steam inside radiator and cap cannot be opened easily due to rapid discharge of steam. Pls suggest any valuable tips before going to mechanic. I could not find any visible leaks except coolant splash marks on the intake hose and radiator cap surrounding areas only on first time heat up warning, that is why I replaced the cap first to diagnose. Mileage: 65000kms Jazak Allah.
column2: why were you attempting to open the radiator cap on a hot engine? You probably have a leaking water pump or some other leak low down causing it to run low on coolant.

column1: I have a Charade 86 Model and I'm in deep trouble for the last two months since I decided to run it on Petrol. My car starts well on petrol and after running a few KM it gets stopped then I start it again after 1 min and it runs fine again a few KM and stopped.. Whereas on CNG it runs perfectly without any missing. In last two months my mechanic did the following to solve the prob: Clean the fuel tank (even two times) as it was rusty. Clean the pipes coming from tank to carbo. Clean / service the carborator. Change the fuel pump. change the fuel filter. After taking all above measures my problem is still there and I'm really disheart now. Could you guys help me to solve this myth. What should I do now... Pls....help me
column2: get CNG lines and replace your fuel lines by them. we recently did the same when we were facing same kind of issue but in our case we had an EFi engine and the fuel pump was quite powerful

Clean the pipes coming from tank to carbo. Clean / service the carborator. Change the fuel pump. change the fuel filter. After taking all above measures my problem is still there and I'm really disheart now. Could you guys help me to solve this myth. What should I do now... Pls....help me
column2: manual fuel pump will fail if run on cng for extended time periods.. i have been using a mitsubishi electrical pump for a long time now after the manual pump dried up. no problems so far.. i start and shut down car on petrol each day
